Title: Presenting Bangalore Times’ Most Desirable Men of 2019...

The actor’s also launched his first home production — Badava Rascal.There are some whispers, nothing confirmed.Rugged and raw, and a poet too!He was seen in the much-awaited Bharaate. He has his next couple of films rolling out soon.Setting #FamilyGoals with wife Vidya.He’s got the moves and the wit to go with it.He has been balancing work with lead roles in two TV shows — one in Kannada (Sarvamangala Mangalye) and one in Telugu (Savithramma Gari Abbayi).No time for love, as he’s always busy flying between Bengaluru and Hyderabad.He’s got one of the fittest bods in the business.7.: The year 2019 saw Bengaluru cricketer Manish win the Syed Mushtaq Ali trophy. Incidentally, it was the character he played in the 2019 film Mundina Nildana, that made him work towards his makeover.Married to former actress Deepika.His hot new body is drool worthy.The TV actor debuted in films with Kiss, which did fairly well. Since then, he’s been looked at with a lot of intrigue. This year, he will be teaming up with the director of his debut film, yet again...He’s supposed to be quite the hit among girls.He’s still got that boyish charm that is very attractive.: Radio host, emcee, standup comedian, actor and writer Danish is what one would call a maverick. He has been prepping for the sequel of Humble.. which will now be a 10-episode web series and has also shot for a role in yet another Kannada film.He's just announced there's a special someone on social media.He can make you laugh, isn't that the best thing about a guy?Part of the 300 club after Sehwag back in 2016, Karun has been part of various domestic matches including the Ranji Trophy and the Duleep Trophy (2019-20). The actor has five films lined up for release in 2020, and had one – Gentleman – that hit the screens recently.Wife Ragini Chandran and he define #RelationshipGoalsHe's got that naughty smile that one can't but help notice.The actor with the bass voice had one film that hit the screens in 2019 – Kavacha. The year 2020 sees him in three more films, the first of which – India vs England – saw him make his debut as a lead actor on the Kannada screen.He's single and ready to mingle.His baritone voice can serenade anyone.With films few and far between, it is a surprise to see the kind of fan following actor Dhruva enjoys. The actor has had just 3 films released since 2012 – all super hits. Through 2019, he has been shooting for his next release – Pogaru (a remake of a Tamil hit).Married to Prerana.He's got this raw and rugged mass appeal.Known for being a part of off-beat films that have also enjoyed commercial success, Rishi kept the flow in 2019 with his performances in Kavaludaari and Sarvajanikarige Suvarnavakasha. The actor has 3 other films in the pipeline this year.Married to Swathi.He's that tall, dark and handsome guy that authors wrote about.TV actor Dheekshith Shetty recently made his big screen debut with Dia. His role has won him a lot of acclaim.He’s single and very ready to mingle, it seems.He’s got that mischievous smile that can melt anyone!He was seen in Thryambakam and in a cameo in Rustum. Vishnu is also keenly prepping himself for a career in the movies and hopes to work in the South Indian industries soon.In love with his workout regime for now, we hear.He's the perfect South Indian hunk.The TV actor is still a favourite on Bramhagantu. He’s also made his foray into films with Demo Piece, which released recently.He’s soaking in all the female attention.His model-like looks and dreamy eyes.He has become every home’s favourite after winning the recent Bigg Boss Kannada Season 7.He’s up for grabs, ladies!He sings, cooks, dances and is every bit the charmer!While this composer won the Best Music Album at Filmfare South Awards, he was also a finalist of Bigg Boss Kannada Season 7. His popularity has grown by leaps and bounds since.His music is his steady date, apparently.He’s that friend that you can date too!He returned to the big screen in 2019 with Chanaksha. He has a host of films readying for release.Very single, it seems.A chocolate boy, who can be massy too.Mr India 2015, Rahul has gradually made inroads into the world of cinema. He appeared in a special role in Diwanji Moola Grand Pix, which released in 2018 and has yet another movie in the pipeline in 2020, Avashyamund – both Malayalam.He's single and living it up.His smile can melt one's heart.

Title: Rohit Shetty: 'Khatron Ke Khiladi' is not just about action, it offers wholesome entertainment
Content: His movies are known for power-packed action. And so, it’s not surprising that Rohit Shetty is hosting — for the fifth time — the upcoming season of the stunt-based reality show, 'Fear Factor — Khatron Ke Khiladi' (KKK). In a chat with BT, the filmmaker shares how the 10th season of the show offers wholesome entertainment to family audiences. Excerpts:KKK is a family show and it’s popular among children and teenagers, especially. They love watching reality shows and therefore, we have doubled the action this year. We have introduced a train sequence, brought in lions and there will also be more stunts involving choppers. This was our first visit to Bulgaria , so we had to work hard on deciding the kind of entertainment offered in each episode. The show might be based on action and adventure, but at the end of the day, it is not just about action, it also offers wholesome entertainment. Rohit Shetty alone cannot entertain, so it was also about the contestants and the humour they showcase. The show is not scripted, everything is spontaneous and that was challenging.My enjoyment depends on what new we are offering. When we are shooting films, there are many safety measures in place, apart from CGI and special effects. We have adhered to all safety norms in the show, too, but it is tougher. In movies, the animals shown are mostly not real and the stunts can also be done by body doubles, which is definitely not the case here. So, yes, I enjoy hosting the show because it is real. Also, the USP of the show lies in its contestants, and I enjoy helping them push the envelope.At the end of the day, we are all technicians and artistes — be it films or TV shows. Akshay Kumar and Ajay Devgn are superstars because of their body of work. Similarly, the contestants on the show also have a body of work behind them, whether it is Dharmesh Yolande, Adaa Khan or Karan Patel. I don’t see or feel any difference.From childhood, stunts have been a part of my life. It is something very common for me now.Contestants need to be disciplined because this is an action-based show. However, they can’t prep because everything on this show is spontaneous. If the contestants are told about the stunts in advance, the surprise element will be lost.

Title: Singing a Tamil song is very challenging: Armaan Malik
Content: Guess who made a quiet trip to Chennai recently? Singer Armaan Malik! He was here to meet Harris Jayaraj for discussions over some songs he was to sing for the composer. Armaan is not new to Tamil films and has already sung the Hindi version of a song for the Rajinikanth-starrer Darbar (Dil Toh Cute Hai, Tharam Maara Single in Tamil); he also sang for the Superstar in Shankar’s 2.0 (Hindi version, again) apart from others.“I have no idea about the film,” laughs Armaan when we speak with him, “I am going to get to know what I am here for in a while; and what I am going to sing will come much later. At the moment, all I know is that Harris sir has approached me to sing a song in Tamil. I have been wanting to sing for him for a long time, and it’s finally happening. So, I didn’t ask any questions, just beat it here pronto. I love it that I sing first and then come to know of the movie down here,” he says.When we insist on knowing the film’s name, he promises us that he will get us the details by the end of the interview. He sends a text to someone about that, and then continues, “They like me singing the way I sing. You know, in Bollywood, sometimes, they ask you to change voice according to the actor. But we also want to be ourselves sometimes — and I am glad that lip-syncing songs are slowly moving away from films and montage songs are taking their place. Dance songs are the trend now, both in south and Bollywood. So, it doesn’t matter who the actor is, we don’t have to modulate our voice. But having said that, I feel my voice suits Allu Arjun a lot — I sang for him in Ala Vaikunthapurramuloo; and in Bollywood, it has to be Tiger Shroff.”But how can one just sing offhand in another language? “I’ve been singing songs in multiple south languages, and I have never had any difficulty singing different languages. I started singing ad jingles in Tamil and Telugu when I was around eight; in fact, that’s when my fascination for trying to sing in different languages started. So, when I got into playback singing as an adult, of course, Bollywood songs were there, but Kannada and Telugu also happened to me. And now, finally, Tamil,” Armaan states.He rates his song for the Vishal-starrer, Paayum Puli, Yaar Intha Muyalkutty, composed by Imman, as one of the best he’s sung in Tamil so far. “I think because of the way the composition had me sing, technique-wise, and the voice modulation involved, it was a challenge, and one of my strongest,” he recalls. “The most beautiful thing down south,” says Armaan, “is that even before the composers approach you for a song, they’d have done their research and background work, listened to the singer’s songs and would have come to the conclusion that you are the best voice for it. They know you can deliver, and that gives you the confidence to do the best, because like I said, everything is tough in a Tamil song and you need a certain skill set with a strong classical base. So, if you’re a pop music person, not formally trained in classical, you’d find it tough. Though I don’t get intimidated by south melodies, if I complete a song in a day, I feel I have done a considerable amount of work,” Armaan laughs.Armaan’s brother, Amaal is also a singer and music director, and the duo has worked together on many films. “There’s no rivalry, but we do have amazing fights in the studio, which everyone knows about. He will say sing one way, I will ask him to change the composition; of course, there’s friendly banter, too. But at the end of the day, when a good song comes out of all this, we’re OK. There’s a comfort level which translates into the song, and the listener can actually figure out this is an Amaal-Armaan song,” says Armaan, who says his 2020 goal is to get more into indie songs and fit in as a solo artiste, “focusing on doing international music”, he says.The interview is about to end, so we ask him, yet again, the name of the movie he’s going to sing for, with Harris. He checks his phone, and reveals, “The movie I am here for, it’s yet-to-be titled, and is directed by the duo of JD-Jerry, lyrics are by PA Vijay, and I am told the actors are debutants.”

Title: Lovey Sasan blessed with a baby boy
Content: TV actress Lovey Sasan and her husband Koushik Krishnamurthy have become parents to a boy. The baby, named Royce , was born on February 19. An elated Lovey told BT, “Royce is God’s most special gift to us, and words cannot describe our feeling. We are very thankful to the doctors who ensured that I had an easy delivery.”Lovey had got married to her Bengaluru-based beau Koushik Krishnamurthy on February 10 last year. The actress, who became popular for her negative role in Saath Nibhaana Saathiya , also had another wedding according to South Indian rituals in May 2019. The actress in her last interview had told us that she would want to continue working on television, but now after the baby it seems that she will need a long break before she gets back to work.

Title: Musician Charan Raj brings hip hop singer Yogi B to debut in Sandalwood for Salaga
Content: Music man MR Charan Raj is known to up the ante and experiment with each of his filmi compositions, be it Godhi Banna Sadharana Mykattu , Kavaludaari, Tagaru or the most recent Suri directorial. He is currently working on the score for Duniya Vijay ’s directorial debut, Salaga, the title track of which was shot recently. At the time, the team had shot using a track version of the song, as Charan was still finalising the voices to use for the final version. And, what he has now managed is that he’s got popular hip hop singer Yogi B to debut in Sandalwood.“Yogi is an independent hip hop and rap artiste of Tamil origin from Malaysia, who has been lending his voice to popular numbers in Tamil cinema. Earlier this week, we recorded the title track of Salaga with him, as his style of singing was best suited for it. His voice is unique and worked well for my composition. This song has a lot of funk and hip hop in it. We recorded the song over three days, as Yogi needed time to get the Kannada pronunciations right. We worked on the song line by line and the final version sounds like it has been sung by a Kannadiga,” says Charan, adding that the song also features classical singer Narayan Sharma and Sanjith Hegde Lyrics by Nagarjun Sharma, who has previously written Hands Up for Avane Srimannarayana, describe the leading man, the underworld and the activities happening in the backdrop. “The visuals are quite raw and are a mix of choreographed sequences and montages, highlighting the leading man, played by Vijay. This song works perfectly for it,” Charan signs off.

Title: most desirable man: KL Rahul is the Most Desirable Man of 2019
Content:
FacebookTwitterPintrest

He’s grown from strength to strength and become an intrinsic part of the Indian cricket team. It is no wonder that KL Rahul is the Bangalore Times Most Desirable Man of 2019, voted to the top from a select list of achievers, all under the age of 40. He’s back after his maiden win in a T20 series as captain and is already busy shooting for multiple assignments. Here’s him unplugged about desirability, female attention and more...I’m flattered that people think I’m a desirable man. I’m happy, but I won’t look too much into it. Of course, winning a title is always nice. And there’s been so much love coming my way over the last one and a half years, especially from Karnataka. I’m deeply humbled.Most youngsters have a keen eye for fashion and trends and I’m no different. I’m just lucky that I’ve had the opportunity to travel around and see what is happening in world fashion. I’ve never been afraid to try new things and have followed all that’s happening in men’s fashion. It is now good to see people look at me, be influenced by my style and try to follow the same.If I have to pick something about me, it has to be the fact that I’m calm, balanced and have a personality of my own. Being a sportsman, there’s a certain personality we have on the field. This is something that has not changed in me. Over the years, people tend to change and lose their originality, but I’ve always remained humble, irrespective of success or failure. I’ve seen criticism and a lot of things, but I’ve remained true to myself. This is what, I hope, makes me desirable. Looks are there today, I’m young and have certain features. But I hope people look beyond that and see my character traits, kindness and outlook towards life.I enjoy it and I won’t lie about that. It feels special to be loved and desired by people, especially women. It does make me feel happy. Though, compliments about my innate nature, character and personality, rather than looks, make me happier.I’ve never been uncomfortable about who I am or what I do. There is social responsibility that comes with being a public figure and there are times when I’ve had to learn to say the right things. I’ve learnt that certain things are unacceptable to the public the hard way. Those are times when I’ve learnt that I’ve to keep quiet. But, overall, there is nothing that I’m uncomfortable with. I know exactly who I am and I don’t need validation of everyone who is around me. I’m OK being me when I go out. There is nothing that I am doing that I need to hide. I’m comfortable sitting in a bar when I’m in Bengaluru. If people recognise me, I’m fine. This is because I follow the responsibilities I have as a sportsman. At the same time, I’m not going to be 26-27 all my life, so I do not take that away from my life too.What is your current relationship status?I’m very committed to my work. I’m in a very content and happy space in my life. I’m not looking for anything, honestly.

Title: Move over mythology, discover Sudama and Krishna as contemporary men in this play
Content: Presenting mythological tales with a contemporary twist has caught the fancy of many theatre aficionados over the years, and the latest to be besotted by the same are the city-based theatre group Kahe Vidushak. Their latest work, Sudama ke Chawal, written by Basant Deo , revisits the famed Indian mythological fable about Lord Krishna and his childhood friend Sudama in a contemporary setting.In the original tale, when Sudama (who lives an impoverished life), goes to meet his childhood friend Krishna (who has become the king of Mathura), Sudama only has a bit of rice that his wife has packed for him to offer to Krishna. The story then explores their interaction. “Our version of this story is a satire that shows how this story would have transpired had it taken place today. Sudama would have proven to be a conniving soul with a corrupted mind. Instead of sharing his meal with Krishna, Sudama is upset that he gave away the only food he had for himself. As in the original fable, here too Krishna blesses Sudama’s family with wealth. However, when Sudama learns of this from his wife, he begins to doubt her integrity. The double standards and cynical nature of humankind today , is thus brought out,” shares director Srinivas Beesetty The one-act play, to be staged at the Alliance Francaise De Bangalore today, is being presented in Swang , a folk-dance-drama form that is native to Madhya Pradesh . “Staged in the proscenium format, musical elements have been woven into the narrative. The performance will primarily be in Hindi, and will include Braj and Bundeli dialects. Even if people are unfamiliar with the dialects, given the folk-art nature of the performance, there will be no language barriers,” Srinivas sums up.

Title: Adoption: I wanted to adopt since I was a teenager: Nandana Sen
Content: Not long ago, Nandana Sen was known for her repertoire as an actress. But soon enough, she shifted focus to being a screenwriter, children’s author and child-rights activist and bid farewell to the screen. In Bengaluru, recently, Nandana spoke to us about adoption and being an adoptive parent. You are mother to a six-year-old daughter, whom you adopted. How has your journey been so far as an adoptive mother?The journey for every mother is, at heart, the same. Yes, I work passionately in several fields I care about, but nothing in the world is more important to me than my identity as a mother. Adopting was a true blessing in my life and has been a transformative journey for me. To be able to fill your home with that kind of joy and give a child what she needs the most, which is love and care, is the most powerful gift that could have been given to me.While adoption is something that a lot more people are opening up to, many end up getting cold feet because of the elaborate process and other issues. How was it for you?I knew that I wanted to adopt as early as when I was a teenager. I wanted to create a family by bringing a child home. It was never an issue with my side of the family, since I spoke about it early on. My family has been extremely supportive about it. My sister too adopted a daughter — my niece Hiya. My husband, John, has been an extremely involved and active parent and the bond he has with our daughter Meghla is beautiful.You left one of your passions, films, to pursue other interests. Would you consider a return to films or maybe write a script on adoption? I will always be passionate about films as a medium, and I love writing screenplays. I’m sure I’ll get back to cinema once my daughter is a bit older. But right now, between having three full-time occupations — writing, motherhood, and child-rights advocacy — I honestly don’t have time to miss anything.What’s your take on the current lot of cinema and the space it gives to female characters, considering you did some very atypical roles in your film career?Though there is abundant talent and passion, even today, women have to struggle harder than men to make a place for themselves, especially as directors. This is why there are conspicuously fewer women directors across the world. The film industry, whether in India or the world over, has a huge gender gap to fill in order to become as open to female directors as it is to female actors.Attachments area

Title: Carnatic ragas have so much versatility: Abby V
Content: 73 Questions’ is a viral video sensation, which poses snappy questions to the biggest celebrities in the American entertainment industry. In ‘73 Ragas With Abby V ’, the titular Tamil origin musician gives a musical touch to the viral format. From Todi in Carnatic to Bhairavi in Hindustani, the Canadian singer gives audiences a whiff of numerous notes.While Abby grew up in Toronto, his training in Indian classical music never took a backseat. His latest video was a product of his passion for Western pop culture and Indian classical music. “The format has become a pop sensation with the biggest celebrities. Since that has been huge, a lot of comedians do a lot of parodies online. People make comedy pieces out of it, so why not make it musical, I wondered. Indian music gives a perfect background for this. The Carnatic ragas have so much versatility,” Abby said on a phone call from Toronto.Abby, who is a disciple of Carnatic music icons Ranjani-Gayatri and Raji Gopalakrishnan, added that Indian fusion music opens up new avenues for diaspora musicians. “There are so many talented Carnatic musicians from all over the world. You have to be in Chennai to perform Carnatic music. While it is not feasible to come to Chennai every year, the passion for Carnatic music is still there. So how do you do that without being part of the kutcheri circuit? That is where these platforms work,” Abby explained.Who is to say that what we are singing now is not an act of fusion that happened a couple of hundred years ago, Abby deliberated. “I remember, Hindustani music was all about Dhrupad music once and then someone came up with the whole concept of Khayal music. Music is always evolving and we are at a beautiful stage where we are accepting classical music at so many different forms,” said Abby, who is looking to merge his Western and classical influences for his future projects.“I do a lot of R&B and pop music in English as well. I have projects coming up in different styles. I have interesting collaborations coming up with a lot of musicians in India, where I try to diversify my body of work as much as I can. It is a beautiful time to be a musician,” Abby said.

Title: My first shot: I went blank the minute the camera rolled, says Mehreen Pirzada
Content: I have been the face of multiple brands, and have had a lot of fun shooting for them. My first ad was for a glycerin soap brand. It had a Cinderella theme and I was quite excited at that time. Then, I did another for a beauty brand. I don’t really know if my ads led me to my first film because Hanu sir (Tollywood director Hanu Raghavapudi) reached out to me through a coordinator in Mumbai. That’s how my first film, Krishna Gaadi Veera Prema Gaadha, happened.Shooting for an ad and shooting for a film are different experiences. When I had to do my first shot for the Telugu film, I was a nervous wreck. But only when the camera would roll. I would be perfectly comfortable with my scene while my director was setting up the scene. But the minute he would say, ‘Clap, scene No 1, Take No 1, Camera Rolling, Action’, I would get confused and go blank. This happened five-six times. So, to make me comfortable, he would keep the camera rolling all the time. My first shot was quite auspicious — I would be praying to God and reciting a slokam.In Tamil, Nenjil Thunivirundhal was my first film, but it was also shot simultaneously in Telugu. At that time, I was not very comfortable with both the languages. So, shooting for the film was quite a blur for me. However, I remember the first scene of Pattas — it’s the one in which I’d be this meek girl waiting for Dhanush to give me way on the road. That shot was okayed in the second take. Shooting with a star like Dhanush was quite an experience and has opened doors for me in Kollywood . Artistes usually dream about Bollywood, but I want to do more films in Tamil.

Title: Kochi Times Most Desirable Woman 2019: Aishwarya Lekshmi
Content: In 2019, Aishwarya Lekshmi consolidated her position in Mollywood, while also broadening her horizons to Kollywood. The Kochi Times Most Desirable Woman 2018 had bagged prestigious projects with the likes of Mani Ratnam and Dhanush and has been shooting across the world. It is no wonder then that the actress has, through an online poll and our vote, won the Kochi Times Most Desirable Woman 2019 . Two-time winner Aishwarya Lekshmi in conversation with us:Awesome! I didn’t expect to win it, but it feels great to be named the most desirable woman again though I hadn’t worked much in Malayalam, last year.To be frank, when I look at my body of work here in 2019, I’m not satisfied. I always want to impress with my work, which I don’t think I have done in the past year. I feel, however, that some of my characters stayed with people, which made me desirable to audiences. I have also not tried to be someone I am not, be it in my social media posts or interviews. And I feel any genuine person can come across as desirable.I feel, other than physical attributes, which can be subjective, being good at your work makes anyone desirable. Being honest and kind with fellow beings is also appealing. One need not be a Mother Teresa, but being kind and well-behaved with those around us can win people’s hearts.All of the above, plus how respectful and well-behaved he is with women. I meet many men as part of my profession, maybe more so than if I were a doctor and sometimes, I come across those who aren’t sure how to speak to women respectfully, and it’s very sad.I set my boundaries and remain professional with them. But when I come across men who know to keep things professional and treat women as equals, I find them extremely desirable. Being knowledgeable, having opinions but also a heart to listen to others’ views, and the skill to correct others sensibly if required, are also desirable qualities.I often wonder how some men have these qualities, while others don’t. I think more than one’s upbringing, it’s a reflection of how well one has brought themselves up and I find the effort taken for this quite impressive. Last but not the least, keeping oneself well-groomed is also important.I can't say just one name. I feel both Lalettan and Mammukka are equally the most desirable men in Mollywood, be it in terms of their success, the longevity of their careers, their personalities, behaviour towards women or the relationships they have built in both personal and professional lives. The stories we hear about them are enough to inspire us. It isn't easy even to aspire for the kind of space they have carved for themselves in the industry.I was shooting for Brother’s Day when I got a call from Mani sir’s office asking me to meet him. That in itself felt like a lottery win! Right from the time I had taken movies seriously, I had watched all his films like in a movie marathon, during my house surgency period. I had also read a book about him.I knew he was all set to work on Ponniyin Selvan, and bought the book online. It has five volumes and will take ages to finish, but I am reading it. Once we met, he did a look test on me, and also an audition. Later, dialogues for the audition was sent to me. Once at the audition, it was already like I was part of the film. It happened in front of those like Thottatharani sir, Ravivarman sir and the like and so, I was a bit tensed. But I guess other than me, everyone knew I was in. Initially, I wasn’t roped in for the character I’m actually playing now, and though there was a change, I’m fine with it.After one and half years of preparation, the character look tests started with me. I could see the excitement of the crew during this process and I am happy I didn’t disappoint them. Even though I made a few mistakes, Mani sir said I am on board and that meant a lot.My character needs to be quite athletic, so I was given almost a month of training for that and I’m still trying to continue remaining fit. My friends, who know Tamil well, helped me with the dialect used in the film. More than the challenges, what strikes me is the amount of immense learning his sets offer. All departments mingle very freely and actors don’t restrict themselves to just doing their scenes. For instance, sometimes, when I am giving close-up shots, actor Karthi delivers his dialogues so that I can present mine well. I guess any ego I had was wiped out on this set.The post-production work are on. Dhanush sir doesn’t talk much, but when he does, he makes things easy for you, work-wise. Also, if he hears about you facing any issue he finds out what the problem is. We shot in London for about two months for the film. The scenes were quite challenging. Sometimes when I face big names, I get the jitters and I guess I experienced a bit of that on this set too.Yes, the shoot should start in April. Akhil is a renowned name in short film circuits and he is using the same crew for this movie also.I am taking 2020 a bit slow… sometimes you need to restructure and re-strategise as an artiste for things to work well. I need to find out what kind of an actor I am and work on soft skills like dancing, singing and more.

Title: On the beat with Kevin B Paul
Content: Chennai-based independent artiste Kevin B Paul better known as, ‘Mr. Kev’ (his artiste name) is upbeat about his debut album. Talking about the album, Dummy In Love: Detox Overdose, he says, “This EP has five songs — Tera Mera, Doc!, Iddly Vada Dosai, May-On-Knees and Shaira. My friends and I worked on this for couple of years to come out with this album. The reason I call the album Dummy In Love: Detox Overdose is because all of them are love songs, and when one is in love, he/she is a dummy. It’s a very confusing experience when you are in love. It’s more like a detox overdose that one experiences when you’re in that journey.”The song Tera Mera written by Alamsha Wahab is the only Hindi song in the album, whereas, Iddly Vada Dosai is written by Mr. Kev and Souvik Mitra, and the other three songs are written by Mr. Kev. Apart from being the vocalist, Mr. Kev has also played acoustic and electric guitars, mouth organ and shakers for a couple of songs in the album.The musician says that all the songs are written in different stages and moments of his life. He says, “Each song shares some special moment with certain people, who were present at that point in my life. So, those who have been there with me in those certain moments of life, would recognise and connect to the lyrics and perhaps get nostalgic, too.”One of the songs from the album, Shaira has an interesting video with sketches, pictures and stop motion. “I am a huge fan of stop motion works and I have been fascinated about it since my college days. The inspiration came from 1985’s a-ha - Take On Me music video. Don’t be shocked when I reveal that my friend Vishnu J Nair with whom I worked on it, has no professional skills in stop motion but we did it anyway (laughs). It took us three days to finish the first 20 seconds of Shaira, which is a 150-second-long song. Vishnu did the sketches and I was executing the stop motion work. In total, we took two-weeks’ time. Over 500 sketches were drawn, and with final edit, re-shoot and everything else, we took two months to complete the video,” he signs off.

Title: J&K likely to nominate members for delimitation panel soon
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

SRINAGAR: Days after the law ministry sought nominations for the delimitation commission for J&K, the newly formed Union Territory is likely to name its chief electoral officer as member and four of its MPs as associate members anytime soon, official sources said on Friday.

Under the law, a delimitation commission is headed by a serving or former judge of the Supreme Court and comprises the Chief Commissioner (CEC) or a representative nominated by him and State/UT election commissioner.

The CEC has already nominated election commissioner Sushil Chandra for the J&K panel, an EC official said.

This commission would be chaired by a retired Supreme Court judge. It is learnt that the Centre has begun shortlisting names.

According to J&K Reorganisation Act, 2019, through the delimitation exercise, the number of seats in the Legislative Assembly is to increase from 107 to 114 with due reservations for SCs and STs.

Title: Kerala edge Railways in thriller to retain Fed Cup volley title
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Representative Photo by Getty Images

A resilient Kerala sealed a dramatic 22-25, 25-20, 22-25, 25-21, 16-14 win over Railways to retain the women's title of the Federation Cup Volleyball Championship at Chittorgarh in Rajasthan on Friday.

The M Sruthi-led side had dominated the field for almost a year. They didn't drop a single set to first win the Federation Cup in Amritsar last October before securing the senior national crown in Bhubaneswar last month. But their superiority was challenged en route to their title on the mud court of the Pratap Volleyball Stadium by a resilient Railways unit.

The same Railways side, comprising veteran Minimol Abraham , Nirmal and Anusree Ghosh , that Kerala had humbled 3-0 in both their previous final meetings were determined to fight back. As a result a five-set thriller was on offer, and Kerala, so accustomed to easy wins, went down 1-0 in no time.

Suddenly, coach CS Sadanandan's girls were in uncharted territory; they had thrown a 4-0 lead in the first set to trail 13-14. Nirmal with her vicious serves had turned the tables for the Railways and Kerala were dumbstruck.

The holders managed to regroup in the second set and drew level as Aswathi bagged a few smart dinks and Anusree KP and Rekha got their spikes around the lanky Railways' blockers. But Railways crawled their way back in the third.

Kerala had appeared lost in the early exchanges in the fourth set before Aswathi Raveendran fetched a pair of morale-boosting points to level the score at 14-all. It was the cue and thereafter Kerala were back in their groove. Soorya inspired the comeback, first with a block on Nirmal and then a sublime spike to make it 21-16.

The decider was evenly fought before captain Sruthi got in the act and gave a two-point lead at 10-8. Though the Railways attempted to derail the Kerala charge they had run out of steam.

Title: Milind Soman: This is the first time I had makkhan-malai in Lucknow: Milind Soman
Content:
Milind Soman (BCCL/ Vishnu Jaiswal)

Milind Soman with wife Ankita Konwar in Lucknow during the Half Marathon (BCCL/ Vishnu Jaiswal)

Milind enjoyed having makkhan malai while in the city (BCCL)

Super model, actor and now a fitness icon, Milind Soman had women’s hearts flutter when he came to Lucknow recently as the brand ambassador of a half marathon. Having visited the city earlier too for the same event, Milind was pleasantly surprised at the increase in participants and Lucknowites’ enthusiasm for fitness. “It’s heartening to see such a large turnout of runners in Lucknow this time,” said Milind as he cheered the runners at the marathon, adding, “Six years ago when I had come for the first marathon, there were hardly 600 participants. This time it’s ten folds, cheers for you Lucknow!”Surrounded by women of all ages, while wife Ankita Konwar smiled indulgently, Milind put a condition of everyone doing push-ups in order to click a selfie with him. And soon he had bevy women lining up who happily performed the task for that one precious picture with the Made In India song model.Milind Soman with wife Ankita Konwar in Lucknow during the Half Marathon (BCCL/ Vishnu Jaiswal)Not oblivious to the sumptuous food the city has to offer, Milind gave in to the temptation and sampled the winter delicacies while in the city. “It’s been very exciting being in Lucknow especially this time because this is the first time I had makkhan-malai here which is something new for me. And of course it was fun to run because this time we took a new route. And obviously with 6000 people it was amazing,” he said. “I think you can feel the excitement now. 600 are not that many but if the participation is six thousand now that means at least 10,000 have thought about running and are perhaps talking about it and hopefully working towards running next year,” said Soman on the growing number of runners in the city.Ask the actor-model why he is off the screen these days and he begs to differ and says that although he’s not off TV or films, he is doing less of it. “Whenever I find the time, I do some acting. Like I’m doing several content for the web, plus there’s also my show in which I am also the judge, so there’s plenty happening on that front,” says he, adding what makes him be seen less on the screen. “There are also so many other things that I am doing at all times that I can’t be a career actor. I’ve never been one in fact, right from the beginning. I can’t be an actor for 300 days in a year. So I can do maybe 40-50 days in a year as an actor but after that it becomes difficult to manage the time and the dates. Like I can’t give weekends because then I’m mostly travelling. So to only be able to give week days and then also say that I can’t give more than 20 days in month, I feel is not fair to the makers. So I’ll do maybe one project in a year. But theatre and theatrical movies have become less, yes because people want one to be there whenever they are called, which I am not, most of the times. They require a lot of time because they are expensive, the canvas is much larger and I don’t have that much time for it, so why have the producer’s money wasted on me when I won’t be around when I am required.”Milind enjoyed having makkhan malai while in the city (BCCL)The 53 year-old married 28-year-old Ankita Konwar in April 2018, says married life is amazing and is going on strong. Milind and Ankita’s pictures on social media sites are all about their chemistry and for people set relationship goals. The two are also active running partners. Talking about his marriage, Milind says, “Married life has been and is going on amazing. Rather, I would say nothing much has changed except that now I don’t take decisions based on my own desires. I have to ask Ankita like what do you think about this, what do you think about that, will this be okay, would you also like to be a part of this, etc. So now you have to think about somebody else as well. You have to take them into confidence, you have to discuss things.”Ask him when he plans to extend his family and Milind laughs and says, “I don’t have any plans to extend the family. Though, we discuss about having a baby, so let’s see.”A champion for the cause of fitness and running, Milind says his inspiration to do so comes from his mom, Usha Soman , who is 74 years old and still participates in several marathons. “Of course my mum has inspired so many people and even Ankita is super inspired by her. I too am amazed at her as to how she’s managed her whole life and now she’s into fitness and all,” says Milind adding that when it comes to fitness, age is no bar if you want to get fit. “It’s all just in the mind. If you set your mind to do it, you can do it. In fact, we had an event in Bengaluru this time called the Grandmother’s 10K which was a 10 kilometre run only for grandmothers. That was a super success and so inspiring because you are looking at grand moms differently then. Normally you see senior citizens walking or perhaps jogging but when you think of grand moms, you think of them as sitting at home, making achaar or knitting, you don’t see them in tights and shorts and running in marathons . That is the whole idea, to break mind sets that you can’t do this, or you can’t do that especially when you have crossed a certain age. If you want to, you can and you must. Then we had the sari runs where we had women running on the streets in saris! So it’s breaking all these mental taboos and stereotypes because all our difficulties are in the mind, very few are physical and material difficulties.”

Title: Thailand’s Anntonia Porsild is all set to judge the grand finale of Miss Diva 2020
Content: Miss Supranational 2019 Anntonia Porsild is all set to be one of the judges at the grand finale of LIVA Miss Diva 2020 tonight. Talking about this first international trip as the reigning queen, she says, “It’s quite overwhelming. I’m still getting used to the fact that people recognise me not only in my country, but abroad as well.”Earlier in December, Anntonia had competed against 76 finalists from various nations and became the first Thai to win the coveted title. “I was doing a lot of charity work back home, and the pageant was simply a spontaneous decision that turned out to be so empowering. Now, I feel like I have a voice to help people lead better lives. However, managing school along with these responsibilities can get challenging at times,” says the 23-year-old, who plans to start her advertising and PR firm along with a foundation that focuses on the importance of health and eco-friendly living.Ask her what she looks for in the upcoming pageant, and she’s quick to respond, “The finalists need to be natural and in their element. It’s their purpose that should reflect in the way they speak. I encourage them to live their flow and be spontaneous, confident, unhindered and free as they live in the moment. Having gone through a similar process, I think I’ll completely relate to them.”Catch the exciting journey of the Divas tonight during the live telecast of the finale at 10 pm on MTV — one of India’s popular youth channels.

Title: Rupali Ganguly back on a fiction show after seven years
Content: Actress Rupali Ganguly , whose last outing in the fiction space was 'Parvarrish — Kuchh Khattee Kuchh Meethi' (2013), is returning to the genre after a gap of seven years. Title: Dress your age no more: JLo at 50 and other celebs who don't play by the rules
Content: We couldn't stop talking about Jennifer Lopez in 2019, thanks to the remake of her 2000 Grammys green dress. And yet again, at the Super Bowl halftime, her performance along with Shakira brought the house down.It is infrequent, if not rare, for cameras to zoom in on women past their 50th birthdays. Well, in JLo's case, it happened quite convincingly, as she glistened in a risque bodysuit adorned with mirror work. But not everyone was impressed and social media remained abuzz with viewers decrying the performance as sexually explicit.When middle-aged women, including celebrities, sport outfits that are young, sexy and modish, commotion and hysterics ensues. However, not everyone bows down to the restrictive rules of so-called age-appropriate dressing. Here's how celebs, including Mariah Carey and Madonna, are proving that age is only a number for them."Why, at the age of 50, did she decide to pitch up ... in a tacky, black-lace bustier?" commented the former editor of a fashion magazine, Alexandra Shulman, following Helena Christensen's appearance in a sexy bustier at Gigi Hadid's birthday party last year. The "cheap shot", as called out by Naomi Campbell, had a perfect response from Christensen. "Let's continue to elevate and support each other, all you beautiful, smart, fun, sexy, hard-working, talented, nurturing women out there #ooopssheworeabustieragain," wrote the former supermodel, along with a picture of her in the 'uplifting' bustier.Before the Hadids and Kardashians, there was Cher. The septuagenarian proved during her Billboard Awards performance in 2017 that she is unstoppable, which in turn, angered the likes of Piers Morgan. "At what point do Cher's outfits become inappropriate? She's 70," he said during his TV show, adding, "Come on Cher for goodness sake love, she's a grandmother, grow old gracefully put them away." Later, in the same episode, Morgan spilled tea over himself, leading viewers to joke that it was an act of "karma". In fact, when Cher wafted down the stage in a shimmering dress with diamond tassels, impressing Morgan was clearly not on top of her wish list.In 2015, a news website wrote that the constant age-shaming of Madonna has become "some sort of sport" after she was criticised for her Grammys outfit. In 2016, yet again, when Madonna wore a bum-baring black outfit to the Met Gala, critics were unforgiving and called for her to start "dressing her age". Soon, hundreds of fans leapt to Madonna's defence and the pop queen hit out at the critics. She called out the rampant "ageism and sexism" in society, while asking her fans to join her "fight for gender equality". Madge's affinity to bold, theatrical looks is no secret and she has always remained true to her style.During the #10yearchallenge, Mariah Carey posted a snap in a sexy lingerie with the caption, "I don't get this 10 year challenge, time is not something I acknowledge." While that day Mariah's Instagram was flooded with compliments,internet has not always been kind to her. In 2016, when the singer donned a tiny leotard and fishnets, her look was panned by many of her fans who felt she was "too old to be walking around in lingerie." Earlier, the singer was slated for turning up at a wedding in a see-through mesh dress. "Mariah is not 26 anymore and it's about time she starts to act her age," wrote a Twitter user.

Title: Is your work life ‘green enough’?
Content:
Start right at the office entrance and bring greenery into the entryway of the room.

Make a green windowsill with plants.

Brighten up the room with a vertical potted plant wall.

Create open shelves with a green hedging.

Use a variety – go with big, bold leafy plants as well as smaller pots.

Do you find yourself stressed out at the end of a work week? This time, instead of checking into a spa, heading for a spin cycle at the gym or driving out of town, to unwind, how about just trying a simple solution that actually starts and ends at your work desk. It’s a desktop plant. That’s right, a study has revealed that a simple potted plant can help you combat workplace stress.Ranjana R Sinha, who is a full-time media professional says, “I have always been someone who just loves plants and greenery and I ensure that I keep at least one or two small indoor plants on my desk. They are easy to care for and maintain. My job as a media professional is a demanding one and keeps me busy 24x7 and the eight -nine hours I spend at my desk with my greens, really is rejuvenating for me. I feel even tending to my plants like watering them or spraying them, de-stresses me completely. I used to be a psychologist and I know how much this can help a person emotionally. Plants at your desktop is a must, I feel.”Adds IT manager Adarsh Shahani, “Plants kind of take my mind out pf work mode. I have a small cactus and philodendron and just looking at them makes me feel relaxed. Ideally, it would be amazing to connect with nature while working, but for those of us who cannot step outside to a garden or nearby park, this is an apt solution.”The next time you have a large pile of to-do stuff at the table or worried about an impending meeting, just gaze at the plant and watch the stress melt away.There is a lot one can choose from. Says owner of a plant nursery of Cyrus Elavia says, “Try peace lily, moneyplant, crypthanus, cholorophytons, sensiveria, peppromia, aglaonema. These don’t require much water, just thrice a week will do. Even if they are not near a window they be fine.”Why stick to just looking at greenery on coworkers’ desks? Bringing the foliage into your personal space in other ways:A cool space saver is to have a round terrarium on your desk. These are low-maintenance little gardens that fit into most spaces. They can be made in round fish bowls or even glasses and bulbs. Says terrarium expert Deepti Pitre, “The biggest advantage is that the terrariums are fuss-free, there’s less mud involved and no water spillage as the base is sealed. You also need very little water. What’s more, you can do with different themes based on your choice – Oriental with a mini Japanese bridge, a zen garden, a beach design with pebbles and sand, ocean theme with a mermaid.”Numerous studies point underline the value of being among greenery. Not only do plants produce oxygen, but they also add to the wellbeing. Experts say, we have a subconscious reaction to nature. It makes people lesser stressed and builds productivity and creativity. This is valuable not just at a workplace, but anywhere.Several offices have made a decision to adopt more greenery into and around their their spaces. From vertical walls on the outside facade to having plants indoors, greenery has been seen to co-relate with a rise in employee output.

Title: Milind Soman: This is the first time I had makkhan-malai in Lucknow: Milind Soman
Content: Super model, actor and now a fitness icon, Milind Soman had women’s hearts flutter when he came to Lucknow recently as the brand ambassador of a half marathon. Having visited the city earlier too for the same event, Milind was pleasantly surprised at the increase in participants and Lucknowites’ enthusiasm for fitness. “It’s heartening to see such a large turnout of runners in Lucknow this time,” said Milind as he cheered the runners at the marathon, adding, “Six years ago when I had come for the first marathon, there were hardly 600 participants. This time it’s ten folds, cheers for you Lucknow!” Surrounded by women of all ages, while wife Ankita Konwar smiled indulgently, Milind put a condition of everyone doing push-ups in order to click a selfie with him. And soon he had bevy women lining up who happily performed the task for that one precious picture with the Made In India song model.Milind Soman with wife Ankita Konwar in Lucknow during the Half Marathon (BCCL/ Vishnu Jaiswal)Not oblivious to the sumptuous food the city has to offer, Milind gave in to the temptation and sampled the winter delicacies while in the city. “It’s been very exciting being in Lucknow especially this time because this is the first time I had makkhan-malai here which is something new for me. And of course it was fun to run because this time we took a new route. And obviously with 6000 people it was amazing,” he said. “I think you can feel the excitement now. 600 are not that many but if the participation is six thousand now that means at least 10,000 have thought about running and are perhaps talking about it and hopefully working towards running next year,” said Soman on the growing number of runners in the city.Ask the actor-model why he is off the screen these days and he begs to differ and says that although he’s not off TV or films, he is doing less of it. “Whenever I find the time, I do some acting. Like I’m doing several content for the web, plus there’s also my show in which I am also the judge, so there’s plenty happening on that front,” says he, adding what makes him be seen less on the screen. “There are also so many other things that I am doing at all times that I can’t be a career actor. I’ve never been one in fact, right from the beginning. I can’t be an actor for 300 days in a year. So I can do maybe 40-50 days in a year as an actor but after that it becomes difficult to manage the time and the dates. Like I can’t give weekends because then I’m mostly travelling. So to only be able to give week days and then also say that I can’t give more than 20 days in month, I feel is not fair to the makers. So I’ll do maybe one project in a year. But theatre and theatrical movies have become less, yes because people want one to be there whenever they are called, which I am not, most of the times. They require a lot of time because they are expensive, the canvas is much larger and I don’t have that much time for it, so why have the producer’s money wasted on me when I won’t be around when I am required.”Milind enjoyed having makkhan malai while in the city (BCCL) The 53 year-old married 28-year-old Ankita Konwar in April 2018, says married life is amazing and is going on strong. Milind and Ankita’s pictures on social media sites are all about their chemistry and for people set relationship goals. The two are also active running partners. Talking about his marriage, Milind says, “Married life has been and is going on amazing. Rather, I would say nothing much has changed except that now I don’t take decisions based on my own desires. I have to ask Ankita like what do you think about this, what do you think about that, will this be okay, would you also like to be a part of this, etc. So now you have to think about somebody else as well. You have to take them into confidence, you have to discuss things.”Ask him when he plans to extend his family and Milind laughs and says, “I don’t have any plans to extend the family. Though, we discuss about having a baby, so let’s see.”A champion for the cause of fitness and running, Milind says his inspiration to do so comes from his mom, Usha Soman , who is 74 years old and still participates in several marathons. “Of course my mum has inspired so many people and even Ankita is super inspired by her. I too am amazed at her as to how she’s managed her whole life and now she’s into fitness and all,” says Milind adding that when it comes to fitness, age is no bar if you want to get fit. “It’s all just in the mind. If you set your mind to do it, you can do it. In fact, we had an event in Bengaluru this time called the Grandmother’s 10K which was a 10 kilometre run only for grandmothers. That was a super success and so inspiring because you are looking at grand moms differently then. Normally you see senior citizens walking or perhaps jogging but when you think of grand moms, you think of them as sitting at home, making achaar or knitting, you don’t see them in tights and shorts and running in marathons . That is the whole idea, to break mind sets that you can’t do this, or you can’t do that especially when you have crossed a certain age. If you want to, you can and you must. Then we had the sari runs where we had women running on the streets in saris! So it’s breaking all these mental taboos and stereotypes because all our difficulties are in the mind, very few are physical and material difficulties.”

Title: Of friendship, love: Bonding over good old days in Delhi
Content:

Salman Khurshid and P Chidambaram

Najeeb Jung and Dilip Cherian

It was an evening of friendship, love and nostalgia, when Montek Singh Ahluwalia , former Deputy Chairman of the erstwhile Planning Commission of India, hosted a get-together for his friends. Conversations flowed from Ahluwalia's St Stephen 's days to his time at Oxford University, and his friends were busy reminiscing about the good old days at the event. From former PM Manmohan Singh to Sharmila Tagore , the party had many big names in attendance.Sarwar Lateef, an economist, who was one of the speakers at the evening, has been friends with Ahluwalia for over six decades. Lateef spoke about Kooler Talk, a campus magazine started by Lateef, Ahluwalia and Mani Shankar Aiyar . Lateef said, "I first met Montek in St Stephen’s College where we were studying Economics. His fellow students found it puzzling that he kept topping every exam, but no one ever saw him studying. So, it didn't come as a surprise when he got the Rhodes scholarship for Oxford University."In his address, Manmohan Singh told the guests that he brought Ahluwalia back to India. He said, "I can make some claim of having introduced Montek to the government system way back in 1973. I don't know about his days at St Stephen's College, but I do know about his days at Oxford. From Oxford, he went on to the World Bank . I tried to persuade Montek to come to India and I made it absolutely clear that I wasn't promising him anything except love for his country. It has been a privilege to work with him."All the speakers of the evening raised a toast to the bond between Ahluwalia and his wife Isher Judge Ahluwalia , Chairperson, Board of Governors, Indian Council for Research on International Economic Relations (ICRIER). Manmohan Singh said, "It is often said that behind every successful man there is a powerful woman. And in this particular case, everyone knows that Isher is that one woman."

Title: Shilpa Shetty Kundra and husband Raj welcome daughter Samisha
Content: Actress Shilpa Shetty Kundra took to social media yesterday to announce the arrival of her baby girl. The actress and husband Raj Kundra , who are parents to eight-year-old Viaan , opted for surrogacy this time around. While their daughter, Samisha Shetty Kundra , was born on February 15, the couple chose the occasion of Mahashivratri to reveal the news to the world.Shilpa shared a picture of the baby holding her father’s finger, and wrote, “Our prayers have been answered with a miracle. With gratitude in our hearts, we are thrilled to announce the arrival of our little angel Samisha Shetty Kundra. Junior SSK in the house. ‘Sa’ in Sanskrit is “to have” and ‘Misha’ in Russian stands for “someone like God”. You personify this name, our Goddess Laxmi and complete our family.”Shilpa, who took an 11-year break from films, will return to the big screen with Sabbir Khan ’s Nikamma. She will also be seen in Priyadarshan ’s Hungama 2, which was announced recently. During her break from films, she set up her business and appeared as a judge on TV reality shows.When we reached out to Shilpa, who has enthusiastically spent days creating a room for her newborn, she told us, “Becoming a parent is a blessing, and to a girl is an even bigger blessing. Raj is a fabulous father, and together, we are hands-on parents. We were completely ready for this. The fact that it happened only means that Samisha was meant to come to us.” And how has her first-born, Viaan, taken the news of his baby sister’s arrival? Shilpa says, “It’s his prayer that has manifested. For the last three years, he has gone to Shirdi with me and only asked for one thing from Sai Baba — a baby sister. I’m so emotional and I can’t believe it has actually happened.”

Title: Mansi Srivastava joins TV show 'Vidya' three weeks after ex Mohit Abrol’s exit
Content: After playing a grey character in 'Divya Drashti', Mansi Srivastava is all set to turn positive in 'Vidya'. The actress will play male lead Namish Taneja ’s childhood friend. Talking about her character, Mansi says, “The show is set in a village, and I will play a Delhi-based designer, who is bubbly and full of life. While Vivek’s (Namish) mother wants us to get married, I don’t want to come in between him and Vidya as I am aware that they love each other.”It is to be noted that Mansi is entering the show around three weeks after her ex-boyfriend, Mohit Abrol ’s track wound up. They had an ugly break-up in January 2019 after being in a relationship for eight years. So, was there any awkwardness about entering the same show close on the heels of Mohit’s exit? Also, would she be comfortable sharing screen space with him in the future? Mansi replies, “I am focused on my character and nothing else. Even if I had to work with him, it would be as professionals, I have nothing to do with him as a person. I have to deal with the situation in a mature way.”
