Title: Two murder cases reported; five arrested
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

cap

Rajkot: Two murder cases were reported from Pardi village of Lodhika taluka in Rajkot district and Una of Gir Somnath district on Thursday night. According to police, five accused in the Pardi murder case had been arrested soon after the crime on Friday.

Accused Deepak Parmar (28), Dileep Parmar (26), Amit Parmar (27), Kailash Parmar (29) and Kishor Parmar (25), had bludgeoned 25-year-old Mitesh Jadav to death with stones in Pardi. They accused told the cops that they had an altercation with Yadav over an issue of driving and as a result of the argument killed him.

Jadav was recently acquitted by a court in the murder case of Ankit Parmar, the history-sheeter of Jetpur.

“Jadav was driving his two-wheeler, while the accused were in their car. After the altercation, Jadav went to Pardi. However, the accused followed him to Pardi, thrashed him before bludgeoning him to death,” said Kuldeepsinh Gohil, sub-inspector with Shapar-Veraval police station.

In the Una case, accused Aizaz Dal, Riyaz Chauhan and Wasim Memon, clubbed one Gulabshah Shahmadar (54) to death in fort locality over old enmity.

“The accused had nursed a grudge against Shahmadar over an issue of firing during the Tazia procession of Moharram, when the victim had picked a fight with the accused,” said an official from Una police station.

Shahmadar’s son Taufiq Shah was also injured in the attack. The accused have been booked on the complaint of Shah and cops have a launched a hunt to nab the accused.

Title: Delhi: Fate of 3,500 men who keep dengue away uncertain
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Representative image

NEW DELHI: Uncertainty continues to loom over the regularisation of 3,500 domestic breeding checkers (DBC) with the municipal authorities unable to start an exercise to enrol them against the vacant positions of field workers.

DBC workers have alleged that to end their last agitation in January, civic officials promised to finalise the procedure for engaging them in the vacant positions by February-end but no work has started so far.

The domestic checkers are contractual employees engaged for checking house-to-house breeding of mosquitoes. There is no official post for DBCs in the Delhi Municipal Corporation Act, forcing them to work on contract for over 20 years. Each of them visits 60 to 70 houses daily to check if coolers, overhead tanks and flower pots have stagnant water, which can be a breeding ground for mosquitoes carrying the dengue, malaria or chikungunya viruses.

“Last year, South Delhi Municipal Corporation (SDMC) mayor Sunita Kangra wrote to the finance ministry for creating a specific position. The ministry said the post could be created only after approval of Delhi government and the lieutenant governor,” said Devanand, president of the Anti-Malaria Ekta Karamchari Union.

It was also clarified candidates would be selected through Delhi Subordinate Services Selection Board exams. “But the majority of us have crossed the age to appear for such exams,” he said, adding that civic officials and the deliberative wing assured them of enrolment through an alternative method. “But no work has started,” said another worker.

A health department official claimed the enrolment in place of field workers, a permanent post, was not simple. “The proposal needs clearance from the House, Delhi government and the LG, and then a gazette notification. The entire process is going to take at least two years. Till then, we have to keep them on contract,” he said.

Title: Now, avail 20% rebate on property tax payment till Feb 25
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Dehradun: Dehradun Municipal Corporation (DMC) has postponed the last date for residents of the old wards to avail a rebate of 20% on property tax (both commercial and residential) payment. Now, the last date to avail this rebate is February 25.

Also, the residents of the 32 new wards can now avail a 20% rebate on the payment of commercial tax till February 25. These residents have been exempted from paying residential tax until 2028.

The move comes after the civic body received several requests in this regard. At first, January 15 was decided as the last date to avail rebate on property tax payments. However, the last date to avail rebate has been extended several times so far.

Notably, the DMC has set a target of Rs 50 crore for its property tax collection for the current financial year and its officials are confident that they will achieve it.

Title: Churchill eye double over MB
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Margao: A lot has changed since Churchill Brothers FC stunned Mohun Bagan 4-2 in the high-scoring I-League encounter in December. Ever since their first and only defeat in 12 games, the Kolkata side have been unstoppable in 10 matches and are now leading the standings with an eight-point gap over second placed Punjab FC.

For Churchill, things have not gone as expected but two back-to-back wins have given Bernardo Tavares’ side some belief they can repeat the feat and do the double when they host Bagan at the Nehru Stadium, Fatorda, on Saturday.

“In football everything is possible. We are training every day and these things can happen. This is a big challenge for us but I have told my boys that it’s against good teams that we can improve. If we win one time, we know we can win for the second time and it is good for the game,” Tavares told TOI on Friday.

Bagan, chasing their second I-League crown, had eight days rest after demolishing Neroca FC 6-2. Kibu Vicuna’s team have been lethal upfront, scoring 27 and conceding just 11. They have secured nine wins and drawn only once in their last 10 league games.

But despite surprising defeats to Indian Arrows, TRAU and defending champions Chennai City FC, Churchill are not far behind with 21 goals and are third in the standings with 19 points from 11 games.

“They (Bagan) are good in defence as well as attack but in some moments in defensive transition, they make some mistakes which we can take advantage. We like to have the ball and play upfront. We like to create opportunities also and I’m sure it will be a good game,” said the Churchill coach.

Churchill had only two days to prepare but will be pleased after captain and star striker Willis Plaza found the net in their 2-1 wins over Aizawl FC and Real Kashmir FC to take his goal tally to seven. Plaza’s striker partner Lalkhawpuimawia has shown what he can do and is the teams second top scorer with four goals. Former captain and medio Richard Costa has undergone a knee surgery and looks to be out for a long period. But Churchill have enough quality in Quan Gomes, Glan Martins and Dawda Ceesay.

Churchill’s centre-back Abu Bakr will have to closely mark Spaniard Fran Gonzalez, the leagues current joint top scorer with nine goals. Then there is former Sevilla and Senegalese striker Papa Diawara, while youngster Nongdamba Naorem also has the ability to create trouble for his markers.

Bagan have seven games more after Churchill and coach Vicuna is not taking anything for granted in their quest for the title.

“Since the beginning, our philosophy, style has remained the same and our teams is playing better every game. It is not possible to get the trophy with 29 points, that means we must continue working and focus on only this game. It is the most important game for us,” said Vicuna.

A win for Churchill will take them to the second spot while Bagan can increase their lead by 11 points.

Title: Private schools accuse child rights body of infringement
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Dehradun: United Forum of Unaided Schools in collaboration with Principals Progressive Schools’ Association (PPSA) has accused State Commission for Protection of Child Rights (SCPCR) of infringement in the functioning of private schools in the city. The schools’ bodies, on Friday, accused the commission officials of misbehaviour and unruly interference in their work and alleged that the state government itself is not taking the RTE seriously.

Talking to TOI, Prem Kashyap, CBSE member and president of PPSA, said that parents are approaching SCPCR with false and fabricated charges against the schools just to avoid payment of the fees for which they have already availed the services.

Meanwhile, SCPCR chief Usha Negi told TOI that private schools are not following RTE norms and if they feel that commission is biased, they are free to approach court. “We have never taken any action (or passed any order) without listening to both sides. If we have done any wrong to any school, they are free to move court. These schools just do not want to follow orders,” she added.

Title: Dynamism, caste equations high on Telangana Congress’ agenda
Content:
Uttam Kumar Reddy

HYDERABAD: Intense lobbying has started in Telangana Congress to succeed Uttam Kumar Reddy as TPCC president. Party sources said the high command is not only looking at a dynamic leader to replace Uttam but also some one who will revive the party in Telangana.The party leadership does not want a repeat of Delhi where it drew a blank in the recent assembly elections. “The leadership is looking at a dynamic leader who can inspire the masses, youngsters and educated sections towards Congress philosophy. Also, he should be able to strengthen NSUI and Youth Congress and lift the party members’ morale at the grassroots in urban and rural areas,” a senior AICC leader. He said caste equations would certainly play a crucial role in finalising the candidate to take over as TPCC chief. With BJP trying to emerge as the only alternative to the ruling TRS, the choice of the new TPCC president to take on both TRS and BJP and steer the party to victory would be on high the leadership’s agenda, he said.Some of the contenders are already camping in Delhi. Former minister and NDMA former vice-chairman Marri Shashidhar Reddy returned from Delhi. Though AICC was supposed to appoint and send two central observers to Hyderabad by this month-end to start the consultation process with 40 to 50 party leaders to finalise the candidate, sources said this exercise could be delayed owing to the recent death of mother of AICC general secretary in-charge of Telangana RC Khuntia .Khuntia will submit a panel of names for TPCC chief’s post to AICC general secretary (organisation) KC Venugopal. The names will have leaders from upper castes, backward classes and Scheduled Castes.

Title: Salma Hayek flaunts her toned figure in swimsuit
Content: American-Mexican actor Salma Hayek shared a picture of herself sitting on the edge of a boat in a swimsuit during a tropical getaway.The 53-year-old actor soaked in the sun in a boat near a rocky cliff where she was seen wearing a black, one-piece swimsuit , white large cat-eye sunglasses and a wide-brim hat.While the gorgeous picture had no caption it did not stop Hayek's fans from praising her.The 'Frida' star got likes of stars like Jennifer Aniston and received comments from her fans.One of the followers wrote, "So pretty."According to a report, the post came two days after a fan commented on one of Hayek's Instagram photos, accusing her of receiving botox.The picture was a selfie which gave her followers a glimpse of the actor while she relaxed on the beach in a magenta swimsuit.

Title: Ex-IAS officers Khulbe, Sinha advisers to PM
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

NEW DELHI: The government on Friday appointed retired IAS officers Bhaskar Khulbe and Amarjeet Sinha as advisers to PM Narendra Modi .

The Appointments Committee of the Cabinet (ACC) approved appointment of the two officers in the rank and scale of secretary to the government on contract basis for two years or until further orders. This is the first time that Modi has appointed any advisers.

Both Khulbe and Sinha are IAS officers of the 1983 batch. Khulbe had earlier served in the PMO while Sinha retired as secretary in the rural development ministry. Khulbe is from the West Bengal cadre while Sinha is from the Bihar cadre.

Khulbe was seen as a trusted officer in the PMO and is known for his efficient handling of complex issues. An alumnus of St Stephen ’s College in the national capital, Sinha topped Delhi University. He also received the Rhodes Scholarship, and the Oxford Cambridge Society of India Scholarship.

Title: Delhi: Hardayal library books to find temporary home in Town Hall
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

The building has also developed cracks at places

NEW DELHI: More than three years after deciding to renovate the Hardayal Municipal Heritage Public Library , the North Delhi Municipal Corporation has issued an order for immediate shifting of its books and records to Town Hall in Chandni Chowk.

As per the order issued on February 13, the records of the establishment department, which are kept in these rooms, will be shifted to the environment management service office opposite Dangal Maidan near Old Delhi station. Rekha Sinha, local councillor and member-secretary of the library, said the shifting was necessary for carrying out the renovation project smoothly. The process is likely to start on Monday.

The project, being undertaken by Indira Gandhi National Centre for Arts (IGNCA), seeks to restore Delhi’s oldest library and preserve its rare collection of books. The library has 1.7 lakh books, out of which 7,000 rare ones were published before 1916 and would be digitised.

“While the repair of the outside plaster started last year, the commissioner recently informed me about the allotment of three rooms in Town Hall for the shift,” said the Jharoda councillor. “While some books and the records will be kept in these rooms and the library staff will also sit there, around half of the books will be packed and kept in the study room of the library itself due to lack of space. All precautionary measures will be taken to save the books from any damage,” she added.

In 2016, Delhi Development Authority granted the corporation Rs 2 crore to restore the building and Rs 1 crore for digitisation. The work was to be undertaken in two phases. “We had to wait for the go-ahead from the Union ministry of heritage and culture. In 2019, we gave the final nod to IGNCA to begin the digitisation of rare books. While the process has started, about 200 extremely rare books will be sent to IGNCA for restoration,” said Sinha.

The work to fix windows, electricity wiring, book racks and illumination will also be taken up. Due to damaged windows, many books, including the Gazette of India, got damaged, said an official. The building has also developed cracks at places.

In September, when TOI visited the place, the library staff said the Gazette of India from 1912 to 1992, kept on the mezzanine floor, got damaged as the window next to its rack was broken.

There is no plan to change the structure of the building because of its heritage status, said a corporation official.

Title: Saptapadi chariot flagged off ahead of mass wedding
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Representative image

MYSURU: To create awareness on the state government’s ‘Saptapadi’ free mass marriage scheme as well as about holding such marriage atop Chamundi hills on April 26, a Saptapati chariot was flagged off from Trineshwara temple in the city on Thursday.

The chariot, flagged off by additional deputy commissioner B R Purnima, will travel to all villages in the district and handbills on the scheme will be distributed to the people.

It is mandatory for couples who intend to marry to submit their applications at the office of the Chamundeshwari temple with necessary records by March 27.

The temple will bear the expenses of these marriages. The temple will spend Rs 55,000 on each couple, including 8 grams of gold for the mangalasutra and Rs 10,000 under ‘Adarsha Vivaha scheme’ by revenue department, Rs 5,000 cash for the bride to purchase white shirt, panche, flowers and Rs 10,000 for bridegroom to buy sari, blouse and flowers.

The social welfare department will also provide Rs 50,000 for Scheduled Caste couple under the promotion of simple marriage scheme. The bride should complete the age of 21 and bridegroom 18 years to register for the marriage scheme.

Title: Telangana: Ill man dies as tenant slaps him over television row
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Representative image

HYDERABAD: A row over high TV volume ended in the death of a man who suffered a heart attack after allegedly being slapped by his tenant at Armoor in Nizamabad .

The deceased house owner, Girmaji Rajender (50), who weighed nearly 120kg and had multiple ailments including diabetes and heart disease, was taken to hospital but was declared dead on arrival.

“Probably fear and weak health triggered a cardiac arrest,” Armoor inspector P Raghavender said, adding that Rajender had stopped working as a labourer due to his illnesses.

According to cops, on Thursday night Rajender increased the TV volume as he could not hear due to the quarrel between his tenant Laxmi Narsaiah and his wife in the portion next door.

“When Narsaiah asked Rajender to reduce the volume, Rajender did not respond. Upset, Narsaiah stormed into Rajender’s house and slapped him,” the inspector said.

Family members along with neighbours of Gol Bangla area in Armoor rushed Rajender to a nearby hospital in an ambulance.

“Rajender was declared brought dead by doctors,” the inspector said. Rajender is survived by his wife and son.

Narsaiah, who makes idlis in a restaurant, fled the house immediately after the incident. Armoor cops have booked a case under IPC Section 304 (ii) (culpable homicide not amounting to murder) against Narsaiah.

Title: Plans to bring Dwarka closer to rest of Delhi
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Increasing frequency on the Airport Line while reducing fares and a strengthened bus connectivity are some of ... Read More

NEW DELHI: A new metro link connecting Dwarka Sector 21 with Sarai Rohilla , running high-quality EMU trains on the existing Dwarka-Bijwasan-Old Delhi-Ghaziabad line, increasing frequency on the Airport Line while reducing fares and a strengthened bus connectivity were some of the measures suggested by a DDA interdisciplinary committee for sustainable development of the sub-city.

The committee was formed by lieutenant governor Anil Baijal in October 2019 to prepare a “strategic” plan dovetailing all projects, optimising usage of land, and framing a policy to develop a complete ecosystem for Dwarka.

The LG was concerned that while DDA had developed over 90% of the land earmarked for residential use, almost 50% of the land meant for commercial and public and semi-public purposes was yet to be developed. About 1,100 hectares “developable land” in Dwarka was yet to be monetised, the LG had observed.

The committee suggested that running EMU trains would connect Dwarka to Bijwasan, Old Delhi and Ghaziabad and reduce travelling time to just 45 minutes. To minimise interchange, a new metro link could be constructed between Sector 21 and Sarai Rohilla via Palam and Delhi Cantonment. Also, the frequency of trains on the Airport Line could be increased and the fares slashed.

To reduce traffic load on roads, the committee suggested that improved bus connectivity with frequency of 2-5 minutes during peak hours and more direct routes to “job centres” should be planned. It added that BRT or light rail could also be explored. All metro stations in Dwarka along Blue Line could be converted as a boulevard and the areas within 500m of stations could be pedestrianised.

“To support IT/ITES industries, options like co-working spaces in TOD schemes, service apartments, rental housing and entertainment facilities are suggested,” the committee’s report said.

On Friday, DDA said that the strategic plan prepared by the committee looked into issues related to regional connectivity of Dwarka, safety and security of women and children, lack of commercial activities, work centres, public activities, parking issues and social infrastructure.

“While finalising the recommendations, the committee discussed issues being faced by Dwarka, including the sub-city not being seen as an investment destination, fragmented projects, women’s safety and congested entry and exit points. In addition to this, there is inefficient public transport and a weak secondary and tertiary network of roads, which is important for shorter commutes through walking or cycling,” said an official.

Title: Telangana government yet to take a call on BC tag to 15 sub-castes
Content:
Telangana CM K Chandrasekhar Rao

HYDERABAD: The Telangana Backward Classes Commission headed by its chairman BS Ramulu recommended for inclusion of 15 sub-castes into BC category and submitted a report to the state government in this regard. This was four months ago. The government, however, has not taken a decision yet.Most of these sub-castes are wandering communities and are neither included in SC or BC category. National BC welfare association president R Krishnaiah said that a majority of these sub-castes are most backward but could not be brought under the SC list as they do not fall under the ‘untouchables’ category.However, a demand for their inclusion in either SC or BC category had been pending for long, BC leaders aver.The Ramulu commission conducted public hearings and found that 15 sub-castes deserved to be extended reservations under BC category. Krishnaiah said some of the sub-sects in BCs are more backward than even SCs and STs. BC associations are demanding that chief minister K Chandrasekhar Rao should not only give a green signal for inclusion of these sub-castes in the BC list, but also enhance BC reservations to 50% in proportionate to their population.Telangana BC welfare association president Yerra Satyanarayana said they are not against inclusion of sub-castes in the BC list, but want the government to enhance the quota to 50% first. Leaders of various BC associations also demanded that the government make public the data collected on BCs and its sub-castes done as part of the samagra kutumba survey.They said there would be heartburn among BCs as they would have to share the quota with a larger number of sub-sects, post-inclusion in the BC list.Already, there are 112 castes and sub-castes in the BC category.

Title: Delhi honour killing: ‘We expected outburst from our families, but not murder’
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Sheetal Chaudhary

NEW DELHI: The love affair between Ankit Bhati and Sheetal Chaudhary had blossomed while they were helping a common friend look for a match. They had managed to keep it under wraps for two years until Bhati’s parents found out about it from a relative. They had reluctantly agreed to their union, but had warned Bhati against marrying Sheetal due to the alleged notoriety of her family in the village.

Sheetal was later allegedly murdered by her family members, who were angry over her “secret marriage” with Bhati, who belonged to the same gotra. The family of the 25-year-old woman from east Delhi allegedly murdered her and dumped her body in a canal in Aligarh, Uttar Pradesh. While the murder took place on January 29, her body was found on January 30.

“I had pleaded with Sheetal’s family members to free her and sort out the differences later. They instead murdered her,” rues Ankit.

The couple had secretly married at Arya Samaj Temple in Kondli, with one of Sheetal’s friends and Ankit’s cousin as witnesses. Their plan was to reveal about it after three months when the court approved their marriage.

“We expected an outburst from our families, but not murder,” says Ankit.

In mid-January, Sheetal had revealed about the wedding to her parents after which they had stopped her from going to the college and even stepping out of home alone. Following Bhati’s persistent efforts to get in touch with her, Sheetal somehow managed to call him on January 29. She informed him that her family was planning something sinister and had called the other members for a meeting.

“Her phone was switched off after this and Ankit was frantically trying to get in touch with her,” says one of Ankit’s cousins. The next day they murdered her. Ankit had, however, presumed the worst and had complained about his wife’s disappearance to the village sarpanch. On February 6, the sarpanch had even called Sheetal’s father, Ravinder Chaudhary , to resolve the issue. Ankit’s kin recalled that Chaudhary had openly claimed to have eliminated Sheetal, and challenged them to bring him to court.

The two families stay in the same locality in New Ashok Nagar. Ankit’s relatives recall how Sheetal was branded as a victim of harassment at the hands of the Bhati family and the neighbourhood was made to believe that she was pursuing further studies at her uncle’s house in Haryana.

Ankit had reached the police station on January 18 with a complaint of kidnapping.

“Sheetal’s family asked her to cut ties with Bhati. But when she refused, they decided to murder her,” police say.

“Ankit has been restless for justice ever since he came to know about the incident. We are trying to counsel him, but it is tough job to do at the moment,” his cousin adds.

Title: Ram temple construction will lay foundation of ‘Ram Rajya’ in country
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Haridwar: The date for construction of Ram temple at Ayodhya will finally be decided at the next meeting of the Ram Janmabhoomi Teerth Kshetra Trust to be held in Ayodhya in the first fortnight of March, Yugapurush Swami Paramanand, a member of the trust said in Haridwar on Friday.

He added, “When the temple construction begins, it will not just lay the foundation of Ram temple, but also the foundation of ‘Ram Rajya’ in the country.”

“When Ram was exiled to the forest, he took help from monkeys, dwellers in forests and caves and other people from the lower social strata of society to achieve his goal. Likewise, in the construction of Ram temple, donations will be accepted from all including the high and the low and the rich and the poor,” the seer alleged adding that “the bricks brought by karsewaks after shilapoojan and stones being cut for decades will all be used in the construction of the temple.”

Title: Until next year? Temperatures set to rise in Delhi from today
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Tilak Bridge

NEW DELHI: Delhi received a bout of winter rain combined with thunderstorms on Thursday night that continued till the early hours of Friday.

Track the pollution level in your city

Safdarjung recorded 1.8mm rain till 8.30 in the morning, while Palam recorded 3.2mm rain, Najafgarh 2mm, Lodhi Road 1.7mm, Ayanagar 1.3mm and Ridge recorded 1mm rain. Rainfall and strong winds brought down the mercury in the national capital. The maximum temperature was recorded at 20.9 degrees Celsius, four notches below normal. The minimum temperature was 15.8 degrees Celsius, five above normal.

“Due to induced cyclonic circulation in Rajasthan, it rained in Delhi-NCR on Thursday night. There was light rainfall in the early hours of Friday too. The temperature will, however, start rising from Saturday. In the next two-three days, it will reach 27 degrees Celsius,” Kuldeep Srivastava, head of the IMD’s regional forecasting centre at Delhi, said.

On Saturday, partly cloudy sky is expected along with mist or shallow fog in the morning. The maximum and minimum temperatures would be around 25 and 12 degrees Celsius, respectively.

The rain on Thursday night also helped the city’s air quality improve significantly. It entered the “moderate” levels with an AQI of 144. On Thursday, the air quality was in the “poor” category (230).

Title: Kolkata: A city’s dream takes shape 33 metres below the river
Content:
Tracks being laid below the riverbed

KOLKATA: Laying of tracks for the East-West Metro corridor along the 520m tunnel has been going on in full swing 33m below the Hooghly riverbed. The underwater tunnel is the prime attraction of the 3.8km Howrah Maidan-Esplanade section.Under the riverbed, around 1,100m of tracks (520m each way) has to be laid. Of it, 450m inside the river tunnel has been completed and another 650m is left.A lot of water has flown below the Howrah bridge since the twin tunnels crossed the river, snaked through Kolkata’s congested areas to reach Mahakaran station (below Laldighi at Dalhousie Square), and burrowed beyond to Esplanade (from where another set of tunnels are now headed towards Sealdah). “Constructing the tunnels, 33m below the riverbed, has been an engineering feat,” said an engineer of Afcons.Truncated services of East-West Metro between Sector V and Salt Lake Stadium stations have started last week. While tunnelling has resumed from Bowbazar and work is in progress at other stations simultaneously, the underwater part of East-West tunnels are getting finishing touches. But the “touch” is quite an elaborate affair.According to engineers, the track-laying work in underground section is a big challenge, especially under the riverbed, since there are sharp curves along the entire stretch. “The track is being laid and manoeuvered along three major curves,” an engineer of Kalindee-Rahee said. KMRC is committed to complete the work of laying the tracks in another two months.While construction major Afcons, which is currently constructing evacuation pathways inside the river tunnels, is contracted to build the 3.8km underground stretch, Kalindee-Rahee, a joint venture company, is laying the tracks along 16km stretch from Sector V to Howrah Maidan. They have already laid tracks from Sector V till Sealdah. And now it is the turn of the Howrah side of the corridor to get the ballastless tracks.The track contractor started laying tracks inside both east and west tunnels passing through the river in January-end. Tunnelling of the river was done in four months in 2017 and construction of the corridor from Howrah Maidan to Esplanade was over in March 2018, after which the track-bed concretization work was done.Meanwhile, Afcons has completed the “bracketing” work inside the underwater tunnels. Fabricating this many brackets — more than 1 lakh — and installing them along the semi-circular surface of the twin tunnels is no mean business. Electrical cables will be mounted on the brackets, along with lights and other fixtures. It will be followed by ventilation work.In another two years, the entire 16km corridor will be commissioned, railway minister Piyush Goyal had promised last week at the first phase inauguration of the rapid transit link that will have trains cruising at 80kmph.Once fully operational, India’s answer to Eurostar will connect Howrah Maidan with Salt Lake’s Sector V, joining the two iconic railway stations — Howrah and Sealdah — along the way.

Title: ‘UT status to Ladakh set to usher in development’
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Ladakh MP Jamyang Tsering Namgyal gives a lecture at Hedgewar Smarak Samiti, Reshimbagh, on Friday

Nagpur: Abrogation of Articles 370 and 35A of the Constitution of India and making Ladakh a union territory (UT) have started showing results as people are getting many facilities they were deprived of over the last many decades, said Jamyang Tsering Namgyal , MP , on Friday.

He was speaking on ‘Ladakh: Kal aur aaj’ at a programme organized by Jivhala Foundation at Maharshi Vyas Sabhagruh, Dr Hedgewar Smarak Samiti premises, Reshimbagh, to mark Shivaji jayanti.

Rashtriya Swayamsevak Sangh (RSS) functionary Shridhar Gadge, president of J&K Study Centre Meera Khadakkar, legislators Anil Sole and Mohan Mate, Manish Meshram and Ashish Vandile were present.

Jamyang, who represents Ladakh in Parliament, said, “Removal of special status to Jammu and Kashmir was a decisive step the Union government took.” Terming the government decision as historic and bold, Jamyang said earlier, no higher education facilities were available to children after schooling while unemployment was a perennial problem. The things are now changing for better with many universities coming up in Ladakh while prospects of job are looking up. This will help develop the region, he added.

“The Union government has beefed up security so that forces inimical to our country’s sovereignty can never dare to resort to any misadventure. People now feel secured. We need a strong government in future also so that attempts to disturb peace are thwarted,” he said.

“Ladakh is not just a piece of land but an amazing destination where people of kind hearts live. It is a place for adventure, meditation, tourism and cultural heritage,” he said.

It is important to ensure proper communication between people and the authorities for development and make the world a better place to live in, he added.

In his address, Gadge mainly spoke about Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA) which is being opposed by many parties. He dispelled the notion that CAA will take away the citizenship as is feared by some sections of the society and said it is a misconception.

Canards spread by vested interests, fake news and miscommunication are the major reasons why some parties are opposed to CAA. Tightening security of the country is priority of the government which every law abiding citizen should respect, he added.

The programme started with paying obeisance to Lord Shiva on Mahashivaratri and saluting the great Maratha warrior Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj.

Vandile made the introductory remarks.

Anchor Abhijit Muley said it is of paramount importance to inculcate in people values to tread on the right path. Instead of only talking about the valour of Shivaji Maharaj, people should follow the principles Chhatrapati held close to his heart, Muley said.

Tushar Mahajan, secretary of Jivhala Foundation, proposed a vote of thanks.

Title: Telangana infant dies after drinking kerosene
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Picture used for representational purpose only

HYDERABAD: An eleven-month-old boy, who accidentally consumed kerosene while playing at his house, died while being shifted to a hospital in Nizamabad on Thursday.

The victim, A Sai Vardhan, from Vallabhapur village in Kotagiri mandal of Nizamabad district , was the third child of Sai Charan, a private employee and Meena. On Thursday, when his parents were busy cleaning the house on the eve of Mahashivaratri, Vardhan went near the stove, where his mother had kept a bottle of kerosene, and accidentally consumed it.

“A little while after consuming kerosene, the boy fell ill and the parents rushed him to a hospital in Bodhan. While he was being shifted from Bodhan hospital to Nizamabad hospital, the boy succumbed,” Kotagiri police said. Family members did not lodge any police complaint and no case was registered.

Title: East-West Metro's tunnelling to end by March 2021, says experts
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

International experts involved in the project said on Friday.

KOLKATA: The last leg of East-West Metro’s tunnelling that resumed on Tuesday will be completed by March next year , international experts involved in the project said on Friday.

TBM Chundee, which was digging the west-bound tunnel, has now become defunct after puncturing an aquifer in August last year. It’s twin, Urvi, will complete the remaining job. According to the experts, Urvi will take five months to burrow 1km eastwards till Sealdah, four months to get dismantled and another three months to dig back 800m to Bowbazar.

Kolkata Metro Rail Corporation (KMRC), the implementing agency of East-West Metro, had set up the expert panel soon after the August 31 disaster that damaged several buildings in Bowbazar. Now, the committee is mandated by Calcutta high court to rigorously monitor the tunnelling work.

“We are accountable to the court and will be monitoring as per its directions,” said committee chairman John Endicott, the Hong Kong-based British geotechnical expert with 50 years of tunnelling experience. Others in the panel are Endicott’s colleague Christopher Bridges , General Consultants (GC) project director Ken Wong and Thailand-based Yuthana Charoenpak, the tunnelling manager of ITD ITD-Cementation, which is contracted to build the 2.5km twin tunnels between Esplanade and Sealdah.

“We have dug an additional 22 boreholes to view the soil profile. There’s nothing unusual about the water. The initial inflow doesn’t matter. But if there is a slight leakage, there is provision for the refurbished TBM (Urvi) for arresting the water in 60 minutes,” explained the experts.

Bridges informed that Urvi has dug around 20m since Tuesday. “It’s moving very slowly. We are still testing the system. When the TBM gathers speed, it will dig around 10m a day.”

A number of features have been added to the machine, which now has sensors to sense anything unusual. There are steel plates to ward off water, provision to inject grease and grout after mining, as each ring is created and various monitoring points to check the parameters during digging.

Referring to the fateful afternoon of August 31, Endicott said water had continuously flooded into the tunnel for two-and-a-half hours, bringing with it silt and sand that led to large-scale ground settlement and had buildings falling one after the other. “There are aquifers everywhere along the East-West Metro’s tunnelling path. If you can stop the water inflow in an hour’s time, you can prevent silt and sand gushing along with it. And that’s what the upgraded machine is now equipped to do,” Endicott said, adding, “The idea is to keep the seal of the TBM dry.”

The seal, a vital component of the TBM, Endicott said, had given away on August 31. “The seals didn’t work. We don’t know why and this led to flooding of the tunnel in Bowbazar. Now there’s a new seal of the tail skin brush and provision to replace the seal if the existing one goes off,” Endicott said.

Title: Telangana: 50 KGBV students fall ill due to food poisoning
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Representative image

DHARMASAGAR (WARANGAL): About 50 students of Kasturba Gandhi Balika Vidyalaya (KGBV) at Mupparam village of Dharmasagar mandal in Warangal Urban district fell ill after having dinner late on Thursday. Sources said that before going to bed, many students complained of stomach ache and vomiting sensation.

After the other students informed special officer Neeraja Reddy, some 37 students were sent to MGM hospital in Warangal. About 10 students were sent to Dharmasagar PHC and the remaining were treated at KGBV Mupparam.

Ghanapur (Station) MLA Rajaiah, a doctor by profession, checked the students and enquired about those admitted to MGM hospital. He coordinated with MGM hospital medical experts and said that if required, students can be sent to Hyderabad for treatment. The students are recovering at MGM and PHC in Warangal. District Education Officer (DEO) Narayana Reddy, alongwith other officials, rushed to Mupparam village to monitor the situation.

Parents alleged that the mess contractor, Dharmaraju, has been providing inferior quality ingredients for the meals. They demanded an inquiry into the incident.

Title: GST November-December 2019 payout: Goa gets just Rs 132 crore
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Representative image

PANAJI: The state government has received just Rs 132 crore as GST compensation from the Centre for the November-December 2019 period.

The total GST component due to the state for the period stands at Rs 250 crore.

A senior official confirmed that the state has received just a part of its GST compensation.

Already struggling to balance its expenditure requirements for capital works with revenue expenditure such as salaries and annual maintenance, the state government has been on a borrowing spree during the current financial year.

Now, it is set to further borrow an amount of Rs 75 crore next week.

Title: 55-yr-old dies at Coronation Hospital, family cites negligence
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Dehradun: Family of a 55-year-old woman suffering from a neurological disorder staged a protest outside Coronation Hospital in Doon on Friday, after she was declared dead by doctors. The patient’s kin alleged that medical negligence led to the death and demanded an inquiry.

State Congress president Pritam Singh reached the hospital and met the protesting family on Friday. The family initially refused to take the body but eventually agreed. Dr BC Ramola, superintendent of Coronation hospital, said a team had been constituted to probe the family’s allegations.

According to the hospital staff, the patient was admitted at the hospital on February 17 with a head injury. “The family hasn’t given anything in written but we will be doing an internal inquiry,” he added.

Title: Kolkata: Commissioner of Railway Safety grants permission for Tallah level crossing
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

The crossing will be shut down after the new Tallah Bridge is constructed.

KOLKATA: The Commissioner of Railway Safety (CRS) has granted permission to Eastern Railway (ER) to construct a level-crossing across the tracks at Tallah. This is an interim measure to ensure smoother movement of traffic and the crossing will be shut down after the new Tallah Bridge is constructed. A similar level-crossing was constructed at Majerhat after the road overbridge (ROB) collapse there.

“A General Arrangement Drawing (GAD) approval for the ROB at Tallah has also been received and sent for CRS sanction. This is the first step towards start of the ROB construction process. Once the CRS sanction is received, meetings will be convened with the state government to decide the design and other issues. Demolition of the existing structure has already started and we will take special measures when the portion directly above the tracks is brought down,” a senior ER official said.

In another development that raises hopes for quicker completion of the new Majerhat ROB, all documents and drawings sought by the CRS have been sent to him by ER on Friday. Work can start in full swing as soon as the CRS carries out an inspection and grants clearance.

According to the RAILWAYS official, the documents were received by the PWD on Wednesday and no time was wasted in despatching them to the CRS. Though a railway officer, the CRS is a post under the ministry of civil aviation and even the railways has no say in any decision he takes.

Title: Table-toppers FC Goa face familiar foes in playoff stage
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Panaji: FC Goa very well know they have to raise their level next season when they become the first Indian club to participate in the AFC Champions League. But for now, the Super Cup champions will turn their focus on the Indian Super League ( ISL ) title that has eluded them twice.

Last year, FC Goa fell short in the final against Bengaluru FC , while in 2015 it were Chennaiyin FC that broke Goan hearts on home soil in a thrilling 3-2 summit clash at Fatorda.

Now, FC Goa could face either one of their familiar rivals in the last-four clash after Chennaiyin sealed their playoff spot on Friday with a 1-0 win over Mumbai City FC. The playoff lineup will be decided on Saturday after defending champions Bengaluru host ATK . And FC Goa will certainly watch it keenly.

“If you go to see, in the next three games there is only one knock out that is the final. Whereas we have two semifinals, home and away. But then it is important we win and give ourselves the best chance over these two semifinals to reach the final,” said FC Goa interim coach Clifford Miranda.

Clifford was put charge of the team only in the last three matches after the management parted ways with Spanish coach Sergio Lobera, who was highly admired for his influence in Indian football in his three-year stay.

But Clifford, under the mentorship of technical director Derrick Pereira, have made the transition smooth without making much changes. They will stick to follow the same pattern and not break FC Goa’s rhythm.

“We will not go any different way because it will mean changing our way of playing. We will go the same way that gets a closer in reaching our objective and will play our natural game,” said the former India midfielder.

Ever since losing 2-0 to ATK in Kolkata, FC Goa have responded strongly in their next five games and remained unbeaten. They scored 14 goals alone in their last three games, conceding only three.

“The players are top professionals and have been working very hard all throughout the season right from day one. Credit should go to each and every one associated with the club right from the beginning. It’s not just last three matches but hard work of everyone who have been there throughout this season,” said Pereira.

FC Goa will get sufficient rest before their first leg semifinal either on February 29 or March 1 but with their current form, look favourites to progress no matter who they play.

Title: Flights from Pithoragarh’s Naini Saini airport cancelled till Feb 26
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Pithoragarh: Flights of Heritage Aviation operating from the Naini Saini airport in Pithoragarh have been cancelled till February 26. This was informed by SDM Pithoragarh Tushar Saini who told TOI on Friday that Heritage Aviation officials had informed the administration that their flights will be cancelled from Feb 21 to Feb 26 due to “operational problems.” The company runs flights on the Dehradun-Pithoragarh and Pithoragarh- Delhi routes. According to sources, all flights on both routes had been booked till Feb 28.

Title: Will implement reservation in promotion: Cong
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Almora: Rajya Sabha MP and senior Congress leader Pradeep Tamta, on Friday, accused the ruling BJP of conspiring to end the reservation for SC/ST.

Tamta said that “opposition to reservation is an old agenda of RSS and BJP is working on this agenda”. Speaking at a press conference, Tamta said that if Congress comes to power, it will implement reservation in promotion. “Social justice is a commitment of our Constitution and the Congress is committed to implementing it,” he said.

Earlier, the Supreme Court had ruled that, “There is no fundamental right which inheres in an individual to claim reservation in promotions.”

Title: Will work to promote Telugu: Former Maharashtra governor C Vidyasagar Rao
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

C Vidyasagar Rao

HYDERABAD: Former Maharashtra governor and senior BJP leader C Vidyasagar Rao on Thursday said he will work for the vigorous promotion of Telugu language till his last breath. He was speaking at an event organised to observe International Mother Language Day here. “Bangladesh went to war over language, got separated and became a nation” he pointed out.

State government advisor Ramanachary, who also participated in the meeting, said that contrary to popular perception, one can become an IAS officer even with Telugu medium. “Things can be better understood and knowledge can be better attained through mother tongue,” he said.

Title: City air now satisfactory, rise in temp to follow
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

New Delhi: Delhi’s air improved to the ‘ satisfactory ’ category on Saturday as the AQI touched 100, better than Friday’s ‘moderate’ at 144 and Thursday’s ‘poor’ at 230.

Data according to Central Pollution Control Board’s central control room showed NCR’s average PM2.5 levels recorded at 49.5 micrograms per cubic metre at 7pm on Saturday. The average PM10 levels, at the same time, also well below the safe standards, were recorded at 91.8 micrograms per cubic metre, data showed. The ‘emergency’ benchmark for these pollutants under Graded Response Action Plan is, respectively, 300 and 500 micrograms per cubic metre, while the safe standards are 60 and 100 micrograms per cubic metre, respectively.

According to SAFAR, the AQI will be in the ‘moderate’ to ‘poor’ category for Sunday. “Marginal deterioration in AQI to the ‘poor’ category is forecast for Monday and Tuesday,” a report on Saturday said.

Earlier, it was a misty morning in the city on Saturday with the minimum temperature settling at 13 degrees Celsius, two notches above the season’s average. The maximum temperature was 24.8 degrees Celsius, normal for this time of the year.

“Rainfall in north India and strong winds for the past three-four days have helped the city’s air quality . The temperature, however, in the next two-three days, will reach 27 degrees Celsius and the rising trend will continue,” Kuldeep Srivastava, head, IMD regional forecasting centre, said, adding that on February 27 and 28, another western disturbance is expected.

On Sunday, a mainly clear sky is expected with mist in the morning. The maximum and minimum temperatures will be around 26 and 13 degrees Celsius, respectively.

Title: Maintenance work may cause weekend blues on Delhi Metro’s Yellow Line
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

A Delhi Metro’s Yellow Line train

NEW DELHI: If you have to travel on Delhi Metro’s Yellow Line this weekend, plan your commute beforehand. Metro train services between Vishwavidyalaya and Kashmere Gate stations will be affected for limited intervals on Saturday and Sunday as Delhi Metro Rail Corporation will be undertaking planned track maintenance work.

An advisory issued by DMRC states that train services between Vishwavidyalaya and Kashmere Gate stations will be run on single line after 9.30 pm till the end of services on Saturday; and then from the start of revenue services till 7.30 am on Sunday. During the affected time periods, trains will be available at a frequency of 15 minutes between Vishwavidyalaya and Kashmere Gate.

“Maintenance work will be carried out between Vidhan Sabha to Vishwavidyalaya metro section,” the advisory adds.

Delhi metro has made several arrangements to ensure there is no inconvenience to commuters during these non-peak hours, said an official.

“Short loop train operation from Vishwavidyalaya to Samaypur Badli and from Kashmere Gate to HUDA City centre will be carried out during the said period. The frequency of the trains will remain as per routine timetable in these section. Trains will be available at a frequency of 15 minutes between Vishwavidyalaya and Kashmere Gate,” reads the advisory.

Feeder buses will also be deployed from Vishwavidyalaya to Kashmere Gate station. The passengers can avail this service free of cost. Regular announcements will be made at the stations and inside the trains on Yellow Line about destination of trains and respective platforms for changeover during this period, the advisory adds.

Title: Trichy-Karur road widening to get going in two months
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Trichy: After sitting on the proposal for six months, the state highways department has finally decided to launch the civil work to widen a narrow 11km stretch of Trichy-Karur national highway in two months. A veritable death trap for commuters, the stretch serves as a crucial link for the western districts with Trichy and delta districts.

In the past five years alone, the road has witnessed at least 82 fatal accidents owing to its narrow width and steep curves. However, six months after the widening proposal received administrative sanction, the delay in starting the work has been frustrating for the local people commuting on the accident-prone stretch. The miscalculation of commuters, mostly two-wheeler riders who try to overtake vehicles along the steep curves, often ends up in fatal accidents.

“We are commuting amidst threat to our lives every day. The widening project should not be withheld further,” P Aiyarappan, a road safety activist, said. Jeeyapuram police station, under whose jurisdiction the Karur road falls, has recorded over 300 road accidents in the last five years of which a majority was reported from the stretch. It was in early 2019 that the state highways department identified the cause of the accidents and proposed to widen the stretch bowing to public demand. The Rs 55crore proposal received administrative sanction in August but there has been no further progress.

Confirming the plan to widen Karur road, highways department said it will float a tender for identifying a suitable contractor on March 18. The 7-metre-wide road will be expanded to 10.5 metres and the steep curves standardised to avert toppling of vehicles. However, the proposed widening seems to have excluded the proposal for a new bridge across Kudamurutti river to replace the ageing two-lane bridge. A new bridge estimated to cost Rs 20 crore is likely to be taken up as a separate project. “The widening project will go on for a year and one end of the road will be widened at a time,” an official with state highways department told TOI.

Title: Why conduct road safety meet on the sly: Activists
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Representative image

TRICHY: The district administration on Thursday conducted the monthly road safety review meeting to discuss the need to make Trichy roads safer. However, a section of road safety activists lamented that such discussions were often conducted secretly.

For better performance of the road safety council, local people have sought the participation of additional and rural representatives to convey their grievances as the majority of complaints taken up at the meeting pertains to city roads.

The mandatory road safety meeting chaired by district collector S Sivarasu and attended by senior police officials at the district collectorate discussed the road safety concerns of the common public.

The district administration said it is permitting two members belonging to non-governmental organisations to raise road infrastructure needs.

“We were told about the conduct of the road safety meeting only after it was over. District administration should invite more people to hear grievances regarding road safety and suggestions to avoid traffic congestion,” K Shyam Sundar, member of Trichy Intra-City Development Endeavours (TIDES) said.

The demand to allow media coverage at road safety meetings as in farmers’ grievance meetings remains unaddressed. “Most of the demands placed at road safety meetings and the press releases we get to see were city-based issues. Rural roads that are deprived of road safety infrastructure are neglected,” V Baskaran, a resident of Vayalur Road said.

When asked about the possibility of increasing public participation at road safety meeting, officials in the district administration gave an elusive answer. “We will think about adding new members to the road safety council,” an official said.

Title: More protesters booked as anti-CAA stir enters day 5
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Trichy: The protest against Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA) at Uzhavar Sandhai grounds continued for the fifth day on Friday even as the police booked around 300 people on Thursday for organising protests in the city without police permission.

As many as 200 Muslims including women stayed put at the venue raising anti-CAA slogans and stood firm on their demand for Tamil Nadu government to pass a resolution against CAA in the assembly.

The protesters at Uzhavar Sandhai were slapped with unlawful assembly, continuous unlawful assembly and public nuisance charges.

On Thursday, the Thillai Nagar police booked 100 people, including 11 identified people, for taking part in the protest. The KK Nagar police registered a case of unlawful assembly against 11 identified students and 70 others for staging a demonstration in front of Jamal Mohammed College.

The students were from colleges in Trichy. There was no protest by students on Friday.

Communist party of India (CPI) secretary R Mutharasan and 80 others including CPI east area secretary Ansarudeen were booked for unlawful assembly near Ramakrishna bridge on Thursday.

Title: Link Cauvery, Vaigai, and Gundar through Manapparai: Farmers
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Street vendors near war memorial in Gandhi market

TRICHY: A couple of weeks after the state government earmarked Rs 700 crore in the budget for the first phase of the Cauvery–Vaigai–Gundar river linking project, farmers in Trichy have urged it to modify the project to benefit rain-fed Manapparai, Marungapuri and Vaiyampatti .

Members of the Tamil Nadu Vivasayigal Sangams of the CPI and CPM as well as of Desiya Thennindiya Nadhigal Inaippu Sangam staged a demonstration in front of the district collector’s office on Friday demanding that the link canal be taken through the three areas instead of directly to Pudukottai from Mayanur in Karur across Cauvery . Trichy collector S Sivarasu was chairing the monthly grievance day meeting when the farmers demonstrated outside.

At present, the project proposes to link Cauvery with Vaigai through the 255.60 km-long canal passing through Trichy, Pudukottai, Sivaganga, Ramanathapuram and Virudhunagar districts. While welcoming the project, the farmers said water problem remains perennial in Manapparai, Marungapuri and Vaiyampatti taluks where farmers depend on rain for agriculture. “This suggestion is not new, so farmers were shocked to find the project omitting the three taluks,” said the CPI-affiliated Tamil Nadu Vivasayigal Sangam’s district secretary Ayilai Sivasurian .

“About 70 kms of the canal will have to be constructed to take the project through the three areas but it is worth it for the sake of the people in the area where water crisis is looming. We request the government to conduct a feasibility study on this before launching the project,” said the district secretary of the CPM-affiliated Tamil Nadu Vivasayigal Sangam V Chidambaram. State president of Desiya Thennindiya Nadhigal Inaippu Sangam P Ayyakannu also suggested shifting the location of branching out of the link canal from Mayanur to a place parallel to Manapparai, Marungapuri and Vaiyampatti.

Title: Government outlines plans for mohalla marshals in Delhi
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Delhi Commission for Women

NEW DELHI: Women and child development minister Rajendra Pal Gautam on Friday met Delhi Commission for Women chief Swati Maliwal to formulate an action plan to ensure women’s safety at the grassroots.

Gautam said ensuring women’s safety was a priority for the AAP government and plans were afoot to deploy mohalla marshals and set up mahila panchayats in the next few months to achieve the goal. “DCW has done exemplary work in the last three years. In AAP’s guarantee card, women’s safety has the topmost priority,” the minister added.

Making Delhi safer for women was among the 10 promises made by chief minister Arvind Kejriwal in his guarantee card released in the run-up to the elections. Kejriwal and his cabinet colleagues had held a meeting with officials on Wednesday for the implementation of the guarantee card in a time-bound manner.

Apart from installation of CCTV cameras and streetlights across the city, the government has promised deployment of bus marshals and mohalla marshals to make women feel safer. “The deployment of mohalla marshals will be a revolutionary step in ensuring overall security and safety at the grassroots level,” Gautam said after meeting the DCW chief.

Maliwal said a pilot project on mohalla marshals was done in Burari where civil defence volunteers conducted regular checks at vulnerable locations. “The results were outstanding and the same model should be implemented across all 70 assembly segments,” Maliwal said in a statement.

The minister has asked DCW to set up a special SC/ST women’s welfare cell.

Title: Too little of Trichy in govt exhibition on 3 years’ achievements
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Trichy: The photo exhibition organized by information and public relations department near Trichy central bus stand on Friday to highlight the three years of governance by the Edappadi K Palaniswami-led AIADMK government had nothing to offer for Trichiites. The photographs of initiatives implemented in the past three years of the state government had very minimal local connect except for the statewide welfare schemes.

As many as 39 photos were displayed at the exhibition conducted as a report card of the state government. Photographs of events organized by various departments including agriculture engineering, youth welfare and sports development were among those displayed. Interestingly, even the photographs taken in 2014 were displayed at the event intended to project the past three years of achievements. While most of the exhibits were pan-state welfare schemes and initiatives, the exhibition had nothing to boast as achievement or fulfilment of the demands of Trichy.

Ironically, the congested central bus stand where the event was organized is itself a hot topic on the development front as there is a long-pending demand to relocate it to a spacious integrated bus terminus on the outskirts. “As far as Trichy is concerned, there is nothing to hail as achievement in the past three years, Gandhi market was not relocated and Srirangam is yet to get a bus stand. Neither old proposals nor any new announcements were implemented to develop Trichy,” V B Jaganath, a resident of Karumandapam, said.

Among the 39 photographs and a few banners displayed, only three photographs seem to project the welfare schemes or innovative projects focussing Trichy, namely resting room for TNSTC drivers and traffic park at old collectorate. It is to be noted that the traffic park installed at old collectorate was jointly funded by several private organisations here. Officials who organized the exhibition maintained that the photographs were selected to highlight the statewide schemes and not focussing Trichy.

Title: Rare snake eye lizard spotted on Kolli hills
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

TRICHY: Leschenault's snake eye lizard – from the lacertid lizard family- endemic to Western Ghats in India and eastern Sri Lanka, has been spotted for the first time in Puliyancholai of Kolli hills. Puliyancholai is a popular tourism destination located in the foothills of Kolli Hills near Thuraiyur, which is about 72 km away from Trichy.

Leschenault's snake eye lizard, named after a France botanist, has transparent lower eyelids that are fused with the upper lids to form a cap over the eye. Scientifically known as Ophisops, they look similar to Skinks, which are very common. While Skink have cylindrical body unlike the Leschenault's snake eye lizard, which have conical body, are not spotted in Kolli hills region, which falls in the Eastern Ghats , said Q Ashoka Chakkaravarthy, field biologist from Centre for Ecology and Conservation, Trichy. It took Chakkaravarthy over a month to confirm the species based on the scale and other features.

During British era, this species was locally distributed in Salem and Coimbatore districts only, especially near the banks of river Cauvery, but it has now been recorded at Puliyancholai, Chakkaravarthy said. Fragmentation of the forest is posing threat to reptiles and amphibians, he said and urged the forest department to take steps to conserve these rare species. Chakkaravarthy said that these reptiles are over-exposed to predators such as domestic cats, poultry and birds and climatic change because of degraded habitat.

“Deforestation with consequent habitat fragmentation is the biggest threat to reptiles and amphibians in this region. This could be a reason why population of many reptile species has been considerably declining,” he said.

“Leschenault’s snake eye lizard was last recorded in Gingee hills in Villupuram in 2018,” said V Gokula, head of zoology department, National College Trichy (NCT).

Gokula said that the spotting of this species in Kolli hills is an additional record. He said that it is an interesting range extension for the species as it was so far found only in Coimbatore and Salem along Western Ghats. While Kolli hills, too, is remanence of Western Ghats, Leschenault's snake eye lizard was not spotted yet in Kolli hills.

Title: Manish Sisodia seeks Delhi’s share in central taxes
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Nirmala Sitharaman and Manish Sisodia

NEW DELHI: In a meeting with Union finance minister Nirmala Sitharaman on Friday, deputy chief minister and state finance minister Manish Sisodia sought a share for Delhi in central taxes, besides allocation of funds for the three corporations on the lines of the Centre providing funds to local bodies of other states. Delhi government gets a grant in lieu of a share in central taxes, which has remained stagnant at Rs 325 crore since 2001-02. “I urged the Union finance minister to give a share in the central taxes so that work can be expedited on establishing more schools and hospitals, Yamuna is cleaned and adequate water and electricity is supplied in the city,” Sisodia said. In a letter addressed to Sitharaman, Sisodia referred to the erstwhile Article 270(3) of the Constitution, which defined the share of taxes between the Centre and Union territories. Omission of Article 270(3) in the year 2000 has resulted in Delhi not receiving its rightful share in central taxes. “The Constitution (80th Amendment) Act, 2000 was passed by Parliament primarily for including corporation tax with personal income tax for resource sharing between states and the Union government. It replaced Article 270 with a new set of provisions. This has had an adverse impact on the state’s finances,” Sisodia mentioned in the letter. The deputy CM further said: “The 15th Finance Commission in its report for financial year 2020-21 has provided 1% of the divisible pool for the newly formed Union Territories of J&K and Ladakh and assigns the same to the central government. As you are aware, J&K and Delhi are on a similar footing within the Constitution as UTs with legislature. Accordingly, additional terms of reference to the finance commission would bring justice to the people of Delhi and rectify the anomaly created by the inadvertent omission of Article 270(3).” Sisodia also said that Delhi has not been given any share in central taxes since 2001. “It is important to mention that 42% of central taxes are given to all other states based on the recommendations of the finance commission. Before 2001, Delhi also used to get a share in it,” he added. Highlighting that Delhi government needs to make large investments in education, health, social welfare, food security, transport, roads, healthcare and other sectors, Sisodia said that if Article 270(3) had not been omitted, then Delhi would have been getting Rs 7,000 crore annually as share from central taxes. “I requested for funds for the municipal corporations of Delhi in the same way as other states get from the central government,” Sisodia said. Sisodia also referred to the recommendations of the Arjun Sengupta Committee according to which the central government had in 1997-98 agreed to bring the funding pattern of Union Territories similar to that of other states.

Title: Woman killed, 12 injured as private bus overturns in Hunsur
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

There were around 30 passengers in the bus

MYSURU: A school teacher died and 12 other passengers were injured after a Kerala-bound private bus in which they were travelling overturned in Hunsur town on Friday midnight.

The deceased is Shareena, 29, a native of Nagpur in Maharastra, who was working as a teacher at a school in Bengaluru. She was travelling to Thalassery in Kerala for ayurvedic treatment.

The driver of the sleeper coach belonging to Kallada Tours and Travels lost control of the speeding bus while trying to avoid another bus coming from the opposite side and hit an electric pole. Due to the impact, the bus overturned, resulting in serious injuries to Shareena and other 15 passengers. There were around 30 passengers in the bus. Shareena,, whose legs were severed in the accident succumbed to injuries on the way to KR Hospital in Mysuru.

Of the injured passengers, Kareena and Sri Raghu were admitted to Bhanavi Hospital while Siraj, Anjana, Lhogin, Farhad, Swetha, Bhavisha, Amrutha, Akshay, Santhosh, Shiny, Shivoth, and bus cleaner Ansaf, were taken to KR Hospital. Bus driver Sudhin managed to escape with minor injuries.

Police said the passengers were fast asleep when the accident took place near the old, narrow bridge across Lakshman Teerta River.

The villagers, who heard the cries of shocked passengers, rushed to their help and informed police as well the electricity department to disconnect power.

Meanwhile, autorickshaw drivers, who had been waiting for passengers near the rural bus stand, rushed to the help of the injured and shifted them to the hospital. Police using cranes lifted the bus and also arranged transport for uninjured passengers to travel to Kerala.

On hearing the tragic news, Shareena’s husband, working as a store manager in a hospital in Bengaluru, rushed to KR Hospital in Mysuru to take the body. Hunsur Town police are investigating the case.

Title: 2 drown in a pond in Mhasrool
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Nashik: Two people drowned in a pond in Mhasrool area of the city on Thursday night.

The deceased — Hemant Sridhar Gangurde (33), a resident of Raju Nagar and Harshal alias Vicky Rajendra Salunkhe (34) of Omkar Nagar — had gone to the pond with three of their friends at 11.30 pm.

Head constable Sudhir Pawar of Mhasrool police station said the five friends, after having dinner, decided to go to the temple of Lord Shiva for Mahashivaratri. However, before entering the temple three of them decided to wash themselves in the nearby pond.

The deceased failed to gauge the depth of the pond and started drowning . The friends managed to fish out Gangurde and took him to Nashik civil hospital where he was declared brought dead.

When police learned that one more person was inside the pond, fire brigade was called and after which Salunkhe’s body was fished out at 2.30 am.

Gangurde had a business of electrical appliances and is survived by his parents, brother, wife and two children. Salunkhe ran a restaurant along Dindori Road and is survived by his parents, wife and a daughter.

The pond known as Seeta Sarovar is on the Warvandi Road in Mhasrool. “It is an ancient pond and quite deep. There is also lot of silt at the bottom of the pond,” a police officer said.

Title: Woman loses gold chain to bike-borne duo
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Trichy: A 45-year-old woman was robbed of her seven sovereign gold chain valued at Rs 70,000 by two bike-borne snatchers near G corner here on Wednesday.

In her complaint, P Geetha of Ranjithapuram, said she was a guest lecturer in the government polytechnic college in Sethurapatti in Trichy. At around 6pm, she was returning home from Ranjithapuram when an unidentified person started following her from behind.

He got close to her and snatched her gold chain and escaped with another person who was waiting on a bike. The woman lodged a complaint with the KK Nagar police on Thursday. tnn

Title: Delhi tourist found dead in hotel room
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Representative image

MUSSORIE: A tourist was found dead in a hotel room in the hill town on Friday. Though police believes it to be a case of natural death, the post mortem is awaited to confirm the cause of death. The incident came to light after the tourist, who was residing in a hotel on Mall Road, did not open the door of his room till late morning. When hotel staff opened the door after breaking a grill, they found the body.

According to SHO Vidhya Bhushan Negi, the deceased has been identified as Jaswinder Jeet Singh Bhatti, 60, a resident of New Delhi.

He added that the family of the deceased have been informed.

Title: Pune man held for brutally assaulting student
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Picture used for representational purpose only

PUNE: The head of an Alandi-based spiritual eduction centre was taken into police custody on Friday on the charge of brutally assaulting an 11-year-old student with a stick because he was allegedly not learning his lessons and left work assigned to him incomplete.

“The boy, Om Raju Chaudhari, failed unconscious due to fluid build up in his chest after the suspect beat him on his chest and other pars of the body. We have shifted him to a private hospital in Pimpri,” senior inspector Ravindra Chaudhar of the Alandi police station said.

Om is currently undergoing treatment at the paediatric intensive care unit of the hospital. A doctor said, “The boy is on ventilator support. His condition is critical.”

The officer said, “We have arrested the suspect, Bhagwan Maharaj Povhane (30), of Alandi. He has been charged under section 307 (attempt to murder) of the Indian Penal Code.”

The boy’s mother, Kavita Chaudhari (28), a resident of Ambi in Vadgaon Maval, lodged an FIR with the police.

The suspect runs a spiritual training centre at Alandi where Om had been studying for a year. In early February, Kavita was informed that Om was not well and the caller told her to take her son home.

“Kavita rushed to the centre and found that Om was unconscious. He was admitted to a private hospital at Talegaon Dabhade,” Chaudhar said.

He said after gaining consciousness Om told her mother that Povhane had brutally beaten him with a stick.

A police team took Povhane into custody from Parbhani district.
