Title: Maharashtra to follow Delhi's education model: Arvind Kejriwal
Content:
Arvind Kejriwal

Delhi govt will provide all possible help to Maharashtra govt to implement edu reforms in their state. This is coop… https://t.co/5csMhkI3th — Arvind Kejriwal (@ArvindKejriwal) 1582298044000

NEW DELHI: Chief minister Arvind Kejriwal on Friday said his government will provide all possible help to Maharashtra in implementing education reforms. His statement came hours after Maharashtra higher education minister Uday Samant discussed various initiatives taken in the education sector under the AAP government with deputy CM Manish Sisodia.“Delhi govt will provide all possible help to Maharashtra govt to implement edu reforms in their state. This is cooperative federalism at its best. Both states can learn so much from each other,” Kejriwal tweeted.Earlier, Samant met Sisodia at Delhi Secretariat. “He said that he had much curiosity to learn about the innovative programmes adopted by the Delhi government to revolutionise its education system,” an official statement from the deputy CM’s office said.After the meeting, Sisodia said: “We want to take the journey of bringing about a revolution in education ahead by adopting and implementing best learning programmes/practices for our children. It’s important to collaborate with each other and learn from the individual experience of education departments of both the states — Delhi and Maharashtra.”

Title: National, state legal services to distribute artificial limbs
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Chief Justice of India Sharad Bobde will inaugurate the camp on March 1

Nagpur: The National Legal Services Authority (NALSA) would be organizing an artificial limb and fitness camp for specially abled persons from March 1 to 7 at MLA Hostel. Chief Justice of India (CJI) Sharad Bobde has taken interest in the project, and consented to inaugurate it.

“The guests would distribute pairs of artificial fitments, specially brought from Jaipur, which is famous for artificial limbs, to divyang persons. The fitments include callipers, wheelchairs, crutches and also artificial limb fitments. They would be distributed free of cost. Over 2,000 fitments would be distributed to needy persons. Disabled persons should register their names with legal services authorities in respective districts of the state,” said registrar (administration) Anju Shende.

Besides the CJI, the event would be graced by Supreme Court judges, including Bhushan Gavai, Surya Kant and Ravindra Bhat, along with senior administrative judge at Nagpur bench of Bombay high court Ravi Deshpande, and others.

“The camp has been organized by NALSA in coordination with Maharashtra State Legal Services Authority (MSLSA), Bhagwan Mahaveer Viklang Sahayata Samiti (BMVSS), and Mahaveer International. An artificial hand fitment is one of the special tools newly introduced by BMVSS. Though deadline for registration is February 25, those who approach after that would also be extended help. No one would be sent back without a fitment,” said Shende, who was accompanied by registrar (judicial) Amit Joshi and DLSA secretary Abhijeet Deshmukh.

Terming it the biggest ever such camp in India, Joshi said MSLSA and DLSA were also holding a massive awareness campaign across the state for identifying needy persons. “We’re not just looking at beneficiaries from Maharashtra, but also from neighbouring states. We’ve arranged for the stay of needy persons at MLA Hostel, where those coming from Jaipur would take measurements and prepare artificial limbs. There would be stalls providing information about various government schemes for the poor and divyangs,” he said.

Deshmukh added that the beneficiaries would be required to carry identity proof like Aadhaar or voting card during registration.

Registration Details

Beneficiaries should register names on mobile no — 7588513545

Documents to be carried — Aadhaar Card, Election Card

(With inputs from Shwetal Kothari)

Title: 2 corporators face music for playing sound beyond permissible limits
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Nashik: Two NMC corporators have been booked by the city police for allegedly violating the noise pollution norms in two separate incidents during the Shiv Jayanti celebrations in the city on Wednesday.

The concerned corporators were part of the Shiv Jayanti celebration committees in Nashik Road and the Ambad area ward. While one case was registered with the Nashik Road police station, the other three cases were registered with the Ambad police station.

In the first incident recorded with the Nashik Road police, a BJP corporator heading the celebrations was found guilty of playing sound beyond the permissible limits.

In the complaint registered with the Nashik Road police, the complainant API of the Nashik Road police said that the noise level on the stage was 127.09 decibels, which was more than the recommended sound level.

Corporator, who is also the president of the Shiv Jayanti celebration committee, in his ward said that he doesn’t want to say much on the issue. “I would not like to comment on the issue. The police found that the noise level of the speakers was more than the permissible levels following which they have registered an offence against me,” he said.

Meanwhile, in Cidco area a corporator along with two more individuals were booked by the Ambad police for the same offence.

According to police officials, the members of the concerned committee was informed about the increased sound level. However, the concerned member did not pay heed to the police instructions following which the office bearers of the concerned members, including a corporator were booked by the police.

Shiv Jayanti celebrations were done on a mass scale all over the city and the Nashik Road area. The police were on their toes all through the day to ensure that there was no untoward incident.

Title: Dravidar Kazhagam calls for state-wide protests on March 23
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Trichy: Dravidar Kazhagam (DK) president K Veeramani on Friday called for state-wide protests in front of central government offices on March 23 against NEET, the issue of ‘threat’ to the rights of state in education and other issues.

Speaking at the social justice conference of the party held at the Uzhavar Sandhai grounds here on Friday, Veeramani said, “DK is going to organise the protest. It is a token protest against the dangers of orders such as the Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA) implemented by the BJP.”

Criticising the BJP government of passing the Acts in the Parliament without allowing discussions, Veeramani said the custom of issuing the bills to the members was not followed now. “The guillotining is happening in the Parliament every day in passing the Acts and laws,” he said.

Veeramani also appealed to the people not to consider the protest as something organised by the DMK, VCK, and others against the BJP but a protest against two sides. “It is a protest against the fascist government under the guise of democracy that acts against social justice, secularism, rights of the states, right to education, sovereignty.”

VCK chief Thol Thirumavalavan who spoke on the occasion, termed the recent Supreme Court judgment on reservation in public services a detrimental to the SCs, STs and OBCs. He also recalled the ‘Rath Yatra’ of BJP against Mandal Commission recommendation for reservations for OBCs. Thirumavalavan said that all SC, ST, OBC people should have taken to the streets against the judgment.

Rajya Sabha DMK MP Tiruchi Siva said the anti-CAA protests would not have erupted if the BJP had included Muslims also among the six religions while passing CAA in the Parliament. “Federalism is crumbling, secularism is fading, socialism has become capitalism and democracy is under threat,” Siva said.

CPI state secretary R Mutharasan slammed Tamil Nadu chief minister Edappadi K Palanisami for his government’s pro-CAA stand and not passing a resolution against the CAA in the assembly. tnn

Title: Pune: Vehicle papers a must for minors to obtain licences
Content:
Representative image

PUNE: An affidavit from parents seeking licence for their wards and production of vehicle registration documents are now necessary to issue a licence for 16- and 17- year-old minors.The Regional Transport Officer (RTO) Vinod Sagare said vehicle registration documents were necessary to check the class and power of the vehicle before issuing a licence to minors.An RTO official said around four years ago, the Nagpur bench of the Bombay high court had barred 16-year-olds from getting a driving licence.“Granting a licence to a 16-year-old was permitted as per the Motor Vehicles Act, 1988 if they rode a motorcycle with the engine capacity not exceeding 50 cc. However, younger children were using 100 cc vehicles, which had greater power. So, granting of such licences was discontinued,” Sagare said.An RTO official said two-wheelers with 50 cc engine capacity were rarely available in India. But, some licences for the category had been issued for children from families who had retained older vehicles, the official said.Sagare said that earlier, parents had to only provide an affidavit granting consent for the issuance of licences to minors. But, now the requirements have changed. “Licences are granted to those over 16 years and below 18 years only after the registration papers are scrutinized as we have to be certain that the minor will use a vehicle below 50 cc engine capacity. However, the number of children and parents opting for such licences is negligible.” he said.Section 4 of the Motor Vehicles Act, 1988, stated, “No person under the age of 18 years shall drive a motor vehicle in any public place: Provided that a motorcycle with engine capacity not exceeding 50 cc may be driven in a public place by a person after attaining the age of 16 years.”Meanwhile, Section 7(2) of the Act stated, “No person under the age of 18 years shall be granted a learner’s licence to drive a motorcycle without gear except with the consent in writing of the person having the care of the person desiring the learner’s licence.”He also said the regional transport office had been taking action against minors found riding on the streets for offences such as driving without a licence or driving a vehicle of a different class that was mentioned on the licence. “It is generally the Pune traffic police that take action against violators. However, if our squad is on ground and comes across such a case, action is taken,” he said.

Title: CPI launches sign drive against Centre’s ‘failure to create jobs’
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Trichy: The state secretary of Communist Party of India (CPI), R Mutharasan, said here on Friday that BJP has come to power for the second term at the Centre. However, they are yet to deliver on their promise about employment that was made before coming to power.

He was speaking after inaugurating ‘Where is my job’ signature campaign organized by All India Youth Federation (AIYF) with the target of getting one crore signatures to remind BJP government of their promise of creating one crore jobs every year.

Addressing at E Pudur, he said unemployment is at its highest in the country. One crore graduates have been awaiting jobs after registering in the employment office in Tamil Nadu alone. “Ruling BJP came to power by promising to take steps to create two crore jobs per year. Five years have passed and they are back again but nothing has been done so far,” he said.

The government agencies conducting competitive examinations for various state government jobs have lost credibility after charges of irregularities.

Today’s youth is losing faith in the government as only those who have money have access to education and job.

Title: Chola era stone pillars with Tamil inscriptions found in Pudukottai district
Content:
The team suggested that the local people and authorities take proper safety measures to preserve the early str... Read More

A nine-line Tamil inscription was found on the northern face of the sluice pillar.

TRICHY: Two Chola era stone pillars with Tamil inscriptions dating back to 10th century CE have been found near Timmayampatti in Pudukottai district. The inscriptions on granite pillars erected on either side of a sluice of a water tank in the village have mention of people assigned the first right on the water in the pond.A nine-line Tamil inscription was found on the northern face of the sluice pillar. The record identifies the pillar as Neerazhikkal (stone that lets out water). The inscription records that the first water right of the pond had been assigned to a certain Kilavan Pavalakkunru alias Kandankusa Velan. Another inscription, running into seven lines on the southern face of the base, records Vaikai Churri alias Uttamacholan, the headman of Uratturnadu who was given the first right to the water in the pond.“Pillars with Chola records are a rarity even though sluice pillars with inscriptions are found in most districts of Tamil Nadu,” said M Nalini, History faculty member, Seethalakshmi Ramasami College, Trichy who was part of the team that carried out the explorative study. Here, two inscriptions of the same period have been found in a single sluice unit which is rare, she said. R Kalaikkovan, director of Dr M Rajamanikkanar Centre for Historical Research , after examining the two granite pillars, said they have been installed on the inner side of the village tank locally known as Kurunkulam (small pond), near its eastern bund.“They are erected on either side of a sluice locally called as madai. This helps to regulate or divert water collected in the pond for agricultural needs. It is a box-like structure supported on the sides by a pair of such pillars,” he said. Repair work undertaken by bringing larger pipes at the outlet of the pond very close to this Chola structure may cause damage to the existing old sluice. The team suggested that the local people and authorities take proper safety measures to preserve the early structure for posterity.

Title: Centre of Excellence for IoT at AU to be startup incubator
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Visakhapatnam: The Union ministry of electronics and information technology, in association with the National Association of Software and Services Companies (Nasscom), has sanctioned a Centre of Excellence for IoT ( Internet of Things ) to Visakhapatnam. A delegation of officials from Nasscom and Andhra government recently visited Andhra University to scout for a suitable location for the Centre.

While Nasscom would contribute about Rs 22.5 crore for the Centre, MeitY will provide nearly Rs 9.5 crore for it. The main objective of the Centre would be to develop innovative applications and build domain capability by supporting the startup community. Corporate players will also join hands with the Centre to support young entrepreneurs in healthcare technology, agritech, robotics, automobile, telecom and others.

The Centre would also provide initial business opportunities and market links through their strategic partners, apart from attracting angel investors for the start-ups. The start-ups would get support on various fronts from the team at the CoE IoT such as market research and business model refinement, among others. The CoE will conduct training sessions, lectures and workshops for the enthusiasts.

According to AU sources, AU officials preliminarily identified three buildings for the Centre. “The setup of the CoE has also been discussed with state minister of industries, commerce, information technology M Goutham Reddy during the latter’s recent visit to the varsity on February 19. Once a building is identified and it gets the required infrastructure for the CoE, funds will be released for it,” said the source.

Even though the CoE was sanctioned several months ago, the Centre has not become operational due to various reasons. In fact, there has been no official announcement on the same. It was learnt that the officials from the Software Technology Parks of India recently deliberated on the CoE with AU officials. Now, AU officials want to expedite its setup and make it operational soon.

Title: Boy feared drowned in Mutha right bank canal
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Pune: A 13-year-old boy was feared drowned after he was swept away by the waters of Mutha right bank canal at Janata Vasahat on Friday afternoon.

A team of Pune fire brigade launched search operation to trace the boy, Suresh Bagal. The fire brigade, however, abandoned the operation in the night due to the darkness.

An officer from the fire brigade said Suresh and his friends had gone for swimming at the canal. “The water was flowing with a speed due to the discharge from the Khadakwasla dam, due to which Bagal was swept away. We looked for him between Janata Vasahat and Mitra Mandal Chowk, but failed to find him,” he said, adding the search operation wil continue on Saturday.

On February 12, two-year-old Sanskar Sable had fallen into a nullah at Dattawadi while he was playing near his house. Sable’s body was recovered by the firemen on the next day from the Mutha river near the Mhatre bridge.

Title: Coronavirus fears: Delhi govt wants passenger vehicles sanitised
Content:
Representative image

NEW DELHI: With coronavirus spreading its wings as a global epidemic, Delhi government’s transport department has asked owners of all the passenger vehicles to keep buses, autorickshaws and taxis “disinfected” all the time.The department has also asked the drivers to carry a self-certification stating that the vehicles they are driving are sanitised. The self-certification has also been made mandatory when these vehicles are brought for regular fitness tests at the transport department’s vehicle inspection unit.While asking the drivers to spray “disinfectant” in their vehicles every day, the transport department has urged vehicle owners to ensure that seat upholstery, headrests, handrails, window locks, handles and other parts of passenger transport that are frequently touched by people, are properly cleaned.Hand sanitiser must be available in theses vehicles, the order further stated.The order has been issued by Anil Chikara, the motor licencing officer of Jhuljhuli’s vehicle inspection unit where school and contract carriage buses come for fitness certification once in two years.Chikara said that all public transport vehicles must ensure that they are clean and sanitised. “Even clause 73 of the Delhi Motor Vehicle Rules – 1993 says that all passenger buses shall be disinfected once in two months and the owner shall furnish a certificate to this effect to the state transport authority. Since coronavirus is now spreading as a global epidemic, it should be our duty to ensure that these vehicles do not become the carrier of such infections and diseases,” he added.Chikara further said that nobody is bothered about dirty seat upholstery, stains of hair oil on head rests, stained grabrail along the stairs of the buses and unclean floor of the vehicles. “All of us who travel in public transport and children who board school buses daily come in contact of these parts. The vehicle owners must clean them regularly as first step towards providing hygienic mobility,” added the expert on public transport.According to an estimate, there are about 18,000 buses, over 90,000 autorickshaws and close to 55,000 taxis apart from a large number of e-rickshaws that ply in the national capital.Chikara said he will soon talk to the officials of DTC and DIMTs, which run cluster buses, to ensure that those vehicles are also “disinfected” on a regular basis. More than 40 lakh people travel on these public buses every day. The enforcement team of the transport department will be asked to check if contract carriage and school buses are clean.

Title: Tamil Nadu student making Tik-Tok videos booked for creating nuisance
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

TRICHY: A 20-year-old college student was booked by Pudukottai police for creating public nuisance on Friday by making videos using Tik-Tok, a mobile application used to post 15-second short videos.

The student was identified as T Kannan, a catering college student from Vadakadu. Some of his videos that are in circulation in the social media show him intercept people on road and other public places. He was also seen dancing for songs by obstructing onlookers.

He travelled to Trichy railway station and bus stand apart from Pudukottai to make videos. Pudukottai district superintendent of police Arun Sakthi Kumar directed Vadakadu police to act against the student following complaints through social media.

Vadakadu police detained him on Thursday and carried out an inquiry. Inspector Barath Srinivasan said that preliminary inquiries revealed that Kannan had interest in dance and mimicry and his college friends encouraged him to make Tik-Tok videos to showcase his skills. We released him after inquiry and warned him against creating trouble to people in public places, said the inspector.

A case has been booked on Kannan under Indian Penal Code (IPC) sections 291 for public nuisance and 341 for wrongful restraint in Vadakadu police station.

Title: Maharashtra: 21-year-old dies after bike crashes into container
Content:
Representative image

PUNE: A 21-year-old engineering student was killed after his motorcycle crashed into a stationary container along the Katraj-Dehu Road bypass in Ambegaon on February 16.Currently residing in a rented accommodation at Maan in Mulshi taluka, the victim — Pranav Atul Galgale — was not permitted to ride two-wheelers after he donated a kidney to his mother. The accident occurred when he was returning to his rented accommodation at Maan in Mulshi taluka after attending a programme at an engineering college in Katraj.“Galgale’s friend told us that he had been commuting in a car off late. But he did not know why Galgale took the motorcycle instead of the car on the day of the accident,” said assistant sub-inspector Mohan Deshmukh of the Bharati Vidyapeeth police.Galgale, whose parents stay in Vile-Parle, was wearing a helmet when the accident occurred. “He suffered injuries on his face and died while being shifted from one hospital to another,” Deshmukh said.He said the police had registered an offence against the container driver on Thursday. “We have obtained the vehicle’s registration number and soon arrest the driver,” he said.Galgale was pursuing engineering at a private college in Lavale. On February 16, he had gone to attend some programme at the college in Katraj.“Around 3.45pm, Galgale had left the college. When he reached near a departmental store along the bypass, his motorcycle crashed into the stationary container,” assistant sub-inspectorDeshmukh said.He said some of the people who saw the accident took Galgale to a private hospital at Katraj.“He had suffered severe injuries on his face. The doctors also found marks of stitches on his stomach. As his condition was critical, Galgale was immediately shifted to another private hospital. But he was pronounced dead by the doctors before admission,” Deshmukh said.The assistant sub-inspector, Deshmukh, said Galgale’s friend was unaware of the reason why the latter rode a two-wheeler on the day of the accident instead of commuting in the car.

Title: Suspects wanted in attempt to murder case held in Nagpur
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Nashik: Two suspects who were wanted in an attempt to murder case were arrested by the crime branch from Nagpur on Thursday.

Inspector at Ambad police station Kamlakar Jadhav said that the suspects—Karan Anna Kaduskar (19) and Manoj alias Sachin Dattu Bhojane (30), both residents of Ambad area, Nashik—were produced before a city court on Friday which remanded them in police custody for three days.

The suspects have been slapped with sections 307 (attempt to murder), 332 (voluntary causing hurt), 427 (mischief to cause damage to the amount of Rs 50 or more), 504 (intentional insult with intent to provoke breach of peace), 506 (criminal intimidation) and 34 (common intention) of the IPC.

Police said that on January 26, both Kaduskar and Bhojane were beating up a person who ran a panipuri stall near Krushna Nagar bus stop and damaging his kiosk. While both the suspect were on a rampage spree, Bajirao Datir (46), a resident of Datir Mala, Ambad, was watching them.

Irritated with the fact that someone was watching them, one of the suspects attacked Bajirao with a chopper. Soon after the attack, the duo fled the scene. Meanwhile, Bajirao lodged a complaint at Ambad police station stating that the two suspects attempted to murder him.

Police said that the suspects were on the run ever since they committed the crime. Police have been looking for the suspects for over three weeks.

A few days ago, a personnel of the crime branch unit II received a tip-off that the suspects were hiding in Nagpur city. Based on the instructions issued by commissioner of police Vishwas Nangare Patil, DCP Laxmikant Patil, ACP Sameer Shaikh and inspector of crime branch unit II Nilesh Bardekar, a team was sent to Nagpur and Kaduskar and Bhojane were arrested.

Officers from the crime branch said that the suspects have been handed over to Ambad police for further investigation.

Title: Surge in summer schedule slot requests hints at extra flights from Pune airport
Content:
File photo of Pune airport

PUNE: The upcoming summer schedule is expected to bring some cheers to the city flyers with the introduction of a few late night or red-eye flights.Pune airport director Kuldeep Singh said all the airlines together requested for 1,343 weekly slots from the city. “I am unable to say anything about the new flights until the slots requested by the airlines are approved by Indian Air Force (IAF) and the Directorate General of Civil Aviation (DGCA),” he said.Confirming about some new flights, a source at the airport said IndiGo would start a direct daily flight to Chandigarh from mid-March. “It will be a red-eye flight and the timings will be announced soon,” the source said.Air Asia, which had suspended its Pune-Kolkata flight during the winter schedule, would resume its services from March 16. “The flight will take off from Kolkata at 7.35pm and land in Pune at 10.35pm. On its return journey, the flight will take off from the city at 11.05pm and land in Kolkata at 1.35am,” an Air Asia spokesperson, told TOI.Another source at the airport said, “The daytime slot issue at the airport still persists. There are some vacant daytime slots and they can be taken up by the airlines. Things will become clear by the next month.”Frequent flyer V V Ravi Kumar said, “It would be great if slots vacated by Jet Airways are restored.”Aviation analyst Dhairyashil Vandekar said, “If an airline is not using its allotted slot, it can surrender it. The Airports Authority of India (AAI) as the slot co-coordinator is expected to monitor the slot usage.”The Jet Airways’ slots to Indore, Singapore, Abu Dhabi and Coimbatore, however, would remain vacant, sources stressed.

Title: Pregnant woman thrashed, forced to do sit-ups on wood theft charge
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Representative image

BALASORE: A 19-year-old woman, who is three-months pregnant , was allegedly thrashed and forced to do sit-ups 20 times by a forest guard on suspicion of stealing wood from the forest.

The incident was reported from Barhapanapashi village under Karanjia forest division of Mayurbhanj district. As news of her harassment spread, Barhapanapashi villagers staged protest and blocked the Karanjia-Baripada road and demanded the arrest of the accused. They also locked the Dudhiani Forest Range office demanding compensation for the victim.

Sarojini Singh, inspector in-charge of Karanjia police station, said a case has been registered on the basis of the complaint filed by the victim. “The forest guard has been detained for questioning and investigation is underway,” she added.

According to the complaint lodged by Sukumati Guria, a team of forest officials led by Kabita Behera, a woman forest guard of Dudhiani Forest Range, raided her house at Barhapanapashi village on Thursday evening, loking for stolen timber.

The woman said the team couldn’t find any stolen item at the house. “Following this, Kabita assaulted me and my 65-year-old mother. Later, she brought me and my brother to the forest range office, where she thrashed both of us and forced me to do 20 sit-ups,” Sukumati said.

She reportedly sustained fracture on her right hand and complained of stomach pain following the assault. She and her mother were first admitted to a local hospital and then shifted to the Karanjia sub-divisional hospital for treatment. Dr Akshay Rath, sub-divisional medical officer of Karanjia hospital, said, “Three months is a critical period of pregnancy. But the woman is doing fine. We have provided her with required treatment and she has been sent back home.”

The incident led her family members to lodge a complaint with Karanjia police. Dudhiani ranger Saroj Kumar Panda said the forest guard has been placed under suspension. “The forest department has also provided an assistance of Rs 10,000 to the victim,” the ranger said.

Title: PMRDA moots Rs 20,000 cess for each flat in new projects to meet water crisis
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

PUNE: The Pune Metropolitan Region Development Authority ( PMRDA ) has placed a proposal before the state irrigation department for charging a one-time water cess of Rs 20,000 from each upcoming flat in the region to build a fund for setting up a water infrastructure system.

While the proposal was earlier cleared for Wagholi in 2018, there is a plan for implementing the same across the 7,000sqkm area in PMRDA.

According to the proposal, the water would be made available from 15 dams of the Maharashtra Krishna Valley Development Corporation. The cost of drawing water from the dams through pipes or canals would be huge and the water cess needs to be collected for this, officials said. However, the same needs to be approved. Already, the PMRDA has placed a demand before the irrigation department for 4TMC water allocation in the area in the next ten years.

The area, which covers 816 villages comprising Maval, Mulshi, Haveli, parts of Bhor, Daund, Shirur, Khed, Purandar and Velhe talukas, has requirement for 12-15 TMC water in the next 30 years.

At present, people in the area rely on groundwater. The estimated current population of nearly 29lakh in the PMRDA limits is also likely to double in the next two decades, which would also push up the demand for water, officials said. A developer said that if the cess has to be paid upfront, then the water should be available when the project is completed as the amount would, in effect, be collected from citizens at the time of booking.

“However, if the housing project is a long-drawn one, then the amount should be collected in phases,’’ said a developer who plans to come up with a project in the area.

Title: Why acne refuses to go away in women above 25
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

NEW DELHI: Acne in young girls isn’t considered a serious problem. But there are instances when the acne refuses to go or reappears among women who are 25 years of age or older.Use of cosmetics or consumption of diet with high glycaemic index such as pastries, chocolates and ice creams is usually blamed for it.

However, according to a new study by the doctors from Ram Manohar Lohia (RML) hospital, the presence of male hormones may have a significant role to play in such cases. Between November 2017 and March 2019, the dermatology department of RML saw 135 women with adult acne as it is called. These women underwent tests to evaluate their complete hormonal profile. Signs of clinical hyperandrogenism or excessive circulating male hormone were present in 72% of such patients.

More than half of the women (57%), who were tested for hormonal imbalance, suffered from androgenic alopecia (hair loss), 50% had scalp problem, 40% had excessive hair on face and 26% of the women reported history of irregular menstruation, according to findings of the research published in International Journal of Dermatology.

Adult acne has been classified into two major subtypes: persistent acne and late onset acne. The research shows persistent acne patients had a higher incidence of Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS) and hormonal abnormalities.

Dr Kabir Sardana, the lead author of the study, advised the patients for endocrinological evaluation. “Women above 25 years of age who suffer from persistent acne may benefit from therapy with anti-androgens,” he said. Many women with adult acne may test negative for circulation of increased male hormones, but they have clear clinical symptoms of the same, added Dr Sardana, professor of dermatology at RML. “In our study, clinical hyperandrogenism was seen in 72% cases, while biochemical hyperandrogenemia was detected in only 18% of patients,” he said.

However, doctors advise that one should not start hormonal therapy on their own as it may cause side-effects.

“While young girls have acne mostly on the cheeks and forehead region, those above 25 to 30 years of age have acne in the jawline or chin area. It does not respond to conventional medicines such as antibiotics and anti-inflammatory drugs. We have to use medicines to reduce oil gland secretion such as isotretinoine and hormonal treatment in the form of oral contraceptive pills,” Dr S C Bharija, who heads the department of dermatology at Sir Ganga Ram hospital, said. He added that the medications continue for up to six months.

He warned against self-medication or use of home remedies with unproven results.

Title: 8 rural cops injured in accident in Nandurbar
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Nashik: As many as eight policemen got injured in Nandurbar , around 190-km from here, when the vehicle they were travelling in rammed against a road side tree on the intervening night of Friday and Saturday.

The team had gone to Nandurbar to be part of the bandobast for the visit of state governor Bhagat Singh Koshyari. A senior police officer said the policemen escaped with minor injuries and were admitted to a government hospital after the accident .

The accident took place around 12.30 am on Nizar Road, around 8-km from the Upnagar police station in Nandurbar. The local residents and police immediately rushed the injured to civil hospital in Nandurbar.

A total of 19 police personnel were travelling in the bus. Superintendent of police Arti Singh said, “The driver apparently had to maneuver the vehicle in haste to avoid collision with vehicle coming from the opposite direction. This led to the accident. The policemen have been discharged.”

Title: Plays depict thoughts of Savarkar, ills of society
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Artistes perform in ‘Kaumarya’ play held at Scientific Society Hall, Laxmi Nagar, on Thursday

Nagpur: Two plays were staged on the opening day of the 59th Maharashtra Hindi Natya Competition, organized by Sanskrutik Karya Shanchalalay, at Scientific Society Hall, Laxmi Nagar, on Thursday.

‘What about Savarkar’, a play written and directed by Pravin Khapre, highlighted the efforts made by the great freedom fighter to bring about a change in the society. Savarkar was a visionary and staunch believer in scientific approach. The drama says his positive approach towards solving the ills afflicting the society will go a long way even in today’s context. The play was staged by Udaan Ek Zep.

It depicted how various ideologies originated in the country and Savarkar’s contribution to the country. The drama depicted how his thoughts were distorted by certain elements. Scenes from the life of Mahatma Gandhi, Dr Babasaheb Ambedkar, Gautam Buddha, and others were also effectively showcased.

Shri Natraj Shaikshanik, Sanskrutik, Krida Sanstha staged ‘Kaumarya’, a play written by Salim Sheikh and directed by Harshad Sasane. It highlighted the life of the people of Kanjarbhat community. It showed that side of the society which is conservative.

The story revolved around a young girl, Surmi, who is forced to marry Suraj due to a promise given by her father. His father was drunk when he promised to his friend that they would get their kids married.

People of this community follow a tradition to check blood as a sign of originality after the marriage. Surmi fails the test and is abandoned by the society. Her husband divorces her and even her parents refuse to accept her.

Surmi refuses to live with the feeling of betrayal by her family. She raises her voice against injustice meted out to her, but the society does not accept her.

The play delivered a message that people should not blindly follow the traditions as there could be some black spots. It forces the society to question the practices harmful to the society.

Various plays will be staged at Scientific Society Hall till March 3.

(Reporting by Janhavi Dave)

Title: Plans afloat to add 200 beds to civil hosp
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

CLEARED SKHER

Nashik: The Nashik civil hospital could soon have more beds to admit patients.

Public health and family welfare minister Rajesh Tope on Thursday visited the civil hospital and found that all the 540 beds were occupied. He was informed that more beds need to be added to the hospital so that it can better cater to the patients coming from all over North Maharashtra.

District civil surgeon Suresh Jagdale confirmed that that they would soon be sending a proposal of adding 200 more beds to the hospital. The new facilities would be built within the same premises.

“Space is not a problem for constructing the 200 additional beds. The number of floors in each hospital wing can be can be increased. With the addition of beds, more doctors will also be appointed to the hospital,” said Jagdale.

Apart from the 540 beds in the hospital, the out patient department attends to close to 800 patients daily. The hospital is also expected to get good quality equipment for diagnosis and treatment. The hospital has won the first prize in the state government’s Kayakalp award twice in four years.

Steps are also being taken to start a medical college in Nashik. Initially, the medical college is expected to function out of the civil hospital. At present, Nashik does not have a government medical college and there is a proposal to set up 120 seats for postgraduate courses and 100 for under graduate courses here.

The Nashik-based Maharashtra University of Health Sciences would be entrusted with the responsibility of running the college. The college would offer postgraduate courses in 11 subjects.

Recently, Tope and Nashik district guardian minister Chhagan Bhujbal chaired a meeting about the project in Mumbai. Bhujbal directed the officials to put the project on a fast-track so that at least PG courses can kick off from the upcoming academic year. Both Deshmukh and Tope had assured that their departments would help in starting the PG classes as soon as possible.

The state government and MUHS will soon sign an MoU outlining the details of the project. The university would be responsible for providing the facility for the college and oversee its functioning. “For the first three years, the college would function at the Nashik civil hospital. Till then, a new medical college and hospital would be constructed within the premises of MUHS. There is ample land available within university,” officials added.

Title: Ravi Varma’s dilapidated studio to regain past glory
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

The studio of ace painter in ruins inside the Palace campus

Vadodara: Art-lovers in Sanskarinagari will get to walk on the art lanes of yore, a time when Raja Ravi Varma created some of his epochal paintings in his 19th century studio in the Laxmi Vilas Palace compound. The famed studio, now a pale reminder of its vibrant days, will get restored to its original glory in around six months’ time.

The royal Gaekwad family has already started reconstruction of the 1880s’ studio in a renovation project that is being co-funded by Indira Gandhi National Centre of Art (IGNCA) and will cost about Rs 40 lakh in the initial stages.

“It is one of the oldest and important heritage structures in the city. But the studio was in dilapidated condition for many years now. We had been thinking of refurbishing it for quiet some time but the structure was in shambles. There was no possibility of revamping it and so decided to rebuild it,” said Samarjitsinh Gaekwad, scion of royal Gaekwad family.

“Heritage experts and architects were consulted before we took up the project as we want to make the studio as original as the old one. Varma’s studio was a simple structure with a gallery and a room. So the original design will be retained. The building will have the original exposed bricks design and will also use limestone and not cement,” Gaekwad told TOI.

The erstwhile Baroda dewan, T Madhavrao had invited Varma to the state in 1881 and soon his works caught the attention of Maharaja Sayajirao Gaekwad III. Gaekwad got a studio built for Varma near the Motibaug Palace where the artist spent a considerable time creating some beautiful paintings.

A young Sayajirao was so impressed by Varma’s works that in 1888, he invited Varma to Ooty where he commissioned 14 mythological paintings illustrating the national epics – Ramayana and Mahabharata – for the decoration of the new Durbar Hall in the new Laxmi Vilas Palace. Later, Sayajirao even gave Rs 50,000 to Varma for starting his printing press.

Though the old structure has been demolished, the Gaekwad family will use the original bricks as much as possible to retain the studio’s earlier avatar.

When asked about the plans for the studio, Gaekwad said that for a few years, IGNCA will have an office there and then the royal family will take over the premises. “We will then decide how we can use the studio,” he added.

Title: Top energy official in Prez team as US, India eye N-deal
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

NEW DELHI: The Trump visit could mark the return after a long time of civil nuclear cooperation to the centre stage of Indo-US bilateral ties with the US looking to circumvent India's liability law to sign a fresh agreement for supplying 6 reactors to India. In the absence of a trade deal, the proposed agreement for nuclear reactors between US energy major Westinghouse and India’s NPCIL could turn out to be the biggest takeaway from Trump’s first visit to India as president.

While there was no official announcement, official sources said that the US Friday included energy secretary Dan Brouillette in the delegation of the higher-ups who will accompany Trump to India. This is being seen as another sign that the 2 countries are close to finalising the agreement for 6 reactors in Andhra Pradesh .

US reservations over India’s Civil Liability for Nuclear Damage (CLND) Act 2010 and the fact that Westinghouse went bankrupt before being acquired by a Japanese company in 2018 only delayed civil nuclear cooperation with India. The government sees nuclear partnership with the US as important for India’s energy security and one which adds significantly to its clean energy options. Officials said though that any commercial agreement had to be consistent with India’s law and practice.

Official sources here said India has already done enough to address concerns in the US that CLND may make suppliers liable for any nuclear mishap. Indian officials have maintained that India’s liability law, while ensuring strict liability, is channelled to the operator. They have also repeatedly told their US counterparts that India’s decision to create a nuclear insurance pool will help considerably in overall risk-management.

Without giving anything away on whether or not the MoU would be signed, MEA spokesperson Raveesh Kumar had Thursday said Westinghouse and NPCIL were involved in a discussion to build 6 1100 MW reactors at Kovvada, Andhra Pradesh. ``Following resolution of Westinghouse’s bankruptcy issues, the two sides are in discussion regarding the division of responsibility of the work. NPCIL has visited the U.S. reference plant to understand Westinghouse’s modular construction methodology,’’ he had said.

The 2 countries are currently also having regular discussions on space cooperation, given their long history of cooperation in, as the official said, civil space arena including earth observation, satellite navigation, and space exploration.

``There is a Joint Working Group to regularly review cooperation and identify new areas. Currently, our sides are cooperating in Mars exploration, heliophysics, and human spaceflight. On commercial front, ISRO has launched 209 satellites from US, on-board PSLV, as co passengers,’’ he said, adding that ISRO is also working with the US government agencies for cooperation in safety of spaceflight through exchange of situational awareness information.

Title: PMC accident insurance cover finds just 27 takers
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Pune Municipal Corporation

PUNE: Only 27 residents availed the corporation’s accident insurance cover in the past one year, triggering posers on the popularity of the scheme.

The data presented before the general body of the Pune Municipal Corporation (PMC) stated that families of 21 citizens who lost their lives in accidents got the benefit of this scheme. Six citizens got financial help for medical treatment after meeting with accidents, the data stated.

“We are trying to reach out to more and more people and inform them about this scheme. More efforts will be made to create awareness about this initiative,” said mayor Murulidhar Mohol.

The PMC had started this initiative for the citizens paying their property tax regularly.

The civic body pays the policy premium for these citizens. The free road accident insurance scheme was a part of the municipal budget and named after Pandit Deendayal Upadhyay.

Owners of around 4.5 lakh properties pay the property tax before the deadline of May 31.

They are all entitled to the special road accident insurance cover of Rs5 lakh for free. The civic administration made a provision of Rs7 crore in the municipal budget for paying the insurance premium.

As per the scheme details, the insured amount is paid to the beneficiaries in case of death or permanent disability. The expenses of hospitalisation are covered in case of serious injuries to the citizen.

The city traffic police data showed that road accident fatalities in 2019 had gone down by 19%. The city recorded 199 fatal accidents and 206 fatalities in 2019.

The year before, the numbers were 240 and 253, respectively.

Title: Only 60 criminal cases against illegal buildings in Pune
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Representative image

PUNE: The civic body has filed only 60 criminal cases against illegal constructions in a year.

Though the Pune Municipal Corporation (PMC) had served notices to over 7,500 constructions, action was taken only against 3,500.

Officials cited staff shortage and court cases as the main reasons for taking fewer action against illegal constructions in the city.

A civic official said criminal cases were only filed against property owners repeatedly found guilty of illegal constructions.

Generally, the PMC’s action involves sending notices to owners of illegal constructions, directing them to show cause for not taking proper permission before construction. The notices offer owners the option of demolishing the illegal constructions themselves. If the property owners do not demolish them, the civic administration razes them.

“In some cases, properties can be partly or fully regularised by paying fines or by using additional transfer of development rights or the floor space index . These compounding cases are dealt with in accordance with the provisions of the development control rule,” said an official.

Details of the action taken so far against illegal constructions were revealed in a reply to a written question in the general body meeting of the PMC. The PMC data showed that the city has been divided into seven zones. On an average, 1,000 notices have been issued pertaining to illegal constructions in each zone. “Many issues have cropped up with regards to illegal construction. Property owners have gone to court in some cases. Some illegal properties are occupied by people which limits the action that can be taken against them,” said a senior civic official.

City engineer Prashant Waghmare stated that the illegal constructions mean those which have been built without the permission of the PMC. Any additional construction carried out other than the sanctioned plan is termed illegal.

Civic activists blamed the nexus among the civic staff, politicians and builders for fewer action against illegal constructions in the city.

“Action is not taken against illegal constructions as politicians are hand-in-glove with the developers,” said Vijay Kumbhar of Surajya Sangharsha Samittee, a citizens’ group.

Title: Delhi: Strings attached can’t help bring down tilting Munirka building
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

The tilted six-storey building in Munirka

NEW DELHI: Under curious glances of bystanders through out the day, the engineering teams of South Delhi Municipal Corporation (SDMC) tried to pull down a six-storey building in Munirka, which tilted on Thursday, with the help of two JCB earthmovers and attached metal wires, but without much “real” output.

The efforts affected the traffic movement across Baba Gang Nath Marg near JNU’s North Gate, but till late Friday evening, the structure just moved slightly towards the road, creating a gap of around 10 inches with adjacent structures, an official said.

A senior official supervising the demolition efforts said the structure had tilted in a way that demolishing it manually would put the lives of labourers in danger while close proximity of other buildings in this densely developed urban village made use of any explosive impossible. “We are trying to pull down the structure. Sending people up means risking their lives while no support can be provided to the structure as it may fall any time,” he said.

Since the building is located on ridge rocks, no machinery can be sent inside to break the beams and the machines can access the structure only from the road, said an engineer. SDMC may now use heavier machineries, but “such machines can only be brought at night”, he said. These machines can be brought only on trawlers, which can enter Delhi only after 11pm.

Besides the JCB machines, a smaller Poclain machine and 15 engineers have been deployed at the site and the corporation has assured that the building will be brought down by Saturday afternoon.

However, the building is not the only dangerously built structure in the Munirka urban village. It is full of six-seven-storey buildings constructed without following any structural safety norms. Renting out these houses is the main source of income here.

Munirka again is not alone; all 135 urban villages in Delhi are now an unplanned mess. SDMC’s engineers get beaten up every time they try to enter these villages to take action, an official of the building department said. “Before the Government of India notification in 2011, people in these villages were not even required to get their building plans passed by the corporation. The situation hasn’t improved much,” he said.

When Delhi was growing, its villages fell under ‘Lal Dora’ boundaries and were exempted from the building bylaws and other regulations of Delhi Municipal Corporation Act. As per the 2006 Tejinder Khanna Committee report, special building bylaws were to be framed for these villages. But nothing happened.

Title: Pune: Peddler in net with opium worth Rs 15 lakh
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Representative image

PUNE: The Pimpri Chinchwad police crime branch on Thursday arrested a drug peddler with 3kg opium, valued at Rs15 lakh, from a market near the Talegaon Dabhade railway station.

Police said Rajendra Suvarna Shekhar Saliyana (28) was from Karnataka and currently residing at Andheri (East) in Mumbai. A police team, led by sub-inspector Sharad Aher, was conducting patrolling when he received information that Saliyana was looking for prospective customers near the compound wall of the railway station.

When Saliyana was frisked, the opium was found on him. He was taken into custody after he failed to offer an explanation as how got the narcotics.

Assistant inspector Prashant Mahale from the anti-narcotics cell, crime branch, said, “The man said he had come to meet his friend in Mumbai and was residing with him at Andheri since the past few days.” An FIR has been registered with the Talegaon Dabhade police.

Title: BIE removes webpage after security concerns
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Vijayawada: The Andhra Pradesh Board of Intermediate Education (APBIE) has taken down one of its web page after a cybersecurity expert from France raised concerns over leakage of personal data of students on Thursday.

The web page was to verify nominal roles of the students by giving hall ticket number as input.

The French cybersecurity expert and hacker identified with his twitter handle as Elliot Alderson tagged official twitter handle of Andhra Pradesh chief minister saying that “one of your website leaks personal data of students including Aadhaar numbers, photos, father and mother names”. He asked to contact him immediately to fix the issue.

The additional chief secretary to the chief minister P V Ramesh responded to his tweet saying that the issue was noted and action will be taken following which the web page was taken down.

Interacting with TOI, Alderson said that the hall ticket numbers are very easy to guess and those with some coding skill can gain access to BIE website and download entire data. There should have been additional security layers while designing the web page keeping in view of privacy of the students he said.

When asked about any additional security measures were taken after his red flag, Alderson said “they simply taken down the page that’s all. They did not really add any additional security features,” he said.

Title: 2.5 lakh properties in PCMC limits stare at huge tax hike from April 1
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

The PCMC failed to decide on a ‘rational’ tax system by Thursday

PIMPRI CHINCHWAD: Owners of nearly half of the properties in Pimpri Chinchwad will have to shell out two-and-a-half times more in their property tax from April 1 as the general body (GB) of the PCMC failed to decide on ‘rational’ tax system on Thursday.

Under the provisions of Maharashtra Municipal Corporation (MMC) Act, civic bodies have to decide in their general body meetings about any changes in property tax by February 20 every year. If this doesn’t happen, municipal commissioners have the power to take such a decision for the new fiscal.

The civic administration had tabled proposals about rationalisation of rateable value for property tax of units assessed before 2007 and increasing water charges for 2020-21 during the general body meeting.

The general body, however, failed to decide on the issues on Thursday (February 20) as three hours were wasted in exchange of words between the BJP and opposition corporators over crimes against women. When a bitter war of words broke out between the corporators, the meeting was adjourned till February 26.

Municipal commissioner Shravan Hardikar had proposed the rationalisation of rateable value in case of old properties, which had to pay less tax than new properties in the same area. As per the proposal, the owners of 2.5 lakh properties assessed before 2007 will have to pay 2.5 times the existing property tax. This will fetch Rs 100 to Rs 150 crore additional revenue to the PCMC.

“The general body has powers to make changes in tax rates till February 20 but no changes were made,” Hardikar said on Friday.

However, not all is lost as decision on increasing water tax can be taken by the general body any time during the fiscal year.

Title: Delhi: Decade-long struggle for Chor Bazaar vendors may end with new address
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

The bazaar began at Ajmeri Gate with a few shopkeepers selling discarded and worn-out clothes.

NEW DELHI: After a decade of struggle, the squatters at the Sunday flea market (also referred to as Kabaadi or Chor Bazaar ) are likely to get a permanent address with the authorities allocating them space behind Salimgarh Fort on Yamuna Pushta.

A total of 1,167 tehbazari vendors were provided space to operate on a trial basis for 12 Sundays starting December 12. After getting a feedback, a decision will be taken for giving them permanent spots.

Ashwani Sharma, general secretary of Old Edward Park Bazaar Association, said, “In December, the Union urban development minister directed the authorities to give us permission to display our wares on the service road opposite Salimgarh Bypass near Yamuna Bazaar. NGO Sewa Bharat had met the minister to grant us relief.”

On December 4, 2019, a joint meeting between officials of PWD, traffic police, Delhi Police and the NGO was called to discuss the matter. It was decided that all agencies, including the municipal corporation, would highlight problems, such as traffic jams or chaos, if they noticed them during the weekly bazaar.

“If the bazaar operates without any hitch till March 8, then the vendors will be allotted permanent spots there. Otherwise, the market will be discontinued,” said the order issued on December 13, 2019.

Mobile toilets have been provided at the market and no parking or vehicular spillover that can hamper the movement of traffic is allowed on the main carriageway.

While the site belongs to PWD, it was decided in the meeting that South Delhi Municipal Corporation would prepare the plan defining the space for each vendor once the decision for their permanency is taken.

“South corporation will demarcate the space for 1,167 vendors who were given tehbazari licence between 1985 and 1989,” said Devender Singh, general secretary of Kabaadi Bazaar Welfare Association. He added that the vendors have been running from pillar to post since 2009 to get a proper site after been evacuated from various places at least 10 times in the past 60 years.

The market has history dating back to 1942. The bazaar began at Ajmeri Gate with a few shopkeepers selling discarded and worn-out clothes. In the past 60 years, the number of vendors has not just swollen to 1,167, but the market has changed addresses from Shaaz ka Talab to Chawri Bazaar, Red Fort, Jama Masjid, Subhash Park and Delhi Secretariat.

The market was shifted to Jama Masjid from Ajmeri Gate. Later, the vendors were asked to squat at Subhash Park (earlier known as Edward Park) and Kasturba Hospital (earlier known as Victoria Hospital). By then, the number of vendors had increased to 250.

In 1982, it found a new place behind Red Fort. Years later, it moved to Subhash Park near Daryaganj. The turbulent journey of the vendors continued with them being given a new address beside Indira Gandhi Stadium close to Players’ Building (Delhi Secretariat).

“Our real struggle started in 2009, a year before the Commonwealth Games. We moved court after the authorities failed to allot us space. The issue was later transferred to the town vending committee of the municipal corporation. We now see a silver lining,” said Sharma.

Title: Face-recognition system at Nashik Road station soon
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Nashik: The Nashik Road railway station will soon be equipped with a face recognition security system as it has made its way to the list of stations marked by the railways in its pilot project of installing face reading/ recognition of passengers.

Under this project, a software has been developed to recognize and track people wanted in criminal cases or history-sheeters. The software will be synchronised with the CCTV system currently installed at the station.

“The software will be synchronised with the CCTV cameras operating at the station. The development is part of the Integrated Security System (ISS) that is being raised at the Nashik Road railway station since 2019,” a senior railway official said.

The face-tracker or face recognition software is the next step of the ISS programme that is being conducted at the railway station.

The railways first covered all the platforms with the CCTV cameras which enable them to track every person entering or exiting the railway station.

“We now have the CCTV coverage covering the entrances, the station, various passenger circulating areas, including the platforms, the foot overbridges, etc. We also have the tracker system in place — meaning if a person is identified — his/her movement can be tracked and captured across all the CCTV cameras,” a Railway Protection Force (RPF) officer said.

The next step of the security cover is the face recognition security system. It will help track people with criminal background.

“The data of wanted criminals, those on the look out notices, those only to be tracked, history-sheeters, etc will be uploaded on the control system. If the person in the said list happens to cross any of the CCTV cameras, it will alert the control room and flash the details of the person. Also, the system will then track the person’s movement on the station premises,” the officer added.

The Nashik Road station is secured with 110 CCTVs. Nashik Road is among the eight stations in Bhusawal divisions which have been fortified with the camera network.

Title: Ajinomoto a safe tastemaker, say its makers
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Madurai: Ajinomoto or MSG (monosodium glutamate), is absolutely safe for human consumption as it is made of natural ingredients . Only imitation products that come from China without regulatory approval are harmful, said managing director Ajinomoto, India, Atsushi Mishuku. Speaking to the reporters in Madurai, he said that they were the first company to produce MSG on a commercial scale. Finest quality crops like sugarcane and tapioca are used for manufacture Ajinomoto. There is an increase in sales and consumption of the product in India now said manager marketing, Govinda Biswas. MSG is made of glutamate, sodium and water which is completely safe to consume, said dietician Dr Dharini Krishnan. Glutamic acid which is also found in breast milk is safe. TNN

Title: Man held on charge of molesting daughter
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Representative image

Title: Government Railway Police to quiz guard & loco pilot for murder on train
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Representative image

PUNE: The Government Railway Police (GRP) have called the loco pilot , his assistant and the guard of the Mumbai-Latur-Bidar Express for their statements to find out what led to the delay in action in connection with the death of a passenger in an assault by 12 men on February 13.

The guard of the Mumbai-Latur-Bidar Express had sent information about a quarrel in the general compartment to the railway control at the Daund station. But by the time action was taken, Sagar Janardan Markad (26), who was travelling with his family, was fatally assaulted by a group of 12 passengers over a fight for a seat.

Markad’s wife had pulled the alarm chain of the train looking for help. But assistance reached only in Daund. “After the chain was pulled, the loco pilot had checked and found out that a quarrel was on in the compartment between some passengers. He had passed on this information to the guard of the train, who, in turn, passed on the update to Daund,” a Pune rail division official told TOI on Thursday.

According to the regulations, once the alarm chain is pulled at a particular station, the information needs to be passed on to the control of the next station. “In this case, the chain was pulled at Hadapsar, Manjri and Loni stations. But other than Daund, the stations in between do not have adequate GRP or Railway Protection Force (RPF) staffers. So the information was passed on to the Daund Junction,” the official said.

The train, after Pune, passed through Ghorpadi, Hadapsar, Manjri, Loni Yard, Loni, Uruli, Yevat, Khutbav, Kedgaon, Kadethan and Patas stations, before reaching Daund. Railway sources said more clarity was needed as to why the information was provided to only Daund. “The other stations also must have at least some GRP or RPF staffers and they could have prevented the assault. It is not possible that all the 13 stations didn’t have any GRP or RPF personnel,” a source said.

The GRP arrested 11 persons involved in the assault, but one managed to escape. “In their statements, the 11 people said the quarrel was unintentional and that they did not know the victim. We have called the loco pilot, his assistant and the guard of the train for their statements. Our jurisdiction is till Loni. The area after Loni comes under the jurisdiction of Daund ,” Pune GRP senior inspector Suresh Singh Goud said.

Sources in the Pune RPF said they had a staff strength of around 500 and a request to increase the manpower was pending with the Railway Board for two years.

Title: Construction materials on Balangir roads lead to accidents
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Frequent accidents due to the road blocked by construction materials and waste have sparked strong resentment ... Read More

BALANGIR: Unauthorised stacking up of building construction materials on the roads of Balangir poses great threat to commuters. Frequent accidents due to the road blocked by construction materials and waste have sparked strong resentment among residents.

People alleged that despite specific laws to penalise the violators, the municipality is taking no steps to stop dumping of construction materials.

Recently two severe road accidents took place in which two motorcyclists got injured on their head and leg after they lost control when the bikes ran over a heap of sand. One of them is still undergoing treatment.

Sunil Sharma, one of the accident victims, said, “I was returning to my house taking Rugudipada-railway station road. Suddenly, my motorcycle ran over the sand, which was lying on the road. I lost control over my vehicle. The bike skidded off and my head hit a mount of stone boulders.”

He was lucky as he has recovered from his injury. But another victim was unfortunate and he is limping as his left leg was grievously hurt. He is still under medication, said a resident.

“It is really unfortunate that municipality is not taking any action the issue. People are breaking rules without any fear of action. I wrote to all officials concerned about the issue to take stringent action against law-breakers,” said Sharma.

Everyday tonnes of construction materials like brick, sand, boulders are stacked on the roads without any prior permission from the municipality, said an official. Not a single road inside the town is free from construction waste.

Bipin Bihari Deep, executive officer of Balangir municipality, said, “We have a team which is responsible to enforce laws and penalise those violating them by stacking construction materials as well as waste on roads. The team has penalised many people in the town.”

The team comprises an amin, a tax collector and an official.

“When any complaint is received, the team inspects the area and acts accordingly to enforce the law. We will definitely clear all roads where construction materials are piling up to ensure safety of commuters in the town,” said Deep.

Title: Telangana: Reforms on anvil, RDOs told not to pass orders in cases
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Telangana CM K Chandrasekhar Rao

HYDERABAD: In a decision that is likely impact several thousands of cases pending in the revenue courts, the revenue department has instructed tahsildars and revenue divisional officers (RDOs) not to issue orders pertaining to revenue cases in their jurisdiction. The orders have been issued by the revenue department at a time when the state government has begun the exercise on the new Revenue Act. The government is planning to unveil the new Revenue Act in the upcoming budget session.

Activists and petitioners, however, faulted the government and said this would lead to further pendency of the cases.

Both tahsildars and RDOs have powers pertaining to revenue matters and hold revenue courts on every Saturday. Generally, the revenue courts deal with the cases pertaining to rights of records (RoR), Tenancy Act, Inam lands, land encroachments and Wakf-related issues. It helps people to resolve issues without approaching the civil courts.

Official sources confirmed that the instructions were issued to tahsildars and RDOs in Rangareddy district. There is, however, no confirmation if the orders are applicable to the entire state. “District collectors have been asked to get details of all the cases, especially pertaining ROR, Inam lands and Tenancy Act, pending in the revenue courts by holding revenue conferences. The collectors were asked to review cases where orders were passed without any merit,” a senior revenue official said.

On several occasions, chief minister K Chandrasekhar Rao has expressed displeasure over the functioning of the revenue department and even raised the issue of corruption in the tahsildar offices at the recent collectors’ conference.

Some officials see the latest orders as a move to strip powers of the revenue authorities. The government is even contemplating granting some of the powers enjoyed by tahsildars to departments like panchayat raj and do away with village revenue officers.

Meanwhile, activists criticised the latest move. “The revenue department is not holding hearings on regular basis for the last one year as the officials were involved in elections and other government programmes. If the tahsildars and RDOs cannot issue orders, then cases will drag for several months,” P Sivarama Krishna, an RTI activist, said.

Title: Report blames ex-ministers Atchnnaidu, Satyanarayana
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Amaravati: As per the vigilance report ESI corporation director C K Ramesh Kumar placed an order with M/s.Tele Health Services Pvt., Ltd., Hyderabad, without calling for tenders on the orders of labour minister K Atchnnaidu. Kumar signed an MoU with M/s.Tele Health Services Pvt., Ltd. to provide toll free services and ECG services on a nomination basis.

“The director agreed to pay Rs.1.80/month for each IP irrespective of calls attended. The director also had an MoU with the same service provider to provide ECG services to the patients at Rs.480/ECG at a time when the same is available in other hospitals for Rs.200,” said the vigilance report.

The report said the service provider claimed the bill by submitting call logs of Telangana state IPs and the directors paid the amount without verifying the call logs. The probe found that the service provider utilised services of PG diploma clinical cardiologists instead of qualified DM cardiologists by violating the agreement.

Similarly, after Atchannaidu moved to transport ministry, new labour minister Pithani Satyanarayana vetoed instructions of labour principal secretary Neerabh Kumar Prasad to selectively clear the bills instead of following the first-come-first basis.

During the term of Ramesh Kumar, work order for establishing Sewage Treatment Plant (STP) at ESI Hospital, Tirupati, worth of Rs.1.94 crores was issued on nomination basis without obtaining any prior permission from the government and without calling open tenders.

Title: BJD, Congress leaders slam AIIMS’ Hindi rule, demand rollback
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

AIIMS in Bhubaneswar

BHUBANESWAR: The row over AIIMS Bhubaneswar ’s directive to use Hindi in official communication has intensified with the BJD saying it would demand a withdrawal of the notice even as the Congress attacked the Narendra Modi government at the Centre, claiming it is an attempt to impose Hindi over the state language, Odia.

The AIIMS Bhubaneswar directive, which was cirulated on Thursday, stirred passions on Friday, the International Mother Language Day, as leaders of different parties and social activists criticized the order which has asked all employees of the hospital to conduct oficial business in Hindi.

Pinaki Mishra, BJD’s Puri MP and the parliament party leader in Lok Sabha, said, “We are the first state to be formed on linguistic basis and we will not allow anyone to sideline our mother tongue, particularly by any institution that is working for the people of our state. We will insist that Odia be used since our people are familiar with it and that will make their task of availing service at AIIMS easier. We will formally lodge our protest with the Union health ministry and ask for a change in this directive.” “All the officers in administration, academic section, hospital administration, finance and accounts and heads of the departments are hereby informed to do their work in Hindi and it should be ensured that the staff members working with them are doing their work in Hindi as applicable under the Official Language Rules, 1976,” read the order issued by P K Ray, deputy director (administration) AIIMS Bhubaneswar.

Reacting to it state Congress president Niranjan Patnaik said, “The circular issued by AIIMS Bhubaneswar imposing Hindi is an insult to Odia language and the rich and vibrant culture of Odisha. There is no place for imposing Hindi in our state.”

Koraput Congress MP Saptagiri Ulaka tweeted, “So AIIMS Bhubaneswar has sent directives to speak and write in Hindi. This is another attempt by the Centre to impose Hindi at the cost of Odia in Odisha. Is the state government aware of this and taking necessary steps to stop this?” Highlighting Ulaka’s tweet, Thiruvananthapuram MP Shashi Tharoor added his own, “This government is squandering the hard-won unity of the country built up over seven decades, based on mutual respect and acceptance of diversity. Their narrow-minded insistence on monolithic uniformity (Hindi, Hindutva, Hindustan) will destroy our unity.”

The directive also drew criticism from All India Congress Committee (AICC) secretary and Virudhunagar MP (Tamil Nadu) Manickam Tagore B, AICC national spokesperson Sharmistha Mukherjee and DMK’s Dharmapuri (Tamil Nadu) MP, S Senthilkumar among others. Defending the AIIMs decision, BJP state president Sameer Mohanty said the institute has issued the office order according to the guidelines of Official Language Rules, 1976. “It is an official procedure. They have not written anywhere that they will issue prescription in Hindi or speak to patients in Hindi only. We should not politicize it,” Mohanty said.

Dillip Dassharma, a member of Utkal Sammilani, said “When the whole world is celebrating International Mother Language Day, AIIMS Bhubaneswar is imposing Hindi on its employees. Most of these employees are from Odisha. This cannot be tolerated.”

With the controversy raging, AIIMS Bhubaneswar deputy director (administration) said they are implementing the Official Language Act. “It is a normal practice in central government offices. We have to follow the Act. It is our administrative practice. It will not be applicable to patients,” Ray said.

Title: Pig terror keeps farmers at Chhota Udepur awake at night
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Vadodara: Seeing villagers take turns to keep vigil at night is a common sight across the state. While in most cases, this nocturnal vigilance has a specific target — thieves and robbers. But what keeps Chhota Udepur farmers awake at night is a four-legged menace — pigs!

Armed with wooden sticks, farmers in two villages of Chhota Udepur — Pochamba and Vantda of Naswadi taluka — are spending sleepless nights, guarding their precious crops from the nightly attacks.

The farmers take turns to keep vigil at night to protect their crops, be it maize or wheat, cotton and groundnut. Pigs have destroyed every standing crop that the farmers have sowed. As the farmers have little or no money to fence their farms, at least 25 men keep a watch to protect their farms from sounder of pigs every single night.

“Earlier we had to keep a watch during the day but now even at night. If we are lax, our entire crop will be ruined,” said Ashwin Bhil. He added that after the farmers sow the seeds, the pigs dig up and remove them. “If it is ready for harvest they will partially eat the maize and ruin the entire crop. The crop becomes completely useless as even the cattle do not eat it then,” said Bhil, who owns a 3 acre farm.

Another farmer Surendra Desai, who owns 14 acres, has hired seven farm labourers to keep watch. “The harassment of pigs is terrible. “Even the cotton crop is not safe. If we doze off for only two hours at night, we are sure to face huge loss the next morning,” rued 72-year-old Desai. Farmers tried all tricks under their sleeves to hoodwink the pigs, like tying sarees around their crops. If the six yards failed to rein in on the pig terror.

Last year, Desai had gathered documents from all the farmers to prepare for putting up fences around the farms under government scheme. Desai had submitted all documents to the local office of Gujarat State Land Development Corporation Ltd too. However, the file is gathering dust till date.Bhil and Desai’s son Mitesh said that maize is an important crop for tribal farmers of Chhota Udepur as they grow it for their personal consumption and sell only the access crop.

“Market price of maize is around Rs590 per quintal which we cannot afford. We, therefore, grow our own crop. But when the pigs destroy the crops, we have to shell out money to buy food from the market,” Bhil said.

Tribal families eat flat bread or ‘rotlo’ made of maize flour — a staple diet in every household.

Title: ‘Taking no responsibility of services offered is unfair trade practice by Ola’ says panel
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Nashik: The District Consumer Grievances Redressal Forum, Nashik has ordered cab aggregator to pay Rs 20,000 to the consumer for cancelling the service without her consent. The forum termed the service as ‘illegal and unfair trade practice’ as the company claimed that ‘it is not a legal entity’.

Brushing aside the contention by the Ola Cab through its counsellor that it was merely a platform of ANI Technologies for providing services of booking of cabs and collection of payments, the Forum in its judgement dated Feb 14, expressed concern over the safety of the people travelling by their cabs and responsibility in case of a mishap.

“The company provides services to hundreds of people every day and yet the company claims that it has no legal entity. Any company in any business has to be registered with the government through various offices even - if it is a grocers’ shop. It is unfair trade practice by the company that gives the service to the people without informing them about its existence, collects money and on top of it ensures that it does not get into any legal hassles emerging from the same,” said the judgement by the three-member forum headed by Milind Sonawane, including Prerna Kalunkhe-Kulkarni and Sachin Shimpi.
