The judgement was delivered in case of the complainant registered by Jaspreet Kaur Rana, resident of Nashik city, who had booked the cab aggregator on Feb 20, 2019, to bring her family members arriving from New Delhi at the Nashik Airport.

When the cab arrived, Rana shared the One Time Password (OTP) with the driver and just when they were above to leave the driver added another passenger in the cab, to which she objected to. The cab driver said that the other passenger was going to pay him Rs 800 and she was to be charged only Rs 400. The same would affect her ride. “The passenger refused to allow the passenger in the car booked by her. Upon this the driver of the cab – Vishal Prakash – and the passenger started quarrelling following which the driver cancelled the booking without her consent and left her stranded,” the counsellor for Rana, AS Kulkarni said.

Replying to the notice issued by the Forum, the cab aggregator through its counsellor VS Talekar said that since the company is just a facilitator and the business was owned by ANI Technologies, it had no role in the dispute between the consumer and the ANI Technologies. “The cab Ola Cab is just in the business of communication between the consumer and the company (ANI Technologies). It does not receive any payment from the person who books the car and hence it is not the consumer of Ola Cab. Basically, it is not a legal entity,” Talekar said in the written reply to the Forum.

The forum took notice of this and questioned the company counsellor that when all the businesses are registered, how does the cab aggregator operate staying out of the purview of legal framework. “The question also arises is that when the company is ferrying hundreds of passengers daily, who will be responsible for any mishap with the consumer?”

The forum found the company guilty and ordered them to pay Rs 20,000 as compensation for mental harassment and Rs 5,000 as compensation for charges incurred.

Title: Vadner Gate closed for 5 days
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Nashik: The Local Military Authorities (LMAs) have closed the Vadner Gate for five days from February 21 due to an event scheduled in the army area. The gate will reopen on February 26.

Civilians who use the gate will have to take the main road through Nashik Road-Vihit Gaon-Lam Road to reach the camp area.

Brigadier J S Goraya, president of Deolali Cantonment Board, told TOI that the gate will remain closed for five days.

“There is an event in the army area due to which we have kept the Vadner Gate closed. The civilians will have to take the main road during this period,” said Goraya.

The event has been planned keeping in mind the three-day-long weekend. “There is a holiday for three days on account of Mahashivratri followed by Saturday and Sunday. It should not create much problem for the civilians,” said Bhagwan Katariya, vice president of the Cantonment Board Deolali.

According to the guidelines of the union defence ministry, the local army authorities can keep the gates closed during any emergency or events with prior information conveyed to the Cantonment Board so that the same is passed on to the civilians.

Title: Telangana high court reverses trial court order, awards seven-year jail for dowry death
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Representative image

HYDERABAD: The Telangana high court has reversed an acquittal order of a Medak trial court by convicting a man and his parents in a dowry death case and awarding them a seven-year jail sentence.

The court slapped Rs 20,000 penalty on each of the three convicts and also ordered them to pay Rs 50,000 compensation to the deceased woman’s family.

The case pertains to the death of 20-year-old Bhagyalakshmi of severe burns in her in-laws’ house in Narsapur on September 15, 2011. The victim was pregnant at the time of her death.

Though Narsapur police arrested husband Duddala Santhosh, his mother Balamani and father Narasimhulu, the trio came out of jail after they were acquitted of dowry harassment charges by the trial court on January 23, 2013. Bhagyalakshmi had married Santhosh on May 16, 2010.

A bench of Chief Justice Raghavendra Singh Chauhan and Justice A Abhishek Reddy reversed the trial court’s order after hearing an appeal of Talari Krishna, brother of the deceased.

Krishna said his sister faced severe harassment by Santosh and his parents seeking additional dowry. Conciliatory efforts were made by Krishna’s parents and maternal uncle to reach out to Santosh and his parents with a promise to give extra gold. But, Bhagyalakshmi died by then.

Charging the in-laws with killing his sister, Krishna filed a police complaint. The trial court, however, did not take any of the evidence placed before it into consideration and relied on minor discrepancies in the statements of Bhagyalakshmi’s parents and maternal uncle and acquitted Santhosh and his parents.

The high court bench, in its order, said the trial court had failed to shift the burden of the proof to the accused under section 113-B of the Evidence Act. “It has failed to appreciate the fact that the accused have not disproved the facts established by the prosecution. The trial court has failed to draw a mandatory presumption under the law,” the bench said.

Making it clear that there were compelling reasons for it to interfere in the trial court order which was unreasonable, the bench recalled the evidence available on record to prove the dowry harassment and concluded that the woman’s death was closely related to it.

Title: City still in top 10 in perception survey
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Madurai: With more than one week left for the nationwide Citizen’s Perception Survey to end, the Madurai Corporation has already achieved more than double the number of the target it had set. The survey is conducted by the Union ministry of housing and urban affairs (MoHUA) to rank 114 cities – 100 smart cities and 14 cities with more than one million population.

While the civic body had set a target of 10,615 by February 15, more than 23,500 people had taken part in the survey, which is 222% higher. The overwhelming participation by the city folk has helped the city to be featured among the top 10 cities in terms of best participation observed by the MoHUA. Madurai has shared 8th spot with Thane Corporation among the top 10 cities, Madurai Corporation officials said.

Surat emerged top and Salem secured got 5th position. Madurai and Salem, the only two cities in Tamil Nadu to have featured in top 10 list, made use of the participation and innovative ideas used by the cities to promote the survey.

“We thoroughly followed the information, education and communication mandated by the MoHUA and put of posters, hoardings, billboards across the city. ‘Namma Madurai’- our campaign was organized to sensitise and guide citizens in taking the survey,” said an official.

Officials said that various colleges and places, where people gather in large numbers were covered to create awareness on the survey. With one more week left for the survey, more people are expected to take part.

According to MoHUA, the survey is being conducted to directly capture citizen’s perception with respect to the quality of life in their cities.

Title: NMC to hold open auction for leasing its properties
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Nashik: The civic administration has decided to hold open auction for leasing its properties. It has also decided to lease properties at 8% of the ready reckconer (RR) rates as against the previous rate of 2.5%.

Nashik Municipal Corporation ( NMC ) recently conducted an audit of its properties and found glaring loopholes in the lease agreement of 900 properties given to private parties and social outfits. In many cases, properties were leased out to parties without any formal agreement while a few others were paying a very low rent. In some cases, the parties concered continued using the properties even after the expiry of the lease period.

Hence, the civic body has decided to put into effect two new policies to ensure lease agreements are given to credible parties in a transparent manner and elected representatives do not have much say on the issue.

Officials from the civic administration said, “The urban development department of the state government has sent a letter directing us to implement a new policy in leasing our properties. As per the new policy, the properties should be leased in an open auction and at 8% of the ready reckoner rates prevailing in the area where the plots are located. The properties of the civic body will now be leased as per the new policy of the state”

“We will soon inform the corporators about the new policy in the general body meeting,” said the officials.

NMC has over 2,800 properties—1,900 of which have been leased out for commercial purposes. The remaining 900 properties have been leased to different social outfits for setting up study halls, community halls, library, laughter clubs, gymnasiums and a host of other facilities.

A few months back, city-based educationist Ratan Luth had filed a public interest litigation (PIL) in the Bombay high court (HC) over the misuse of civic properties.

During a hearing last year, the HC had directed NMC to submit a report on the status of properties that were given to social institutes and NGOs at nominal rates on May 3. The civic body failed to submit the report.

The court then pulled up the municipal corporation for not maintaining a record of its properties. It also directed municipal commissioner Radhakrishna Game to remain present during the next hearing.

On being taken to task by the HC, NMC started taking action against the properties being misused and sealed 382 of the 945 properties it owns across six divisions.

Thereafter, the HC directed NMC to give a detailed history of each property. The civic body has conducted an audit of all its properties and will present the report before the court in the next hearing.

Title: Atchnnaidu dismisses vigilance charges
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Amaravati: After the vigilance and enforcement report blew whistle on irregularities taken place in purchase of drugs and surgical items in ESI hospitals during the TDP regime, labour minister Gummanur Jayaram said the state government would not spare anyone who was involved in the scandal.

“We will surely send all those responsible for looting of workers monies including Atchnnaidu to jail. TDP leaders have not left behind even daily wagers,” said Jayaram.

YSRC trade union leader P Gautham Reddy demanded the immediate arrest of Atchnnaidu to bring more facts out.

Atchnnaidu condemned the allegations against him saying that the government was trying to implicate him with false charges. “I dare them to take action against me if my role in the scandal is proved,” Atchnnaidu told the media.

He said that he had merely asked the officials to follow the Telangana model in awarding the contracts to avoid duplication and delay in finalization of the contracts. “It doesn’t mean asking the officials to violate the rules. My family had never compromised on values, ethics and principles,” Atchnnaidu clarified.

He said that he was never involved in corrupt practices during his two-decade-long public life.

Former minister and TDP leader Kollu Ravindra said that YSRC government was targeting Atchnnaidu as he belongs to backward classes community. The false campaign against Atchnnaidu is an attack on the entire BC communities, said Ravindra.

Title: Loan dues: Banks to auction properties of Rayapati Sambasiva Rao, Sujana Chowdary
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Rayapati Sambasiva Rao

VIJAYAWADA: With Enforcement Directorate and CBI pursuing them for alleged bank frauds, industrialists-turned-politicians Rayapati Sambasiva Rao and Yalamanchili Satyanarayana Chowdary ( Sujana Chowdary ) may lose their properties pledged as collaterals for loans.

Andhra Bank has issued an e-auction notice to property belonging to the family of Rayapati Sambasiva Rao. Bank of India issued a similar notice to sell properties belonging to Sujana Chowdary. The auctions will be held on March 23 if they failed to repay the loan.

According to the notice given by Bank of India, Sujana Universal Industries Limited has Rs 322 crore dues against the loan taken from the bank till October 26, 2018 the date from when the company has defaulted in repayment of loan. The total outstanding as on February 18, 2020 has become Rs 400.84 crore along with 13.95% interest.

The bank said the company has defaulted on the loan and did not make any payment even after serving the 60-day period demand notice. In order to recover the outstanding amount, the bank has decided to auction the properties belonging to the guarantors.

The bank has named YS Chowdary, the late Y Shivalinga Prasad, Y Jathin Kumar, Y Shivaramakrishna, ST Prasad, Gottumukkala Srinivasa Raju, M/s Splendid Metal Products Limited formerly known as Sujana Metal Products Limited, M/s Sujana Capital Services Limited, M/s Sujana Pumps and Motors Limited, M/s Nueeon Towers Limited erstwhile Sujana Towers Limited and M/s SAARC Net Limited as the guarantors for Sujana Universal Industries.

As part of the loan recovery, BOI has decided to auction five properties either directly owned by Sujana Chowdary or having general power of attorney. All the properties are vacant lands in Tamil Nadu owned by Y Sivalingaprasad, Y Jathin, ST Prasad, Shivaramakrishna and Sujana Chowdary himself. The total extent of lands admeasuring to 36,260 sqft of house sites.

In case of Rayapati Sambasiva Rao, Andhra Bank has issued notice for sale of a commercial building at Guntur admeasuring 22,500 sqft against to the recovery of Rs 837.37 crore loan availed by M/s Transstroy (India) Limited, Cherukuri Sridhar, M Sambasiva Rao, Rayapati Ranga Rao, Devika Rani and Lakshmi whereas the guarantors for the loan are Rayapati Jagadesh, Rayapati Jeevan, Narayya Chowdary, Ranga Rao, Devika Rani, Lakshmi, Y Jaganmohan and Ch Vani. The property that was put for auction was in the name of guarantor Y Jaganmohan.

Though Rayapati Sambasiva Rao was not the direct barrower or guarantor for the loan, his family members are stakeholders in Transstroy Company and availed loan on behalf of the company. Both Transstroy and Sujana Universal Industries are being probed by CBI and ED for alleged bank fraud and money laundering following complaints from the banks.

Title: Mumbai man held for duping Anand bizman of Rs 40 lakh
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Abdul Rehman Safri

Vadodara: A resident of Mumbai was arrested by detection of crime branch (DCB) on Friday for duping a businessman from Anand.

Abdul Rehman Safri was nabbed after Amit Motani filed a complaint of cheating against him at the crime branch. According to the police, Motani filed a complaint on Thursday following which the cops swung into action.

Motani told the police that he was introduced to Safri by a friend about three and half years ago. Safri told him that he wanted to sell off his office space in Mayfair Atrium as he was in need of money. Motani saw the office and decided to buy it for Rs 50 lakh. He gave Rs 40 lakh to Safri in instalments in 2018 and got the sale agreement in his wife’s name.

In May 2019, when Motani went to the office he bought, he saw the name of Bhagirathsinh Jadeja written outside. Motani tried to reach Safri but his phone was switched off.

When he met Safri’s wife in the city, she said she was not in contact with him since a year. Motani then approached the crime branch and filed a complaint of cheating.

Title: TRS mulls B Vinod Kumar, Kalvakuntla Kavitha for one RS berth from Telangana
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Kalvakuntla Kavitha

HYDERABAD: The TRS leadership is considering the names of former Nizamabad MP Kalvakuntla Kavitha and former Karimnagar MP B Vinod Kumar to fill one of the two Rajya Sabha member slots from Telangana, the elections of which are set to be held next month. For the other Rajya Sabha berth, the party may consider an SC or ST leader, sources said.

BJP MP Garikapati Mohan Rao and Congress MP KVP Ramachandra Rao from Telangana are retiring in April this year. TRS secretary general and MP K Keshava Rao is also retiring this April. Though Keshava Rao claimed that he was transferred to Telangana and Ramachandra Rao shifted to AP, a Rajya Sabha bulletin, however, clarified that such transfer did not take place.

Kavitha had lost from Nizamabad in the 2019 Lok Sabha polls. Though there was speculation that she could be made an MLA, it did not materialise. Vinod, who also faced a surprise defeat at the hands of BJP MP Bandi Sanjay, was later appointed vice-chairman of Telangana State Planning Board.

Sources in TRS said Vinod stands a better chance because of his contacts in Delhi. “Vinod was deputy floor leader in Lok Sabha between 2014-2019 and has maintained good contacts in Delhi. He used to interact with Union ministers and senior officials in Delhi and take up state’s issues with the Centre. Keeping this in mind, TRS chief K Chandrasekhar Rao may send him to the Rajya Sabha,” the sources said.

Among the other leaders, Khammam former MP Ponguleti Srinivas Reddy, former speakers Suresh Reddy and S Madhusudhana Chary have been trying for Rajya Sabha membership. As of now, only BC and other caste leaders were accommodated by the party. TRS has six MPs in the Upper House. MP D Srinivas, though technically is with TRS, has not been on good terms with the party leadership.

Since TRS has clear majority to secure the two berths from the Upper House, its strength is set to rise to seven. The party is planning to play a key role in the Rajya Sabha where BJP does not have sufficient numbers.

Title: Chennai: In fight over wall, students counter political graffiti with social messages
Content:
Students paint on the compound wall of Dr Ambedkar Arts College, Vyasarpadi. (Photo credit: Ramesh Shankar)

CHENNAI: Much like the 2014 film ‘Madras’, a feud is on between two factions in the city over a wall. But unlike the film, where two political groups fought, here local politicos and students of Dr Ambedkar Arts College in Vysarpadi are locked in a feud. While the party workers are trying to appropriate the compound wall to draw graffiti, the students are using it to spread social messages.Students from the department of social work said they are on a mission to reclaim the compound wall from political parties. Using art as a medium, they are writing messages on substance abuse, female infanticide, conservation of water, unity in diversity and education for girls.(Photo credit: Ramesh Shankar)The wall and the footpath along the college have been in a state of neglect. A student said pedestrians often urinated near the wall and nearby residents dumped garbage on the adjoining footpath.“We wanted to put an end to this. To keep the surroundings clean, we have taken the initiative. It was appreciated by many, including our college administration,” she said.But this has not gone down well with the local members of the ruling party. The party functionaries are trying to take over a section of the wall and have allegedly intimidated the students from painting on the section they claim as theirs.After the students cleaned and whitewashed the wall, local politicians acted swiftly and engaged painters overnight. They painted graffiti professing their loyalty to their leaders and to mark the 74th birth anniversary of former chief minister J Jayalalithaa. The names of CM Edappadi K Palaniswami and his deputy O Panneerselvam featured in the graffiti.“They said they have reserved the wall for the party. They drew a line and told us strictly not to cross it. Our faculty members took up the issue and tried to talk to them but it headed nowhere,” one of the students said.Students are now working till late into the night to wrap up their mural by Sunday. College principal A Geetha said, “We want to encourage the students to restore the institution walls. But there is pressure. We will try to reclaim it.”AIADMK north Chennai (east) district secretary R S Rajesh said students and faculty of the college brought the issue to his notice and he has taken action. “The compound wall belongs to the college. We will not disturb the students in anyway. I have also asked the party workers to stay away from the wall,” he said.

Title: Andhra Pradesh: Two dead as truck rams bullock cart
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

The truck which rammed the bullock cart from behind

VIJAYAWADA: Two persons died on the spot, while four others were wounded, after a truck rammed against a bullock cart near Thimmapuram village of Edlapadu mandal in Guntur district on early hours of Friday.

The deceased were identified as Nimmagadda Koteswara Rao and Koduru Shivaji – both farmers and bullock cart riders. According to Nageswara Rao, sub-inspector of Edlapadu police station, the incident happened at around 4.30 am when four bullock carts were carrying lofty, illuminated ‘prabhalu,’ made of bamboo and decorated with coloured cloth and paper. They were heading towards the local Shiva temple to participate in the Mahashivaratri celebration. A speeding truck coming from behind couldn’t break in time and rammed against the bullock carts leaving two of the riders dead.

Meanwhile, traffic came to a standstill as devotees protested demanding action against the truck driver and protested the two persons’ deaths and the destroyed ‘prabhalu’.

Four others suffered ghastly wounds and were rushed to a local government hospital for treatment.

Title: Big crowds throng temples in southern dists for Shivrathri
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Madurai: Devotees thronged the temples in southern districts and prayers were held throughout the night on Friday on the occasion of Mahashivrathri festival.

The Sri Meenakshi Sundareswarar temple remained open throughout the night, and special poojas were performed. Temple Joint Commissioner N Natarajan said that the poojas would go on from 10 P.M on Friday to 5 A.M on Saturday. Special security arrangements were made at the temple keeping in mind the huge attendance.

The devotees cooked pongal and made offerings at many roadside temples near the Meenakshi temple on Friday night. The Muktheeswarar temple near the Mariamman Teppakulam was also open throughout the night with rituals being performed.

In the southern districts of Virudhunagar, Ramanathapuram and Sivaganga, people went in bullock carts to their village temples and made offerings as per the tradition. “We go in a bullock cart to the Madakulam Ayyanar temple in Madurai, every year, as has been the tradition,” said Periyasamy of Malliampatti in Dindigul, who was among the 200 families that came to Madurai riding on 50 bullock carts.

Musical events and stage dramas were held on the temple premise in villages. At the Kochadai Muthiasamy temple, people were seen occupying places which they had booked in advance, with goats and roosters they had brought for sacrificing on Saturday.

Title: Industry rues lack of infra projects
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Madurai: Trade and industry have by and large welcomed many features in the state budget presented by deputy chief minister O Panneerselvam though they have unanimously expressed concern over the Rs 22,000 crore revenue deficit.

Introduction of a new road safety department in the main districts including Madurai would reduce road accidents. They also welcomed the proposal for new medical colleges in 11 districts and reduction of stamp duty from 1% to 0.25%. Tamilnadu Foodgrains Merchants Association Limited welcomed the mega food park to be established on 53.36 acres at Gangaikondan in Tirunelveli district at Rs 77.94 crore. The Rs 11,000 crore for cooperative agricultural loans, Rs 200 crore waiver of interest on farm loans and allocation of Rs 11,894 crore for agriculture were also welcomed.

Allocation of Rs 655 crore to build new ponds and waterlines, Rs 500 crore for 1,364 water resource schemes, Rs 200 crore for Cauvery – Gundar scheme, Rs 649 crore for rehabilitating 906 ponds and 183 reservoirs and 37 artificial wells and Rs 2,962 crore to modernise agricultural activities will give a boost to rural economy. Madurai District Tiny and Small Scale Industries Association (Maditssia) has welcomed the allotment of Rs 100 crore to create new entrepreneurs, hike in interest subsidy for MSMEs from 3% to 5% and increase in the investment cap for unemployed youth from Rs 10 lakh to Rs 15 lakh.

Tamilnadu Chamber of Commerce and Industry welcomed the Chennai – Kanyakumari economic corridor scheme as well as diversion of 1,100 tmc excess water from Godavari to Tamil Nadu. However, Maditssia expressed disappointment over lack of a visionary scheme for the sector. It regretted there were no major infrastructure development projects which were badly needed for Madurai. There was also no announcement on metro rail for Madurai to decongest the city. There was no mention about initiatives for fast-tracking the Madurai – Tuticorin industrial corridor of excellence mooted by former CM Jayalalithaa in 2013. A scheme like the Rs 500 crore allotted for a desalination plant at Nemmeli should have been made for Sayalkudi in Tuticorin.

Foodgrains merchants association expressed concern over no announcement to commence kudimaramath works in Vaigai dam despite an announcement made seven years ago.

Title: NGT urged to direct lake restoration
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Hyderabad: Highlighting the plight of city lakes before NGT’s southern bench (Chennai) on Thursday, activist Lubna Sarwath said how water bodies in the city are being converted into land and surface water is being polluted. The bench was hearing a case regarding the restoration of Mamasani Kunta in Puppalguda village. It has posted the next hearing on February 26. Sarwath alleged that these issues were not being addressed by the state government, in spite of repeated petitions. tnn

Title: Corpn seeks another Rs 310cr to meet drinking water needs
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Madurai: The Madurai Corporation has sought Rs 310 crore more from the Asian Development Bank (ADB) for drinking water distribution for 57 wards in core city area, comprising 72 wards. Already, the corporation has obtained the nod for Rs 252 crore from ADB to cover 28 wards in newly-added areas.

“We had planned to get loan from from the Housing and Urban Development Corporation Limited (HUDCO). ABD has come forward to provide loan for water distribution project as well. With the approval having been obtained for the Rs 252 crore package, a formal request has been sent for approval for the Rs 310 crore package,” a corporation official said.

Work on the drinking water project worth over Rs 1,000 crore, which is implemented in three packages, aims to draw 125 MLD from Mullaperiyar dam, and is already in progress. The civic body is planning to provide round-the-clock drinking water supply to all the 100 wards. Of these, 15 wards coming under area-based development (ABD) area are already covered for water distribution. The corporation is tapping fund from ADB for the rest of the city, under two packages.

Package one consists of the construction of a check dam and pumping water from the Lower Camp to Pannaipatti at a cost of Rs 320 crore. Package two is the construction of a water treatment plant at Pannaipatti at an estimated cost of Rs 110 crore. “The 125 million litres a day (MLD) capacity facility will be developed on a build operate and transfer (BOT) basis. The third package will be providing a giant water line from Pannaipatti to Madurai covering around 75km at an estimated cost of Rs 590 crore.

Corporation commissioner S Visakan recently said that work order has been issued for package two, while packages one and three will be completed in two weeks’ time. All the files regarding the project are treated with utmost speed and it will be ensured that the project gets implemented at the earliest, he said.

At present, Madurai has got water source of only around 170 million litres a day (MLD), but available water from the existing sources is around 150 MLD. The city’s present water requirement is more than 220 MLD.

Title: Civic body to build new office building for Nashik East division at Dwarka
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Nashik: The Nashik Municipal Corporation (NMC) has decided to build a new office building for Nashik East division in Dwarka area of the city and necessary financial provision will to be made for it in the civic budget for the financial year 2020-21.

After the existing East division office in a British-era building developed cracks, the civic body moved half of the departments to its existing building in Old Pandit colony. The building also houses the office of Nashik West division.

The issue was also raised by the corporators during the recent General Body meeting. Corporator Mushir Sayyad had complained that moving of some departments to Nashik West divisional office building is causing inconvenience to citizens as it is far away from the existing office.

Mayor Satish Kulkarni said that this British-era building will be repaired and renovated shortly. “The civic body has identified a place for the new office building for Nashik East division and this new building will soon be constructed there,” he said.

This British-era structure had developed cracks due to peepal trees growing behind the building. The cracks were exposed after the NMC axed the trees last year.

Following this, the NMC had urged the archaeology department to suggest measures to repair and renovate the structure. Accordingly, an expert team of the archaeology department inspected the building.

Following the inspection, the team suggested the NMC to immediately put soil bags near the walls so that the structure does not collapse.

The NMC has a total of six divisions — Nashik East, Nashik West, Nashik Road, Satpur, Cidco and Panchavati — and all services to city residents are provided through these offices.

Title: Man held for real estate fraud
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Hyderabad: Punjagutta cops arrested a man for duping people under the guise of selling villas. “S Anitha from Anantapur booked two villas by paying Rs 14 lakh as advance,” said Punjagutta SI Satish Kumar. When the accused started avoiding Anitha, she lodged a complaint. tnn

Title: Art auction to raise funds for conserving elephants
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Shagun Mehra is working to save elephants dying in accidents

Vadodara: On Saturday evening, the city will host an auction for saving elephants that have been dying on the rail tracks since decades.

Shagun Mehra, an entrepreneur working for conservation of elephants, has organized an auction of valuable items, photographs, paintings and sculptures at the Laxmi Vilas Palace.

Proceedings from the auction will be used for saving the elephants in the wild.

“During my visit to Spain about one-and-half-years ago, a scientist told me that hundreds of elephants die in train accidents. I was shocked to know about it. When I returned to India, I did some research and learnt that about 300 elephants die due to train collisions every year,” Mehra told TOI.

“Elephants are important part of our ecosystem. So I decided to do something about it and began visiting the states that have population of elephants. I also launched Ear to the Wild Foundation (EWF) for conserving elephants and their habitat,” Mehra said. EWF has partnered with Wildlife Institute of India, state forest authorities and the Indian Railways for bringing down the elephant-train collisions.

She added that the money raised from the auction would be used for buying special sensors, conserving habitat of elephants and building bridges that elephants can use. Member of royal Gaekwad family, Radhikaraje Gaekwad, who has come out in support of the initiative, said, “We all know how elephants are dying due to train accidents and something must be done to save them. So I decided to support this cause. If you see, the emblem of Baroda state too has elephants.”

Apart from items, on auction is tea with Gaekwad, cooking lessons from chef Rahul Akerkar, bat having autograph of Sachin Tendulkar and luxury stay at a hotel in Sindhudurg.

Title: In fight for a united India, West Bengal CM Mamata Banerjee lays stress on language
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Chief Minister of West Bengal

KOLKATA: Offering tribute on the International Mother Language Day , chief minister Mamata Banerjee built her alternative narrative, projecting language as mother and the need to protect the motherland.

“Our motherland is like our mother. We have to work for the unity of the motherland,” Banerjee said at Deshapriya Park on Friday, laying the primacy on language and not on religion. “There have been attempts to break the nation’s unity. I urge people of all communities to stand united and fight for a united India,” she said.

The chief minister’s emphasis on language made it clear that she was speaking about the languages spoken by people of diverse religions and castes. “It is time that people protected unity in diversity . We have to stay together, irrespective of religions and castes. The mother can never be divided,” she said. Minister of state for information and cultural affairs Indranil Sen sang a song written by the chief minister against the new citizenship law.

Banerjee, who inaugurated a work shed for tanneries at Bantala through remote control and a shelter for cobblers at Janbazar, switched from Bengali to Hindi as she felt people from outside the state would find it easier to understand her.

Political analyst Yogendra Yadav , who was present at the programme, said though Hindi was the national language of the country, it was one of the most recent languages, while Tamil, Maithili and Bangla were older ones. “The best way to celebrate the unity of India is to recognize its diversity. Any attempt to steamroll people would be detrimental to the unity of the country,” he said.

“India is not Europe, it is not Israel either. It has its own features. India is a country, which has a khichdi of languages,” said the political analyst, pointing out that if the stress was solely on Hindi, Hindu and Hindustan, the country would be in pieces. At the end of the programme, Yadav said, he held political discussions with Banerjee.

Bangladesh deputy high commission, too, held day-long events to pay tributes to February 21 martyrs on the International Mother Language Day.

Title: Devotees throng roads for Shivji Ki Savari
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Vadodara: Thousands attended the Shivji Ki Savari — Lord Shiva’s chariot procession — organised on the occasion of Maha Shivratri in the city on Friday. Along with the Maha Aarti and inauguration of the renovated pond, Sursagar wore a festive look on Friday. The procession and event witnessed unprecedented attendance of devotees.

The chariot ferried the Lord Shiva sitting on Nandi, Goddess Parvati and their sons Ganesha as well as Kartikeya, through the main thoroughfares of the city.

The procession commenced from the Ranmukteshwar Temple in Pratapnagar and culminated at Sursagar.

The procession had a series of floats including those of select government departments. Several men, women and children dressed as various gods and goddesses participated in the procession. Members of different ‘akhadas’ in the city displayed skills like malkhambh and rope malkhambh during the procession on floats allocated to them.

The event culminated with the inauguration of Sursagar by chief minister Vijay Rupani who also performed Maha Aarti of the Sarveshwar Mahadev idol located in the centre of the Sursagar pond. Union minister Amit Shah, however, could not attend the event.

Speaking to media persons on the side lines of the event Rupani said that he had prayed for a powerful and prosperous Gujarat and its people. He added that the third eye of Lord Shiva will burn all those who wishes ill for the country.

Title: Narsingi cops arrest chain snatcher
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Hyderabad: Narsingi police arrested a chain snatcher after he was caught by locals while trying to snatch a woman’s gold chain. But the woman raised an alarm and pushed the accused off his bike. Locals handed him over to the cops. tnn

Title: Rebuild Broken Bridge, Madras high court tells authorities
Content:
Broken bridge at Adyar in Chennai

CHENNAI: The ‘ Broken Bridge ’ — that once connected Srinivasapuram in Foreshore Estate with MRC Nagar and Adyar — holds the key to decongest an entire stretch of Santhome High Road and Greenways Road, right up to Besant Nagar beach.Underscoring its potential to emerge as an alternative route for the entire stretch, the Madras high court has asked Greater Chennai Corporation to explore the possibility of constructing a wide road connecting Marina Loop Road to Besant Nagar, via the Broken Bridge, to reduce traffic.“It seems that the existing connecting road from Loop Road to Besant Nagar, which is said to have been destroyed in the floods of 1970s or so, still exists in a damaged condition,” the court noted and suggested the corporation and state authorities to explore the possibilities of recreating the link.This will not only create alternative road to reduce the burden of traffic on the beach road via DGS Dinakaran Road to Adyar up to airport, but also provide alternate suitable motorable road for traffic, observed a division bench of Justice Vineet Kothari and Justice R Suresh Kumar on Friday.At present, the two arterial roads get choked during rush hours. A survey of traffic movement on DGS Dinakaran Road and Durgabai Deshmukh Road by the traffic police in early 2019 had found that 32,353 vehicles ply between 5pm and 8pm. During peak morning hours, about 26,120 vehicles use the stretch that connects Adyar and Fort St George.The court made the suggestions after perusing status reports filed by the corporation commissioner and the joint director of fisheries on steps taken to free Loop Road of encroachments and the enumeration of fish vendors, in response to a PIL by Fisherman Care.According to the enumeration report filed by the fisheries department, a total of 356 vendors have been identified in three areas of the loop road. Noting that the vendors are yet to produce relevant documents, the court directed the authorities to ensure the process is complete within three weeks.In his report, corporation commissioner G Prakash stated that action plan for removal of encroachments other than enumerated fish vendors along the loop road will be taken by the fisheries department with help from the civic body and police. The commissioner also stated that design for the permanent fish market is yet to be finalized and the estimate will be prepared before March 15.Noting down the submissions by the civic body that the proposed fish market will be completed by June this year, the court directed the officials to encourage the fishermen to carry on their business in the allotted space. Taking note of the submission by the additional advocate-general that besides the fishermen residing in the loop road area, other fishermen too sell their fish along the loop road, the court asked the authorities to restrict the other fishermen.“It is expected that both police and corporation will ensure free flow of traffic on the loop road area on all days, especially throughout the congestion hours of morning and evening,” the court said and also suggested the authorities to explore the possibility of constructing two foot overbridges (FOBs) from the sea-side of loop road to the proposed fish market area to facilitate movement of fishermen without having to cross the loop road.

Title: Swachh workshop concludes
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Tirupati: “Tirupati will stand as a torch bearer for the rest of India in solid waste management,” said VK Jindal, joint secretary and mission director of the Swachh Bharat Mission. The Swachh Bharat Mission workshop, conducted for various municipalities and municipal corporations of AP in the city, concluded on Friday.

Stressing that nature does not generate waste, it is only humans who generate waste, VK Jindal pointed out that if not managed correctly, it will have serious negative impacts on life.

Tirupati MLA Bhumana Karunakar Reddy felt that if the political and administration representatives worked together with dedication, the results will be amazing. tnn

Title: Santiniketan: With financial crisis, Visva-Bharati is on life support, says vice-chancellor Bidyut Chakraborty
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Vice-chancellor Bidyut Chakraborty

SANTINIKETAN: Visva-Bharati is going through an acute financial crisis, it is “ailing and running on life support”, said the university vice-chancellor , Bidyut Chakraborty, at a programme observing International Mother Language Day on Friday.

He went on to say, “On October 2, one cannot enter Raj Ghat as it is too crowded, with all thieves, wearing caps, queue up there. But they act in the exactly opposite way of Gandhiji’s ideals throughout the year.”

Claiming how many have been “milking” the university Chakraborty said, “Visva-Bharati has become a goose that lays the golden eggs. Most people here are good but a handful are using social media and other mediums to tarnish the image of Visva-Bharati. Local businessmen even dared to abuse the vice-chancellor and lodge a complaint of sexual harassment against him. But everyone remained silent.” Local traders recently were up in arms after the permission for Poush Mela stalls were distributed online.

The VC criticized a “section of media” for misquoting him. “A part of my speech was fleshed out to stir controversy. Some teachers, too, post adverse comments online,” he said, adding he was not scared of criticism.

Title: Police hunt down deadly phone snatching gang
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Coimbatore: Six days after a gang stabbed an engineering student, who had refused to hand over his mobile phone , to death at Sulur here , the rural police on Friday arrested six youths in connection with the case.

Police identified them as R Mohan, 21, of Periyar Nagar at Masakalipalayam, S Sathish Kumar, 20, of Patel Street at Vellalore, R Vijay, 21, of Veeramathi Amman Kovil at Vellalore, S Surya, 19, of Periyar Nagar at Masakalipalayam, S Ganesh Vetrivel, 20, of Ondipudur and V Mohanraj, 18, of Vellalore.

Preliminary inquiry revealed that Sathish Kumar, Surya, Ganesh Vetrivel and Mohanraj had become friends while they were students of a corporation school. “They had dropped out from Class X and were doing odd jobs for some time. They later befriended Mohan and Vijay. Surya was facing two cases for causing public nuisance and Mohan, three cases for selling ganja and one for theft. Mohan used to supply ganja to his friends,” a police officer said.

The six-member gang decided to snatch mobile phones from people to make some quick cash. “They used to roam the streets at night to snatch phones. They would sell the phones and buy liquor,” he told TOI.

Last Saturday, around 11.30pm, they targeted D Tamilselvan, 20, of Sadayan Thottam in Nadu Arasur, a third year Mechanical Engineering student in a private college. “He was on the way to his home from a bus stand. The gang waylaid him and attempted to snatch his phone. When he resisted, Ganesh Vetrivel stabbed Tamilselvan in his right chest. When the student cried for help, the gang escaped from the spot on two motorcycles,” the officer said.

Ten minutes later, the gang snatched a phone from K Mahalingam, 25, of Vasantha Nagar at Arasur, who was on his moped. They also stabbed him before taking his moped. They abandoned the vehicle a kilometre away from the crime scene.

Police superintendent Sujit Kumar had formed six special teams to nab the gang. Though the gang members had removed the SIM card from the stolen mobile phone and had inserted a new one, police tracked the IMEI number of the device and arrested them.

Police also seized two motorcycles, a knife and a mobile phone from them. They will be produced before the Sulur judicial magistrate on Saturday.

Title: APERC lays out 6-pt formula to improve ailing power utilities
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Vijayawada: Andhra Pradesh Electricity Regulation Commission ( APERC ) has proposed a six-point formula for salvage the ailing power utilities in the state.

In a review meeting with energy department officials on Friday, APERC chairman Justice C V Nagarjuna Reddy asked them to focus on improving transparency, accountability, quality, efficiency, promotion of new technologies and reduction of transmission and distribution losses.

The commission has decided to conduct fortnightly reviews with the power utilities to monitor the development and progress of the sector. The APERC chairman also said that the commission will conduct scrutiny of all power purchases up to date to ensure savings.

Emphasising the need for power utilities to become financially self-reliant apart from ensuring transparency and accountability, the chairman suggested to make cost effective power available to consumers.

Justice Reddy said the commission has made an extensive exercise in deciding the new tariff order that will benefit 99% of the consumers.

“For the first time the tariff order was fixed based on the consumption of billing month as against to the method of levying charges based on consumption during the previous financial year” he said.

Justice Reddy said the commission would lay more focus on improving efficiency of power sector and to ensure affordable and reliable uninterrupted power supply. Referring to considerable increase in power demand in Andhra Pradesh, the chairman told the officials to take all steps to ensure quality power made available to farmers and industrial sectors as it will spur economic growth of the state.

The chairman also pressed for establishing a grievance redressal mechanism from assistant engineer (AE) level to CMD level by setting up complaint boxes. He said the power utilities should work on establishing an emotional connect with the consumers to achieve better results.

Title: Free cycles distributed to over 2,000 corpn school students in Madurai
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Madurai: The city corporation distributed cycles to 2,332 students studying in corporation schools on Friday. Minister for co-operatives Sellur K Raju said that more than 17,000 bicycles, at a cost of Rs 4.38 crore, have been distributed to students in Madurai corporation between 2013 and 2020. The cycles were distributed to the students of eleventh standard including 469 boys and 1,863 girls.

There are 97 schools in Madurai Corporation, including 51 primary, 22 middle, nine high schools and 15 higher secondary schools, with 17,976 students.

Between 2011 and 2020, 2.34 lakh cycles have been distributed in the district. A sanction of Rs 9.87 crore has been made to distribute 25,034 cycles this year, he said.

The minister also spoke on other works initiated by the government including smart classrooms, improvement of basic infrastructure and evening snacks for 6,262 students writing their public examinations this year.

Corporation commissioner S Visakan said that the happy schooling programme in corporation schools was helping create a healthy relationship between teachers and students. Sixteen students who performed outstandingly in last year’s SSLC examination from corporation schools were now training their juniors on how to excel in the examinations, he added.

“Forty-one schools in the Madurai corporation have been provided with Wi-Fi with the help of private organisations. HCL has come forward to upgrade the playgrounds of corporation schools and build a new playground opposite the corporation swimming pool,” he said.

Madurai MP Su Venkatesan, MLA V V Rajan Chellappa, among others were present.

Title: Increase height of median: Motorists
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Coimbatore: In the wake of Thursday’s accident on Salem-Kochi road near Avinashi that claimed 19 lives, motorists who regularly use the stretch say the height of the median should be increased to avoid such accidents in future.

The median on the accident spot is less than a foot. Motorists wanted to increase the height of the median on six-lane national highway by at least three feet.

K Subramaniam, 44, a businessman from Avinashi in Tirupur district, is a regular user of the Salem-Kochi NH road. He said the height of the median on the stretch should be increased at least by three feet. “If the median was at three feet height, the container truck would not have entered the other side of the lane. So, the NHAI officials should think of increasing the height of the median,” Subramaniam said.

U Udhayasankar, project manager, NHAI Project Implementation unit, Coimbatore, said the height of the median is 22 cm on Kochi- Salem NHAI stretch. It is constructed as per Indian Road Congress norms. There is no flaw in the road and median design, he added.

Meanwhile, the Tirupur city police have decided to send a letter to the Kerala government urging it to cancel the driving licence of the truck driver who caused the accident.

Deputy commissioner of police (crime & traffic), Tirupur city, V Badri Narayanan told TOI that the city traffic police would soon send a detailed report to the Kerala government about the accident and would urge it to cancel the driving licence of the container truck driver permanently.

The driver of the container truck driver, K A Hemaraj, 37, of Kollathumkundil at Ottapalam near Palakkad, was arrested by the Thirumuruganpoondi police on Thursday. He was produced before the judicial magistrate court -III in Tirupur on Friday.

Later, he was remanded in judicial custody for 15 days and lodged in the Coimbatore Central Prison.

Title: Gujarat: Driver, conductor rape passenger on luxury bus rooftop
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Representative image

Title: Race Course model road project shifts to top gear
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Coimbatore: One-and-a-half years after proposing to turn the Race Course Road into a model road under the smart cities mission, the city corporation has obtained approval from the mission’s high-powered steering committee.

The road and its scheme road for about three kilometres will be developed into a model road by incorporation innovative components at the cost of Rs 40.67 crore, a corporation official said. The corporation has floated tender for the work and the bid will open on March 11.

Whenever the project inched close to clearance, objections were raised pertaining to the components. As a result, the consultant designing the project as well as officials of the smart city ended up redesigning it. The team managed to obtain the nod recently after a long struggle.

The project will kick-off within a couple of weeks after a suitable bidder is selected, the official said. “The stretch is one of the vibrant public places in the city. It has its own residential and commercial space. We have designed the project by retaining its uniqueness.”

“In addition to the existing footpath, a footpath and a separate parking space will be created. While the existing footpath can be used for walking or jogging, the other one can be used by retail users,” the official said.

The men’s gym will be renovated and fitted with synthetic rubber flooring. More equipment will be installed.

Another workout area for women and a children’s park will be set up near the State Judicial Academy. “Thus, mothers making use of the gym will be able to keep an eye on their children,” the official said. “The children’s park near the Government Arts College will be turned into an amphitheatre.”

All junctions under the project will be redesigned. “Table-top zebra crossings and pedestrian islands will be set up. Utilities including power lines and telecom cables will pass under the ground,” the official said. “Apart from maintaining green space along the road, more green space will be created. Designated space will be allotted to street vendors. Information boards, water fountains and shaded walkways will also be set up.”

Title: Grass on NH median catches fire, sparks concern in city
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Madurai: The grass on the median along the four-lane highway in Thanakkankulam near Thiruparankundram towards Samayanallur caught fire on Thursday. According to locals, it is an indication that as summer is approaching, the grass and shrubs on medians are prone to fire due to heat. However, the reason for Thursday’s fire is still unknown. “It may be a careless cigarette discarded by a driver,” said K Thirupathi of Thankkankulam, who had seen the fire.

On Thursday, a raging fire went on for several metres, on the median from Thanakkankulam towards Samayanallur, and locals who saw it doused it. Tree saplings and shrubs have been planted on the medians of the national highways (NH) under the Green Highways (Plantation and Maintenance) Policy of 2015.

The objectives of the policy is to reduce the impact of air pollution and dust, provide much needed shade on hot roads during summer, reduce the impact of increasing noise pollution caused due to increase in number of vehicles and arrest soil erosion at the embankment slopes. After rains last year, the trees and shrubs planted under the policy thrived.

The agency that is given the contract for planting the trees is also responsible for maintaining it also. They have to prune the trees and the grass. There are workers, who water the plants, with tankers and they also clean the medians sometimes.

“However, keeping the grass moist is important in the hot summer to prevent any major accident, due to fire on the medians,” said S Shanmugam, another witness to the fire.

Highway department sources said that the agency in-charge would have to comply with rules and ensure through proper maintenance that there are no such fires, failing which, action could be taken against them as per the conditions of the policy, which could be for non-compliance of the Forests (conservation) Act 1980.

Title: Good response to citizen’s survey in Madurai
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Madurai: With more than one week left for the nationwide Citizen’s Perception Survey to end, the Madurai Corporation has already achieved more than double the number of the target it had set. The survey is conducted by the Union ministry of housing and urban affairs (MoHUA) to rank 114 cities – 100 smart cities and 14 cities with more than one million population.

While the civic body had set a target of 10,615 by February 15, more than 23,500 people had taken part in the survey, which is 222% higher. The overwhelming participation by the city folk has helped the city to be featured among the top 10 cities in terms of best participation observed by the MoHUA. Madurai has shared 8th spot with Thane Corporation among the top 10 cities, Madurai Corporation officials said.

Surat emerged top and Salem secured got 5th position. Madurai and Salem, the only two cities in Tamil Nadu to have featured in top 10 list, made use of the participation and innovative ideas used by the cities to promote the survey.

“We thoroughly followed the information, education and communication mandated by the MoHUA and put of posters, hoardings, billboards across the city. ‘Namma Madurai’- our campaign was organized to sensitise and guide citizens in taking the survey,” said an official.

Officials said that various colleges and places, where people gather in large numbers were covered to create awareness on the survey. With one more week left for the survey, more people are expected to take part.

According to MoHUA, the survey is being conducted to directly capture citizen’s perception with respect to the quality of life in their cities.

Title: TN relaxes norms for new private law colleges
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Chennai: The Tamil Nadu government has relaxed norms to establish private self-financing law colleges.

Earlier, permission was given only if the college management was able to find the stipulated land — four acres to 10 acres — within 15 radius of a district court or sessions court. Finding such parcels of land is proving to be a costly affair for many people planning to start new law colleges. Now, the condition has been relaxed so that the land could be within 30km radius of a district court or sessions court.

The state law department issued orders in this regard on February 19, making amendments to the Tamil Nadu Establishment of Private Law Colleges (Regulation) Rules, 2018. Tamil Nadu had a blanket ban on private law schools till 2014. The rules, which were introduced in 2018, faced stiff from the DMK which opposed opening up law education to the private sector. Tamil Nadu law minister C V Shanmugham had countered that the amendments were more to regulate the existing institutions and not to encourage new ones.

Following the new rules, however, the number of private institutions in the field has increased from one in 2014 to 14 now. Many among them are deemed universities which offer law courses alongside other professional courses. At present, TN has the highest number of private law colleges in south India. Yet the number is less compared to some states such as Rajasthan, Gujarat, Haryana and Maharashtra.

“Further privatisation will affect the quality of judicial profession,” K Raja, former zonal secretary of Association of University Teachers (AUT) working at Trichy National Law School. Ten years ago, TN allowed private colleges to offer Bachelor of Education (BEd) and teacher training courses in diploma mode. Until then, BEd and diploma graduates were able to find teaching jobs. Now, hundreds of colleges produce graduates, but their quality is poor and not even one-tenth of those passing out finds jobs.

When the number of cases registered in TN is not going to increase much, there is no need to produce more lawyers, said Raja. There is not much scope for law graduates to get employed in private sector except for a handful corporates which recruit one or two legal advisors, he said. S Prabakaran, vice-chairman of the Bar Council of India (BCI), said that BCI recently imposed a three-year moratorium on approval of new colleges across the country and it shall be relaxed only if courts give a direction. But courts have expressed disappointment over opening of too many private law colleges.

Title: RTC workers’ union up in arms over allowing private buses to operate on select routes
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Vijayawada: A fresh problem is brewing in Andhra Pradesh State Road Transport Corporation (APSRTC) over allowing private buses and school buses into bus stations and to operate them on select routes. While the vice-chairman and managing director (VC&MD) of APSRTC justified the move, the workers’ unions have taken the issue up with the management.

The recognised workers union of APSRTC, Employees Union (EU), said in a statement on Friday that the decision has to be rolled back immediately in the interest of the corporation. “There is no other option for us other than taking the protest route if the management decides to go ahead with the decision,” said Palisetti Damodhar, general secretary of EU.

Madireddy Pratap, VC & MD of APSRTC, justified the proposal and said that allowing private buses was in the interest of passengers. He observed that Rs 12 to Rs 17 is being spent per kilometre by the state-run transport corporation on the buses. “APSRTC is not in a position to spend that much. To give better services to the passengers, we have held talks with private operators. Instead of forcing passengers to do a footboard journey, with limited resources of APSRTC, what was wrong in allowing private players to give better services?” he asked, while justifying the move.

However, the proposal is still in discussions and no decision was taken, Madireddy said, at a press conference.

Workers’ unions took serious objections to the comments and termed it as a unilateral decision.

Damodhar observed that on one hand the state government and the transport minister said that to ease the financial burden on APSRTC, all the employees were merged into the government and they do not have any intention to privatise neither buses nor bus routes. “However, the actions of the VC&MD are in contrary to the government promise and creating lot of confusion among workers,” he said.

Damodhar further alleged that since taking over the charge as vice-chairman and managing director, Madireddy is not willing to take up the issues of workers. “He is never available to us to speak over many pending issues because of which the problems are getting aggravated,” Damodhar said.

Title: Cash-strapped VMC to buy car for edu committee chairman
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Vadodara: The cash-strapped Vadodara Municipal Corporation (VMC) is set to dent its resources further by spending Rs 18.55 lakh to buy a car for the chairman of the municipal primary education committee.

The chairman of VMC’s school education committee, which operates 105 schools in the city, is eligible for an official car.

A proposal prepared for the procurement of the new car states that the chairman has to visit the schools in the city as well as travel to Ahmedabad and Gandhinagar for meetings.

The proposal adds that the present Toyota Innova that the chairman uses is a decade old and has already clocked 2.82lakh kilometres. Also it keeps requiring maintenance frequently and over Rs 6 lakh has already been spent on the maintenance of the vehicle.

The VMC will procure a new Toyota Innova Crysta for the chairman from a city-based dealer. Recently, the VMC has procured two similar model vehicles for the VMC mayor and deputy mayor.

Title: No need to conduct NRC exercise in TN: Seeman
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Madurai: The BJP government first ruined the Indian economy by introducing demonetisation and goods and services tax (GST), and now it has introduced the Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA) and National Register of Citizens (NRC) without worrying about the nosediving economy and the joblessness, Naam Tamilar Katchi (NTK) leader Seeman has said.

Addressing the anti-CAA protesters at Nelpettai and Mahaboobpalayam in Madurai on Friday, Seeman said, “There is no need to conduct NRC exercise or implement CAA in Tamil Nadu .”

He also visited the protesters at Sungam pallival, where a protest organized by the Madurai district Iykkiya Jamath, continued for the fifth day.

At Mahaboobpalayam, people from the Muslim community continued the protest for the eighth day on Friday. A large number of people from the community, with women outnumbering the men, took part in the protest. A large number of police personnel were deployed at both venues. TNN

Title: ART bill will ensure standardization of IVF, IUI protocols, say experts
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Coimbatore: Fertility specialists in the city said the effectiveness of the Assisted Reproductive Technology (ART) Regulation Bill, 2020 , which was passed by the Union cabinet two days ago, would depend on how well the health department implement the bill’s clauses. They, however , welcomed the move to regulate ART clinics.

Dr Kannagi Uthariraj, head of department of fertility and reproductive medicine at Kovai Medical Centre and Hospital, said, “The bill makes it mandatory for an infertility clinic to register with the state health department and submit paper work to show it has the required staff and infrastructure. It also requires them to document the type of cases that they treat, number of in vitro fertilization (IVF) and intrauterine insemination (IUI) they perform, and the success rate.”

According to Dr Mirudhubashini Govindarajan, clinical director, Motherhood by Women’s Centre, the bill would ensure standardization of IVF and IUI protocols and techniques and that they are performed only when required that too according to guidelines. “It will also ensure that no unnecessary or unproven techniques are forced on patients.”

At 164, Tamil Nadu boasts of the second highest number of fertility clinics and ART centres that are registered with the Indian Council of Medical Research (ICMR) in the country.

Fertility specialists said multiple issues could occur when couples approach infertility clinics that don’t follow the set rules and protocols. “We have come across cases in which clinics have implanted an embryo that was developed with third party egg and sperm without the couples’ consent. There are also cases in which clinics keep the couples in dark about the plan to use another man’s sperm or another woman’s egg for IVF till the last moment,” Dr Uthariraj said.

There are also infertility clinics that display fake credentials and staff that they do not have.

“The bill has clauses related to required staff and infrastructure that a clinic should have. It is a welcome move as there are clinics that operate with just consultant embryologist and andrologist, who visit the centre once in a week or so. You need a full-time embryologist to maintain the lab 24x7 for the best results. Otherwise, it’s a drain on the couple,” Dr Mirudhubashini said.

Gynecologists, meanwhile, welcomed the move to make insurance covers for egg donors mandatory and stop multiple embryo implantation. “Often, when we do embryo reduction after three of the four implants, it sometimes affects the healthy babies also. So, we are working towards a single embryo implantation, which through genetic testing has proven to be the best. The insurance cover for egg donors would help in preventing their exploitation,” said Dr Meenakshi Priya, fertility consultant at NOVA IVF Fertility.

However, the act has limitations too. “The act mandates submission of paperwork and consents, which clinics could cook up. It would work only if the doctor works with a conscience and clinics’ statements are crosschecked and inspected,” Dr Uthariraj said.

Pointing out that making the genetic testing of embryos mandatory may lead to sex selection issues, as results would reveal the gender, Dr Priya, said, “So, how the government will ensure sex determination does not happen along with genetic testing is yet to be seen.”

Title: Class XII students anxious over board, entrance exams
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Madurai: Class XII students who will be appearing for the state board exam seem to be worried over the entrance exams as they have to perform well in both to secure a seat in a college of their choice.

“Everyone used to say board exam marks will be used for counselling and getting a good seat in college. But now we have to do well in board and entrance exams, which is giving us so much pressure,” said Prithvi R, a Class XII student.

Like him, many Class XII students are questioning the need for them to sweat it out in board exam, especially, since in most cases they are forced to take subjects that will not make a big difference in their future choice of course.

Teachers and career counsellors point out that the main issue is that students need to approach board and competitive entrance exams, including NEET and JEE, in different ways. “Competitive exams demand a different approach as the questions are multiple choice and application oriented. These exams are based on both Class XI and XII syllabus while the board exams are based only on Class XII syllabus. Students cannot afford to pay less attention to board exams as the admissions to state engineering colleges is based on board exam scores,” said Senthilnathan M, president, private schools correspondents’ confederation.

The principal of a corporation school said that preparing for boards makes the students pause preparation for entrance exams. “It requires extraordinary hard work and luck to get success in both. We have to bet on a crash course for entrance exams after board exams for students to succeed,” said the teacher.

However, career counsellors said that children who are unsure of which career to pursue struggle with entrance exams, especially those from government schools and those who have scored less. “The pressure is immense because of the tough competition for getting seats these days. Those who would have scored well in board exams are not guaranteed to do well in entrance exams. Many go into depression as they find themselves unable to perform well in entrance exam. They and their parents do not understand the different scenarios,” said Nivethitha R, a counsellor based in Simmakkal.

Title: Protest is a right, says HC but allows Bhim Army meet only
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Nagpur: After asserting that protests make a safety valve for the society and are a fundamental right, the high court that rapped police for denying a permission to Dalit outfit Bhim Army to hold a meeting at Reshimbagh ground next to RSS’s Smruti Mandir campus has given it a go-ahead, but not for a protest. The permission comes with an express condition that there would be no protests at the site. The court has mentioned that the ground will be available only for the purpose of a workers’ meet as mentioned by the Bhim Army in its application. The meet will be held on Saturday.

The Reshimbagh ground, located right outside Smruti Mandir boundary wall, has also been the site of RSS functions like annual Vijayadashami event when a public meet is held to mark the organization’s foundation day. The meet is addressed by RSS sarsanghchalak (chief). The ground comes under Nagpur Improvement Trust (NIT).

The outfit’s petition against police’s denial to hold a meeting at Reshimbagh ground was heard by the division bench of Bombay high court’s Nagpur bench.

The court has now observed that the meet would be held between 2pm and 5pm, against the 10-hour permission sought by the organizers. The orders says, “The meet shall be for the avowed purpose of workers’ meet only as disclosed in the application. It shall not be converted into a public demonstration and protest.”

“The meet will not be used for political purposes. No inflammatory speeches or such speeches that would tend to incite violence or spread hatred among citizens or communal ill-feelings or which would lower down the dignity and reputation of citizens or prejudicially affect the integrity or sovereignty of the country shall be given in the meeting,” says the order.

Apart from internal issues, there was a possibility of raking up issues like opposition to National Register of Citizens (NRC) and Citizenship (Amendment) Act (CAA) during the meet. The Bhim Army founder Chandrashekhar Azad Ravan has been in the midst of controversies over protests against NRC-CAA and was also prevented from entering Delhi. He will now have to give an undertaking to abide by the conditions laid down by the court.

Bhim Army perhaps would be the only non-RSS outfit to hold a mass meet that can be deemed to be of political nature at the Reshimbagh ground at least in recent past. The organizers have sought permission for a gathering of over 10,000 persons.

One of the grounds for which police had denied permission was that both RSS and Bhim Army profess contradicting ideologies due to which holding a programme at Reshimbagh ground could have led to a law and order situation. The reasoning was seriously condemned by the court saying mere location or any other organization’s office nearby cannot be the reason for denial of permission to hold a meet.

Title: VMC drivers withdraw agitation
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Vadodara: Drivers roped in by the Vadodara Municipal Corporation (VMC) through contractors ended their strike after 24 hours of holding demonstrations at the civic body’s vehicle pool. The drivers have been assured that a meeting to discuss the possibility of absorbing them on VMC rolls will be discussed next week.

Representatives of the drivers said that the drivers stayed at the vehicle pool throughout Thursday night. Panic triggers were pressed as the VMC relies heavily on drivers for its vehicles as it has several vacancies of drivers that are not being filled up. It ropes in vendors to supply it drivers who drive vehicles from official cars to trucks and other heavy vehicles.

The drivers are demanding that they should be absorbed into service by VMC in the same way as the sanitation workers. After a meeting on Friday, the drivers were assured that their demands will be discussed towards the end of this month. The drivers were willing to wait till then and decided to withdraw the stir.

Title: Goa sets up fast track court for crimes against kids
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Representative image

PANAJI: The state government in concurrence with high court of Bombay has constituted a Fast Track Special Court (FTSC) at Panaji , for expeditious trial and disposal of rape cases registered under the Protection of Children from Sexual Offences ( POSCO ) Act, 2012.

The court will have jurisdiction across the state. The department of law and judiciary issued an order in this regard on Friday.

The FTSC has been constituted on direction of the Supreme court.

Title: 26 tigers ‘missing’ from Ranthambore, says Rajasthan MP
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

File photo of tiger from the Ranthambore sanctuary

JAIPUR: In a sharp blow to conservation, 26 tigers have been reported missing from the Ranthambore National Park (RNP) over a decade. The matter came to light after Diya Kumari , the member of National Tiger Conservation Authority (NTCA), on Wednesday wrote a letter to Union minister of environment and forest, Prakash Javadekar, requesting for a high-level inquiry to probe the missing tigers.

The letter dated February 19 (Wednesday) reads, “In a recent confidential report submitted to the state government, status of 116 tigers of Ranthambore National Park (RNP) is disturbing. It states that as many as 26 tigers are missing from the park.”

The MP also stated in her letter that the attitude of officials concerned and authorities of the park was "half-hearted and lackadaisical". “A national park is supposed to conserve the endangered animals and not lead to the decrease in their numbers,” she said in her letter. She also said the poachers must be identified, caught and strict action must be taken against them to prevent recurrence of such incidents. Chief wildlife warden, Arindam Tomar said, “These big cats have disappeared between 2012 to 2018. We are examining the cases one by one to trace the tigers. They are called missing, as their bodies were not recovered.”

According to sources, the forest administration at RNP has numbered 116 tigers, till date. It is claimed, since 2011, nine male tigers and 16 females tigers are missing from the park. According to the ‘missing tiger report’, 2017 was the last time when male tiger T-77 and tigress T-90 went missing. Sources said, “In past two years, no reports of missing tigers have surfaced.”

Wildlife activists have not ruled out poaching of these missing tigers, considering the national park’s history. There are many villages in close proximity of the region that pose a threat to the big cat. The nearby villages include Aanwad, Bhairoonpura, Laxmipura, Lasoda , Jetpur , Godal and Sawaiganj, among others.

Title: BJP guns for transport min’s head
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Jaipur: Rajastan BJP on Friday demanded resignation of transport minister Pratap Singh Khachariyawas on moral grounds following a corruption racket busted by the anti-corruption bureau in the transport department. BJP MLA from Malaviya Nagar Kalicharan Saraf put up 12 questions for CM Ashok Gehlot to answer related to the corruption case while seeking the resignation of Khachariyawas.

The questions include transport minister’s relations with arrested transporter Jaswant Yadav. “Who was collecting money from the agents? The sum of Rs 1.50 crore collected from the agents were to be delivered to whom?,” asked Saraf.

The ACB busted a racket involving transport department officials and middlemen allowing buses without permit in lieu of monthly bribe. The ACB kept eight transport officers and middlemen on watch for weeks before busting them and arresting one red handed with total of 1.50 crore cash.

Title: Min inspects site for new Ramnad MCH
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Madurai: Chief minister Edappadi K Palaniswami will lay the foundation stone for the construction of the newly-approved Ramanathapuram Government Medical College Hospital on March 1. As part of it, health minister C Vijayabaskar oversaw the preparations on Friday.

The minister inspected the site at the Ramanathapuram integrated district collector office campus accompanied by district collector K Veera Raghava Rao and other top district officials.

Speaking to reporters, the minister said, “In just one year, our CM has got permission from the Centre for constructing 11 medical colleges worth a total of Rs 3,575 crore.” tnn

Title: Government schools, degree colleges to introduce AI & robotics courses in Telangana
Content:
Picture used for representational purpose only

HYDERABAD: Artificial intelligence (AI) is set to take a centre stage during academic year 2020-21 with various educational institutions, including government minority schools, degree and engineering colleges, set to introduce dedicated curriculum on it.Speaking at the World Education Summit organised by Elets, a digital education platform, B Shafiullah, secretary of Telangana Minority Residential Education Institutions Society, said that they will be introducing AI and robotics as part of the curriculum in all minority schools from the ensuing academic year.“We will be introducing modules on artificial intelligence and robotics for which we have partnered with Indian Institute of Technology-Hyderabad and Duck Learning Labs (Singapore) to develop content that can be imparted to students,” said Shafiullah.The government is also planning to introduce new courses on artificial intelligence, data sciences and data analytics in degree colleges in the ensuing academic year. A committee has been constituted by the Telangana State Council of Higher Education (TSCHE) to look into the anomalies in introducing the new courses. Discussions are rife over introduction of bachelor of science courses into AI, machine learning, blockchain technology, data sciences, data analytics, etc.“On a pilot basis, these courses will first be introduced in government and autonomous degree colleges, following which we will extend them to other private colleges as well. These courses will be of 30 credits likely to be divided in six semesters,” said an official on the sidelines of the two-day summit.Given the errors in declaring results in the last academic year, the Telangana State Board of Intermediate Education (TSBIE) has decided to implement AI-based evaluation system from the academic year 2020-21.“The evaluation process will involve computer reading of OMR sheets and intelligent character recognition.
