After the OMR sheets are evaluated, the descriptive answer sheets will be scanned using ICR to verify marks allotted by each evaluator,” said Syed Omar Jaleel, chief executive officer and secretary of TSBIE, adding that in the final stage, AI will be deployed to check the accuracy of both OMR and ICR.Apart from this, TSBIE has decided to generate audio and video content for the curriculum which can be screened at virtual classrooms that the board intends to extend to 100 more colleges in the ensuing academic year. Currently, there are 64 colleges with virtual classrooms. “We have already tied up with Centurion University and Institute of Chartered Accountants of India to develop digital content for us,” said Jaleel.

Title: Students speak up for equality
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Madurai: College students of Madurai joined hands to highlight violence against women and the importance of gender equality through a special event held at Gandhi Museum on Friday. EKTA resource centre for women spearheaded the event organised as part of one billion rising (OBR), an eight-year-long global campaign to end violence against women.

Over 500 students from around 20 colleges, including department of communication, Madurai Kamaraj University, Madurai Institute of Social Sciences, and several non-governmental organisations (NGOs) took part. The event saw a procession by students, flying of balloons, and administration of the OBR oath against gender-based violence. Students raised slogans to end violence against women. “Violence against women prevails significantly in society. It is always an ongoing process to spread awareness and sensitise both men and women about gender equality ,” said Bimla C, director, EKTA resource centre for women. TNN

Title: Fire breaks out in bread factory in Doon
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

yyyyyyyyy

Dehradun: A major fire broke out in a bread factory during early morning hours of Friday in the Patel Nagar area of the city. According to fire department sources, the fire broke out on the second floor of the factory building from where seven workers were rescued by firemen. As many as nine vehicles and 18 firemen were deployed for the operation, which ran for nearly five hours.

The fire likely occurred due to the bursting of the LPG cylinders in the factory. “We got the information of the accident at around 3:30 am. Around seven LPG cylinders are believed to have blasted. We doused the flames from three different directions. Fortunately, the other LPG cylinders didn’t catch fire. The area had as many as 40 LPG cylinders. All seven rescued workers are unhurt. The operation lasted till 9 am,” said Ashish Guari, a fireman.

Title: 50-yr-old jailed for life for raping niece
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Kota: After a trial for nearly nine months, a POCSO court in Kota on Thursday sentenced a 50-year-old man to life in jail and fined him Rs 30,000 for raping his 9-year-old maternal niece at her house where he was staying as a guest in May 2019.

POCSO court-V in Kota sentenced the man under sections of IPC and POCSO acts, special public prosecutor, POCSO court-V Suresh Verma told on Friday. The convict, who is a government employee in the archaeological department and is the maternal uncle (Mama) of the minor survivor, was staying as a guest at her house in May 2019 following his transfer to Kota from Jaipur, Verma said. The convict, on the night of May 14, 2019, when the survivor’s mother, a government doctor, was on duty, he molested the minor and raped her, he added.

The minor survivor did not speak of the crime due to shame for a couple of days but eventually on May 18, 2019 she narrated her ordeal to her mother who rushed to R.K. Puram police station and lodged a complaint on May 19, 2019. Statements of at least 13 witnesses were recorded during the trial he added.

Title: Trump’s visit may give healthcare shot in arm
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

NEW DELHI: Healthcare is going to be an important focus area for PM Narendra Modi and President Donald Trump when they sit down for official talks on Tuesday. The two countries are likely to sign an MoU for strengthening cooperation on mental and emotional well-being, official sources said.

Another MoU on strengthening cooperation in the generic medicine regime is also expected to be signed.

The first MoU is expected to allow India to learn from US’ experience in a field marked by a serious lack of understanding here. It is also expected to facilitate a greater access for Indian traditional therapies and medicines to the large US market.

“In India there is a lack of understanding and caring for mental and emotional issues as health care issues, while in the US exists a strong culture of researching and treating mental and emotional well-being issues as health care issues. There is also a provision in this MoU to use traditional therapies and medicines to address mental well-being issues,’’ said a source on condition of anonymity.

On generic medicines, while US is home to one of the largest markets in the world, India is a large producer of generic drugs. The MoU is expected to allow India to learn from one of the most sophisticated and advanced regimes on food and drug protocols and, as a source said, improve access for India’s generics in the US market as well benefit Indian consumers by ensuring higher standards of generic drug standard compliance.

India and the US also have ongoing cooperation in cancer research, prevention, control, management and research and regular joint working group meetings are taking place on the same.

The two countries had signed an MoU for the establishment and operation of Global Disease Detection – India Centre [GDDIC] with the aim of strengthening the epidemiology and laboratory capacity in India. GDD – India Centre is operative since April 2011.

India has initiated the second round of the Global Adult Tobacco Survey in 2015-16 in technical partnership with the US government, sources said underlining the significance of ties with the US in the pharmaceutical sector. The Indian pharmaceutical industry is one of the largest in the world ranking third in terms of volume and 13th in terms of value. India accounts for 20% of global exports in generics and supplies about 50% of global demand for various vaccines, and about 40% of generic demand in the US.

Title: Nirogi Rajasthan in school textbooks soon, says Ashok Gehlot
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Ashok Gehlot

JAIPUR: Underlining the importance of Nirogi Rajasthan campaign, chief minister Ashok Gehlot has announced its inclusion in textbooks as part of a curriculum.

“Our aim is to spread information related to health under this campaign,” said Gehlot, while explaining the reason for including it in textbooks.

The announcement was made on Friday during the review meeting chaired by Gehlot on the campaign and the status of new medical colleges across the state. Sources told TOI that this campaign would be included in school textbooks like the way BJP government had introduced the Bhamashah scheme.

Gehlot boasted the campaign among the foremost schemes in the country dealing with preventive healthcare. “This campaign will motivate people to stay fit and to take the right medical care. Soon, we will launch a helpline which will provide health related information to people,” said Gehlot. The campaign was launched to mark the first anniversary of the Congress government in the state on December 17.

Divulging the details of the campaign, Gehlot said soon they would carry out a digital health survey of every individual in the state which include health related data. The survey will be carried out by ANM and the Asha workers.

He expressed confidence that the survey would pave the way for the success of the campaign and make Rajasthan healthy. Directing officials on how to make the campaign successful, Gehlot said they would make sure to provide health facilities to individuals at their doorstep.

“The government will seek help from Bhamashahs (donors), NGOs and civil society in developing the health centres,” said Gehlot. He also announced to start construction of new medical colleges before September. Taking cognisance of the complaints related to poor construction at Churu and Bharatpur medical colleges, Gehlot directed officials to investigate all complaints.

Title: Hyderabad: UIDAI changes tack on notice recipients, can appear any day
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

UIDAI had asked the recipients to depose before the IO on February 20

HYDERABAD: Apprehensive of unsavoury sequence of events leading to clashes and violence, UIDAI has now asked the recipients of notices to appear before the inquiry officer (IO) on any day before May 29 by submitting relevant documents.

Eighty seven residents in the Old City have been served notices to clarify on how they ended up in possession of Aadhaar cards .

Initially, UIDAI had asked the recipients to depose before the IO on February 20. Following an uproar from various quarters, including AIMIM chief Asaduddin Owaisi , UIDAI issued a release saying it had cancelled the Feb 20 deposition and instead gave time till May 20 to the recipients.

However, on Friday, UIDAI came up with another relaxation. “Instead of one particular day of inquiry, those who have received the notices can go to the UIDAI office on any day with the documents before May 29,” a senior official said.

Highly-placed sources said the state police had warned the UIDAI authorities about the probability of a clash and violence if the inquiry were to be conducted in a particular function hall in the city.

“It is in this backdrop, UIDAI has decided to change its decision,” sources said.

Officials said they would ask the recipients to correct their documents if there were errors. “If there are no irregularities, the recipients need not worry as their Aadhaar cards will be continued,” officials said.

The inquiry itself is a tedious process since UIDAI had destroyed the hard copies of the all the documents submitted by the residents during the enrolment drive. For document verification, there is an internal procedure from a designated authority within the UIDAI, officials said.

Once investigation of documents is done and if the complicity of operators at the time of enrolment is found, UIDAI will file police complaints. “If the operators are found to have goofed up during enrolment in issuing the Aadhaar cards, the errant staff will be arrested,” an official said.

Meanwhile, officials said notices were meant to be served on 127 residents. While they had been issued to 87 residents, for 40 others the notices are yet to be served.

Title: After days of clear weather, rain, snow lash several parts of U’khand
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Nainital Witnesses Season’s Sixth Snowfall, Char Dham Shrines, Dhanaulti Also Under White Cover

Dehradun/Nainital/Uttarkashi/Mussoorie/Pithoragarh: After several days of clear weather, the weather took a turn in Uttarakhand as several districts, including Dehradun , Nainital , Udham Singh Nagar, Bageshwar and Champawat, were lashed by rain , hail , and snow .

The plain areas of the state started receiving rainfall around Thursday midnight. Simultaneously, the upper reaches of Nainital witnessed snowfall and so did Dhanaulti near Mussoorie , Munsyari in Kumaon as well as the Char Dham shrine towns.

State capital Dehradun started receiving rainfall from Thursday late night and the spell continued till Friday morning. The precipitation brought down the minimum temperature of the city to 12 degrees Celsius and the maximum temperature to 21 degrees Celsius on Friday. “There was heavy thunderstorm on Thursday night which continued till Friday morning. For the next two days, there won’t be any rainfall in the plains. Hills can receive light-to-moderate rainfall. Skies will get clear again from Monday,” said Bikram Singh, director of the regional meteorological department.

In Nainital district, Cheena Peak and Kilbury got wrapped in a snow blanket while hail was reported at Snow View Point and Birds Eye View Point. “The snowfall started at around midnight and continued till early morning. The roads to Cheena Peak and Kilbury were covered in snow. Mall Road and the other lower regions received hail stones,” said Amar Shukla, a Nainital resident.

The rainfall and the strong winds also caused high waves in the Naini lake. While the tourists enjoyed this sudden change in weather conditions in the lake town, the low-lying areas in the plains of the district got waterlogged forcing many to remain indoors.

The higher reaches around Mussoorie, including Dhanaulti, also received around three inches of snow. “Intermittent snowfall started at around 4 am and continued till around 10 am on Friday,” Devendra Belwal, a Dhanaulti resident, said. Surkanda Devi Peak also got covered in eight-to-ten inches deep snow.

Upper Himalayan regions, including Badrinath, Kedarnath, Gangotri and Yamunotri, also received fresh spell of snowfall. Rain disrupted traffic movements at several places in the region. “The condition of Gangotri National Highway, which was already in bad shape due to the ongoing all-weather road construction works, worsened due to rainfall,” said a local resident.

In Pithoragarh , rain and snowfall disrupted daily life and vehicular movement was halted on Tanakpur-Pithoragarh road after a landslide at Swala in Champawat district.

Kalamuni in Munsyari got covered in four-inch-deep snow. Kailash Mansarowar route in Dharchula tehsil had to be shut for vehicles due to snowfall. Thal-Munsyari Road also got blocked due to road damage at Balik. The weather conditions also disrupted Maha Shivratri celebrations in the region.

Title: Blood sample of Madurai man tests negative for Covid-19
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Blood sample of a 47-year-old man, admitted to the Covid-19 isolation ward in Government Rajaji Hospital (GRH) in Madurai, tested negative for coronavirus infection , district health officials said on Friday. The blood sample was sent to King Institute of Preventive Medicine in Chennai.

“We don’t have any cause for alarm now. We will be treating him like a regular patient now for his breathing difficulty and respiratory illness,” said GRH dean Dr J Sangumani. Health officials said the man’s health was improving and he would soon be shifted to the general ward. The man was admitted to the COVID-19 isolation ward on Wednesday evening with symptoms of wheezing, which doctors had said indicated asthma. Since the man had recently returned from Singapore, his sample was sent for testing and he was admitted to the isolation ward only as a precaution.

Meanwhile, health officials have urged the public not to panic at any time and to keep practising hand and cough hygiene. “There is no cause for concern in Madurai. The monitoring of home quarantined persons and screening processes at Madurai airport continue,” said a senior health official. tnn

Title: Bengaluru: Wanted to convey we are patriots too, Amulya Leona Noronha tells police
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Amulya detained by police as she raised Pro Pakistan Slogan at anti-CAA event in Bengaluru

BENGALURU: Amulya Leona Noronha , 19, who was arrested on Thursday for raising pro-Pakistan slogans in Bengaluru, has told police that, in her speech, she had wanted to compare the silence that greets her reference to the neighbouring country with the applause that follows ‘ Hindustan zindabad ’ but she her speech was cut short and she was whisked away.

“I wanted to convey the message that people against CAA and NRC are being labelled anti-nationals and asked to go to Pakistan. I wanted to prove that we too are patriots by comparing the responses to Pakistan Zindabad and Hindustan Zindabad slogans,” Amulya, a II year BA student of NMKRV College, was quoted as saying in her statement to the police.

Booked for sedition, Amulya was produced before a magistrate late on Thursday. She has been remanded to judicial custody for 14 days. A bail petition filed on her behalf was adjourned to Monday.

Police said a team led by assistant commissioner of police, Chickpet, has been formed to check Amulya’s antecedents. “We will investigate her contacts, associates and what motivated her to raise slogans,” police said.

Amulya told police she was involved in many protests including against global warming, corruption and other social issues in the past. However, recent incidents including the killing of journalist-activist Gauri Lankesh and attacks on students prompted her to participate in protests against CAA, she told police.

Explaining what really transpired, Amulya told police, “I began my speech saying Pakistan Zindabad thrice and Hindustan Zindabad. Enraged, organisers tried to snatch the mike from me. I asked them to allow me to convey what I wanted to say, but they refused. After they snatched the mike, I told them, ‘I said Pakistan Zindabad and Hindustan zindabad but the difference between these two is...’ but organisers, police and Owaisi stopped me abruptly and police took me away. Though I demanded that I be allowed to conclude my speech they did not allow me,” she told police.

Title: Woman in US loses husband and delivers baby in 24 hours
Tamil Nadu: Woman held with 8kg marijuana
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Representative image

COIMBATORE: Police on Friday arrested a 37-year-old woman and seized 8kg of marijuana (ganja) from her at Gandhipuram in the city.

Mubeena, of Arul Nagar at Kannappa Nagar, was nabbed while she was smuggling the contraband from Visakhapatnam in Andhra Pradesh to the city.

Acting on a tip, Rathinapuri (law&order) police inspector M Deivasigamani said Mubeena was intercepted by a special team when she reached Gandhipuram bus stand.

On interrogation, police found the consignment in her possession.

Mubeena, wife of Anwar Basha, told police that she had separated from her husband. To run her family and taking care of her two sons, she started to sell marijuana, police said. She used to buy marijuana from whole-sellers in Visakhapatnam.

Mubeena was taken to the Rathinapuri police station with the help of women cops. She was arrested and produced before a court.

Later, she was remanded in judicial custody.

Title: Rituals, fasts, prayers mark Shivaratri
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Vijayawada: Chants of ‘Om Namah Shivaay’ reverberated across the city on Friday on the occasion of Mahashivaratri . After completing a holy dip in the Krishna River at the three main bathing ghats, pilgrims thronged to the nearest Shiva temples.

The old Shiva temple in One Town area and the Malleswara Swamy shrine atop the Indrakeeladri hill not only saw the most number of devotees visiting but also had the most happening events. From performing special pujas to cows, to abhishekams offered to the Shiva Lingas, the atmosphere at the temples was charged with religious fervour.

Lakhs of devotees thronged the temples from the early hours of the morning, with several waiting to witness the Shiva-Parvati Kalyanam (marriage) which was organised by Sri Durga Mallesewara Swami temple authorities. A mass abhishekam for Lord Shiva took place at the Mahamandapam. Officials said that new clothes were presented for the Shiva-Parvati Kalyanam at the Magabahula Ekadasi Tidhi. Not surprisingly, the Durga Ghat was marginally more crowded than the Punnami and Ferry Ghats.

On the other hand, devotees waited patiently in queues for darshan at the Sri Ramalingeswara Swami temple in Yanamalakuduru. Fervent Shiva Bhakts cherished the visual feast of Prabha Mahotsavam at Yanamalakuduru temple. Later, temple authorities conducted a massive procession across Bandar Road.

Cops made elaborate arrangements and diverted traffic flowing through out the Hyderabad highway to make way for the processions. At least 13 different processions were reported to the police across the city in the evening. On the downside, the price for fruits and flowers soared with the demand increasing steeply on account of the festival. The fruit and flower markets in the city witnessed a heavy rush since the eve of the festival, giving vendors a brisk business.

“Business is always good during Mahashivaratri, as most devotees fast during the day and prefer to have fruits. Even though the demand is high and the prices too witness a spike, our margins are pretty much the same,” K Srinivas Rao, a fruit vendor explained.

Title: Hyderabad: ‘Shaheen Bagh’ like protest in Old City after Friday prayers
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Students participate in a protest organised against CAA, NRC and NPR on Friday

CHARMINAR: Scores of men, women and children staged a ‘ Shaheen Bagh’ like protest at Jamal Banda Barkas against Citizenship (Amendment) Act (CAA), National Population Register (NPR) and National Register of Citizens (NRC) on Friday. The protesters raised anti-government slogans and demanded immediate rollback of CAA , NPR and NRC.

“Several people are joining the protest and we want to convey a strong and clear message to chief minister K Chandrasekhar Rao to put a stay on the proposed NPR exercise in the state immediately,” said Shiraz Khan, a protester.

Women protesters said that though they were not given permission by the police to organise a protest meet, they will still continue with the protest.

The police has repeatedly denied permission to TS & AP Joint Action Committee (JAC) for holding women’s protest meet in Hyderabad.

Several people joined the protest organised at Barkas eidgah ground as well as outside mosques at Mehdipatnam and Vijay Nagar Colony after the Friday prayers .

Syed Mohsin, another protester, said, “People need to unite against CAA, NPR and NRC and should not wait for anybody’s call to join the protest. People from all communities have to stand up and raise their voice against the controversial laws.”

The agitators made it clear that they would not step back till their demands are met.

Title: Thrashing of Dalits: Congress, BJP leaders meet Nagaur victims
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Union minister Arjun Meghwal interacts with family members of victims

JAIPUR: Union minister Arjun Ram Meghwal on Friday demanded the resignation of chief minister Ashok Gehlot while he visited Dalit youths brutally thrashed and abused in Nagaur a few days ago.

The incident has brought a political storm in the state as a battery of political leaders from various parties, including the BJP, the Congress and the Rastriya Loktanrik Party reached Nagaur as a part of fact-finding teams constituted by their respective parties.

The Nagaur police investigating the assault case of Dalit youths on Friday said that they were in a process of identifying a few more persons who were involved in thrashing the youths.

Police said that they were on a mode to identify some persons who were spotted in the video that went viral.

Police so far have arrested seven persons for the brutal assault and abuse in this case so far. However, the incident has triggered a war of words among political leaders.

An inquiry committee formed by BJP led by Union minister Arjunram Meghwal met the families of the Dalit youths and also talked to them on the incident.

“Law and order has deteriorated in Rajasthan since Ashok Gehlot led government came into power. This incident has crossed all the limits of Dalit oppression. If there is any morality left in the Congress party, chief minister Ashok Gehlot should resign,” he said while talking to the newsmen.

Questioning the functioning of Nagaur police, he said, “They should have acted promptly after the information of Dalit youths beaten badly, stripped and faced inhuman act.”

He demanded security and compensation for the family of victims. BJP team took information from the police, administrative officials, victims and villagers.

Meanwhile, members of committee formed by the Pradesh Congress Committee (PCC) also reached Nagaur. This included state’s social justice minister Bhawanralal Meghwal, MLA Harish Meena and other leaders. These leaders also met the victimized youth and assured a fair investigation.

“We assure fair justice to the youths who have faced atrocity and have urged the police not to spare a single person,” Bhanwarlal Meghwal said.

MLA Narayan Beniwal of RLP and party workers also met the victims. Beniwal assured the victims and family members of all possible help. He also started a sit-in Dharna at Khinvsar.

“Victims and their families should be provided security and compensation. Strict action required against the guilty policemen who have shown utter negligence in handling the case,” he added.

Title: NU promoting non-existent student cells on new-look portal
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Nagpur: The revamped online portal of Nagpur University (NU) is promoting various facilities for overall development and assistance of students, even as these schemes have either stopped functioning or disbanded for want of funds several years ago.

Among such facility links on the new portal are foreign students cell, research activities, equal opportunity cell, career and counselling cell. Professors who were part of these cells blamed students for bringing the facilities to a standstill. They say students would go for high cost professional training and assistance outside, and don’t care for ‘free of cost’ university facilities.

Students welfare and development director Abhay Mudgal said, “We have been trying to initiate all-round development programmes for students with focus on soft skills and career counselling. There are also initiatives on stress and time management for students,” he said.

NU sources said the department has been taking the initiative of reviving the cells and different forums for students, but it received a poor response from professors coordinating these activities.

Among the plans to activate the dormant cells by December 31 was publishing a manual for students. The deadline for this has now been extended till March 31. An audit of the schemes too was done but its handbook is still not ready, they said.

“The handbook will have crucial information for students, especially those with disabilities, about schemes and facilities for them,” sources said.

Mudgal said as per Section 56 of the Universities Act, it is mandatory to have programmes for overall development of students. “Efforts are on to make more information available to students,” he said.

Slamming the university, senate member and students’ leader Manmohan Bajpai said he had realized the issue of website and incomplete details on it during the previous senate meeting last year. “I would be taking it up during this senate meeting on March 6 too. Bungalows and international hostel are lying idle, even the PG hostel warden’s bungalow is lying empty. These places can be utilized for students welfare,” he said.

On the training, career and counselling cells, Bajpai said the university must fund and keep these cells running. “A committee was formed, of which I was a part too. We had recommended that such cells must be kept open but the finance section said it can’t allocate funds,” he said.

Regarding students’ reluctance, Bajpai said several students complained to him about not finding any details anywhere in the university. “Unless they know, how would students enrol. Such unaware and untrained students going out bring a bad name to the university,” he said.

Title: Coaching centre owner arrested for role in forest guard exam cheating
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

yyyyyyyyyyyyyyyy

Roorkee: Haridwar police on Friday arrested Mukesh Saini, 42, a coaching centre owner from Gurukul Narsan in Haridwar district, who had allegedly been involved in providing solutions of competitive examination papers to aspirants through Bluetooth devices during exams. Saini, a retired Army jawan, had reportedly been involved in helping aspirants in this manner in the recently-conducted forest guard examination held on February 16.

Saini’s name had cropped up in the forest guard exam matter when an aspirant registered a complaint with Manglaur police that Saini had assured to get him passed in the written examination and had taken Rs one lakh in advance from him against a total agreed sum of Rs 5 lakh. When Saini did not appear at the examination centre on February 16 for his help, the disappointed job-seeker approached police. Haridwar SSP Senthil Avoodai K Raj said that the police have also identified seven other fraudsters apart from Saini. One of these, the police said, runs a coaching centre in Roorkee, like Saini, whose coaching centre is at Gurukul Narsan.

The SSP added that “the accused Mukesh Saini is a habitual offender who has been jail in the years 2016 and 2018 as well for his role in facilitating mass copying in different government job examinations.”

Title: Amulya Leona Noronha had links to Naxals: Karnataka CM
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Karnataka CM BS Yediyurappa

MYSURU/BENGALURU: Within 12 hours of 19-year-old Amulya Leona Noronha being arrested on charges of sedition, chief minister BS Yediyurappa said investigations conducted overnight indicated the girl had an “association” with Naxals .

“Preliminary investigation has revealed that she [Amulya] had links with Naxal organisations in the past,” Yediyurappa said in Mysuru. In the same breath, Yediyurappa went on to add Amulya was also a “victim” of certain vested groups who are “instigating” youngsters. “If we don’t act decisively, it won’t end. The government will deal sternly with organisations which are brainwashing youths,” the CM said, without naming any organisation.

Congress urged the government to hand out stringent punishment to Amulya, while Former chief minister HD Kumaraswamy of the JD(S) also condemned Amulya’s act and said organisers of events should be careful about such people. “The fact that organisers snatched the mike from her immediately after she raised slogans shows they were unaware of her intentions.”

Ballari BJP MLA G Somasekhar Reddy urged the Centre and the state governments to deport people raising anti-national slogans to Pakistan. He also said Hindus need less than five minutes to show MP Asaduddin Owaisi his place. “The organisation of Owaisi says they want 15 minutes to finish off Hindus. But we don’t 15 minutes. Just five minutes will do,” he said.

DK Shivakumar of the Congress in the morning differed with his party colleagues’ views and said the teenager was trying to clarify her statement, but was not given an opportunity on stage. “I have seen several other speeches of hers but could not find anything [wrong],” the former minister said. However, with his comment attracting a lot of negative publicity, Shivakumar, in a tweet in the afternoon, said he will “never defend any person including Amulya” if they have made anti-national speeches.

Title: Central Jail facing demolition for IMS, yet gets new infra works
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Nagpur: Even as the 150-acre Nagpur Central Jail is soon slated to make way for an Inter-Modal Station (IMS) at Ajni, the state home department is approving infrastructure and developmental works there worth crores and meant to last next 50 years or more.

City MP and Union minister Nitin Gadkari had proposed Inter-Modal Station (IMS) on entire 150 acre land of Central Jail two years ago. Nagpur Metropolitan Region Development Authority (NMRDA) has also reserved 150 acres to shift the Central Jail to mouza Chincholi and Babulkheda in Kamptee tehsil.

The home department issued a notification on Thursday giving administrative approval to spend Rs1.20 crore for development of new hanging yard in the Central Jail. “Existing hanging yard is very old and in shambles. Additional general of prisons, Pune, has suggested the work. Accordingly, state’s public works department (PWD) prepared the proposal,” the notification stated.

Sources from Central Jail and PWD told TOI the existing hanging yard was constructed in the British era. The yard does not have the facility for post mortem and offices. The new yard has been proposed on the lines of the hanging yard at Pune’s Yerwada Jail.

The proposed work has raised a big question as the Central Jail us supposed to be acquired by the National Highways Authority of India (NHAI) for IMS. On September 22, 2017, the then CM Devendra Fadnavis had announced plans to shift Central Jail out of city. In February 2019, Gadkari got approved Rs1,000 crore for IMS and performed bhoomipuja in March 2019.

Costing Rs2,277 crore, IMS will come up in sprawling 490 acre land, including 150 acre of Central Jail.

A NHAI official said, “We will require Central Jail for IMS phase-II. The project has been approved considering land available by shifting Central Jail. At present, we are concentrating on phase-I, which will come up on Central Railway land,” he said.

The new hanging yard costing Rs1.20 crore will have a life of 50 years or more.

Also, the Central Jail does not witness frequent hanging cases. Wankhede Brothers from Amravati were hanged here in 1984. After a gap of 31 years, 1993 Mumbai bomb blast convict Yakub Menon was hanged on July 30, 2015. Since then, no one has been hanged here.

The PWD has also started renovation and expansion of the kitchen in Central Jail for which funds were approved by District Planning Committee (DPC). A few months ago, the home department had given administrative approval for construction of eight new barracks, which is set to begin soon.

Central Jail SP Anup Kumar Kumare said approved works and some in the pipeline are necessary for Central Jail so government sanctioned funds. “We have no intimation from government about shifting of jail from here to new place as on date. Proposal of new hanging yard was submitted a year ago. We are proposing whatever works are necessary for the jail as a regular practice. It is up to the government to approve,” he said.

For the new jail, NMRDA had reserved 150 acre land in Metro Region, that does not need to be acquired as the entire land is owned by the state government. However, the government is yet to begin the process to shift the Central Jail even on paper, creating confusion and leading to wastage of public money.

Title: 2L devotees at Kotappakonda
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Narasaraopet: Devotees thronged the famous Shiva temple atop Kotappakonda in Guntur district on the occasion of Mahasivarathri on Friday.

Pilgrims from Krishna, Guntur, Prakasam districts and neighbouring Telangana districts reached the hilltop temple in the early hours of the morning to go for darshan. The queues were packed with pilgrims, which included women and children. Sources said that more than 2 lakh pilgrims had visited the temple by late on Friday night and the number might touch 5 lakh by Saturday morning, as darshan would continue through the night with a brief break.

The district administration made elaborate arrangements to ensure smooth darshan for the people. The district administration set up special tents at the bottom of the Kotappakonda hill and provided all required assistance to the pilgrims. With farmers content with the yield and prices during the current season, the turnout was more than expected.

Deputy speaker Kona Raghupathi, government whip Pinnelli Ramakrishna Reddy, local legislator Dr Gopireddy Srinivasa Reddy, Narasaraopet MP Lavu Srikrishnadeva Rayalu were among those who visited the Lord in the first hour of Friday. Interestingly, most of the VIPs were seen taking the common darshan queue, to avoid inconveniencing the general public.

Rural District SP Ch Vijaya Rao camped at Kotappakonda and monitored security arrangements. Nearly 2,500 police personnel, including senior officials, were deployed at various points to avoid any untoward incidents. With the pilgrim rush is expected to continue throughout the night, the police kept close vigil on suspected anti-social elements. The police also directed organisers of electric chariots to avoid obscene dances on the chariots.

Senior officials from Andhra Pradesh Central Power Distribution Company were also camped in the temple premises to attend to emergencies. The discom made arrangements for uninterrupted power supply in the area.

Meanwhile, areas which have prominent Shiva temples including Amaravati, Satrasala and Daida also witnessed a heavy pilgrim turnout. Devotees were seen taking holy dip in river Krishna at bathing ghats in Amaravati before going for darshan.

Title: Industry welcomes bid to set up textile park
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Coimbatore: The confederation of Indian textile industry (Citi) has welcomed the ministry of textiles’ announcement to set up a mega textile park in Tamil Nadu’s western region.

The park is expected to help stakeholders scale up operation to meet global demand. Citi said the park will enable the powerloom sector and other decentralized sectors to consolidate in different clusters and start affording modern technology. Scaling up operations will also help them compete with countries like Bangladesh and Vietnam that had entered the sector recently.

Citi chairman T Rajkumar issued a statement on Friday, appreciating the initiative to encourage scale of operations through the mega textile park scheme. “The flagship technology upgradation fund scheme (TUFS), has already attracted over Rs 4 lakh-crore during the last two decades. The scheme for integrated textile parks will enable decentralized sectors to consolidate in clusters and go for modern technology,” he said.

Textiles secretary Ravi Capoor had met industry stakeholders to discuss and get inputs for framing the scheme on February 17. Citi also welcomed textile minister Smriti Irani’s efforts to formulate the new textile policy expected to be announced this year.

Title: Salem bus accident: Death toll touches 7
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

SALEM: The death toll in the accident involving pilgrims from Nepal rose to seven in the early hours of Friday when a 60-year-old critically injured breathed his last at the Government Mohan Kumaramangalam Medical College and Hospital in the city.

Police identified the deceased as Rashi Lal Chaudhuri. Police said they were taking efforts to shift the bodies to Coimbatore or Chennai and then airlift them to Nepal. The state government seems to have assured to bear the cost of transportation.

Meanwhile, a few relatives of the deceased arrived in the city from Nepal on Friday. They met senior police officers, who assured them that the government would help them take the bodies back home.

The accident took place in the early hours of Thursday when the bus carrying 35 Nepali tourists collided with an omnibus coming in from the opposite direction near Omalur in Salem .

In another development, a minibus on trial run caught fire, sparking flutter in Salem on Friday. Police said that Madhesh from Ammapettai had bought the used minibus from Bengaluru and had brought it to Salem a few days ago. After fixing the faulty parts, he got driver Mahesh to drive it towards the regional transport office. When the bus was nearing Sivankaradu on Chennai-Salem highway, the vehicle caught fire. Mahesh jumped out of the bus and escaped unhurt. However, the entire bus went up in flames.

Title: Water sources in Ernakulam rural areas are set to go dry: KWA
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

People depending on water sources such as bore wells and wells could be worst affected by rising temperatures.

KOCHI: Rising mercury levels are expected to leave rural areas of Ernakulam parched . The state water authority is worried that residents who depend on standalone water supply schemes, bore wells, wells and other similar resources will be worst affected as the district heads for a drought-like situation.

“These sources will dry up, and people will be forced to depend on water provided by KWA . The real challenge before the authority will be to ensure enough drinking water supply to these areas,” said assistant executive engineer Shyju Thadathil.

KWA currently provides 225mn litres per day (MLD) of water from Aluva treatment plant and 100 MLD from Maradu treatment plant. Despite the intense temperatures, there is adequate water in Periyar and Muvattupuzha rivers, which feed these plants. “The urban areas of Ernakulam, including Kochi corporation and suburbs, are dependent on water supply from these two plants, where supply is constant,” he said.

However, KWA is yet to get a clear picture on increased demand in rural areas. Sources said discussions are being held at various levels on drought-mitigation measures that need to be put in place.

Meanwhile, officials at the Aluva plant said the number of tanker trucks arriving at filling points has dropped considerably. “During the last two days just 12-13 tanker trucks came to filling points,” said a KWA official, adding that the trucks might be taking advantage of the relaxations with regard to sourcing water.

There are 12 filling points attached to the Aluva plant.

Water tankers have also been cleared to draw water from sources with an FBO licence. The water from these sources are sent to government or NABL-accredited for testing and certified. The testing has to be done once every six months. “So, tankers could now be depending on other authorised sources for water,” the official said. He said the treatment plant at Aluva can share 10 MLD water with tanker trips and can serve 800 to 900 trips.

The Maradu plant has 13 filling points and according to KWA they service around 180 tanker trucks every day. The plant can provide water to 500 tanker trucks a day. “Though the number of trucks at Aluva plant has declined, this is not the case at Maradu,” said an official.

Title: Maha Rudrabhishekam at Srisailam
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Tirupati: Spiritual fervour was all pervasive as lakhs of devotees queued up at the Lord Shiva temples at Srisailam in Kurnool district and Srikalahasti in Chittoor district, to celebrate Mahasivrathri on Friday. Other Shiva temples in Rayalaseema districts also witnessed similar turnouts.

Sivaratri festivities began around midnight at the Srisailam temple with the Mangalavadyam and other daily rituals. As lakhs of devotees continued to throng to the temple—the sacred abode of Lord Mallikarjuna Swamy and goddess Brahmarambika Devi—Andhra Pradesh state endowments minister Vellampalli Srinivas accompanied by Srisailam MLA Shilpa Chakrapani Reddy, and other officials, inspected several places across the temple town and closely monitored the increasing influx of devotees.

The main attraction of the Mahasivaratri celebrations at the Srisailam temple is the Lingodhbhava Maha Rudrabhishekam where 11 priests conduct rituals for three hours after 10 pm.

The family of Pridvi Venkateswarlu from Prakasam district donates the cloth every year. The Sivaratri celebrations concluded with the Kalyanotsavam performed around midnight.

Similarly, thousands of devotees took part in the festivities observed at the Srikalahasteeswara swamy temple at Srikalahasti in Chittoor district.

TTD’s Kapileswara swamy temple in Tirupati also witnessed a heavy influx of devotees throughout the day, where the annual Brahmotsavams festival is also under way.

Title: File cheating case against tribal dept officials: HC
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Aurangabad: The Aurangabad bench of the Bombay high court recently directed that offences be registered against the tribal development department officials concerned for misappropriation of lakhs of rupees under the pretext of buying books for the tribal boys and girls, who stay in the divisional level hostels in Aurangabad.

The bench comprising Justices T V Nalawade and M G Sewelikar directed registration of “offences punishable under Sections 420, 468, 471, 409, 120-B, 34 etc. of the IPC and other sections, if the police find that the crime needs, to be registered.’’

The petitioner, Shaikh Hussain Dadabhai of Shirsgaon in Shrirampur taluka of Ahmednagar district, had approached the high court through lawyer Saeed Shaikh seeking directions to the authorities concerned and the police to take action and register offences against various tribal development department officials for fraud and cheating.

Lawyer Saeed Shaikh said that the petitioner had earlier approached different departments against bogus purchase of books for hostels for years 2016-17 and 2017-18 and irregularities in food supply. “When they didn’t act, he approached the high court, which had also appointed court commissioner to ascertain the allegations,” he said.

The state government and different officials of the tribal development department, including wardens and project officers and the police officials at Aurangabad, were respondents to the case. “The allegations were in respect of mainly two activities - purchase of books for hostels and under the tribal development department for the years 2016-17 and 2017-18 and irregularities in respect of diet and food supply.”

While partly allowing the petition, the HC bench observed “there are specific allegations in respect of irregularities noticed in purchase of books and complaint was already given to the tribal development department, the revenue department, the director general of police and the director general of anti-corruption bureau. The complaints were given to the authorities supervising the government hostels created for tribal students in Aurangabad.”

The court said it had appointed court commissioner to inquire into the allegations involving the purchase of books to tune of lakhs of rupees.

The court observed “on the basis of inspection made, the court commissioner came to the conclusion that the persons working in the hostel were not able to show that the books were actually purchased as per the bills.’’

It further observed “the aforesaid circumstances support the allegations made by the petitioner. The circumstances have created probability that the books were actually not purchased, but false record of purchase of books was created and the money, which was made available, is misappropriated. In view of these circumstances, this court holds that direction needs to be given to the police station concerned to register the crime and make investigation into the allegations.”

Title: Forest guard recruitments mired in controversy since start
Content: Dehradun: The recruitment of forest guards in Uttarakhand —for which 1218 vacancies were announced in 2017, the first time since the state was formed in 2000 — has been mired in controversy right from the beginning. Soon after the vacancies were advertised in August 2017 by the Uttarakhand Subordinate Service Selection Commission (UKSSSC), forest minister Harak Singh Rawat had the recruitment process stopped demanding that the age limit of candidates be increased to 28 years and the eligibility clause of having a qualification in either Science or Agriculture removed as most of the hill youth were not educated in science and therefore would not be eligible or these jobs. This, the minsiter said, had been told to him by many aspirants from the hills.A cabinet meeting was thereafter called and on May 28, 2018, the amendment in the eligibility criteria was done as per the forest minister’s demand. In July 2018, the forest guard posts were once again advertised and around 1.56 lakh candidates applied for the posts.Meanwhile, the daily wage workers of forest department approached the high court demanding either a stay on the recruitment process or ensuring a quota for workers who had been working in the forest department since a long time so that they get absorbed as forest guards. Even though their demand was rejected by the court, the recruitment got delayed again.The UKSSSC again started the process of recruitment in which it stated that before the written test, a physical test of candidates will be conducted. This was considered ‘impractical’ by forest officials who suggested that the written test be conducted before the physical test.Again, a cabinet meeting was called in August 2019 to make changes in the test process, recruitment advertisements were again published and eventually a written test was held this month across 376 centres in the state.However, one of the candidates uploaded a picture of his OMR (Optical Mark Recognition) answersheet on social media, triggering controversy regarding possible cheating and irregularities in the examination.Forest minister Harak Singh Rawat, when queried by TOI on Friday regarding the controversies surrounding the examination, said, “The special investigation team ( SIT) is probing the matter. Whether the examinations will be declared null or void or not would depend on their findings. Once we know the facts, we will be in a position to take the next decision.”

Title: Student ends her life after former friend demands Rs 50k
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Nagpur: Mahima Rane, 21, a second year student, committed suicide at her residence at PWS quarters, KDK College road, by consuming poison on February 18 after which family members came across a recorded conversation in her cell phone in which her former male friend was heard threatening the victim to cough up Rs 50,000.

She was declared dead at government medical college and hospital on Thursday.

The family plans to hand over the recording to Nandanvan police to register an offence against the male friend. The victim’s parents also found a torn picture of the male friend at the room where she stayed.

Rane, the elder of two siblings, had eloped with the male friend a few years ago but returned the following day. Her family had lodged a complaint at Nandanvan police station.

Sources said that Rane had distanced herself from the male friend but the audio recording in her cell phone has now stunned her kin.

Rane’s father Gurudutta, a tea seller, said that his daughter was alone at home when she consumed some insecticide. “My daughter had alerted a neighbour on the cell phone after consuming the poison. She was rushed to a private hospital by the neighbours who had later alerted me too. We had later taken her to GMCH where she was declared brought dead,” he said.

“I unofficially made an officer listen to the recorded conversation at the police station. In the recording, my daughter was being repeatedly threatened and abused,” said the aggrieved father.

Nandanvan police have so far registered a case of accidental death.

Title: Bootlegger kills self after police surround him
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Representative image

JAIPUR: A 38-year-old man allegedly involved in selling Indian Made Foreign Liquor (IMFL) committed suicide after being surrounded by police at Surpura village near Shahpura on the National Highway-8 late on Thursday evening.

According to police, acting on a tip off that illegal IMFL is been sold at a room situated at Surpura village under Shahpura police station area.

“Our team rushed to the spot and cordoned off the area while the accused locked himself inside a liquor shop. We kept asking the accused identified as Rajendra alias Raju to surrender,” said Shankar Dutt Sharma , superintendent of police (Rural) told TOI.

Police team was surprised while Rajendra suddenly announced that he has consumed poison. “Initially, our team thought he lying since he was left with no option other than to surrender. However, he came out and was gasping and started vomiting,” said a senior police officer.

While the police kept asking the accused to come out so that he could be taken to the hospital, he came out at 11.15pm.

“The deceased was involved in illegal selling of IMFL. He was earlier arrested in a case of illegal smuggling of liquor on January 8 and we have three cases pending against him at Shahpura,” said Gyanchand Yadav , ASP, Jaipur (Rural).

Title: Kedarnath doors to open on April 29
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Portals of the Kedarnath shrine — which is currently closed for winter — would open at 6.10am on April 29.

DEHRADUN: On the occasion of Maha Shivratri on Friday, it was formally announced that the portals of the Kedarnath shrine — which is currently closed for winter — would open at 6.10am on April 29. The decision was taken in a meeting of the Badri Kedar Temple Committee (BKTC) at Shri Omkareshwar temple at Ukhimath.

Chairperson of BKTC Mohan Prasad Thapiliyal along with Kedarnath MLA Manoj Rawat and CEO of BKTC BD Singh were present in the meeting. It was announced that the palanquin of the deity would leave Omkareshwar temple on April 26 after a prayer ceremony. The night’s halt would be at Gaurikund on April 27 and on the evening of April 28, the palanquin would reach Kedarnath. After a prayer ceremony, the portals would be thrown open to devotees in the morning hours of April 29.

It has already been announced that the portals of Badrinath shrine would open at 4.30 am on April 30. The decision was taken in a meeting on the occasion of Basant Panchami on January 29. The portals of Gangotri and Yamunotri would be opened on Akshay Tritiya on April 26, but the time is yet to be finalised.

Last year saw a record turnout of pilgrims and there was a significant rise in numbers in comparison to 2018. Char Dham Yatra and Hemkund Sahib saw a total pilgrim footfall of 34.10 lakh last year, as per state government estimates. Badrinath saw maximum devotee turnout with 11.74 lakh pilgrims, Kedarnath witnessed 10.02 lakh pilgrims while 5.30 lakh paid obeisance at Gangotri and Yamunotri shrines, as per the estimates.

Title: Census India-2021: Each enumerator to cover 600-800 people
Content:
Picture used for representational purpose only

HYDERABAD: As part of the 16th Indian Census, which will be taken up in 2021 through a mobile phone application, each field-level enumerator will cover about 600 to 800 people in about 150 houses. The Census, which will begin on April 1, will follow a four-tier system.Training for the first tier Group 1 officers is complete, while enumerators are yet to be identified. Enumerators will seek information of mobile number of the head of the family, information related to toilets, TV, Internet, vehicles owned, source of drinking water, besides asking other questions during the house listing phase of the exercise. In a first, Census India-2021 will move away from the traditional pen and paper and will be conducted through a mobile phone application.In the first tier, those who take up the exercise will be called master trainers, who are mostly group I officers. Each district will have one or two master trainers. The Census officials have asked the state government to depute only those officers who will not retire by 2021. District officials have already sent the revenue maps of mandals and villages to the Census department.Next-level officials are field trainers, who are mostly headmasters, higher-level teaching staff and statistical officers and GHMC staffers. These officials will train supervisors, who form part of the third tier. Supervisors, in turn, will monitor the ground-level enumerators. Supervisors are mostly teachers working in district and mandal level.The ground-level enumerators are those who are junior teachers. Officials said enumeration would be divided after taking into account the workload in 559 revenue mandals of the state. While Delhi will roll out the National Population Register (NPR) on April 1, it is learnt that unlike Census, NPR updating process will not happen on the same day across India. Telangana is yet to announce the dates.

Title: Removed 93/121 illegal shrines: NMC informs HC
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Nagpur: Responding to the judiciary’s directives on removing city’s illegal religious structures, the Nagpur Municipal Corporation (NMC) informed that it had demolished 93 out of 121, which were identified by the District Level Committee and placed in ‘B’ category.

A division bench comprising justices Ravi Deshpande and Amit Borkar then adjourned the hearing a plea (WP No 6177/2006) till next week. It was filed by social workers Dr Gajanan Zade and Manohar Khorgade through counsel Firdos Mirza, praying for removal of encroachments, including religious structures, pandals, stages, statues and others from roads, pavements and public utility places.

In an affidavit filed in the Nagpur bench of Bombay high court as per its directives of January 29, the civic body informed that remaining 19/121 structures came under the jurisdiction of different authorities like Nagpur Improvement trust (NIT), South-Eastern Central Railway (SECR), Central Railway (CR) and Nazul among others. “Those structures should be removed by respective authorities. In nine other cases, stay is granted by HC and it’s in operation as on today,” the NMC said, adding that it had complied with the HC’s directives.

The NIT also submitted its affidavit as per the HC directives stating that 25 such unauthorized religious structures standing on public land came under its jurisdiction. “We’ve already demolished all such structures on roads, pavements, footpath along with those on the public land and open spaces, as identified by the NMC’s committee. We’ve also removed the debris left after the demolition of those structures from time to time,” NIT said.

NIT informed that State Urban Development Department had issued a notification on August 27, 2019, through which its seven schemes were transferred to NMC.

Earlier, the NMC informed that Laxmi Nagar Zone has 24 unauthorized structures of which 21 were razed and the debris was removed. One came under NIT’s jurisdiction while HC had granted a stay in two other cases. In Dharampeth Zone, 52 such structures were identified and of them 48 were removed while four received stay from the HC.

About 14 such structures fall under the Mangalwari Zone of which four were removed. Out of remaining 10, there is HC stay in one case while nine are under Indian Railway’s jurisdiction. The NMC had already informed the railways and also offered required machinery to remove them. In Hanuman Nagar Zone, out of eight such structures, six were razed in remaining two cases there is a court stay.

Title: Railway minister gives in-principle approval for Delhi-Doon Tejas train
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Chief minister Trivendra Singh Rawat in a meeting with Union minister of railways Piyush Goyal

Dehradun: Union minister for railways Piyush Goyal has given an in-principle approval for a Tejas train on the Dehradun-Hariwdar-Delhi route. This was communicated by the railway minister to chief minister Trivendra Singh Rawat in a meeting in New Delhi on Friday. A communique from the CM ’s office said that the railway minister assured that the Tejas train will commence as soon as a pathway is made available for it.

Goyal added that for the upcoming Kumbh in 2021, preparations would be made by the railways on the lines of the Prayagraj Kumbh. Regarding the Rishikesh-Karnaprayag rail project, Goyal said that innovative works would be done on this ambitious rail project that will connect the plains of Garhwal with the hills.

On the modernisation of Dehradun railway station, the railway minister said that the work would be completed by November this year.

Earlier in the meeting, Rawat informed Goyal about the current progress of the Rishikesh-Karnaprayag railway line. He said that under the 126-km project, the change of forest land to non-forest land has been approved and added that 167 hectares of private revenue land has been acquired.

“Geo Technical Investigation has also been completed for the project. A road under-bridge and a road over-bridge have been prepared, which have been opened for regular traffic,” he said.

The CM also requested the railway minister to approve the new railway lines of Lalkua-Khatima, Tanakpur-Bageshwar and Kashipur-Dhampur. He said that the above three railway lines have great importance from the development and strategic point of view of the mountainous region. He requested that the Lalkuan-Shaktipharm-Sitarganj-Khatima new rail project be approved and be funded by the Centre. Rawat said that to speed up the pace of economic development in Pithoragarh and Bageshwar region, the Tanakpur-Bageshwar rail line was critical. He also requested the Centre to bear the total cost of the new railway line from Kashipur to Dhampur via Jaspur, the communique from the CM’s office said.

Title: Giriraj: India paying price for failing to send Muslims to Pak
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

NEW DELHI/PATNA: Just about a week after he was pulled up by BJP president J P Nadda for his remark that the Deoband seminary was a “Gangotri” of terrorism, animal husbandry minister Giriraj Singh kicked up a fresh row saying the country was paying the price for its failure to send Muslims to Pakistan.

The minister said greater effort should have been made to bring Hindus to India after the Islamic state of Pakistan came into being at the time of Independence. The BJP MP from Begusarai made the remark in Purnea district which has a sizeable Muslim population while canvassing for the Citizenship (Amendment) Act.

Though BJP did not offer any comment immediately, Singh’s remarks once again puts it in an embarrassing position. After the recent loss in the Delhi assembly polls, home minister Amit Shah had disapproved of inflammatory speeches by some of his party colleagues.

On CAA, Singh highlighted the need for such a legislation and said, “When our forefathers were fighting for independence from British rule, Jinnah was pushing for creation of an Islamic state. Our forefathers, however, committed a mistake. Had they ensured that all our Muslim brothers were sent to Pakistan and Hindus brought here, the need for such a move (CAA) would not have arisen. This did not happen and we have paid a heavy price for it.”

Title: Rs 2,000cr to reboot power distribution network
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

In the first phase that will be completed by April 1, 2021, as many as 16 districts have been included in the ... Read More

JAIPUR: Snakebites, wild animal attacks and family life disorders are common for farmers as they go out in the night to irrigate their fields. But these difficulties will be a thing of past if the Budget proposals for providing power during day time get implemented over the next three years.

Chief minister Ashok Gehlot on Thursday announced an ambitious Rs 2,000-crore plan to reboot the power distribution network and enhance the capacity of the existing infrastructure to make day power a reality for farmers.

Gehlot laid out a three-phase timeline with number of districts in each one and said by April 2023, 13 lakh farmers in all the districts able to get day power. In the first phase that would be completed by April 1, 2021, 16 districts have been included in the plan. Five districts have been included in second phase that would be completed by April 2022, while third phase will have 13 districts. “This requires a huge capacity enhancement in transmission and distribution network and putting up new grid sub-stations (GSS). But the benefits to farmers will be invaluable. The chief minister has announced a time-bound programme, breaking down the number of districts in each phase. We are quite confident to achieve the target by April 1, 2023,” said Ajitabh Sharma , principal secretary, energy department. The government has estimated the requirement of 6 new GSS of 220 kv, 30 GSS of 132 kv, 287 GSS of 33 kv so that additional power load can be supplied to the households of farmers.

But Sharma said while the day power would be met through the conventional power, the solar energy will be utilised to reduce the load on peak hour power. “During day time, power consumption is high. But we will tap solar power though Kusum scheme so that demand for thermal power gets reduced,” said Sharma.

Sources said the government would need to spend more for giving peak hour power to farmers. “There will be a small burden on the government to provide peak hour power to farmers but the benefits for farmers outweigh the extra cost,” he said.

Title: ‘Excessive’ tree cutting at district court irks lawyers
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Nagpur: Many city lawyers are outraged over ‘excessive’ cutting/trimming of trees on district court premises which happened when the court was closed on account of Mahashivratri on Friday.

Photos of chopped mature tree branches went viral in various lawyers’ WhatsApp groups leading to many seeking answers.

Advocate Prakash Jaiswal was part of the team which had planted these trees way back in 2009. “Around hundred trees were planted and these were from the same lot. They had grown beautifully and their height was till our fourth floor. Today, they have been stripped bare,” said Jaiswal.

Advocate Ranjan Deshpande said on one hand huge awareness is being created about saving trees and then such a “thing happens on the court premises itself”.

Though permission had been sought from the civic body for trimming of trees, its officials accepted that the people who carried out the work had exceeded their brief.

Amol Chorpagar, garden superintendent, Nagpur Municipal Corporation (NMC), said, “Specific permission was given only for the trimming of the trees and it is ridiculous that the cutting has happened to this level. We will enquire into the matter and take action.”

Advocate Kalyani Deshpande, who is amicus curiae in a tree felling related PIL, said that she will approach the high court over Friday’s incident. “There is a difference between cutting and trimming of trees and that this should be taken into consideration,” said Deshpande.

Advocate Nitin Deshmukh, secretary of District Bar Association, however, felt that things were getting overplayed. “The fire department conducted a survey and found that access to court buildings was an obstacle which would have increased chances of a mishap. Due to this, the decision of trimming the trees was taken. No uprooting of trees has occurred,” said Deshmukh.

(Reporting by

Shwetal Kothari)

Title: Nagpur Metro station shops finding takers
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Nagpur: Even though ridership of Nagpur Metro may not be impressive, the commercial space in its stations is finding takers. This may help in increasing the ridership. A Metro official said that so far, eleven commercial spaces have been either leased or bids were received for them.

A coaching class has started at the Institution of Engineers Metro station. Metro officials are very pleased as many students use Metro to commute to the class.

Other than this, Naivedyam Group has leased a shop at Lokmanya Nagar Metro station. A bid has been received for a shop in Institution of Engineers, two for Rani Jhansi Square station, one for Subhash Nagar and Lokmanya Nagar each. Mother Dairy has purchased three shops in Jai Prakash Nagar, Khapri and Airport stations. Another bid has been received for a shop in Jai Prakash Nagar.

The shops have been leased for nine years. The rent is on per square feet basis and depends on the location of the station.

Metro’s biggest commercial realty project is the traffic and transport management centre (TTMC) opposite Yeshwant Stadium. It will have a 25 storey tower and two 19 storey ones. The TTMC will be connected to Sitabuldi station with a foot overbridge.

Metro had floated bids for constructing the project on public private partnership (PPP) basis but did not get good response due to slump in realty. It has now prepared a new revenue model for constructing it.

MahaMetro plans to earn more than 50% revenue through non-ticket sources. Most of this will come from rentals of commercial space and sale of commercial and residential space. These projects are, however, years away. Many of them are yet to be designed. The slump in the real estate sector has delayed the plans of the agency.

Meanwhile, co-branding of Metro stations is getting good response from private companies. The last date to submit bids is February 25 and the exact number will be known after that. Under this scheme, a Metro station will have the name of the private agency that pays royalty to MahaMetro.

Title: Amulya was naive, but sedition too harsh a charge: Student-activists
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Organisers snatched the mike from Amulya Leona Noronha before she could complete her speech at the anti-CAA ra... Read More

BENGALURU: Student-activists admit 19-year-old Amulya Leona Noronha ’s chant at an anti-Citizenship Amendment Act rally on Thursday was "naïve and tactless" but said her actions did not warrant such a hard charge as sedition to be filed against her.

In a statement on social media platforms, activists labelled her ‘Pakistan Zindabad’ chant "callous, ill-intentioned and careless". They also clarified Amulya is neither their spokesperson nor leader and they were unaware of the contents of her speech. They said her slogans discredited efforts of students and youth in maintaining peaceful dissent.

In another post, a student activist also questioned the organisers for washing their hands of Amulya, although she had a speaker’s badge and a VVIP entry tag. "It is clear that the generation that gave us this country will not protect us from its atrocities," the statement read.

Samreen Banu, a student, said irrespective of what Amulya’s intention was, she should have been sensitive to sentiments of people. "Why was Pakistan even mentioned at a protest against CAA?" she asked. Teresa Braggs, another student-activist, said, "We admit it was irresponsible and tactless of her to begin her speech in that fashion. If that is all she had to say, we condemn it. But we also don’t condone slapping arbitrary and draconian charges like sedition on protesters. She was not allowed to finish her speech and was manhandled by men."

Mariyam Saigal, a poet and student, said she does not support the slogan or any country that oppresses its people on grounds of religion.

"I’m in India because I want to live in a secular nation, not an Islamist state or a Hindu Rashtriya or any extremist country. But can’t we have the maturity to forgive a kid for her naive statement?" she said.

Mariyam said the way Amulya began her speech was "immature", but the manner in which it was cut short was "unfortunate" too. "Many men have harassed Amulya. We are so concerned about what a woman said rather than the violence that follows. We hold student protesters accountable for such petty things, but there are much bigger issues and we don’t hold the government to the same standard."

Zia Nomani of Hum Bharath Ke Log said Amulya had quit the group on January 20 and that she should have started the speech differently. "The theatric performances proved to be unfortunate. She could have started the speech with ‘Nepal Zindabad’ or ‘Sri Lanka Zindabad’ instead of this. There is a way and place to speak things and people can pick other platforms to speak what they want. This is about our fight against CAA, NRC and NPR. We need to stick to the agenda."

Title: 1% hike in stamp duty to pinch home buyers
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Representative image

JAIPUR: Buying houses will be dearer as the state government has proposed to increase stamp duty on registration of property by 1%. Though the state government decided to slash the district-level committee (DLC) rates by 10%, realtors believe this would not provide a big relief as these rates were increased by 20 to 25 % six months ago.

Currently, the state government levies 5% stamp duty from men and 4% from women on property including 1% registration fee. Increase in 1% on the registry would burn a hole in the pocket of buyers.

A developer explained that if a man plans to purchase a Rs 1-crore property, he has to pay Rs 6 lakh and Rs 60,000 surcharge (1% of the total registration charge). Even if the DLC is decreased by 10%, a man will end up paying more. “Now buyers have to pay total 7% on the value of 90 lakh, which is Rs 6.30 lakh. On this amount, 1% surcharged will be imposed. The consumer will be end up paying 33,000 extra,” explained a developer.

Developers alleged that at a time when the real estate market was facing a slowdown in the state, successive governments increased the rates from 15% to 30% since 2014. “Imposing 1% additional stamp duty will discourage buyers. The government has actually not done much for the realty,” said Ankur Tiwari, a developer.

Gehlot announced that stamp duty on land patta issued by state government and local bodies will be calculated on the amount taken for patta instead of district lease committee (DLC) rates or market price.

“The move will encourage plot owners who are escaping from taking lease deeds. Also it is expected to provide many small plot owners who will be exempted from paying stamp duty as per hefty DLC rates,” said Manoj Agarwal , a plot owner.

Title: Kerala: Nearly 60 have lucky escape as Ro-Ro, tourist boat collide
Content:
A video grab shows a Ro-Ro vessel pushing a private tourist boat at the Kochi sea mouth on Friday afternoon. A... Read More

KOCHI: A tragedy was averted on Friday after a roll on-roll off (Ro-Ro) ferry service vessel, operating between Fort Kochi and Vypeen, collided with a boat carrying tourists on a sight-seeing trip. In videos, which went viral, the Ro-Ro vessel could be seen pushing the boat a fair distance after the collision.Both vessels were not speeding, and this proved to be the saving grace. Around 30 persons were on each of the vessels. Both sets of operators have filed a complaint with police.“The Ro-Ro driver seems to have not seen the boat while backing up. However, another allegation is the tourist boat came out of nowhere into the Ro-Ro’s path as it set off from Fort Kochi. We will conduct an investigation to find out what exactly happened,” said an officer with Fort Kochi police.Sources said the tourists were taking pictures when the incident happened. The boat sustained damages but left the scene soon after, sources said. The Ro-Ro had come in contact with the lower portion of the boat and the tourists were on the upper deck, they said.Sources with the Kerala Shipping and Inland Navigation Corporation said the Ro-Ro vessel also sustained minor damages.“We have registered a case under Section 280 (rash navigation of vessel) of the IPC and begun a probe,” said a police officer.In Video: Kerala: Nearly 60 have lucky escape as ferry, tourist boat collide

Title: Mangaluru: QR code scamsters can empty your bank balance
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

In 2019, Mangaluru city cyber police station registered about 600 FIRs, and an equal number of non-cognizable ... Read More

MANGALURU: The city is witnessing a rise in the number of QR code scams . They have the potential to wipe your account clean. A quick response code is similar to a bar code, which is an image that can be read by a machine.

Last week, an electronic shop in the central business district area received a call, and the caller addressed himself as an officer in the Indian Army . He then booked a refrigerator and said that he would make the payment for it through a digital wallet platform.

After obtaining the digital wallet number, he transferred a small amount, to gain the trust of the dealer. Later, the conman called the shop and said that he has sent a QR code to scan, to the shopkeeper’s WhatsApp number, which will help him to make the remaining payment, and the same will be credited to the account. When the shopkeeper scanned the same, all the money from his bank account got transferred to the conman’s account.

“Such incidents are on the rise in Mangaluru . People easily believe it when the person calling introduces themselves as personnel of the Indian Army. In reality, these are conmen with a new modus operandi of conning people, especially those who run shops and restaurants,” said an official from the city cyber police station, on condition of anonymity.

Such cases are increasing every day, and were first reported from December last year. “The cases of QR code scams are on the rise in the city, and in the past three months, city cyber police have registered more than 100 cases,” said a source, adding that all the victims are shopkeepers involved in various business activities.

Due to the QR code scam, victims are losing money, anywhere between Rs 25,000 and Rs 50,000 or more. Apart from it, such fraudsters are active in the online market place. The conmen claim to be Indian Army personnel. “A woman, who put up some household things on sale online, too was a victim of the QR Code scam,” added a cyber police official. Such incidents take place mostly on weekends or public holidays, where banks remain closed.

In 2019, Mangaluru city cyber police station registered about 600 FIRs, and an equal number of non-cognizable reports related to various cybercrimes in the city.

Title: Nagpur RTE seats oversubscribed by 300% as 20,010 apply for 6,797 seats
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Nagpur: Even though February 29 is the last date to apply for free seats under the Right to Education (RTE) Act, they have already been over subscribed by 300% in Nagpur, a trend which the district has witnessed for the last couple of years.

The irony is that despite being over subscribed a couple of times over, every year seats go vacant. While this may very well happen again this year, another problem looming is the boycott of RTE admissions by many schools over reimbursement issues. For the 6,797 seats, the state education department has already received 20,010 applications.

Education officials say the irony is a result of parents wanting admission is specific schools. An official, who did not wish to be identified said, “The prospect of getting free education in a specific school is obviously a more lucrative option. So the big brand English medium schools are the preferred choice and if their ward’s name does not figure in the final list, they simply back out.” The official said there was currently no system in place to know in which non-RTE schools these parents then take admissions.

The ‘boycott’ is not reflecting on the application portal as the state education department has automatically entered all schools in the lottery pool. The face off will happen after the lottery is declared and schools refuse to complete admission formalities.

Independent English Schools Association (IESA) has already decided to stay away from the admission process and will soon be putting up notices on their premises announcing the same.

Rajendra Dayma, president of IESA had told TOI during an earlier interaction that this year their association will take a tough stance. “There are many schools who have not got any reimbursement till date citing some or the other reason. Some have been handed part of their claim and are being strung along for the remainder. We take a strong exception this kind of tactic,” said Dayma.

Around 32 children in rural area to get transportation aid

In rural areas where students do not have access to primary school within the specified 1km distance, the government will provide financial aid for transportation to the nearest available school.
