The government is yet to finalise the DPR for the coaching hub which will give a push to this scheme.

Title: Teacher in Pocso case innocent, reiterate kin
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Kottayam: The relatives and friends of Narendra Babu , the music teacher who committed suicide after being an accused in POCSO case , still maintain that the case was framed against him and he was innocent .

The music teacher had written a very detailed suicide note along with complaint letters to the district collector, magistrate and the SP. The relatives hope that the police will initiate a probe based on the letter’s content.

Anil, a relative of the deceased said that they will wait for a couple of days for the police to initiate action. “We will move legally if there is no action by police,” he said. Meanwhile, Vaikom CI said that they will probe the issues raised by Babu in the letter.

Babu, 51, an Arattukulangara native, was found hanging from a tree near his house in the premises of a volleyball court, on Thursday morning. He was a music teacher in an Ettumanur school. Several handwritten papers were pinned on to the net of the volleyball court in which he had explained his innocence. He had also displayed the complaint by the students.

“He was unable to face people after serving 45 days in jail. He was a popular artist,” said Anil. Three school staff, including a woman, were behind framing him as an accused, he added.

None of the complaints by 14 students and two parents had anything to do with sexual abuse, Anil said. The woman was instrumental in making the students file complaints, he added.

“The complaints were strange: the teacher calling one student ‘chetta’ (elder brother) always, catching hold by the collar of the shirt, laying his palm over that of the student while using a computer mouse, making one student sing in class always, raising one of the eyebrow, etc,” said Anil.

Title: 25kg ganja seized, three peddlers arrested in Hyderabad
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Picture used for representational purpose only

HYDERABAD: Excise sleuths arrested three peddlers and seized 25kg ganja worth Rs 6.5 lakh from their possession on Friday.

The accused have been identified as Talwade Basava (26) of Mangalhat, Kureel Vishal (28) and Kureel Vijay (28) of Katendan.

Acting on specific information, excise sleuths kept a watch at Moghul Ka Nala, and seized 1kg ganja and a scooter from Basava.

During the interrogation, Basava revealed the names of his gang members, Vishal and Vijay. Sleuths then raided a house in Laxmiguda in Katendan and seized 24.9kg ganja, concealed in four bags, from Vishal and Vijay. They also seized a Skoda car used for transporting ganja. Also seized were four cellphones and an electronic weighing machine.

Vishal and Vijay are habitual offenders. According to excise officials, Vishal has been maintaining a group of employees stationed at Gachibowli, Madhapur, Sheikpet, Attapur and Tolichowki, who will deliver ganja to customers. “Vishal receives calls from customers and as per his instructions, delivery guys handover ganja to customers and collect money,” Assistant Excise Superintendant N Anji Reddy said. The accused have been selling 30 grams of ganja for Rs1,000.

Title: Maharashtra: Satara residents to protest toll at Anewadi
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Representative image

PUNE: Satara residents will take out a protest march on Sunday to demand toll exemption for Satara-registered vehicles (MH11) at Anewadi toll plaza.

The protest comes days after Union minister for road transport and highways Nitin Gadkari announced toll exemption for MH12 (Pune) and MH14 (Pimpri Chinchwad) registered vehicles at the Khed Shivapur toll plaza along the Pune-Satara highway.

The residents will start the protest march from Powai Naka to Anewadi toll plaza at 10am on Sunday. “We are seeking exemption for MH11 and MH50 (Karad) vehicles at this toll plaza. Besides, our demands include construction of public toilets at 10km distance each as well as completion of the highway,” Satara resident Jay Shedge said.

Pavanjit Mane, who has been spearheading the movement for completion of work along the highway, said, “Leaders from Pune availed exemption at Khed Shivapur due to poor roads and incomplete bridges. We are also facing the same problems. We have communicated with the district collector about completion of work along the highway. They have improved road condition but the work is pending. We will reach out to Union minister Gadkari soon,” he said.

Title: ITI students get vocational training
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Aurangabad: As many as 30 students of the Government Industrial Training Institute (ITI) took part in the three-day training organised from February 20 in which they learnt the operations of a numerical control (CNC) machine.

The multi-phased training has been facilitated by the government and private stakeholders. It will help students secure jobs in local industries.

The Marathwada Association for Small Scale Industries and Agriculture (Massia) skill development centre in association with German government initiative ‘Deutsche Gesellschaft für Internationale Zusammenarbeit GmbH’ or GIZ organises skill trainings to bridge skill gap for developing employable manpower.

The three-day industrial training is provided by technical centre established by Ace Micromatic Group at Waluj. A total of 30 youths learning turner trade at the government ITI campus are undergoing the training. Mandar Mahajan, head of Ace technical centre, said it is first phase of orientation training.

“In the future, as part of the second phase, selected students will undergo three weeks of training in CNC operation and programming theory and training,” he said.

Title: Madhya Pradesh: Mentally disturbed man plays doctor in hospital, prescribes pills
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Representative image

BHOPAL: A mentally disturbed man sat in a doctor’s chair on finding it unoccupied at a civil hospital in MP’s Chhattarpur on Wednesday, ‘checked’ patients and even scribbled outlandish prescriptions for half an hour before he was caught out. Questioned by the civil surgeon, he advised him to “see a psychiatrist” instead, and even wrote down a prescription.

“An inquiry has been ordered to find out how the man posed as a doctor undetected for so long,” minister in charge of Chhattarpur, Brajendra Singh Rathore, said. He hasn’t been identified yet.

The impostor was roaming around the Civil Hospital on Wednesday afternoon when he saw the chamber of mental health programme vacant and promptly took the doctor’s chair. The doctor posted in the room was assigned some other duty so it was vacant, civil surgeon R S Tripathi said.

Soon enough, patients trickled in and ‘doctor sahib’ began checking them. One of the patients, Bhalloo Yadav, said: “I peeped into the room and found a doctor sitting in the chair. I told him I had fever and body-ache. He spoke like a doctor and did not give any impression that he was mentally disturbed.”

Yadav said he showed him the parcha or OPD slip. “He examined me exactly like a doctor and scribbled some medicines,” he said.

At least half a dozen patients consulted the doctor and walked away with prescriptions. In the medical store, hospital employee Anoop Shukla grew alarmed on seeing the bizarre prescriptions, written in red ink.

He asked one of the patients where the doctor who checked them was sitting, and sprinted there. One look at the ‘doctor’, and he ran pell-mell to get senior officials and the security.

The impostor was removed from the room. Civil surgeon Dr Tripathi said, “ No one knows his name. After he was removed from the chamber, I interacted with him and immediately realized that the man needs psychiatric help. He, in turn, asked me to see a psychiatrist and left my room. He even prescribed some medicines for me before leaving.”

Title: 5 killed in jeep-state bus collision
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Kolhapur: Five people were killed and six injured when the jeep they were travelling in collided with a state bus on the Solapur-Barshi road on Friday morning.

While four of the deceased were killed on the spot, the fifth person succumbed to his injuries while being taken to the hospital. The six injured are undergoing treatment at a hospital. All of them were employees of Barshi Taluka Panchayat Samiti.

Solapur rural police said that around 12 employees of the panchayat samiti were going to Solapur to attend a meeting of a small savings group when the jeep they were travelling in collided with a Maharashtra State Road Transport Corporation (MSRTC) bus around 10.15am. The jeep was badly damaged in the mishap.

Residents here said that the accident took place when the jeep driver tried to manoeuvre a pothole on the road. The residents further said that the Shelgaon-Raleras road, where the accident happened, was pockmarked with big potholes and needed resurfacing.

Title: Kashi-Mahakal Express chugs off with Shiva chants, songs & selfies
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Indore: Chanting ‘Jai Shri Mahakal’ and ‘Har-Har Mahadev’, 450 passengers began their journey to Varanasi from Indore on Kashi-Mahakal Express that started from Island Platform on Friday morning.

The third private luxury train of Indian Railways Catering and Tourism Corporation (IRCTC) with nine AC-3 Class coaches departed from Indore at 10.55am after it was flagged off by Indore MP Shankar Lalwani on the occasion of Mahashivratri. The train is scheduled to reach Varanasi at 05.00am on Saturday.

“It was a long-pending demand of people to have a direct train service between two Jyotirlingas - Ujjain and Varanasi. On our request, the train was extended to Indore which will provide connectivity to third Jyotirlinga in Omkareshwar,” said Lalwani.

On being asked about reserving a seat for Lord Mahakal, he said that the seat has been vacated for passengers, and the deity has been placed in pantry car coach. “The train will also provide direct connectivity for those who wish to travel to Lucknow, Kanpur etc.,” he added.

Like its pre-inaugural run, a religious band was there with its members all decked up in traditional attire with Malwi Pagdi, and this added to the fervor prompting many passengers including elderly join, play and sing with the band.

A huge crowd had also gathered at the station to attend commercial inauguration of this ‘holy train’, and it will be operating tri-weekly between Varanasi and Indore, bi-weekly via Kanpur and Lucknow, and a weekly service via Kanpur and Allahabad.

During the course of its journey, the train will halt at Ujjain, Sant Hirdaramnagar (near Bhopal), and Bina railway stations in Madhya Pradesh.

An IRCTC spokesman said that this train comes with high-class on-board services available with exclusive optional tour packages for the passengers covering the religious, business as well as tourism sites between Uttar Pradesh and Madhya Pradesh.

It will cover a distance of 1,131km between Indore and Varanasi via Lucknow and a distance of 1,102km between Indore and Varanasi via Prayagraj in around 19 hours. There will be two dedicated private guards in every coach and light devotional music will be played during journey. Only, vegetarian meals will be served to passengers.

Title: Breast cancer deaths increased 63% in 2019
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Indore: Breast cancer became most common cause of cancer death than any other type at Government Cancer Hospital. An increase of 63% in death of female patients suffering from breast cancer was recorded in 2019 at the hospital.

The fatality figures of the associated hospital of Mahatma Gandhi Memorial Medical College, show that 36 females died of breast cancer in 2019 as compared to 22 in 2018.

In the year 2019, breast cancer emerged as top cancer killer causing 15.92% of the total deaths, followed by blood cancer, tongue cancer, and vaginal cancer combined constituting 14.15 %, 7.07% 6.19% of total toll respectively.

However, in the year 2018, blood cancer constituted 14.45% of total deaths, followed by breast cancer at 8.83%, vaginal cancer at 7.63% and oesophagus at 6.42%.

Blaming modern life style for increase in number of breast cancer, the hospital superintendent Dr Ramesh Arya said, “Breast cancer has witnessed a rise because of modern life style, junk foods and less physical exercise in daily routine. Also, surge in consumption of contraceptives pill by women and late marriages leading to delayed pregnancy are major reason behind increase in number of breast cancer patients.”

The figures also show 6% increase in total female deaths this year. The female patients constituted 47.38% of the total deaths in 2018 as compared to 53% of in 2019 despite a decline of 10% death due to cancer and A dip of 3.26% in new cancer patients. The number of cancer patients coming up for follow-up in 2019 in comparison to 2018 also seen a decline of 17.51%.

A cancer expert Dr Rakesh Taran said, “The number of breast cancer patients has risen as a result of a stressful life, increase in consumption of food with extra cheese, fats along with increased usage of non-reusable plastic.”

The relative risk of breast cancer has increased also due to delayed lactation and less children, said Taran adding that reporting of cancer has increased in last few years due to rise in awareness and health facilities and support through various health schemes.

Title: Kolhapur: Structural audit of Mahalaxmi temple
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

File photo of Mahalaxmi temple

KOLHAPUR: With an aim to increase tourism and boost the image of Kolhapur as a pilgrimage destination, the Paschim Maharashtra Devasthan Samiti ( PMDS ) has decided to conduct a structural audit of Mahalaxmi temple in the city and the Jotiba temple on the Panhala hills in Wadi Ratnagiri village as part of the conservation and restoration works.

PMDS looks after more than 3,042 temples in Western Maharashtra. As per a release issued by the PMDS, the restoration work of Mahalaxmi temple and Jotiba temple is underway. Before the work is completed, the samiti plans to conduct a structural audit of these temples.

A private firm has started the restoration work at the temples from February 10. Incharge of PMDS Mahesh Jadhav said, “We appeal people to come forward and submit old photographs and documents of these temples, if they have any, to the PMDS office as it will help in the structural audit of the temples.”

“The audit will help us add to the aesthetic beauty of the temples. Once completed, we will try reviving the natural beauty of the temples based on the recommendations of the company. This will ultimately help bring in more tourists to the temples,” said Jadhav.

“We have also taken steps like maintaning electronic records of all the transactions related to the temples that fall under our jurisdiction. This will increase the transparency of the transactions conducted by PMDS,” he said.

On an average around 1,500 devotees visit Mahalaxmi temple every day. The footfall increases during summer and winter and reaches a peak during Navaratra and Dasara, when more than 10 lakh devotees visit the temple.

Situated above 3,000 feet above sea level and around 17km away from Kolhapur, Jotiba temple attracts around 7 lakh devotees during the annual yatra every year. Devotees from Kolhapur, Sangli, Satara and the neighbouring districts of Maharashtra, alongside states like Karnataka, Andhra Pradesh and Madhya Pradesh, visit the temple throughout the year.

Title: Woman, 24, held in B’luru over Kashmir poster
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

BENGALURU: A 24-year-old woman was arrested for allegedly holding out a placard with a slogan “Muslim, Dalit , Kashmiri, Bahujan , Adivasi, Trans Liberation Now” in English and Kannada, during a protest by a few pro-Kannada and pro-Hindu organisations against Amulya Leona Noronha at Town Hall here on Friday.

Malleswaram resident Ardra Narayanan , a freelance graphic designer, was produced before a magistrate later in the day and remanded in judicial custody for 14 days.

Ardra’s Facebook profile says she is a student of philosophy at IGNOU. She had also tagged student-activist Amulya, who was arrested on Thursday for raising pro-Pakistan slogans , to some of her FB posts.

Police said Ardra told them she arrived at Town Hall to protest against the “injustice in the nation”. She found several organisations already protesting so she stood at a distance and was waiting for the protestors to disperse when the crowd caught her. But the protesters claimed Ardra had raised pro-Pakistan slogans. Police, however, said Ardra didn’t shout any slogans.

Title: Kolhapur airport may soon begin flights to Panaji & Ahmedabad
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Kolhapur: With passenger traffic crossing 1.25 lakh mark within 14 months of resuming operations and taking more destinations under its purview, the Kolhapur airport has opened new avenues for the city’s development.

Kamal Kumar Kataria, director of Kolhapur Airport, said that with the current development work, the airport will be an integral part of the city.

He said that two new routes — Kolhapur-Panaji and Kolhapur-Ahmedabad — are on the cards for the convenience of passengers. “The decision on the same is yet to be taken, but we will soon see these new destinations on offering,” he said.

The officials from the traders’ union said that the connectivity of the airport to the metro cities has highlighted its importance.

According to Kataria, the airport currently hosts refuelling facility which has proved to be an important asset. When asked on its impact on the current aviation scene, he said that earlier when any aircraft arrived at the Kolhapur airport, the operators had to ensure that they carry extra fuel before departing to their next destination. The limited availability of the fuel restricted the number of passengers to be boarded on a plane. However, it is not a scenario any more. With the availability of aviation fuel, the airlines are able to carry more passengers than before.

Kataria said that they are working relentlessly on the development of the airport which is now an integral part of the city’s transportation needs.

He said that during the floods in August last year, the airport was the sole land mass that was available for rescue and rehabilitation operations which averted any unwarranted situation in the region.

According to Kataria, the air service resumed from December 9, 2018, with Bengaluru and Hyderabad as its to and fro destinations by Air Alliance. At present, the airport is served by Air Alliance, IndiGo, and TruJet on the Hyderabad, Bengaluru, Tirupati and Mumbai routes respectively.

He added that the airport registered a total of around 2,500 flight movements — 2,000 by scheduled operators and over 500 non-scheduled — till date. The non-scheduled flights were mostly witnessed during the election phase and the flood situation when the city was totally blocked by floodwater and the only mode of transport available was airways.

According to Kataria, the airport is also going through development works worth Rs 274 crore which includes 14 km compound wall, Rs 80 crore runway expansion, Rs 65 crore terminal building and air traffic control tower.

It has to be noted that the Kolhapur airport is located at the Ujalaiwadi neighbourhood which is around 9 km from the main city.

Title: Homeopathy hospital, minority resident school for Ajmer
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Representative image

AJMER: The state Budget has brought some good news for the district. Ajmer will get a homeopathy hospital while the DNA test lab is already up and running. Both will certainly provide jobs to locals, experts said. Another important announcement was the setting up of a minority resident school in Masuda for which 17 hectares have been allotted.

However, the marble sector and the spices market did not get any mention in the Budget as CM Ashok Gehlot did not announce any industrial areas. Being as largest producer of quartz, the former Vasundahra Raje government in their state budget had announced a ceramic hub for Ajmer. The DNA test lab has already been constructed in Ajmer on Lohagal Road at a cost of Rs 23 crore and tests like toxicology, biology and serology are being done. Another important announcement is the government homeopathy college which will make Ajmer as a technical education city.

Similarly, the government hospital of Kekeri will get CT scan and MRI machines which will help patients of that belt. At present, patients have to come Ajmer city to get these tests.

Resident school for minorities will help to educate children, mostly girls from the backward regions of rural Ajmer. The Masuda rural belt has a large population of minorities and is backward in terms of education.

The announcement of repairing Bisalpur dam will certainly help the district in improving water supply.

Title: Ahmedabad court acquits woman of abusing woman cop
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Representative image

AHMEDABAD: A 25-year-old woman was acquitted of charges of abusing to a woman cop because the cop could not remember in court as to which expletive the accused had actually hurled towards her.

The case involved a Gora resident, Supreetkaur Sahota and a woman assistant sub-inspector Bhavnaben Vankar. In July 2018, the ASI stopped Sahota on her two-wheeler at Hebatpur for alleged violation of traffic norms. The ASI tried to fine the rider for not wearing a helmet and driving the vehicle without documents, but Sahota allegedly began a quarrel and abused the cop.

Vankar lodged an FIR against Sahota for causing hindrance to her in performing her duty under Section 186 of IPC, and also under Section 294B of IPC for using vulgar words against her. The court dropped Section 186 because the proper procedure was not followed.

So far as charge of hurling abuses to the cop was concerned, Vankar could did not remember as to which particular obscene expletive was uttered by the accused.

After conducting a trial, a magisterial court at the Mirzapur rural court acquitted Sahota by giving her the benefit of doubt.

Title: New oven story in district jail, inmates turn pros donning the baker’s hat
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Indore: Inmates at Indore’s district jail are gearing up to start selling pizza, cookies and bread produced from their newly-opened bakery. They have received manufacturing and selling licence from food and drugs department for their bakery for five years.

“We have been allowed Rs 12 lakh yearly turnover. If the amount exceeds it, we will have to renew licence,” district jail superintendent Aditi Chaturvedi told TOI.

She said that products and items will be sold at competitive rates, probably a bit less than the market price without compromising the quality and taste.

For past few months they were preparing variety of products only for inmates and jail staff. But now, their products will be sold to public and they are happy to work as bakers.

Team of bakers, who have been trained by experts, say they are now ready to take up any challenge and aim to create their own products in future.

Jail superintendent Chaturvedi said that they will now target schools, institutions and local market to sell their bakery products.

“The highest selling item till now is bread. We supply at least 10kg of bread every day to Central jail. Since there are more inmates who require medical attention, they are advised to have bread and milk. Even foreigners whose wheat intake is not as good as Indian inmates are allowed to have bread. Children are also sometimes given bread for a change from regular food,” she said.

By selling products, inmates also have a chance to make money which is deposited in their bank accounts. The official said that according to government norms, inmates earn Rs 72 per day for unskilled labour and Rs 120 a day for skilled labour.

The authorities also claimed that they will try selling the bread in Indore jail circle, which will help them in increasing their revenue. “It will be done through proper procedure. We will float our bids for tenders and hope to get contracts,” she said.

The inmates are also planning to create a new range of chocolates.

Title: Kuttanad begins ‘puncha’ harvesting
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Alappuzha: The ‘ puncha ’ harvesting of Kuttanad began on Friday with Alappuzha district collector M Anjana inaugurating it in the 190-hectare paddy field in Chithira Kayal . The Valiya Pattathanam paddy field in Edathua will be the next on February 23.

The paddy harvesting will come into full swing by March. The harvesting is delayed in many paddy fields as sowing was behind schedule in several areas due to rain and a shortage of seeds.

“Though ‘puncha’ harvesting has begun, we are worried as farmers face shortage of combined harvesters. We are also concerned of the distribution of price for our paddy by the state government. Kerala state civil supplies corporation (Supplyco) procures paddy from the farmers and the government has announced that the procurement price will be credited to the farmers’ accounts within a week. However, several farmers are yet to receive the price for their second crop cultivation last year,” said Tinto K Edayadi, a farmer.

Till date 34,000 farmers in the district have registered online with Supplyco for selling their produce this season. Supplyco has extended the deadline for online registration to February 25.

The agriculture officials said that they are expecting a bumper crop this season. “The procurement price offered this season is Rs 26.95/kg. This includes the minimum support price of Rs 18.15 and the state incentive bonus of Rs 8.80,” the officials said.

Kuttanad peasants of 1,217 ‘padasekharasamithies’, famous for biosaline farming, have indulged in ‘puncha’ farming in 26,268 hectares. A farmer needs 50 to 60kg seeds per acre for ‘puncha’ farming. The cost of 1kg seeds was Rs 32 and the state government distributed 40kg to farmers free of cost. The farmers have used ‘Uma’ seeds and are expecting at least 2,200-3,000kg paddy this year. The price of 1kg paddy is Rs 26.95. A farmer may get at least Rs 59,000 per acre if everything is on track.

For puncha farming, a farmer, who does not have his own land, should pay a lease amount of minimum Rs 20,000 per acre. Apart from that, he also needs to spend at least Rs 30,000 per acre for the cultivation.

Besides, a farmer has to pay Rs 180 labour charge per quintal for loading harvested paddy crops from water-locked paddy fields onto trucks. To fill 45kg harvested paddy in sacks, the labour cost is Rs 35 per sack.

Title: Telangana: Devotees throng temples on Mahashivaratri
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

File photo

HYDERABAD: Serpentine queues were seen outside temples across the city as devotees performed abhishekams, kalyanams and special pujas to seek blessings on the occasion of Mahashivaratri on Friday.

Mahashivaratri is celebrated to observe the union of Lord Shiva and Goddess Parvati. Some people also celebrate it as the day Shiva saved mankind by consuming a pot of poison during Samudra Manthan or the mythical churning of the ocean.

“I and my family went to the temple early in the morning. The temple had organised a jaagran where we sang devotional songs,” said Suresh M, a resident of Srinagar Colony.

Devotees gathered in large numbers at Pancha Janyeswara Swamy temple in Hare Krishna Golden Temple in Banjara Hills. Shivala Ghat Temple at Puranapul, Shankar mutt at Nallakunta and Keesragutta in the outskirts of the city also saw huge crowds.

The popular Shiva temples at Vemulawada, Bala Brahmeshwara temple in Alampur and Ramappa temple also saw huge turnouts.

Chief minister K Chandrashekhar Rao conveyed his greetings to the people of Telangana.

Title: Vicky Donor among bulls, top stud in the country
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

GIR-141 was born on March 10, 2015, in Gujarat and brought to MP when it was one year old

BHOPAL: Meet India’s most 'potent' bull. A six-foot-tall, 600-kilo hunk of the Gir breed at Bhopal ’s Central Semen Station has been certified by the Centre as the “best bull in the country”.

Around 7ml of its semen, collected every 72 hours, is enough to impregnate 900 cows, says its bio-data. Named GIR-141 , the big-horned bull is so precious that you need to don a biological protection suit to get within a few feet of him.

Demand for its semen has been shooting up for the past few months, ever since word of its.. er..special quality got around. But as of now, MP authorities are still in the possessive stage and reluctant to share it outside the state. “We have to improve local indigenous breeds first,” reasoned an official.

“There are 53 semen stations in the country, where select high quality bulls are kept for semen doses for breed improvement. Data of each bull is available with the Union government, which ranks the best bulls in the country. GIR-141 was identified as the best bull in India and we are proud to have it in our semen station,” said Bhopal semen station manager Dr Deepali Deshpande.

GIR-141 was born on March 10, 2015, in Gujarat and brought to MP when it was a year old. Its semen collection started a year-and-a-half ago.

The brawny, tan coloured bull is fed a diet of over 24kg a day — 10kg each of wheat straw and green fodder, 4kg of ‘concentrate’ (protein supplements, cereals and bran) and 100gm mineral mixture — to remain in top shape.

No one without proper kit is allowed beyond the bio-security wall that surrounds its enclosure, and GIR-141 is given horn to hoof medical every three months.

A semen straw from GIR-141 costs Rs 24. Over 25,000 semen straws have been sold so far in MP, and its price may go up once it is offered to other states, officials believe. Nitin Chourey, who is into artificial insemination in Harda, said: “I am always in search of high quality bull semen and locate bulls from different parts of country. I got GIR-141 semen last year and it has given birth to healthy calves. The results are the best I have got so far”.

H B S Bhadoria, managing director of MP Livestock and Poultry Development Corporation, said GIR-141 is the best bull in the country. “It has been certified by the Union government. The certification was based on milk yield potential — the milk capacity of GIR-141’s mother was 7,468 litres in 305 days, the highest ever in the country. This bull is being used to transfer its mother’s genetic potential to future generations and the results are way better than expected,” he said.

Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Representative image

JAIPUR: With Rs 4,245 crore proposed for the upgradation of 8,663 kilometre of rural roads under the Pradhan Mantri Gram Sadak Yojana (PMGSY) Phase III, deputy chief minister Sachin Pilot on Friday announced that in the first batch of Phase III, around 2,200 kilometre of roads will be upgraded in the state at a budget of Rs 1,139 crore.

Title: Supreme Court order on water dispute not setback for Goa, says BJP
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

PANAJI: BJP on Friday said that the Supreme Court ’s order allowing the Mhadei Water Disputes Tribunal (MWDT) award to be notified was not a setback for the state as Karnataka would not be able to divert any water from the river basin till Goa’s petition is heard in July.

Former South Goa MP Narendra Sawaikar said that even if the tribunal’s award was notified, it would take Karnataka two to three months to get the remaining clearances required to begin diverting water.

“Assuming the notification comes out and Karnataka jumps up, it does not mean anything till the Supreme Court does not pass an order on Mhadei,” Sawaikar said.

He said that the Supreme Court’s decision to allow Goa’s appeal and to hear it on priority over a period of three days in July indicated that the apex court found merit in Goa’s contention.

Sawaikar, who is also a BJP spokesperson, said that the state government and BJP would keep a close watch on the critical river to ensure that water is not clandestinely diverted.

“We will represent to the Supreme Court if they are playing mischief with the award. We won’t allow Karnataka to divert any water from Mhadei,” he said.

BJP state president Sadanand Tanawade said that the party had finalised its state executive committee, which includes permanent invitees and special invitees. BJP women’s wing, youth wing and other wings will be formed after the zilla panchayat polls.

Assuming the notification comes out and Karnataka jumps up, it does not mean anything till the Supreme Court does not pass an order on Mhadei.

Title: Kolhapur becoming popular for shooting films
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Kolhapur: From big-budget films to low budget ones, the city and the outskirts in the district are witnessing an increase in the number of shooting films for the past couple of years.

According to a local production manager, in locations like Rankala, Panhala, Jotiba, Gaganbawda, Gargoti, and Radhanagari, films are shot every year due to the scenic beauty, easy availability of the place and cheap facilities.

The development of Chitranagari is playing an important role in the city’s development as a production hub.

Milind Ashtekar, a local production manager, said the shooting locations mainly depend on the demand of the story. If the story needs scenic beauty, then the locations in Kolhapur are the best ones.

Panhala, Jotiba, Gaganbawda and several villages witnesses good number of productions.

Ashtekar, who has been in the film production business for over 20 years in Kolhapur, said that for a film or serial production, the basic requirements are to look for easy transportation facility, food facility, lodging facility and the easy availability of local artists.

“The production team has to arrive in Kolhapur with their production team and their main artists, everything else is available here,” he said.

He said that every year 10-15 films, 5-10 serials, and several short films are shot in the vicinity of the city.

“A film production lasts a week to four weeks or more, depending on their story, locations, and budget,” he said.

According to Ashtekar, depending on the scheduled shoot, the final cost varies for a film but it is cheaper compared to Pune or Mumbai.

When the Chitranagari was shut down due to lack of funds and non-availability of infrastructure, the industry was going through its worst phase, said a local artist.

The centres in Pune and Mumbai was recognised as the best locations for the Marathi film shoot. But the scenario is changing and Kolhapur is being recognised.

He added that the short film directors from the city had won the last two year’s Filmfare people’s choice award for their respective short films. This shows the budding talent.

Sayaji Shinde, the veteran actor who acted in more than 300 Marathi, Hindi, and South’s film industry said that Kolhapur has always been recognised by many filmmakers and that needs to be retained. If serious producers could invest in their projects in the city, it will be good for the industry as well as the city.

Title: Now, districts to get drones for monitoring natural disasters
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Representative image

JAIPUR: Every district collector in the state will be provided drones for better monitoring during natural disasters, announced Chief Minister Ashok Gehlot while presenting the budget on Thursday. The budget for this has been sanctioned under relief, disaster management and civil defense department.

The chief minister also announced a budget of Rs 10 crore for providing model equipment to civil defense and state disaster response force. He also allocated Rs 26 crore for 100 fire tenders to be provided to the districts.

Apart from these, under relief, disaster management and civil defense, Rs 12 crore has been allocated for water resources department for flood control and Rs 3 crore for forest department for controlling forest fire.

Under food and civil supplies, computarization of food and civil supplies offices will be done at Rs 16 crore and fair price shops will be authorised for e-mitra centres, said the chief minister while presenting the budget.

The chief minister also announced that a Khadi Plaza in Jaipur at Rs 10 crore will be built as a mark of respect to Mahatma Gandhi on his 150th birth anniversary. He also said that financial assistance of Rs 2 crore will be given for computerization of 144 Khadi institutions and bunkar sangh .

For the minorities department, the chief minister announced construction of residential school buildings for minority boys and girls at Masuda and Kaman Block at Rs 41.60 crore. He also said three minority girls hostel buildings will be set up in Nagaur, Sawai Madhopur and Ladnu. Apart from these, the chief minister also announced setting up of a 100-bed boys hostel in Jaipur at Rs 5 crore and gave a grant of Rs 5 crore to Waqf board.

Title: Socio-economic survey delayed? No decision yet
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

NEW DELHI: The government is yet to take a final call on deferring the survey on domestic tourism expenditure and multiple indicators and a decision will be taken only after the issue is discussed with all the stakeholders.

The talk of deferring the survey came amid reports of attacks on personnel undertaking the survey from several states in the wake of the protests against the Citizenship (Amendment) Act (CAA).

“There have been reports of teams being attacked. There have been sporadic reports of violence and a misconception has been created. We will take a final call on whether to go ahead with the surveys or not,” said a senior official in the statistics and programme implementation ministry.

Sources said the standing committee on statistics headed by former chief statistician Pronab Sen is also expected to discuss the issue on February 26. “If we don’t get the responses to our questionnaires there’s is no point going ahead with the survey,” an official said.

Title: Truck driving on wrong side hits bike, couple dead
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Representative image

INDORE: A couple from Ujjain died in road accident at Navlakha Road Square on Friday, when truck coming from the wrong end hit their bike. The deceased have been identified as Sunil Kumawat , 43 and his wife Sarita aged around 40. “We have registered case under section 304 of IPC for culpable homicide not amounting to murder against the driver and seized the vehicles,” police station in charge Narendra Singh Raghuwanshi said. The search for accused driver was on and he will be nabbed soon, he added.

According to police, the incident took place between 1.00 pm and 1.30 pm, when Kumawat was going with his wife on a two-wheeler. A speeding truck coming from wrong side hit his bike. Kumawat died on spot and his wife succumbed on way to hospital, said police.

Commuters informed police immediately after the incident and tried to catch driver of the truck, who entered into a shop nearby. Beat police officers took the couple to hospital but were declared brought dead. The driver managed to escape, said police.

Title: Cow smugglers fire at police in Bharatpur, sub-inspector injured
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Representative image

JAIPUR: A sub-inspector was injured in a fierce encounter while chasing a group of cow smugglers at Ghatmika village under Kaman police station area of Bharatpur district on Friday.

Police have detained some persons in this connection.

Acting on a tip-off, a team of police officers including Quick Response Team (QRT) reached the spot where they had specific information on the presence of cow smugglers.

“After been surrounded by the police, unidentified persons involved in cow smuggling opened fire in which a sub-inspector was injured. He has sustained pellet injuries near one of his eye and other parts of the body. He has been rushed to SMS Hospital for treatment,” said a senior police officer of Bharatpur district.

DSP Devendra Singh Rajawat said after specific information on cow smuggling near the hills of Ghatmika village, a well-equipped team of police officers rushed to the spot.

“The cow smugglers started firing and managed to flee from the scene,” Rajawat added.

This is not the first time when police team witnessed firing while chasing cow smugglers. The smugglers in Kaman area of Mewat region have been fearlessly opening fire on police teams.

“We have seized a few vehicles and have detained some persons. Hopefully, we will nail down the culprits,” said a senior officer of Bharatpur district.

Title: Ahead of Trump visit, Mumtaz Mahal and Shahjahan get mudpacks at their final resting place for Ist time in 389 years
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Agra: The replicas of the graves of Mughal emperor Shahjahan and his wife Mumtaz Mahal are undergoing a clay-pack treatment for a ‘facelift’ ahead of US President Donald Trump’s visit to the 17th century monument on February 24.

Ever since the two were buried here 389 years ago (Mumtaz Mahal in 1631 and Shahjahan in 1666), this would be the first time that the replicas of their graves are being treated to look clean. The real graves of the royal couple, much austere than their false marble copies, lie in a chamber below the crypt containing them. The real graves are opened only for three days in a year for devotees who come to offer prayers during Shahjahan’s Urs. The 22-step staircase leading to the real graves is narrow and no visiting foreign dignitary in the past expressed desire to see the real graves.

Confirming this, superintending archaeologist (science branch) of Archaeological Survey of India (ASI), M K Bhatnagar, said that the mud-pack treatment on the graves was started last week and will be finished by Friday evening.

The clay-pack treatment is based on a traditional mix which is used by Indian women to restore their natural glow on the face. “A thick layer of lime-rich clay is plastered over the affected part and left to dry,” said an official, adding that when it dries the flakes are removed from the surface with a soft brush and washed with distilled water to clear the impurities.

The huge brass chandelier installed over the graves has also been cleaned with “tamarind water”. The red sandstone platform at the royal gate, the Chameli floor, the central tank and the sides of the pathways of the fountain inside the monument are also being cleaned.

Besides, the ASI has also undertaken cleaning of the monument in a big way to remove the dark spots on the walls and the floors.

Earlier, a joint study to look into the factors behind the discolouration of the Taj Mahal by the Indian Institute of Technology (IIT), Kanpur, ASI and US-based Georgia Institute of Technology (Atlanta) and University of Wisconsin (Madison) had revealed that air pollution is the real cause behind the damage to the monument. The study was published in Environmental Science & Technology journal in December 2014. As per recommendation of Parliamentary Standing Committee in the year 2015, the science branch has been carrying out scientific cleaning by using clay pack therapy for entire main mausoleum of Taj Mahal including minarets.

The monument had been given the mud-pack treatment five times in the past. While the maiden mud-pack treatment took place in 1994, the second and third ones were given in 2001 and 2008. In May 2014 to get rid of decades of paan and gutkha stains left by the visitors on the interior walls of the world heritage building. In February 2019, the four minarets and north side of the Taj Mahal were again given fresh mud-pack treatment.

Title: Six die in mishap in Hanumangarh while going to Purabsar
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Jaipur: Six people including a man and wife and a mother-son duo were killed in a head on collision between a jeep and a truck near Purabsar bus stand in Rawatsar tehsil of Hanumangarh district on Friday. A 12-year-old girl and a 13-year-old boy were among those who lost their lives. A nine-year-old girl sustained grave injuries and is battling for life at a government hospital in Hanumangarh.

All the seven people in the jeep were returning from a religious function at their relative’s place.

“Out of seven people in the jeep, six lost their lives except the nine-year-old girl identified as Pooja who is battling for life in the hospital,” said a senior police officer.

Police said the collision was nasty. Soon after the accident, a rescue team including villagers, policemen and others equipped with metal cutters and hammers rushed to the spot to bail out the trapped passengers.

All the deceased were residents of Mayala Ki Dhani in Rawatsar and were returning to Purabsar.

According to police, the accident took place while the jeep coming from Hanumangarh-Kisnagarh highway crushed into a truck coming from opposite direction. “With a nasty collision the jeep was badly damaged. All the deceased were sent to the mortuary of government hospital at Hanumangarh,” said a senior police officer.

The deceased were identified as Nirmala (30), Mukesh Kumar (22), Budhram (60), his wife Gomti (55) and Vijay (13) and Vipana (12). Vijay and Vipana are the son and daugther of Nirmala.

Title: City group collects 70 litre milk from devotees
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Aurangabad: Members of a citizen group appealed to people visiting Shiv temples on the occasion of Mahashivaratri on Friday to avoid pouring milk on the deity and instead give it to them.

Around 70 litre of milk was collected and given to a children's home and the relatives of the patients' at Government Medical College and Hospital.

The citizen group, Maheshwari Paryavaran Group, carried out the campaign during Mahashivratri for the fourth successive year this time.

Along with the representatives from Baba Sai Home for children with AIDS and Roti Bank, that serves food to the patients’ relatives at the GMCH, the group members had placed cans to carry milk at the temples the day before the occasion.

On Friday, volunteers deployed at the temples requested the people to give the milk to them instead of pouring it on the deity. The members said that this year, there was an increase in awareness about the cause of collecting milk instead of pouring it.

“Without much insistence, the people poured only a spoonful of milk over the deity and gave the rest to us. Many avoided bringing milk at all,” Jamuna Mandhani of the group said.

In order to prevent water pollution and wastage of food, the volunteers of Maheshwari Paryavaran Group carried out the campaign.

This year too, the group members had coordinated with the temple authorities several days before Mahashivratri. The campaign was mainly implemented at Khadkeshwar Temple in Khadkeshwar and Rameshwar Temple in Shahgunj which witnesses hundreds of people offering their prayers on the occasion.

Title: Artists pick up brush to paint city walls to welcome Trump
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Agra: The visit by US president Donald Trump and his wife Melania here on February 24 has given artists a chance to literally paint the walls on the VVIP route in the city in a hue of colours. Teams of artists from Dr Bhimrao Ambedkar University, Agra College and an NGO, ‘India Rising’, are now busy decorating the walls on the route to be taken by the couple with a series of messages and paintings. A proposal to the effect was made by the district administration and Agra Municipal Corporation (AMC) in a bid to spruce up the city for the visitors.

The themes vary from Prime Minister Narendra Modi shaking hands with president Trump, flags of US and India, Mahatma Gandhi and depiction of Swachh Bharat Mission.

These paintings on the VVIP route from Kheria Airbase to the Taj Mahal also carry messages like “Jai Shri Krishna”, “Radhey, Radhey Trump” and “Athithi Devo Bhava (the guest is god)”. These messages are being painted on the walls on both sides of the road.

The artists said the work would be completed by Sunday evening.

Shardul Mishra, a teacher at Agra University’s Institute of Fine Arts. said, “A team of 20 students and teachers are making wall paintings on the VVIP route. We will be covering 150 stretches of wall on both sides of the road.”

Sandeep Agarwal, president of ‘India Rising’, said, “We are voluntarily making wall paintings to welcome the US president. District authorities have asked us to use our creativity to make the visit of the state guest look as a festive occasion.”

Title: Casino deploys pvt security at CoP jetty
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Panaji: Even as chief minister Pramod Sawant inaugurated the country’s first floating jetty, which is an extension of the captain of ports jetty, bouncers hired by Big Daddy Casino were deployed at the entrance of the jetty and on the floating jetty to prevent entry.

Ports minister Michael Lobo said that he would “investigate” why private security personnel were hired by the off-shore casino to prevent locals from viewing the floating jetty.

“The floating jetty is connected to the main jetty and has nothing to do with casino Big Daddy,” said Lobo when asked if the floating jetty had been leased to Golden Globe Hotels Private Limited and its associate company Worldwide Resorts and Entertainment Pvt. Ltd, which owns Big Daddy Casino.

However, when the matter of the private company deploying security guards for a public function was raised with the chief minister, he laughed it off and went on to inaugurate the jetty.

Title: Gujarat: ‘Saving animal culture can help climate change adaptation’
Content:
Representative image

GANDHINAGAR: Humans aren’t the only species that can be identified by their cultures. Other primates including chimpanzees, bonobos, two species of gorillas and three species of orangutans can be identified by culture .With animal culture — learning of non-human species through socially transmitted behaviour — for the first time being linked to conservation at the 13th Conference of Parties to the CMS under way in Gandhinagar , their odds to survive climate change may have improved, experts say.“For the last thirty years scientists have been observing and writing of culture in non-human species. There is enough evidence today that apart from the seven species of great apes, some species of elephants, whales and dolphins acquire knowledge and skills through social learning. For instance, one can identify the area of a certain subspecies of chimpanzee based on culture. Some have tribes, some have a certain kind of dance,” said renowned conservationist and biologist Ian Redmond in an interview with TOI.Redmond, known for his work on apes and elephants and the Ambassador for the United Nations Environment Programme (UNEP) Convention on Migratory Species (CMS), said that in the face of climate change when there isn’t enough time for genetic evolution, cultural evolution can happen faster, increasing chances of survival.CMS has been leading efforts to use knowledge of animal culture to protect endangered wildlife. It is the only United Nations treaty that addresses migratory species and their habitats across borders.Two proposals will be presented to delegates this week to consider conservation measures for the Eastern tropical Pacific sperm whale and the nut-cracking chimpanzee. Apart from individual learning, some animals learn socially from adults or peers about various behaviours, including optimal migration routes the proposals claim.“Animal culture allows us to understand how animals live as individuals rather than thinking they are all copies. In some migratory birds, when juveniles first migrate with their parentsthere is direct transfer of information. If we destroy a population, and this has happened or cranes in the US, efforts to re-introduce them are difficult as there were no adults left,” said Fernando Spina, chairman, Scientific Council CMS Italian Ringing Centre ISPRA.Supporting individuals that act as ‘repositories’ of social knowledge such as elephant matriarchs could be as important as conserving critical habitat, he added.Species like elk or mountain sheep can modify migration paths and combat climate change due to their cultural learnings, said Giuseppe Notarbartolo di Sciara, president, Tethys Research Institute.

Title: FIRs brushed under the rug to maintain a clean record?
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Bhopal: Kamla Nagar police station area, which has become infamous for cases related to window/windscreen smashing, tops the list of police stations with the highest number of crimes in the city in 2019. Most of these crimes are registered as Non-Cognizable Reports (NCR).

The 2019 data suggest that in almost all the police stations the number of NCRs registered was higher or equal to the number of FIRs (crimes under IPC) registered.

Retired senior police officers maintained that the high ratio of NCR indicates that police were not registering all the offences reported and filing NCRs to avoid the burden of investigations. It is not only tarnishing the image of cops in society and creating a distrust for them, but also leads to an increase in the number of serious offences.

In NCR, police cannot conduct a probe on their own. If the complainant wants action against the accused, he/she will have to approach the court with the NCR and then on the court’s order, police will investigate the case. A police officer said that less than 1% of the complainants approach court after police register NCR.

In many cases of vandalising vehicles reported at Kamla Nagar police station, police registered NCR and avoided a thorough investigation. As a result, more than 100 vehicles parked outside houses in the locality were vandalised and some even torched by miscreants. When the situation got out of control, police swung into action and nabbed the accused. It was found that the incidents were the result of gang wars between hardcore criminals.

A senior city police officer, on condition of anonymity, told TOI that the number of NCRs show the grim picture of crime rate, which is on the rise in the city. Most of the SHOs in the city try to avoid registering FIR as it reflects poorly on the crime graph of the police station concerned. Only the FIRs are reviewed in crime meetings and not NCRs, so the actual rise in the city's crime rate is not assessed.

He added that Bhopal being a state capital has many law and order duties on regular basis. Most of the times, SHOs and even the second in command at police stations are deployed on duties outside the police stations. Only 3-4 men run the police stations and they try to avoid registering cases to avoid documental formalities.

Retired DG Arun Gurtoo said this is a serious issue. Rise in the NCR ratio clearly indicates that the police are not registering all the offences reported. He said senior police officers must monitor the Rojnamcha or daily report regularly and analyse NCRs specifically.

Speaking on the large number of NCRs registered at police stations, DIG Irshad Wali said that mostly in offences in which there is no injury or disputes within family members, NCR is registered. The complainant approaches police under sudden provocation, but the very next day starts pleading that the case be cancelled. He admitted that many times, police staff do not register FIR to evade the trouble of investigation. But in many cases, people do not want to pursue the case themselves, so NCR are registered.

Title: Beware! This gang steals from car by diverting your attention
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Indore: Beware, better safe than sorry — police are on the lookout for a gang of thieves, who accost car drivers by saying that they ran the vehicle on their foot. While trying to pick up a fight with drivers, other gang members steal mobile phones, cash and expensive items from vehicle.

Almost half a dozen such incidents have been reported in past one week ringing alarm bells in police department. Incidents where child beggars helped accused steal mobile phone from car of victim have also come to fore. “They surrounded the car and started banging on windows and scratching doors,” said complainant RK Gupta while speaking to police. Gupta was also attacked, when he returned and asked for his phones back.

The modus operandi of gang includes scaring victim and making him panic in the moment such that he doesn’t pay attention to items kept in the car and his attention is diverted to accused, who is shouting at him. One of the accused might also come to the victim from left side of the car and tell him that he ran the vehicle over his foot. The other one would come from right side and bang on the window. If window on the left is open, the accused would steal the items while the one on the right would shout at him and keep him engaged.

Victim Rajneesh Khare said that accused deliberately do things that make the person sitting in the car panic. “They bang on windows from different sides incessantly. So in order to avoid any damage, one rolls the window which makes it easy for them to open the door from the side you are not watching and steal items kept on seat or elsewhere within their reach,” said Khare.

Senior police officials claimed that preventive actions are being initiated to stop such incidents and traffic officials on signals as well as officials on duty have been alerted about such incidents and have been asked to take stringent actions.

The victims told TOI that the only way to avoid such an incident is to avoid what the accused is saying, make a video of them and leave the spot without opening the doors or window. “If they do not let you leave the spot, park your vehicle by roadside, dial 100, get out of the car, lock it and only then speak to them,” said Khare.

Title: Flight crew, air traffic controllers to undergo random drug tests
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

NEW DELHI: In a bid to make flying safer, flight crew and air traffic controllers (ATCO) will now be tested for drug abuse, just like the breath-analyser (BA) checks to ensure they are not tipsy.

Directorate General of Civil Aviation (DGCA) chief Arun Kumar has ordered “random drug testing for the consumption of (10) psychoactive substances” like cocaine, marijuana/hashish, MDMA or ecstasy and morphine/opiate. A pilot or ATCO testing positive for drug abuse for the first time will be grou- nded and undergo de-addiction/rehabilitation programme. Failing for the second time will mean cancellation of licence, which means such a person will not be able to work as a pilot or controller again.

People refusing to undergo this test “shall be removed from the safety sensitive duties until they clear detailed drug testing profile within a week, failing which the license of the involved person shall be suspended for three years,” the order stated.

While a start has been made with key positions, the DGCA will gradually bring more aviation personnel under the drug test. Testing will be done by a DGCA-authorised laboratory at six airports of Delhi, Mumbai, Chennai, Kolkata, Bangalore and Hyderabad in phase 1. Airlines and Airports Authority of India (which provides ATC services) “shall ensure that at least 10% of (their flight crew and ATCOs) are covered in a year.”

Apart from random checks, pilots and ATCOs will have to be tested for drug abuse at three stages: before getting hired; after an accident and follow-up testing of confirmed cases. All positive cases will have to be reported to the DGCA within 24 hours. Testing will be done on urine samples collected from the randomly selected staff. Samples shall be collected only with consent of the person required to undergo test.

Title: Maldives home minister meets Shah, reviews security ties
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

NEW DELHI: Home minister Amit Shah on Friday held detailed discussions with his Maldivian counterpart Shei- kh Imran Abdulla, during which the two sides reviewed bilateral cooperation in the areas of security and law enforcement cooperation.

Abdulla is on a four-day visit to India since Thursday.

“Met Mr Sheikh Imran Abdulla, home minister of the Republic of Maldives . Held extensive discussions on ways to further deepen and strengthen ties between India and Maldives,” Shah tweeted after the meeting.

Later, a delegation headed by Abdulla was hosted by the Enforcement Directorate at its headquarters in Delhi on Friday where they were given an extensive presentation on the working of the agency and about the Prevention of Money Laundering Act (PMLA) infrastructure.

According to sources, ED will assist Maldives in setting up a probe agency like itself and guide the island nation on raising a PMLA infrastructure. Abdulla spent half a day at the ED office meeting its officials and understanding the functioning of the agency.

Title: Army’s new HQ set to be ready in 5 years
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

NEW DELHI: The foundation stone for the new Army headquarters or the ‘ Thal Sena Bhawan’ (TSB), which will house 1,684 officers and 4,330 other staff personnel by bringing together the eight existing offices of the force in different parts of the Capital, was laid by defence minister Rajnath Singh at Delhi Cantonment on Friday.

The TSB, spread over 39 acres to include the 6,104 offices in a multi-storey “green” building complex with parking, will take at least five years to be completed at a cost of around Rs 750 crore.

Title: Huge demand for organic vegetables grown in prison
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Visakhapatnam: Vegetables grown by inmates of the central prison is seeing an increased demand. Authorities of the central prison have set up a stall at Adavivaram where prisoners can sell the vegetables they grow. The jail administration is even considering increasing production to meet high demand.

Speaking to TOI, S Rahul, superintendent of Vizag central prison said that of the total amount of vegetables grown by the prisoners, nearly 300kg is consumed by them per day. “Since the inmates are growing organic vegetables, the demand for prison-grown vegetables has gone up among people travelling through the Adavivaram route in the morning.”

More than 60 inmates of the central prison grow brinjal, ladies’ finger, tomato, bottle gourd, ridge gourd and other vegetables in around six acres land at the central prison. Vegetable production itself fetches Rs2,000 to Rs3,000 for the department per day. The prisoners sell the vegetables between Rs 30-Rs40 per kg based on market demands.

A number of inmates have previous agriculture experience. They use the drip and sprinkler irrigation method to water the crop. Water is drawn from three water bodies in the vicinity.

T Anil Kumar, a resident of Arilova who comes to buy vegetables from this stall said, “The inmates are trying to make their farming 100% organic. The quality of vegetables is really good. I purchase these prison-grown vegetables whenever I pass through the area.”

S Rahul, the superintendent of the prison said that inmates also grow good-quality red chilli and turmeric powder. “These are expected to hit the market by March. The spices unit will be inaugurated on February 24.”

Prison authorities plan to produce over Rs50 lakh worth chilli powder and turmeric powder per year. They have procured red chilli from Guntur and organic turmeric from Narsipatnam and Chintapalli.

With the average expenditure per inmate increasing every year, the Andhra Pradesh prison department is providing skill development training to prisoners under the Skill-India programme to increase revenue and to ensure that inmates find employment upon being released from prison.

Title: Mahashivaratri: Thousands of devotees offer prayers
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Visakhapatnam: A sea of devotees thronged Lord Shiva temples in north-coastal Andhra Pradesh on the occasion of Mahashivaratri on Friday. There are more than 100 temples dedicated to Lord Shiva in the region. Some of the major ones include the Appikonda in Visakhapatnam, Srimukhalingeswara temple in Srikakulam and Punyagiri in Vizianagaram.

Thousands turned up to visit the Maha Kumbhabhisekham organised by TS Subbarami Reddy Lalitha Kala Parishad at Beach Road in the city. Maheswara Sharma, a priest at the temple in Kailasagiri said, “The ‘abhisekham’ to the Shiva Lingam began at 4am. Devotees arrived at the temple before sunrise.”

The ancient Appikonda located along the Bay of Bengal near Visakhapatnam Steel Plant was crowded with devotees having arrived from various parts of the district. “Cultural activities, an exhibition along the coast and special rituals to Lord Shiva at Appikonda temple were centres of attraction,” said P Srikanth, a devotee.

The Lord Shiva temple at Punyagiri in S Kota mandal of Vizianagaram attracted devotees for its waterfall. Moreover, prayers were offered to Lord Shiva inside Borra Caves near Araku Valley. Authorities of the Sri Bhavani Sametha Kailasagiri Swamy temple organised cultural programmes. GVMC authorities and city police mobilised forces at the beach to monitor the holy dip on Saturday morning.

The only damper to the festive spirit was the death of 45-year-old A Reddy from Srikakulam. Reddy, a native of Palakonda drowned in Vamsadhara while taking a dip in the river.

Title: Missing girls from Visakhapatnam traced in Bengaluru
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Representative image

VISAKHAPATNAM: The three girls who had gone missing from Dwarakanagar area on February 17 were traced in Bengaluru, Karnataka on Friday. They will reach the city either on Saturday or Sunday.

Inspector of Dwaraka police station, Y Murali Rao, said their teams visited Chennai, Tirupati and Bengaluru and one of the teams traced the missing girls in Bengaluru. “Our teams have been making efforts to reunite the girls with their parents” Rao added. However, police are yet to ascertain the exact reasons for their running away from home.

The three siblings had left home on February 17. On the same day, they had sent their mother an SMS stating that their parents should not look for them and claimed that they would commit suicide. When the parents tried to call, the phone was switched-off.

Title: GVMC seizes 6 tonnes of plastic in four months
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Visakhapatnam: The Greater Visakhapatnam Municipal Corporation ( GVMC ) has seized nearly 6 tonnes of single-use plastic over the last four months. The city’s civic body has also imposed hefty penalties on violators.

The GVMC had outlawed the use of single-use plastic through a gazette notification around two years ago. Consequently, traders and vendors have started asking customers to bring their own bags or pay Rs10 to avail cotton bags. In some parts, meat vendors have started using dry leaves to pack meat. The Union government also issued an advisory to address the issue of plastic waste. Under plastic waste management rules of 2016, all producers who use plastic packaging are required to collect an equal amount of plastic under the extended producer responsibility framework. tnn

Title: Mother-daughter pairs screened for HPV
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Visakhapatnam: A medical camp was held at Homi Bhabha Cancer Hospital and Research Centre (HBCH&RC), Aganampudi, that sought to screen pairs of mothers and daughters for human papillomavirus ( HPV ), which is one of the main causes of cervical cancer.

Dr D Leela, gynaecology oncologist at HBCH&RC said cervical cancer is the second most commonly diagnosed cancer in India. The mother’s awareness about the symptoms and risk factors has a large impact on the daughter's knowledge and attitude. Mother and adolescent daughter pairs were selected as the sample as they are the target population at risk for suffering from carcinoma cervix. Mothers who are 30 and above in age are screened for breast and cervical cancer. Daughters between 10 to 14 years are given two doses of HPV vaccination at an interval of six months while above 15 years were given three doses at a zero, two and six months’ interval to protect against HPV infection, thereby preventing cervical cancer. said Dr D Leela.

In a bid to prevent cervical cancer incidence, Dr D Raghunatha Rao, director of HBCH&RC said, “We have adopted remote villages like Appapuram and Dhananipeta in Srikakulam district for complete screening of all women and vaccination of all girls against HPV virus, that causes cervical cancer. Until now, we have conducted more than 100 pairs of mother-daughter screening process. Our goal is to achieve 85% of cervical cancer screening between the age group of 35-45 and 90% vaccination among adolescent girls.”

Title: US-Taliban deal could leave Indian infra in Afghanistan vulnerable
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

NEW DELHI: For the past decade, Indian policymakers and security leadership have anticipated a withdrawal of US troops from Afghanistan, and what that would mean for India. The world now has a date. On Friday, the US and Taliban, in coordinated statements, announced that the two sides would sign a peace agreement on February 29.

The peace deal is expected to kick off two processes — a phased withdrawal of US troops and an ‘intra-Afghan’ dialogue. The first test will be a “significant reduction in violence” across Afghanistan. “Intra-Afghan negotiations will start soon thereafter, and will build on this fundamental step to deliver a comprehensive and permanent ceasefire and the future political roadmap for Afghanistan. The only way to achieve a sustainable peace in Afghanistan is for Afghans to come together and agree on the way forward,” US secretary of state Mike Pompeo said.

Afghanistan and its future will now be an important element in the talks the Indian leadership will have with US President Donald Trump and his cabinet next week. India will be interested in the timeline of US withdrawal as well as the details of a security/counter-terrorism presence the US may have in Afghanistan.

Tilak Devasher, formerly with RAW, said, "India's interest is to secure the investments we have made in Afghanistan in the past two decades, and the security of our diplomats, personnel and missions. In addition, we would be wary of ungoverned spaces in that country, which could become grounds for terror groups to flourish. Of particular concern would be the prospect that Pakistan could use any such spaces to move its anti-India terror infrastructure, groups like LeT and JeM from Pakistan.”

In a sense, the peace deal could be a victory of sorts for Pakistan, which has been Taliban’s principal supporter for ever. Pakistan has been pressured by the US to bring the Taliban to the negotiating table and prima facie, it has delivered. It is significant, therefore, that despite Pakistan’s importance in getting this deal together, it could not stay off the FATF grey list, which PM Imran Khan had desperately wanted.

Former ambassador to Afghanistan Gautam Mukhopadhyaya said, “For the sake of peace that Afghans desperately want after decades of war and terrorism, any opportunity for inter-Afghan talks should be welcomed and given a chance. But Afghans will be entering such talks with the US repositioned as a facilitator rather than strategic political and military partner, and neither the Afghans nor we should be under any illusions that the decks are stacked against it. The Afghans need all the political support from the international community that they can get.”

The Afghan election results were just made public after months, giving Ashraf Ghani another victory. The results have been rejected by Abdullah Abdullah and others. Neither the US nor Pakistan have congratulated Ghani, only India and the EU have. It’s no secret that the Taliban does not consider the Kabul government to be legitimate. This not only places Ghani and his government in an uncertain position, it could allow the Taliban to pick off the different groups and oust Ghani in the foreseeable future. In an oped, Sirajuddin Haqqani, deputy leader of the Taliban and head of the dreaded Haqqani Network, emphasised a “new Afghanistan”. The contours of that will be watched warily from India.

Title: Students stage protest at VDA
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Visakhapatnam: Students of Visakhapatnam Defence Academy (VDA) staged a protest on Friday demanding facilities such as a playground, a swimming pool, quality food and a reduction in fees. The situation turned tense when the authorities allegedly tried to lock up agitating students in a cellar.

A few students tried to meet the administrative officer of the academy but were reportedly prevented from doing so. Ch Suri Naidu, inspector, Gajuwaka police, interacted with agitating students. “We have not registered a case as the students refused to lodge a complaint. The academy management has assured to look into the complaints,” Naidu said.tnn

Title: After guv’s prod, Lucknow Univ plans courses in ‘garbha sanskar’
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

LUCKNOW: What should a pregnant woman eat and wear? How should she behave in daily life and keep fit with yoga? What kind of music is good for her? All this and much more will now be taught at the Institute of Women’s Studies of Lucknow University .

The new certificate and diploma courses on ‘garbha sanskar’ will be launched in the new academic session. LU will be the first state university to introduce such a course.

The move comes after governor Anandiben Patel , also the chancellor of all state universities, suggested to authorities to train girls on how to perform their prospective role as mothers. She cited the example of Abhimanyu, from the Mahabharata , who learnt warfare skills in his mother’s womb.

In her convocation address in LU last year, Patel had said in India, no formal education is imparted to girls about pregnancy, whereas in Germany , there is a dedicated institute. Though designed mainly for females, male students can also opt for the two courses.

Title: Now playing: Laser show with a gallery seat at Almatti Dam
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

The sound and light show is expected to increase the number of visitors to the reservoir in Vijayapura distric... Read More

ALMATTI (VIJAYAPURA): The much-awaited laser show has kicked off at the Almatti, making it perhaps the second largest such spectacle in south India, after the one at Hyderabad’s Lumbini Park . Tourists say the play of lights on the water is a sight to behold and the Alamatti is soon becoming the ‘KRS of North Karnataka’.

Named after Lal Bahadur Shastri, the reservoir stands 519.6 metres tall and is set to be raised to 524.3m. Surrounded by rock gardens, the dam site, spanning 77 acres, is one of the hottest tourist destinations in the region. The laser show began from January 26.

“The laser setup costs Rs 7 crore and the garden for the show was constructed in 2017 at Rs 4.4 crore,” said RP Kulkarni, chief engineer of the dam zone, KBJNL. “Due to lack of seating arrangement for the audience, the inauguration was deferred. The recent floods also caused severe damage to the garden.”

The government sanctioned Rs 88 lakh for repairs and Rs 2 crore to create seating. “The show is centred on patriotism. Other themes like folklore, mythology, background of the Krishna river, irrigation and history are in programming,” Kulkarni said. Spread over 20 minutes, the multimedia show throws up a water screen of 16.8 million colour patterns, set to digital sound effect from 12 speakers.

Andani Tolamatti, a shopkeeper at IB Circle in Almatti, said the laser

show is drawing tourists from as far as Mumbai, Solapur and Hyderabad. “We are also urging visitors to stop and enjoy the show. Those who have seen it say it is notches above the music fountain,” he said.

“Many visitors from south Karnataka are saying Almatti has more to offer than KRS,” said Laxman Darbar, a local musician. “Almatti has a heritage too because of the legends associated with Ramayana. The Sitimani and Almatti hills are natural marvels and provide an organic backdrop for the imposing dam. The roads leading to the dam, with their ups and downs, make for a thrilling journey.”

Shekhar Palani, a resident, credited several officials, former and serving, for bringing the laser show to Alamatti. “Retired chief engineer C Anantharamu, CE Kulkarni and other officials like Abdul Hassan, SH Manjappa, Narendra, SB Chittawadagi and Shankrayya Mathapati have worked over several years to achieve this,” he said.

Title: Activist condemns rampant misuse of sedition law
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

HUBBALLI: Condemning the chanting of Pro-Pakistan slogans at rallies and events organised to protest Citizenship (Amendment) Act ( CAA ) and the National Register of Citizens ( NRC ), co-convener of the Samajwadi Samagam Sunilam, in the same vein, lambasted the misuse of provisions of the sedition law to muzzle dissent.

Calling for a detailed inquiry into the incident at Freedom Park in Bengaluru, wherein a 19-year-old girl was arrested after raising a Pro-Pakistan slogan , Sunilam said, “Filing cases against such individuals must be followed by a detailed inquiry. Off late, the sedition law is being misused indiscriminately. Cases filed against the parent of a student, and teachers of a school in Bidar, and the incident involving a writer in Koppal are regrettable. Misuse of the sedition law was not as rampant earlier.”

“In its first phase, our awareness rally ‘Bharat Jodo, Samvidhan Bachao Samajwadi Yatra’ will pass through 16 states of the country, and leaders of six of them will participate in the event. It will conclude in March in Hyderabad,” said Sunilam.

Charging the central government with rolling out CAA, NRC and the National Population Register to distract the people from the cratering economy, Sunilam said, “The number of youngsters currently unemployed in India stands at a staggering 15 crore, while the Gross Domestic Product is now hovering in the 2% to 4% range.”

Convener of Samajwadi Samagam Arun Kumar Srivastav said that the CAA and NRC were issues that concerned not just Hindus and Muslims, but all the poor people of India. Srivastav claimed that the Government of India could, only if it would, solve the plaguing problem of unemployment in a day. “Health and education are two sectors that have suffered neglect by Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s government. More than five crore people can be provided employment in the education sector alone given the number of vacancies for teachers. Posts of teachers are lying unfilled even in premier colleges such as IIT,” he added.

Alleging that Electronic Voting Machines (EVMs) were tampered with in the Lok Sabha elections held last year, Srivastav said, “The Election Commission is not being honest about this. The officials are not allowing those who wish to demonstrate how this can be done. They are asking sceptics to prove their point from a distance, without allowing any of them to touch the device or open it. The truth will come out if the EVM is opened.”
