He pointed to the use of ballot papers for elections in most developed countries. “We are planning on carrying out a nationwide rally to raise awareness about electoral malpractices,” Srivastav said.

Title: Dingaleshwar Swami reiterates claim to pontifical throne of Moorusavir Math
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Dingaleshwar Swami, sought the presence of Rajyogindra Swami at Sunday’s meeting

HUBBALLI: The dispute over succession to the pontifical throne of the Moorusavir Math was at the centre of yet another dramatic episode here on Friday with Dingaleshwar Swamiji of Balehosur Math being a principal character in the sequence of events. While he claimed that he was the rightful successor to Gurusidda Rajyogindra Swamiji, the incumbent seer of Moorusavir Mutt, legal advisor to the chief minister Mohan Limbikai lashed out at the former for needlessly raking up the issue.

Dingaleshwar Swami said that he would hold a Satya Darshana, a congregation of Moorusavir Math devotees within its premises on Sunday and explain his stance on the issue of succession. Calling on Rajyogindra Swami to clear the air surrounding the question of his successor, Dingaleshwar Swami said, “His continued silence will only further muddle the issue.”

Although Limbikai said that no meeting would be permitted on the premises of the Moorusavir Math on Sunday, Dingaleshwar Swami said that there was no question of backing down at this juncture. “We have sought permission from police to hold the meeting, to attend which devotees from various districts are coming here. There is no restriction on devotees willing to attend the meeting. It will be a peaceful meeting and police must ensure adequate security for the session,” Dingaleshwar Swami added.

On the other hand, Limbikai dismissed reports of his having signed a letter confirming Dingaleshwar Swami as the successor to Rajyogindra Swami. “That is a closed chapter and there is nothing to be gained by discussing it. Rajyogindra Swamiji is capable of overseeing the daily affairs of the math, and will continue to be its seer,” Limbikai added.

Dingaleshwar Swami, meanwhile, sought the presence of Rajyogindra Swami at Sunday’s meeting, in the course of which he claimed he would justify his claim to the Moorusavir Math’s pontifical office. Dingaleshwar Swami liked his plight to that of a groom left stranded on his wedding day owing to a ply of a few conspirators who abduct the bride-to-be.

Dingaleshwar Swamiji alleged that Rajyogindra Swami was being confined by those opposed to the former. “A few people are keeping mum over the issue by stating that the issue is sub-judice. But I want to state that the matter is not pending before the court,” he added.

Dharwad district in-charge minister Jagadish Shettar expressed dismay over the controversy that had erupted over the issue, which he pointed out was pending before the court. “I am not aware of Dingaleshwar Swami’s ‘Satya Darshana’. Members of the high-powered committee of the math have not announced the date for such a meeting, and such events must be discussed in public,” said Shettar.

Title: More than 1,000 wrestlers set to showcase prowess at Karnataka Kusti Habba
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Three mud arenas have been prepared for the Karnataka Kusti Habba

DHARWAD: ‘Karnataka Kusti Habba ’, the four-day state level mega wrestling competition will be held at the Karnatak College grounds here on Saturday.

It is the second edition of the state-level indigenous wrestling competitions and being held for the first time in the district.

Over 1,200 native wrestlers will wrestle for various titles at this event, which has been organised by the department of youth empowerment and sports in association with the district administration and Hubballi-Dharwad Municipal Corporation (HDMC).

Chief minister B S Yediyurappa is scheduled to inaugurate the event at 4 pm. on Saturday. Union parliamentary affairs minister Pralhad Joshi, deputy chief ministers Govind Karajol, Ashwathanarayana, Lakshman Savadi, youth empowerment and sports minister C T Ravi, minister in charge of the district Jagadish Shettar and others will be the chief guests. Dharwad MLA Amrut Desai will preside over the inaugural session.

Eminent wrestling champions of national and international repute including the winner of the gold medal at the Asian Games Kartar Singh, Olympics bronze medal winner Yogeshwar Dutt, Rajiv Gandhi Khel Ratna awardee woman wrestler Sakshi Mallick and others will participate in this event.

North Karnataka region still hosts large number of indigenous wrestlers and the indigenous gymnasiums known as ‘Garadi Mane’.

Three mud wrestling arenas have been prepared for the competitions.

Amrut Desai who is supervising the arrangements said as a tribute to the legendary wrestlers of this region, the wrestling arenas and entrances of the venue will be named after the Hind Kesari awardee Chumbaa Mutnal, Jyoti Ustad, Maruti Ustad, Parishappa Narasinganavar, Mudukappa Kusugal, Manappa Amaragol and Santosh Hosamani of Chikkamalligwad. These wrestlers have not only won laurels but also strived to preserve, conserve and promote this native sport, he said.

Boarding and lodging for the participants will be provided at 17 locations; arrangements have been to feed 2,000 people including coaches and umpires at the premises of the District Institute of Education and Training (DIET). A medical unit too has been set up.

Department of food and civil supplies will host a food mela at the football ground.

Title: 29 pedestrians killed near Bengaluru Metro stations in 2 years: Study
Content:
Pedestrians wait to cross a busy road near Majestic Metro station

Times View Last month, BMRCL announced that it would allow non-Metro commuters to use the Metro’s facilities for free, in an attempt to reduce the number of pedestrian accidents near its stations. But apart from this welcome initiative, more needs to be done, especially around crowded areas like Majestic. More foot overbridges and a greater police presence would go a long way in ensuring citizen safety around Metro stations. The authorities concerned also need to make sure the proposed and recently built overbridges are well maintained and easy to use, which is often not the case.

BENGALURU: In an indication of poor pedestrian facilities, 29 pedestrians were killed in and around Metro stations during 2017 and 2018, shows a study by The Footpath Initiative .The study is based on statistics available with traffic police. According to TFI — an urban project aimed at improving walkers ’ safety in Bengaluru — these fatalities were recorded within 150 metres of the stations.The maximum pedestrian deaths (6) were reported from Majestic Interchange station, where the two currently functional corridors intersect. It could be due to heavy pedestrian movement in an area that is a transport hub with railway and bus stations, the study said. It’s one of the busiest Metro stations on the entire network.Statistics show Green Line stations accounted for more deaths than those on Purple Line. Goraguntepalya reported the second highest deaths (4), while Rajajinagar and Yeshwantpur saw three each. Similarly, Peenya Industry and Dasarahalli witnessed two deaths each. Other Green Line stations at KR Market, Chickpet, Jalahalli and Nagasandra witnessed one death each.Stations along Purple Line were comparatively safer for pedestrians. Mysuru Road, Deepanjali Nagar, Vidhana Soudha, Indiranagar and Byappanahalli stations reported one death each.Green Line (24.2km) is longer than Purple Line (18.2km) but the latter has more ridership. Stretches like Bengaluru-Tumakuru highway, along which Green Line runs, are more dangerous for Metro passengers to cross.Even as government agencies, including BBMP, BMRCL and DULT, have been promising safe at-grade pedestrian crossings, wider pavements and cycle tracks along all stations, walkers remain vulnerable to accidents.“We have compiled the report based on FIR data pertaining to pedestrian fatalities in the vicinity of Metro stations. The data indicate more deaths occur while people are crossing roads around stations. Safe at-grade crossings could be built on roads leading to Metro stations at a fraction of the overall project cost. This will save lives in the years to come,” said Anusha Chitturi, co-founder of TFI.When contacted, BMRCL managing director Ajay Seth said: “Most existing Metro stations will have a crossover or foot overbridge (FOB) for pedestrians by August. The facilities can be used by non-Metro users too.” “In Nagasandra, an FOB is being done built by BMRCL. BBMP will take up work on one at Dasarahalli. The tender for design consultant for the Yeshwantpur FOB had to be scrapped as the lowest bidder didn’t understand the scope of the work. The design is being organised through another agency,” he added.

Title: Amulya sent to custody; she has Naxal links, alleges BSY
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

BENGALURU/ CHIKKAMAGALURU/MYSURU: Amulya Leona Noronha , the 19-year-old activist who was arrested and charged with sedition for chanting ‘Pakistan Zindabad’ at an anti-CAA event in Bengaluru, was on Friday produced before a magistrate who remanded her in judicial custody for 14 days. Hearing on a bail plea filed on her behalf in the same court has been adjourned to Monday.

Amulya was arrested on Thursday when she resorted to pro-Pakistan sloganeering before starting her speech at the anti-CAA event, which was attended by AIMIM chief Asaduddin Owaisi .

Adding a new angle to her offence, Karnataka chief minister B S Yediyurappa on Friday said preliminary investigations conducted overnight have revealed that she has an “association” with Naxals. He, however, added that Amulya was also a “victim” of certain vested groups, who are instigating youngsters.

According to sources, Amulya has told police that, in her speech, she had wanted to compare the silence that greets her reference to Pakistan with the applause that follows ‘ Hindustan zindabad ’ but her speech was cut short.

City police commissioner Bhaskar Rao on Friday said the organisers of the event will be questioned and they will also be dealt under the (sedition) law. “We will investigate who instigated Amulya to raise those slogans and action will be taken. Did they (organisers) not know what she was speaking? The drama of allowing her to talk and trying to prevent her after something damaging was said won’t work. The organisers should know who they are inviting and what they are going to speak,” Rao said.

Barely a few hours after Amulya’s pro-Pakistan slogan, her house in Shivapura in Chikkamagaluru district was attacked by a mob. Police rushed to her house and escorted her family members to an undisclosed location as a precautionary measure, even as locals held a protest in front of the house till noon.

Meanwhile, Amulya’s father Osvald Noronha apologised for his daughter’s action. “I will not extend any legal help to her. Let her stay in jail for a few days. She will understand the law of the land.”

Title: Rajnath lays foundation stone, Army’s new HQ set to be ready in 5 yrs
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

NEW DELHI: The foundation stone for the new Army headquarters or the ‘ Thal Sena Bhawan’ (TSB), which will house 1,684 officers and 4,330 other staff personnel by bringing together the eight existing offices of the force in different parts of the Capital, was laid by defence minister Rajnath Singh at Delhi Cantonment on Friday.

The TSB, spread over 39 acres to include the 6,104 offices in a multi-storey “green” building complex with parking, will take at least five years to be completed at a cost of around Rs 750 crore. “All the departments of the Army as well as the (new) Department of Military Affairs will come under one roof here,” said defence minister Rajnath Singh.

Though most Army officers will shift to the new TSB opposite the Manekshaw Centre in Delhi Cantonment when it comes up, the brass will continue to work from the South Block on the Raisina Hill complex or where the defence ministry is shifted under the proposed Central Vista redevelopment project.

“The offices of senior functionaries in the Army, including the chief and vice-chief, will always be co-located with the Raksha Mantri’s office, wherever it may be” said Army chief General M M Naravane.

Title: US air force new dress code to include turbans
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

WASHINGTON: The US air force has updated its dress code to accommodate the religious sentiments of various communities, including the Sikhs, making it easier for them to join the service. Under the new guidelines, which were finalised recently, Sikhs and Muslims can seek a religious accommodation to wear turbans, beards, unshorn hair and hijabs, and expect to be approved as long as their appearance is “neat and conservative”, except under extremely limited circumstances.

The policy also clarifies that O-6 level commanders can approve an airman’s request for such an accommodation in no more than 30 days (or 60 days if the accommodation is requested outside of the US), and that an accommodation, once granted, will generally follow the airman throughout his or her career. The air force’s clarification closely resembles the US army’s 2017 policy adjustment, which similarly clarified the terms and process for soldiers requesting religious accommodations.

Title: Bengaluru: 3 women rob teenager in Majestic
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Representative image

BENGALURU: An 18-year-old youth was allegedly robbed by three women between KSRTC bus stand and BMTC bus stand in Majestic on Thursday.

Upparpet police said Prajwal M, a college dropout from Challakere town in Chitradurga district, arrived at the KSRTC bus stand around 12.30am and was to board a BMTC bus to reach satellite bus stand on Mysuru Road.

"Prajwal was walking towards the BMTC bus stand when three women demanded he accompany them. Prajwal refused to oblige. But the women demanded he give them some money if he is not interested in accompanying them. They threatened Prajwal that they would scream and create a scene alleging that he misbehaved with them. A scared Prajwal gave them Rs 4,000 and the trio escaped from the spot," a police officer said. Police have registered a case of extortion and efforts are on to trace the trio.

Title: PIO Google staffer held on suspicion of wife’s death
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Seattle-based Google product manager Sonam Saxena was arrested in Hawaii on Wednesday on suspicion of the second degree murder of his wife. Sonam, 43, was arrested after his wife, Smriti , went missing a day earlier. A body was found near Aneaho’omalu Bay, her last known location. The police have yet to positively identify the body as Smriti’s.

Prior to police finding the body, Saxena told news outlet West Hawaii Today that he last saw his wife in that area, and that she had suffered an asthma attack. He said he offered to return to their room at the Waikoloa Beach Resort to get her inhaler. He said he was “disturbed” because, upon returning, he found his wife’s phone and purse but she was missing. He said he rushed back to his room to dial 911. “We called out for her, but there was nothing. No response.”

Saxena had even put out a call for help on his LinkedIn page. saying: “ Can you please promote this tweet so that I can tell my daughters where their Mom is #help.” The Saxenas have two children.

Sonam worked for Google and Smitri for Microsoft. Sonam moved to Seattle from India in 2008.

Title: Government to seek NPA relief for companies hit by coronavirus
Content:
(Representative image)

NEW DELHI: The government is going to seek a relaxation in rules for classification of bank loans to a certain set of companies as a “sub-standard” asset, citing difficulties faced by them. These entities are engaged in export and import, or are those that depend on raw materials and inputs, from China where businesses have been impacted due to the coronavirus outbreak.The move follows a petition from some industry representatives to finance minister Nirmala Sitharaman to not just relax the norms but also ensure access to funds to tide over payment issues that may arise due to problems in accessing inputs and critical raw material. The proposal is part of a host of measures that have been identified by the finance ministry for action, following consultations with industry and other government departments, sources told TOI.The finance ministry is expected to take up the issue with the Reserve Bank of India (RBI) over the next few days to ensure that companies that are part of special mention accounts (SMAs) continue to get access to funds despite payment problems.The change in the Income Recognition and Asset Classification (IRAC) norms is seen to be a temporary measure till the impact of the deadly virus recedes. A company is put in an SMA-0 category if the principal or loan remains unpaid for up to 30 days, while defaults of 31 to 60 days results in an SMA-2 classification. Amounts remaining overdue for up to 90 days lead to an SMA-3 categorisation.During the interaction, it had emerged that some of the industries — such as pharmaceuticals, electronics, auto parts and solar equipment — had been impacted by coronavirus, which has now claimed over 2,200 lives and infected close to 80,000 people.Following the FM’s consultations, the government has already moved in to invoke the “force majeure” clause to provide relief to suppliers who are finding it tough to execute government contracts due to the coronavirus outbreak. Late Thursday evening, the government instructed customs authorities to provide 24x7 clearance at all airports, seaports and inland container depots. Some of the other moves are expected to be announced over the coming days.

Title: New deadline for completing Outer Ring Road is year end
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Nagpur: The National Highways Authority of India’s (NHAI’s) contractor MEP Infrastructure has set a deadline for completing the Outer Ring Road by year end. The work order for the 61-kilometre stretch was issued in April 2016 and it was to be completed in three years.

Project director NL Yeotkar said the work had been divided into two packages — 33km-long first package which covered the stretch from Jamtha to Fetri via Gondkhairi and the 28km-long second one from Fetri to Pawangaon on Bhandara Road (beyond Kapsi).

“The first package at the cost of Rs 531 crore is 52% complete while the second one at Rs 649 crore is 43.5% ready,” he added.

Yeotkar admitted that the contract period expired long ago and added that the contractor had been fined. “We could not terminate the contract as we had not handed over the entire land. Now, 100% land required for the project is with him. He is facing some financial problems and is holding talks with the bank. I’m unaware of the outcome,” he said.

Under this project, NHAI will construct a new 40-km cement concrete four-lane road from Gondkhairi on Amravati Road to Bhilgaon-Sirpur on the Kamptee-Jabalpur section of NH 44 via Fetri on Kalmeshwar-Katol road, Bharatwada, Panjara on Koradi-Chhindwara section of NH 47. It will also widen the 21-km stretch from Gondkhairi to Gavasi Manapur on NH 44 from the existing two-lane to four-lane and convert it to concrete road. The ORR will also have an interchange with the under-construction Mumbai-Nagpur super expressway. NHAI will construct five railway overbridges, 20 minor bridges and 15 underpasses under the project.

The project is being developed under NHAI’s hybrid annuity system. NHAI will pay 40% of total cost to the contractor during the construction period. The remaining 60% will be paid in three instalments over 15 years from the date of completion with a fixed rate of return. When the work order was issued, the project was the first in the state and second in the country to be developed under hybrid annuity system.

NHAI will levy toll to recover the project cost. Toll will be recovered by NHAI through a private agency other than the one executing the project.

Title: Sebi eyes unique ids for shares to tackle Karvy-type frauds
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

(File photo)

BENGALURU: To prevent frauds like what happened at Karvy Stock Broking, markets regulator Sebi is considering a unique identity number for dematerialised shares that will establish a trail of ownership.

Before the demat era, switching shares was not possible. As a share certificate changed hands, the transactions were recorded on the certificate itself. In dematerialised shares, transfers are documented, but the absence of a unique identity made it possible for Karvy to pledge clients’ shares, held in its account, as if they were its own. Both Sebi and the NSE are currently probing this fraud.

Karvy had pledged shares with Bajaj Finance, ICICI Bank , HDFC Bank, IndusInd Bank and others to raise funds. It owes Bajaj Finance as much as Rs 300 crore.

“In the physical era, every share had three numbers — certificate numbers and a distinctive number which were unique to that company share, and the folio number, which marked the ownership.

The new owner’s folio number would be recorded on the reverse of the certificate after every transaction,” said a Sebi official, aware of the discussions.

Sources said Sebi could look at employing decentralised ledgers like blockchain or hashgraphs for maintaining historical records of the unique ids for shares.

“After demat, shares — like currency — became untraceable. If unique certificate numbers had been in existence, Karvy could have never pledged its clients’ shares as its own without the banks noticing,” said the official. Of some 95,000 affected clients, Karvy returned securities of nearly 83,000 clients. Now lenders have appealed, claiming a lien on the shares.

Title: 1st Test: India bundled out for 165 against New Zealand on Day 2
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Ajinkya Rahane looks back after his dismissal against New Zealand at the Basin Reserve in Wellington. (AP Phot... Read More

WELLINGTON: Debutante Kyle Jamieson and veteran Tim Southee took four wickets apiece to knock India out for a paltry 165 in little over an hour on the second day of the first Test here on Saturday.

Jamieson (4/49 in 16 overs) and Southee (4/49 in 20.1 overs) took four of the five wickets that fell on the second morning with India adding only 43 runs to their overnight score of 122 for 5.

SCORECARD

Rishabh Pant (19) started with a six but then a horrible mix-up with senior partner Ajinkya Rahane (46) resulted in a run-out and the little chances of recovery was gone for good.

Ravichandran Ashwin got a beauty from Southee, pretty similar to what Prithvi Shaw got, while Rahane inside edged one while trying to leave it alone.

It was Mohammed Shami (21), who chanced his arms a bit hitting a few blows that got India above 150-run mark.

He added 22 runs with Ishant Sharma for the ninth wicket. They were both out in quick succession as the innings folded in only 68.1 overs.

Title: Devpt works in Gadchiroli to get boost: Anil Deshmukh
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Nagpur: Anil Deshmukh, on his first visit to the Maoist-affected tribal Gadchiroli district after taking over as home minister, said at a press meet on Friday that pending development works in remote localities will pick up pace soon. He also said tackling the rebel movement would be done in a phased manner by the Mahavikas Aghadi (MVA) government.

Deshmukh, flanked by former minister Dharmaraobaba Atram, collector Deepak Singla, DIG Mahadeo Tambade and SP Shailesh Balkawade, also said issues related to the district, especially those related to development, would be addressed on priority. The government would try to find phase-wise solutions to developmental works.

During the visit, Deshmukh also reviewed security issues and different projects under the district administrations in separate meetings. He also met party workers from different parts of Gadchiroli, who raised a demand to construct a statue of former district guardian minister and ex-home minister late RR Patil.

Deshmukh, reiterating the stance of MVA alliance, and echoing the opinion of his party supremo Sharad Pawar regarding the Elgar parishad and Koregaon-Bhima case, raised question on the Central government’s decision to hand over the probe to the National Investigation Agency (NIA). He said that the Centre had taken a unilateral decision in this matter.

“Just when we were considering formation of Special Investigating Team (SIT) to probe the two cases of Elgar parishad and Koregaon-Bhima, the Centre shifted them to NIA without consulting the state,” he said. Deshmukh also said the past government bracketed anyone who raised question on them or opposed their moves as ‘urban Naxal’.

Deshmukh also said the government would now consider restarting recruitment process in police department and also in the Maharashtra State Security Corporation. “The recruitment would throw open opportunities for aspirants in Gadchiroli district too,” he said.

Stressing on increasing employment facilities, Deshmukh said projects like Surjagadh need to be supported. “Our government is trying to revive projects like Surjagadh to generate employment here,” said the home minister.

Deshmukh also said his government would ensure adequate compensation for ryots who faced losses due to overflow from the Medigadda baragge of Telangana. He said there is a coordination meeting going on between officials of the two states.

Title: Chanda cops to verify use of subsidized coal by industries
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Chandrapur: Local crime branch has intensified probe into the alleged coal scam and has dispatched four teams to industries that are suspected to be involved in sale of subsidized coal in open market at premium rates.

LCB in-charge PI Omprakash Kokate informed that cops had summoned representatives of the industries that had lifted the coal from mines for questioning. However, as none of the industries responded, a team each has been dispatched to four separate districts to investigate the records of subsidized coal taken and utilized by the beneficiary units.

Kokate claimed that seven companies under scanner are Geeta Refinery, Bhumi Cotex and Asthlaxmi Reloading Pvt Ltd from Jalna, Roshan Linework from Rajur in Yavatmal district, Ram-Ratan Casting, Nagpur, Umesh Boards and Paper Mills of Aurangabad and Shri Minerals and Chemicals, Bhandara.

“Our teams are going to visit the industries in Jalna, Bhandara, Yavatmal and Nagpur. Cops will verify the records related to lifting of subsidized coal, transportation procedure, stock and utilization,” said Kokate.

LCB team had detained 26 trucks loaded with subsidized coal at a private coal depot near Nagada village on Tuesday. The coal was allotted to seven industries by Maharashtra State Mining Corporation (MSMC) at subsidized rate for industrial use. However, the coal was taken to the private depot where the LCB team conducted the raid.

Meanwhile, the deadlock over filing of the complaint continues between the LCB and MSMC as the corporation officials are not willing to file any report without their own inquiry into the alleged malpractice.

MSMC general manager Premchand Tembhre said the utilization committee would check the record of coal lifted by the concerned company and its utilization during recent months. “Only after procedural inquiry, we will decide if there is any illegality involved in dumping of coal at private coal depot,” he said.

Though the LCB is continuing probe, it is not willing to file suo motu complaint. “The government agency responsible for ensuring that subsidized coal allocated to industrial units is not misused or sold in market should file the complaint. But MSMC has denied to take the responsibility. Hence, we are investigating on our own, while they (MSMC officials) carry out their inquiry,” said Kokate.

MSMC allocates quota of subsidized coal to hundreds of industries across the state every month. There is possibility that many of these companies are seeking excessive quota, while a bunch of them might be closed and still claiming the coal and selling it in the open market through traders.

Title: Thane: Teacher held for molesting five students
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Representative image

KALYAN: A 48-year-old teacher was on Friday arrested for molesting five students at a Titwala school. The teacher was booked for molestation under sections of the IPC and the Pocso Act.

Police said the teacher, after molesting the students, would blackmail them, saying that if they complained to anybody, he would fail them in exams. The school has sacked Vishal Mitkar.

Police said the incident came to light after a girl complained to her parents. She said he would harass other students too. Parents on Thursday informed the school and complained to the police, who registered an FIR, said senior inspector Balaji Pandhare.

(The victims' identity has not been revealed to protect their privacy as per Supreme court directives on cases related to sexual assault)

Title: 4 women die in earth collapse at weir site
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Nagpur: Four woman labourers were killed and three others were injured after loose earth collapsed on them during excavation at the site of an under-construction weir on a nullah at Pathkedi, near Adasa village in Saoner tehsil, on Friday. The accident site is around 40km from the city.

The deceased have been identified as Varsha Madavi (26), Anusaya Tekam (45), Sunita Kailash (35) and Rampyari Kakoriya (18). Three others were injured and rushed to Nagpur for treatment, and later discharged.

It’s learnt the women labourers were engaged in construction work for the irrigation department, which had kicked off around a week ago. The labourers from Madhya Pradesh had taken no precaution against such earth collapse.

Police sources said the women labourers had been digging for the last few days. The upper layer of earth collapsed on the labourers engaged in digging at the base of the pit. The other labourers tried to rescue the women trapped under the earth but they could not be retrieved until a JCB was pressed into action. The deceased were taken to Madhya Pradesh after post mortem was performed.

Saoner police have registered an offence against contractor Mandeep Chaudhuri and site supervisor Jagdish Prasad for causing death due to negligence. tnn

Title: Man sends wife pics before hanging self
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Nagpur: A 24-year-old man sent his wife pictures of himself tying a scarf to the ceiling fan before committing suicide at a rented flat in Ajni on Thursday. The deceased, identified as Nihal Singh, hanged himself allegedly over a tiff with his wife.

According to police, Nihal, a diploma student, had done love marriage around a year ago. On Thursday, both Nihal and his wife had gone to houses of their respective parents.

The couple had a fight after Nihal reached the home of his in-laws to pick up his wife late in the night. Nihal had to leave home alone. He later made a video call to his wife and they again got into a quarrel, following which he sent her pictures of himself tying a scarf to the ceiling fan. Nihal also told his wife that he was committing suicide, said cops and added that he had threatened to end his life earlier too.

Meanwhile, Nihal’s wife along with her relatives rushed to her house but till then Nihal had ended his life. Ajni police have registered accidental death.

Title: Are you creating brands or consumers?
Content:
(From Left): Hemant Malik (divisional chief executive, foods business, ITC), Subodh Bhargava (independent dire... Read More

How brands and new business models create sustainable growth

A dive into how companies can make consumers active participants in value creation

Trust is the world’s biggest economic power

How companies can use it to their advantage

Innovation pays most when uncertainty peaks

How marketers can anticipate change, prepare for it and enjoy it

NEW DELHI: The second day of Star FLOW — The Change Festival, an initiative by The Times of India — opened with the session ‘The New Brand Model — Are you creating Brands or Consumers?’ by Marty Neumeier, director of CEO Branding at Liquid Agency, redefining branding for marketers.“I changed it from being a logo, or a message or a campaign or a product to being something else. A brand is a person’s gut feeling about the product, service or company,” said Neumeier.The best-selling author said a brand is not what a company thinks it is but rather what a customer thinks it is. “You have to look at it from the other way round, which is really hard. Companies have difficulty in seeing their brands from the point of view of the customer. But that’s the main trick,” said Neumeier, who wrote several books, including ‘The Brand Gap’ and ‘ZAG’.Power has shifted from companies to customers because of the internet and social media, he said, while explaining that in the new-age brand model, companies create customers first. “For instance, you co-design a product or service with a specific set of customers you want to work for. They help you create it. They keep telling people about this great product they are involved with. They build a tribe.”Neumeier told marketers that people are not focused on products as much they mean. “Customers buy products to build their identities, they hate being sold, but they love to buy, they buy in tribes to feel safe and successful. And, the company with the strongest tribe wins.”Erich Joachimsthaler, the founder and CEO of Vivaldi Group, a New York-headquartered 150-person independent strategy, brand, and innovation marketing consulting firm, opened his session by dividing branding into two parts — brand strategy and brand architecture.While strategy is what a company is or aspires to be, architecture combines all things such as products and strategy, said Joachimsthaler. Talking about evolution of branding, he said the clamour around technology started about a quarter of a century ago with ecommerce and search algorithm, followed by social media. Currently, people are talking about AI, IoT and Blockchain.“While earlier the brand architecture was confined to a world of walls characterised by production, marketing, design, and research, now it is more about the world of web characterised by producers and consumers,” said Joachimsthaler.He quoted the example of Lego and how the company aced the brand strategy. “Lego reached out to its customers and asked them to build designs with old Lego sets and put them online. If the design won more than 10,000 votes, it would be mass-produced by Lego.”He said through this process, they involved customers in value creation. This led to people talking about the brand in their circles and created powerful branding.He said while in earlier days, branding was about extracting premium, currently it is about engaging with the customers. Elaborating about how to build a strong brand, he listed three things — network effect, learning effect and viral effect. The network effect talks about how a product becomes more valuable as more and more people talk about it. The learning effect happens as the company applies human knowledge and artificial intelligence to make its brand better. And, the viral effect kicks in when consumers become advocates of a brand and encourage others to use these products and services.Philipp Kristian Deikhoner, author of the book, The Trust Economy, said marketers and brands across the world have had to cope up with shifts in generations, from baby boomers to Gen X, millennials and Gen Z and tweak their strategies. With the rise of the Zen Z, one of the most important avenues for the brands to tap is the ‘Trust Economy’.The Trust Economy deals with trust being the most impactful economic power. Deikhoner said Trust Economy is driven by Gen Z and Gen Y, enabled by data, technology and digital platforms and it values factors, such as, speed, flexibility, agility and convenience.Deikhoner said the experience inside an organisation mirrors the experience outside and hence building trust within the organisation is the first step in that direction. “Work environment in most organisations isn’t conducive to innovation, as there isn’t enough trust between the people. When organisations hire young people, they need to trust them and enable them to innovate.”Once the trust has been established within the organisation, it would further help in building trust among customers. “The brands need to weave stories and then make the customers trust their stories,” said Deikhoner, adding, it is however important that these stories are authentic and honest, especially in case of a controversial product, such as a cigarette or an alcohol brand.Talking about the ways brands can salvage trust after having had a breach, he said that it depends on number of breaches that have taken place and the history of the brand. If the brand has had a long reputable history, a couple of breaches are manageable. However, even in this case, it is important that the brands are honest. “The best strategy in case of a breach is to be upfront, accept the mistake, instead of trying to put it away and manipulate customers.” He gave the example of an oil spill by a company, saying that the involvement was very high, the customers forgot about the breach in a very short time, hence the customer’s involvement with the brand is also a very important factor in handling such breaches.While maintaining trust on their part, brands also have to be careful that they do not give customers a window of opportunity to break the trust. “For instance, if an e-commerce company is getting customers through frequent discounts, the trust they are generating is transactional in nature and hence once the discount goes away, the customer moves to break the trust,” said Deikhoner. He added that companies tend to seem too needy and desperate when they offer too many discounts or promotions.From showing images of the garage where computer maker Hewlett-Packard (HP) was founded to charting the routes of Amerigo Vespucci and Christopher Columbus on a giant map, Charles Leadbeater, author and leading authority on innovation and creativity, revealed how uncertainty can lead to new possibilities.Leadbeater urged marketers to look beyond the mainstream into the margins and ask radically different questions without assuming that one knows.“Be curious not only about your existing customers but about people who might become your customers.”Leadbeater spoke about how the mountain bike was created by modifying cruiser bicycles and why sitting in office for long hours is not a good idea because meeting similar people is not the right way to come up with an innovative idea. Quoting the example of Jaipur Foot as a pathbreaking innovation, he advised marketers and companies to seek out a community because the real unit of innovation is a creative community with a cause.

Title: City woman dies in K’taka accident
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Nagpur: Sharin Francis, a teacher, was killed after the bus in which she was travelling overturned on Friday at Hunsur in Karnataka. Sherin was the daughter of city-based excise department official Ravindra Francis. Several others too were injured in the accident.

Sources said that Sherin, who lives with her husband in Bengaluru, was travelling to Kerala for some ayurvedic treatment when the accident took place.

“My daughter had a problem so she regularly used to go to Kerala for getting ayurvedic treatment. I spoke to her for an hour on Thursday night. After that, she might have boarded the bus for Kerala,” said Francis.

“Sharin was living in Bengaluru since the last three to four years. She got married a few years ago and was working as a teacher,” he added. Sources said that Sharin suffered excessive blood loss after her leg got fractured in the accident.

Family sources said that her body is being brought to Bengaluru via road from Mysuru. She will be brought to the city on Saturday morning by flight.

Title: Western Railway sets Delisle ROB work deadline for BMC
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

A source said WR told BMC that approaches to the Lower Parel bridge should be ready by November 20 (File photo... Read More

MUMBAI: Western Railway has told the BMC to get approaches to Delisle bridge ready by November 2020, as it plans to open the connector by then. It also flagged off issues of encroachments, cables and muck, the removal of which is necessary by BMC to prevent damage to bridges.

The February 20 meeting was between a WR team led by divisional railway commissioner (DRM) G V L Satyakumar and municipal commissioner Pravin Pardeshi.

A source said WR told BMC that approaches to the Lower Parel bridge should be ready by November 20 and Frere bridge before May.

Delisle bridge was shut on July 24, 2018, after joint safety audit by WR and BMC. The railway portion was dismantled and construction above it is under progress.

The IIT-B had recommended a change in the super structure of Frere ROB, whose work is in progress, ever since it was closed on January. WR plans to rebuild the bridge by May 20.

WR also told BMC to remove encroachments from Mahalaxmi ROB to undertake repairs. On Dharavi ROB, WR said there were encroachments at the south-east side. There were also discussions on reconstruction or construction of bridges over railway land, like Gokhale bridge in Andheri and two ROBs in Mahalaxmi.

Title: Simplicity delivers solutions beyond tech: Sonam Wangchuk
Content:
Innovator, education reformist, inspiration for the film 3 Idiots and Ramon Magsaysay Award winner Sonam Wangc... Read More

NEW DELHI: With the onset of tourism in the Leh valley, the locals started getting influenced by the architecture followed in the cities and town. Soon enough, many mud houses were being converted into cement houses as a cement house was a sign of affluence. However, the houses made with cement were unfit for the weather and turned extremely cold during the winters.“After spending significant money on building cement houses, people were forced to spend more money on keeping these houses warm,” says Sonam Wangchuk , innovator, education reformist, inspiration for the film 3 Idiots and Ramon Magsaysay Award winner.Wangchuck and his students wanted to sell the idea of mud houses to the people in the valley, but they realised that the poor did not want these houses as ‘no one wants to be known as poor’.“We then started building mud houses with contemporary architecture and interiors, making them aspirational. Soon, many rich people were building the mud houses and the poor were not tearing away their mud houses for the cement ones,” said Wangchuk, while talking on a session about Simplicity Delivers Beyond-Tech Solutions. He said creating a market and impression around the product also helped them in marketing it.The idea was to brand and position the idea in a way that it sells among the people. Talking about another such simple innovation, he spoke about the concept of ‘Ice Stupas’. Ice Stupas are basically small man-made glaciers that can provide water to the farmers in a region in the, otherwise, dry periods of spring and summer. “Instead of telling people that these were cones of ice, we presented them as Ice Stupas and we even put prayer flags around them,” said Wangchuk. He and his students further got environment ambassadors to endorse the idea and innovation. The Ice Stupa soon became a movement worldwide and people started having stupa building competitions and ice stupa cafes.Going beyond the idea of branding and marketing these innovations, Wangchuk said these were just small fixes and would not help the mountains in the long-term. “We realised that we need to get people to change their behaviour and have to communicate in an innovative way that resonates with them,” he said. Here comes his latest ‘innovation’ called Live Simply movement. The movement allows people to register their steps on the website and it would tell them their contribution towards saving the environment in monetary terms.“One of the most important things about marketing is that the brands have to walk the talk. “I have stopped ironing my clothes to save electricity, I wear shoes bought in 1989 and wear clothes torn and sewn,” said Wangchuk.

Title: Wipro Digital acquires US firm
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

(File photo)

BENGALURU: Wipro Digital , the digital business unit of Wipro, has acquired Washingtonbased Rational Interaction, a full-service digital customer experience (CX) company for an undisclosed sum.

The acquisition will scale Wipro Digital’s offering aimed at chief marketing officers (CMO) to provide bespoke and effective solutions for the marketing suite.

Rational Interaction helps brands create sustained CX programme, with core offerings that include strategic advising, customer acquisition, and customer life cycle management. “The acquisition comes at a time when companies increasingly compete solely on CX, and the market for CX spending is growing exponentially,” said Rajan Kohli, president of Wipro Digital.

Founded in 2009, Rational Interaction has more than 300 employees and offices in Seattle and Bellevue, WA, Dublin, and Sydney . Founded and led by women, Rational Interaction has become one of Washington state’s 100 largest privately-held companies with a roster of Fortune 50 clients.

Title: A Fish Called Hilsa
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Kolkata: Have you ever wondered exactly how many bones your favourite one-kilo hilsa has? Well, it has around 46-48 vertebrae, lots more than humans, and roughly 1,500 smaller bones. This includes the deadly-looking spear-shaped “pin bone” — freely lying “floating bones” within the fish muscles.

Salt Lake-based ophthalmologist Arnab Biswas’s seven-year-old research on hilsa, arguably Bengalis’ favourite fish — had prompted him to first do a CT scan on the fish to understand its bone structure and, later, over several days, painstakingly count every bone it had. And this is just one aspect of Biswas’s hilsa research.

And to think he just wanted to write a cookbook. Starting from that, Biswas has now ended up digging up every possible detail about the hilsa, instead. For seven years, he has worked with a myriad people — fossil experts, fisheries experts, oceanographers, local fishermen, just to dig up unknown nuggets about the fish.

Biswas, whose work ‘Way of the Hilsa’, in which he collaborated with Thailand-based researcher Pratchaya Phinthong and Bangladeshi artist Md Sajedul Haque for display in the Dhaka Art Summit (DAS) in Dhaka’s Shilpakala Academy on February 8, now argues that the hilsa’s origin may be even older that what available research suggests. “It is largely believed from the fossils found in Italy, Japan, Rajasthan and Mizoram that the hilsa’s ancestors, the Clupeidae family [a family of ray-finned fishes, comprising the herrings, shads, sardines, hilsa, and menhadens], can be traced back to 40-50 million years,” Biswas argues. But symbols traced back to the Indus Valley Civilisation denote a fish closely resembling the hilsa, he says. “I have superimposed the hilsa on these symbols, and it matches perfectly,” he says.

And that is not all. “If you know about Jhulelal — a 1000 AD saint, the most revered deity of the Sindhi Hindus and revered by Muslims as Zinda Pir, you’ll know that he travels on a fish on the Indus river. This was the palla, the local name of hilsa in Sindh. Even in the Ajanta caves, in the pictorial representation of the Monkey God in Bodhisattva, there are fish visible on the river. And they, too, have the same shape,” he says. “The palla fish were all believed to come from the Saraswati basin. Also consider the spread of the fossils from Italy to Mizoram,” he says.

Biswas, who along with his wife and son, has been travelling to the coastal belts of India, Bangladesh and Myammar to dig more details, says too little is being done to save the fish. “From my understanding the Hilsa will always come back to the place where it was born. In their life span of 4-5 years, they will make three to four attempts to swim upstream in the river to breed. This is essential for many reasons,” he says. “When the Hilsa swims against the tide on the river to find a breeding place, it eats very less. It also forms polyunsaturated fatty acid. It also urinates more leaving out the toxins from the body. And due to the swimming, the muscles are softer. So, the taste is basically a culmination of all these,” he argues.

Another thing to consider is what hilsa feed on, Biswas says. “I tried to collect plankton samples from a depth of 40 feet in the Ganges. This is what the hilsa feeds on, primarily. However, due to pollution, their natural food resource is now getting sparse,” he adds. “Historically, we know that hilsa swam upstream 1,500km in the Ganges, up to Allahabad. In the Sindh river, it travelled 750km upstream till Multan. Now, that is no longer the case. Instead, we are fishing them from the seas and have set up the Farakka barrage. And by artificial production of hilsa, we are playing havoc with their in-built ‘GPS system’, which allows them to swim thousands of kilometres to breed,” he says. It’s no wonder, he says, that people often complain that hilsa these days don’t taste as good.

The changing patterns of hilsa migration — which has seen disruptions — is a large part of Biswas’s work, with Phinthong and Haque. “I had been in Rangoon and up along the Iravati river, also to several places in Bangladesh,” he says. Similarly, Phinthong and Haque have travelled to Farakka several times. “Viewed in isolation, the Farakka barrage, built in 1975, may seem to be one issue. But this is symptomatic of a larger issue of creating man-made obstacles on their migratory paths, which has large-scale implications.” The other factor, he adds, which may push hilsa to oblivion is the fishing of khoka-ilish or immature hilsa. The Bangladesh government has imposed a fortnight-long fishing ban immediately after Laxmi Puja, he informs, just to stop this.

Biswas says it is a “rarity” for a fish to be so fused with the socio-cultural ethos of Bengalis. “Recently, in Bangladesh, they tried to start a tradition on Poila Baisakh — the Bengali New Year — to have Panta-Ilish. This became so popular that the government had to step in to remind people that this wasn’t Bengali culture. But what the government was trying to do, and rightly so, was to stop fishing of khoka-ilish. In Bengal, too, we have witnessed similar efforts by the government,” he says. “Now, compare this with the much older ritual in Bangladesh’s Faridpur — of having Hilsa roe with puffed rice on Dashami, after immersion. That was the last time they would eat hilsa, starting again only from Saraswati Puja. In Bengal, jora-Ilish or a pair of hilsa is offered in the Puja. Now we understand the reason why people stopped having hilsa in this period. This was breeding time. This window allowed newborn hilsa, called jhatka, to swim back to the seas,” he says.

He signs off with an interesting question: If people could do it then, why not now?

(The writer had been to Dhaka at the invitation of Samdani Art Foundation)

Title: Calcutta high court junks green legal paper, switches to white A4 sheets
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

: The Calcutta High Court

KOLKATA: The Calcutta High Court has dumped green to go green.

All submissions to the Calcutta HC contained in petitions, affidavits and applications will now have to be printed on white A4-size executive bond papers instead of the green or embossed papers used till now, a notification issued earlier this week has said.

Green paper, also known as “legal paper”, is thicker and more damaging to the environment, say experts. Use of such paper also pinches litigants’ pockets; a 500-sheet pack of green paper costs Rs 310 but a similar one of A4 sheets comes for Rs 200.

The initial notification for this change came on January 20. It stated that documents to be submitted in the appellate side of the court should be printed not on green paper but on legal chart paper or on chart paper “cut to legal size” (8.5 inches by 14 inches). The notification also specified the letter font and size and the spacing between letters in computer printed petitions, appeals or affidavits. This notification was to come into retrospective effect from January 1, 2020.

But HC advocate Nikunj Berlia wrote to the Chief Justice on January 24, pointing out that litigants who used green paper between January 1 and January 20 would then suffer. He also questioned the rationale of not having the same rules for the Original side of the court.

Berlia pointed out that the stipulations would leave two-thirds of the page blank, contributing to a huge wastage. He then pushed for printing on both sides, pointing out that people had no problem reading books or magazines.

Berlia filed a petition on these issues that was mentioned by advocate Phiroze Edulji on Monday for early hearing. The fresh notification came a day later, on Tuesday, addressing most of Berlia’s grievances. The new paper rule now applies to both original and appellate sides of the court and the legal chart paper provision has been removed with new margin specifications allowing for full utilisation of space.

The only issue that is yet to be resolved is the matter of printing on both sides. “Reading double-sided books and magazines do not appear problematic for us. Neither then should reading petitions. That will diminish paper consumption by nearly half. A tree produces 8,333 sheets of virgin-non-recycled-paper and it takes 10 litres (2.6 gallons) of water to create a piece of paper. This effortless fix will have a breath-taking effect on our environment,” Berlia’s petition stated.

Title: Why we pay a king’s ransom to eat the ‘king’
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Kolkata: For the hilsa , the undisputable status of ‘king’ of all fishes — if you ask a Bengali — is both a blessing and a curse. The silver slivers of heaven might be getting a lot of attention from both gourmands and chefs, but this is precisely why it is largely responsible for its fast disappearance from Bengal’s platters.

And, with supplies getting thinner and thinner, the cost of hilsa has been shooting through the roof. Experts have spelt doom for the fish, unless prevailing fishing styles, river pollution, riverbed siltation are not reversed. And this is not an easy ask.

For the average Bengali household, having hilsa for lunch or dinner has become an extreme luxury. The smaller variety is tasteless, while the bigger ones, weighing more than 1.5kg, cost a fortune, going for anything between Rs 1,500 and Rs 2,000 a kilo.

“For decades altogether, our insatiable greed has been responsible for the fast-decreasing catch of hilsa,” says Satinath Patra, secretary, West Bengal Fishermen’s Welfare Association. “We continued bottom-trawling and caught juvenile hilsa indiscriminately without paying any heed to the state fisheries department’s notification prohibiting fishing between September 15 sand October 24. We learnt little from our Bangladeshi counterparts,” he adds.

According to the notification, fishing is prohibited in the sea and adjoining estuaries in the deltaic zones from April 15 to May 31 and from September 15 to October 24 to facilitate undisturbed breeding of hilsa. Besides, fishing, hoarding and selling of juvenile hilsa smaller than 23cm in length is prohibited. But only a handful of fishermen comply with such norms, Patra concedes.

Earlier, catching mature hilsa during its upstream swim used to be the sustainable practice among fishermen. “Hilsa used to migrate all the way to Allahabad in the Ganga river system from Bangladesh. Building of a barrage in Farakka completely blocked the Hooghly-Bhagirathi migratory route. I asked one of the architects of the barrage whether he kept in mind the fish passage. He admitted that the barrage was built in a hurry, omitting many things,” said West Bengal Pollution Control Board chairman Kalyan Rudra, who is a river expert.

Though hilsa lives in saltwater, it swims to freshwater and estuarine waters to spawn. Hilsa normally has a life expectancy of four to five years, during which they spawn thrice. They start swimming upstream during the southwest monsoon, when the Hooghly swells. The juveniles go back to the sea and repeat the cycle. These juveniles are caught during their seaward migration with fine nets, says Asim Nath, a fisheries expert with the Sidho Kanhu Birsa University.

There were desperate measures on the part of the government. To ramp up the hilsa supply round the year, scientists from Kakdwip’s Institute of Aqua Culture have been trying an innovative method of cultivating the fish in tank water with induced salinity, but the measure has been met with little success.

The scientists initially failed to save the seedlings but after making changes in the salinity content of the water and bringing changes in the feed, are now optimistic. Some apprehensions were expressed about whether the unique taste of the fish would be retained as it travels through the Pacific Ocean before coming to the shores of Bengal. “We are hopeful now. As the feed consists of ‘phytoplankton’, the taste will be intact,” said a scientist.

Title: ‘Egiye ashun’ posters put Sovan back in reckoning
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Kolkata: Residents of south Kolkata on Friday woke up to “Apni egiye ashun Sovanda” (come forward Sovanda) posters put up along major roads in the run-up to civic polls, sparking speculation about which side former mayor Sovan Chatterjee is on.

The posters bear no political party’s name but are embossed with a lotus symbol. These have been issued by Kolkata Nagarik Brinda, an innocuous group, but doesn’t clarify the affiliation question. The posters call for reclusive Sovan’s return to restore the old glory of Kolkata Municipal Corporation and resume the “good work” he had done as mayor and finish development projects for the city.

Bengal BJP vice-president Jayprakash Majumdar didn’t consider the posters official. “These posters were not issued by the party. But we all want Sovanda back at work. There is no denying he has the experience, and did good work for the city,” Majumdar said and added that Sovan was now with BJP.

Were the posters a teaser for Sovan’s return to active politics under the BJP banner? So it would seem from what Sovan’s friend Baisakhi Banerjee said. “Sovanda distanced himself from active politics for past several months owing to differences of opinion with some BJP leaders. But I will be happy to see him back in action. I am surprised to see that even a poster can elicit such response despite his long absence from political arena,” she said.

Baisakhi, however, didn’t name BJP. What’s more is her recent visit to Trinamool senior Partha Chatterjee’s Naktala home that has sent out mixed signals about Sovan’s political future.

“Sovan left the party himself. He has to decide what he will do now. I wish him to come back to active politics,” said Partha Chatterjee.

Political observers believe Sovan has issued the posters to ensure his mayoral candidacy in the battle for the Kolkata municipal polls.

Bengal BJP, however, is not making any promises to Sovan before he takes the civic poll plunge. “We are yet to decide candidates and faces for the municipal election,” BJP state general secretary Sayantan Basu said.

There is no commitment from Trinamool either about Sovan leading the ruling-party brigade in Kolkata civic polls.

Title: BJP awaits police nod for Amit Shah’s Kolkata rally
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Union home minister Amit Shah

KOLKATA: Bengal BJP is yet to get a go-ahead from the police for holding Union home minister Amit Shah ’s rally in Kolkata on March 1. The party has lined up a civic reception for Shah on the Shahid Minar ground for steer- ing the Citizenship (Amendment) Act in Parliament. “We sought police permission for holding the rally on the Shahid Minar ground. But Lalbazar has neither given a go-ahead to the meeting, nor has it turned down our proposal,” Bengal BJP president Dilip Ghosh said on Friday. In 2014, Bengal BJP had to move court for holding then BJP president Shah’s rally in Kolkata. Ghosh hopes that police won’t come in the way of the home minister’s programme. Police are yet to communicate their decision to the rally organisers. Ghosh said BJP has received permission from the Army, the custodian of the Shahid Minar ground. He added that the use of loudspeakers on that date won’t go against the ban on use of microphones during board examinations. “First, the Shahid Minar ground doesn’t come under any residential area. There is no chance of disturbance to students and their parents. Second, there is no examination scheduled that day,” the Bengal BJP president said. BJP is looking up to Shah’s rally to give the party a fillip at a time anti-CAA protesters have been regularly hitting the city streets even as BJP leaders are busy holding pro-CAA rallies in the districts. “We wanted PM Narendra Modi to come to Kolkata. But he has pre-occupations. Amitji is coming on March 1,” Ghosh said. Trinamool senior and state parliamentary affairs minister Partha Chatterjee has no problem over Shah’s Kolkata visit. “He had come to Kolkata earlier as BJP president. He is the Union home minister now. I believe he will hold the rally abiding by the rules and protocol for holding the programme,” Chatterjee said.

Title: Smokers more susceptible to coronavirus attack, say experts
Content:
Representative image

KOLKATA: Smoking makes you several times more vulnerable to an attack by the novel coronavirus nCoV ) that has taken more than 2,000 lives across China and southeast Asia so far, warn experts.A cell receptor — a component in the cell to which viruses stick easily — turns more pronounced in smokers thus attracting the virus and allowing it entry into the system, the experts have pointed out. In case of an outbreak in the state, transmission of the virus could be rapid since 36% of Bengal’s population use tobacco and two-thirds of Kolkatans are exposed to smoking in public places, according to a recent study.Studies conducted in the aftermath of the SARS outbreak in 2003 revealed that the ACE2 or the angiotensin converting enzyme 2 receptor of the human cell turns more ‘expressed’ in smokers. Both the human airway epithelia as well as lung parenchyma of smokers were found to have the more pronounced receptor and a considerable number of them were afflicted with SARS — the deadly respiratory distress triggered by a virus that resulted in more than 800 deaths. It might be happening in the case of Covid-19 as well, suspect doctors.SARS and Covid-19 are similar in the way they affect the human system. Both affect the lungs severely leading to respiratory distress and death in some cases, pointed out consultant Arindam Biswas.Biswas said, “Some initial analyses have suggested that COVID-19 might have affected smokers more than the rest. While the studies are still incomplete there is reason to believe that it’s true since both SARS and COVID affect the human system in a similar fashion.” Kolkata, he added, could be at a greater risk due to the large number of smokers in the city.Is it too late for a smoker to quit now hoping to avoid the virus? It takes at least 2-3 years for the ACE2 receptor to lose its prominence, said experts. “Quitting now may lessen your breathing distress but it won’t save you from the virus,” said Biswas.Any virus that affects the upper respiratory tract like the adeno, rhino or the nCoV is likely to affect smokers more, pointed out virologist Amitabha Nandy. “Smoking reduces the normal immunity of the lungs’ mucus membranes making them more prone to a viral attack. So, it is likely that nCov, too, will affect smokers more easily,” said Nandy.Potent viruses like SARS and nCoV usually infiltrate the lower respiratory tract, said RN Tagore International Institute of Cardiac Sciences (RTIICS) critical care head Souren Panja. “While those getting into the upper respiratory tract are relatively harmless, the ones triggering SARS and nCoV tend to affect the lungs and trigger pneumonia,” said Panja.Explaining the latest threat, experts pointed out that nCoV was a mutated strain of the coronavirus group to which humans are yet to grow a resistance.

Title: Three Kolkata youths, 5 from Alipurduar die in 2 accidents
Content:
This story is from February 22, 2020

Family members of Raj Das at their Keshab Chandra Sen Street residence

TARAKESHWAR/JALPAIGURI/KOLKATA: Three of four north Kolkata youths on their way to the Shiva temple in Tarakeshwar and five men from Alipurduar lost their lives in two accidents that occurred between late Thursday night and early Friday.

Narkelbagan’s Akash Das, a 26-year-old app-cab driver, and friends Raj Das, a 21-year-old Calcutta Medical College sweeper from Keshab Chandra Sen Street, neighbour Rajesh Das (20) and Chhotu Das (16) left home at 1.30am on Friday for Nimtolla Ghat’s Bhootnath Mandir and then set out for Tarakeshwar. In Balaigari, off Tarakeshwar, the two-wheeler that carried all four slammed into a truck.

Akash, Raj and Rajesh died almost immediately while Chhotu is battling for life, police said. Chhotu has been brought to Kolkata for treatment. The victims’ families had no knowledge of the two-wheeler. Raj’s father Shibnath said his son worked as a sweeper and had married only a month back. Akash, he added, has a son who is less than a year old. “They were well-behaved and stayed away from trouble. We never realised their wish to offer puja in Tarakeshwar (on Shivratri) would lead to their deaths. Our families have been destroyed,” Shibnath said.

Akash’s father and Rajesh’s family have left for Tarakeshwar to bring back the bodies. “The victims were on a vehicle that collided with a truck. Investigations are on,” Hooghly police superintendent Tanmoy Bose said.

Locals protesting against the accident blocked the Baidyabati-Tarakeshwar SH-2 for an hour.

In the accident at Birpara in Alipurduar at 12.30am, all five victims in their mid-30s were drunk, police claimed. Asraf Ali (driver), Barun Sarkar, Manoj Shah, Mithun Das and Sanjay Biswas died on the spot when their MUV hit a stone chip-laden dumper from behind near Demdema tea estate on Asian Highway 48. They were on their way to Jalpaiguri’s Gayerkata from Birpara.

The sixth person in their vehicle, Sibu Mondol, was grievously injured. He was rushed to Birpara state general hospital, from where he was taken to a private nursing home in Siliguri.

The collision was so massive that the dumper’s rear axel broke apart. “The driver rammed the vehicle into the dumper from behind. The manner in which the dumper’s rear axel broke, I would say it was a close shave for its driver and helper,” a police official said.

Title: Pragyan Ojha: I have many special memories but receiving my test cap from Sachin sir tops the list: Pragyan
Content:
‘I didn’t want to reach a stage where I’d get stagnant and my career would be headed nowhere’

‘Receiving ‘Man of the Match’ award for my 10-wicket haul against West Indies was special’

‘I look forward to spending time with my five month-old son, Yohaan’

In November 2009, Pragyan Ojha , a 23-year-old off-spinner from Odisha , made his way into the Indian test team. On a Kanpur wicket that had a bit of grass on it, Ojha kept things tight and got four wickets in the match (two in each innings), including the prize wicket of Mahela Jayawardene. While Pragyan’s bowling figures from that test match aren’t exactly spectacular, what made the occasion special for the youngster was to receive his test cap from the legendary Sachin Tendulkar .“I can never forget the moment when I received my test cap from Sachin Tendulkar sir. I was extremely nervous but he made me feel so comfortable. Playing for India is a huge honour in itself but to be welcomed into the fold by Sachin sir himself was truly a special feeling,” shares Ojha, who announced his retirement from international and first-class cricket on Friday.The Hyderabad-based cricketer played 24 tests and 18 ODIs for India and despite not featuring in a single international fixture since 2013, Ojha continued to play domestic cricket till 2019. The off-spinner tells us that the decision to retire was not an easy one but he knew it was the right decision. “Having played professional cricket for 16 years, it’s hard to just give it all up. When I wrote an official letter to Board of Control for Cricket in India (BCCI) and Hyderabad Cricket Association (HCA) announcing my retirement, it was one of the hardest things I’ve done. But I thought the time has come for me to move on, because I didn’t want to reach a point where I’d get stagnant as a cricketer and my career would be headed nowhere,” says the 33-year-old, adding, “Cricket is something that I love and I didn’t want to get to a stage where I start hating something that I have loved so deeply for so many years. So I know that this is was the right time to announce my retirement.Pragyan, who also played in the Indian Premier League (for Team Hyderabad and Mumbai respectively) looks back fondly on his journey as a cricketer. Although, it has been six years since he’s played international cricket, Pragyan says he’s cherished every single moment he’s been on the cricket pitch — be it first class cricket orinternational cricket. “Some of my best performances have come in domestic cricket and I’ve made many memories that will last me for a lifetime. I feel proud to be part of the Indian cricket team and at the same time, I’m happy for whatever chances I’ve got to prove myself in all formats of the game. I’ve always given my 100 per cent in every match I played,” says Pragyan, his voice shaking with emotion. “One of my most memorable moments on the cricket pitch was when I won the ‘Man of the Match’ award for taking 10 wickets in a match against West Indies in 2013. It was coincidentally Sachin Tendulkar’s last (200th) test match too. I’m going to miss all the fun and banter that we had in the dressing room. We used to have great fun, especially while travelling. I’m going to miss all of that,” he adds.Pragyan reserves special praise for his mentors Venkatapathy Raju and VVS Laxman, who’ve had a huge influence on him as a cricketer. “Both Venkatapathy Raju and VVS Laxman have a special place in my life. I got inspired to play cricket by Venkatapathy Raju, he was my role model. Laxman, on the other hand, has been like an elder brother to me and was always there when I needed him. Their contribution to my game and career has been immense,” he says.While he’s called time on his career as a cricketer, Pragyan looks forward to his second innings, especially spending time with his five month-old son, Yohaan.“I want to spend as much time as I can with Yohaan and watch him grow up. I’ve already entered commentary as well and will continue doing that. Apart from that, I don’t know what the future holds for me, but I can’t wait to find out,” he says, signing off.

Playing for India is a huge honour in itself but to be welcomed into the fold by Sachin sir himself was truly a special feeling,” shares Ojha, who announced his retirement from international and first-class cricket on Friday.The Hyderabad-based cricketer played 24 tests and 18 ODIs for India and despite not featuring in a single international fixture since 2013, Ojha continued to play domestic cricket till 2019. The off-spinner tells us that the decision to retire was not an easy one but he knew it was the right decision. “Having played professional cricket for 16 years, it’s hard to just give it all up. When I wrote an official letter to Board of Control for Cricket in India (BCCI) and Hyderabad Cricket Association (HCA) announcing my retirement, it was one of the hardest things I’ve done. But I thought the time has come for me to move on, because I didn’t want to reach a point where I’d get stagnant as a cricketer and my career would be headed nowhere,” says the 33-year-old, adding, “Cricket is something that I love and I didn’t want to get to a stage where I start hating something that I have loved so deeply for so many years. So I know that this is was the right time to announce my retirement.Pragyan, who also played in the Indian Premier League (for Team Hyderabad and Mumbai respectively) looks back fondly on his journey as a cricketer. Although, it has been six years since he’s played international cricket, Pragyan says he’s cherished every single moment he’s been on the cricket pitch — be it first class cricket orinternational cricket. “Some of my best performances have come in domestic cricket and I’ve made many memories that will last me for a lifetime. I feel proud to be part of the Indian cricket team and at the same time, I’m happy for whatever chances I’ve got to prove myself in all formats of the game. I’ve always given my 100 per cent in every match I played,” says Pragyan, his voice shaking with emotion. “One of my most memorable moments on the cricket pitch was when I won the ‘Man of the Match’ award for taking 10 wickets in a match against West Indies in 2013. It was coincidentally Sachin Tendulkar’s last (200th) test match too. I’m going to miss all the fun and banter that we had in the dressing room. We used to have great fun, especially while travelling. I’m going to miss all of that,” he adds.Pragyan reserves special praise for his mentors Venkatapathy Raju and VVS Laxman, who’ve had a huge influence on him as a cricketer. “Both Venkatapathy Raju and VVS Laxman have a special place in my life. I got inspired to play cricket by Venkatapathy Raju, he was my role model. Laxman, on the other hand, has been like an elder brother to me and was always there when I needed him. Their contribution to my game and career has been immense,” he says.While he’s called time on his career as a cricketer, Pragyan looks forward to his second innings, especially spending time with his five month-old son, Yohaan.“I want to spend as much time as I can with Yohaan and watch him grow up. I’ve already entered commentary as well and will continue doing that. Apart from that, I don’t know what the future holds for me, but I can’t wait to find out,” he says, signing off.
